P\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nScientific and Technical Information Office\t\n1972\nNATIONAL AERONAUTICS AND SPACE ADMINISTRATION\nWashington, D.C.\n\non Service\n9 00\n\nPRECEDING PAGE hLANK NOT FILMED\nPREFACE\nThe Symposium on Advanced Approaches to Fatigue Evaluation held in Miami Beach,\nFlorida, on May 13-14, 1971, was the sixth in a series sponsored by the International\nCommittee on Aeronautical Fatigue (ICAF). The proceedings of the five earlier symposia were published as listed in the references to this preface.\nThe ICAF is an informal organization of experts on fatigue from 10 nations.\nEach nation is represented by a single representative, in most cases from the national\naerospace research organization in his country. J. Branger of Eidg. Flugzeugwerk,\nEmmen, Switzerland, is Executive Secretary. The Committee was organized among five\nWestern European nations in 1952 to promote a "fruitful and effective exchange of information on all aspects of aeronautical fatigue problems among the member nations." The\nCommittee was gradually expanded until it reached its present size in 1965. Biennial\nmeetings are organized and hosted by the members on a rotating basis.\nThe theme of the Symposium, "Advanced Approaches to Fatigue Evaluation," permitted discussion of many broad aspects of the fatigue problem in aeronautical structures.\nThe introductory lecture, "The Philosophy Which Underlies the Structural Tests of\na Supersonic Transport Aircraft With Particular Attention to the Thermal Cycle," presented by E. L. Ripley of the United Kingdom who was especially invited as the Plantema\nMemorial Lecturer, follows a tradition established 4 years earlier at the Melbourne\nmeeting of ICAF. The Memorial Lecture honors Dr. Frederick J. Plantema, the first\nExecutive Secretary of ICAF. In his modest but effective manner, Dr. Plantema was the\ndriving force for organizing and directing ICAF during its first 14 years.\nThis volume contains the complete text of each of the papers presented at the\nSymposium and three additional papers submitted later that were judged to be important\nadjuncts to these proceedings.\nThe editors sincerely appreciate the enthusiastic support of other ICAF members\nwho solicited papers from their respective countries and acted as session chairmen at\nthe meeting. They wish to express appreciation also to the authors who prepared and\ndelivered papers for the Symposium. Finally, grateful acknowledgment is made to the\nNational Aeronautics and Space Administration, whose financial and administrative support made the Symposium and the publication of these proceedings possible.\n\niii\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Plantema, F. J.; and Schijve, J., eds.: Full-Scale Fatigue Testing of Aircraft\nStructures. Pergamon Press, Inc., 1961.\n2. Barrois, W.; and Ripley, E. L., eds.: Fatigue of Aircraft Structures. Macmillan Co.,\nc. 1963.\n3. Schijve, J.; Heath-Smith, J. R.; and Welbourne, E. R., eds.: Symposium on Current\nAeronautical Fatigue Problems. Pergamon Press, Inc., 1965.\n4. Gassner, E.; and Schutz, W., eds.: Fatigue Design Procedures. Pergamon Press,\nInc., c.1969.\n5. Mann, J. Y.; and McMillan, I., eds.: Aircraft Fatigue \xe2\x80\x94 Design, Operational, and\nEconomic Aspects. Programme of 5th ICAF Symposium (Melbourne, Australia),\nMay 1967.\n\niv\n\nCONTENTS\nPage\n\nPREFACE . . . . . . . . . .\t .\t . .\t . .\t . . . . . . . .\t .\t . .\t .\t .\t .\t . . .\t . .\t .\t . .\t . .\t .\t\n\niii\n\nTHIRD FREDERICK J. .\t\n\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\n.\n.\n.\n.\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n.\t\n\n48\n48\n49\n49\n50\n52\n52\n52\n53\n53\n53\n54\n54\n55\n55\n55\n55\n56\n56\n57\n57\n57\n57\n58\n58\n\n3\n\nPage\nREFERENCES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ,\t\n\n59\n60\n\n. . , .\t\n\n62\n\nTHE PHILOSOPHY WHICH UNDERLIES THE STRUCTURAL TESTS OF\nA SUPERSONIC TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT WITH PARTICULAR\nATTENTION TO THE THERMAL CYCLE\nBy E. L. Ripley\nRoyal Aircraft Establishment\nFarnborough, Hampshire, United Kingdom\nSUMMARY\nThe supersonic transport aircraft has brought a new challenge to the structural\ntest engineer. Over the years he has developed skills in representing in the laboratory the conditions that occur in flight and in devising techniques to apply these to the\nstructure. Supersonic flight has introduced important new features into the test programme, particularly for supersonic transport aircraft. Of these new features the\nmost significant is probably the prolonged heating and then cooling of the structure\nduring each flight. Much basic research has been necessary to understand the effects\nof such a thermal cycle on the structure, and novel engineering techniques have been\ndeveloped to simulate the cycle in the test laboratory.\nThe information presented in this paper is based on data obtained from the\nConcorde. Much of this data also applies to other supersonic transport aircraft. The\ndesign and development of the Concorde is a joint effort of the British and French, and\nthe structural test programme is shared, as are all the other activities. Vast numbers of small specimens have been tested to determine the behaviour of the materials\nused in the aircraft. Major components of the aircraft structure, totalling almost a\ncomplete aircraft, have been made and are being tested to help the constructors in\neach country in the design and development of the structure. Tests on two complete\nairframes will give information for the certification of the aircraft. A static test was\nconducted in France and a fatigue test in the United Kingdom. Fail-safe tests are\nbeing made to demonstrate the crack-propagation characteristics of the structure and\nits residual strength.\nThe paper describes these aspects of the structural test programme in some\ndetail, dealing particularly with the problems associated with the thermal cycle. The\nbiggest of these problems is the setting up of the fatigue test on the complete airframe; therefore, this is covered more extensively with a discussion about how the\ntest time can be shortened and with a description of the practical aspects of the test.\n\n5\n\nINTRODUCTION\nBackground\nIn 1967 a paper entitled \'Design Philosophy and Fatigue Testing of the Concorde"\nwas presented at the Fifth Symposium of the International Committee on Aeronautical\nFatigue (ICAF) at Melbourne, Australia. (See ref. 1.) Four years later, the basic subject of the structural testing of a supersonic transport aircraft is to be considered again\nby the ICAF, this time at the Sixth Symposium at Miami Beach, Florida, U.S.A. In the\nmeantime, some updating of the subject was given in a paper to the Eleventh AngloAmerican Conference at the Royal Aeronautical Society, London, in 1969 (ref. 2). The\npresent paper brings the story up to date and in doing so incorporates an appreciable\namount of the basic information from the other papers for completeness.\nThe state of the art in structural-strength testing is now well advanced, and the purpose of the present paper is to examine the way this state has to be further developed to\nmeet the needs of the supersonic transport aircraft. The supersonic transport aircraft\nwill be subjected to all the familiar patterns of ground and flight loads, and these patterns\nmust be represented in the structural tests using the techniques which have been developed\nand proven over many years. What is new is the thermal cycle which produces prolonged\nheating and then cooling during each flight. The thermal cycle sets up thermal stresses\nwhich are in themselves another loading action. Prolonged time at elevated temperature\nintroduces creep and overageing. Further consideration of interaction effects which the\nthermal cycle may have on the static and fatigue strengths of the aircraft is necessary.\nThe data presented in this paper were obtained from structural tests on the\nConcorde, and illustrations are given of what has been done on that aircraft. The principles underlying this work are believed to be equally applicable to other supersonic\ntransport aircraft. The design and development of the Concorde (fig. 1) are a joint effort\nof the British and the French, and the structural test programme is shared, as are all the\nother activities. Throughout the programme the aim has been to employ wherever possible test techniques which have been well established and proven throughout the years.\nMuch new research has, however, been necessary to understand the effects of the thermal\ncycle on the structure, and novel engineering techniques have been developed to simulate\nit in the test laboratory.\nVast numbers of small specimens have been tested to determine the behaviour of\nthe materials used in the aircraft. Major components of the aircraft structure, totalling\nalmost a complete aircraft, have been tested to help the constructors in each country in\nthe design and development of the structure. Two complete airframes will be tested to\ngive information for the certification of the aircraft. A static test will be made in France\nand a fatigue test in the United Kingdom. Fail-safe tests are being made to demonstrate\n6\n\nthe crack-propagation characteristics of the structure and its residual strength. Drop,\nstatic, and fatigue tests are being made on the nose and main undercarriages. Acoustic\nfatigue tests are being made to investigate the effects on the structure of engine noise and\nvarious pressure-fluctuation effects in the airflow. Dynamic response in the structural\nloads is being measured on the structure in ground tests and in flight tests. The measurements and tests are most comprehensive, and the Concorde will certainly be one of\nthe most thoroughly tested aircraft ever flown.\nIt is not possible in this paper to cover all these aspects in full detail, and preference is given to the strength-test programme with particular reference to the problems\nassociated with the thermal cycle. The biggest problem has been the setting up of the\nfatigue test on the complete airframe, and some of the practical aspects of this are dealt\nwith hereinafter.\nPhysical quantities used in this paper, their basic unit, and pertinent conversion\nfactors are listed in table I.\nStructural-Load Environment\nA typical flight profile of the Concorde is that after take-off the aircraft will climb\nsubsonically to a suitable altitude and then, still climbing, accelerate to its cruising speed\nof about a Mach number M of 2.0. After the cruise phase has been completed, the aircraft will decelerate to subsonic speed at altitude and then descend to its destination.\n(See fig. 2.) In the initial climb at subsonic speeds, the external surfaces of the aircraft\nwill cool a little and then heat up in the acceleration phase to a temperature of about\n1000 C, which will be maintained during cruise. (See fig. 3.) During deceleration and\ndescent, the external structural temperature will drop to about -20 0 C and rise again to\nambient temperature on landing. (See fig. 4.)\nThe Concorde will be subjected to all the normal aircraft loads \xe2\x80\x94 taxying loads,\nground-air-ground cycle, gust and manoeuvre loads, cabin pressurisation, etc. Almost\nall of these will occur while the aircraft is on the ground or flying subsonically; that is,\nwhile the structure is at ambient temperature before the acceleration phase or is\napproaching ambient temperature after the deceleration phase. The exception is any turbulence which may be encountered while the aircraft is flying supersonically and the\nstructure is hot.\nOne of the most important of the thermal effects is the thermal stress which develops because the temperature of the internal structure lags behind that of the surface\nstructure as a result of the time it takes for heat to be conducted to it. Thus on the climb\nthe external structure will be hotter than the internal structure, and this will set up thermal stresses due to the different amount of expansion. During the cruise the temperature\nof the internal structure will gradually approach that of the external structure and the\n7\n\nthermal stresses will decay. The reverse effect takes place during descent and recovery\non the ground; thus, thermal stresses of opposite sign are produced. Such a stress situation has a significant effect on fatigue life. If the structure is deep, these stresses are\nabout one-half the maximum stress permissible for the required life.\nTwo other thermal effects which need to be considered are overageing and creep.\nWhen a material is being manufactured, it is often subjected to heat treatment to "age"\nit in order to obtain its desired strength. If subsequently it is subjected to long periods\nat elevated temperature, it will "overage," and its strength will fall slightly. If the material is subjected to long periods at elevated temperature while under load, it will "creep"\nwhich means it will remain extended or deformed even after the load and temperature are\nremoved. It is necessary to ensure that the amount of creep occurring is limited so that\nunacceptable deformation of the structure is prevented. An upper limit of 0.1-percent\ntotal plastic strain after 20 000 hours was chosen as a reasonable criterion, based mainly\non structural experience in which a 0.1-percent tensile-proof condition has been used for\ndesign purposes for many years.\nThus the structure is subjected to the normal loading environment interspersed with\nperiods at elevated temperature and a thermal-stress cycle each supersonic flight. This\nenvironment is further complicated by the presence of fuel tanks acting as heat sinks, with\ntheir changing levels of fuel during flight and with fuel transfer from tank to tank to preserve aircraft balance for subsonic and supersonic flight. The task of the designer and\ntest engineer is indeed complex since he must understand and interpret all of these effects\nand their interactions.\nAcknowledgements\nThe author gratefully acknowledges the able and willing assistance of his colleagues\nin the Royal Aircraft Establishment (R.A.E.), especially those in the Structures\nDepartment, who helped with all the many details necessary for the preparation of the\npaper and made valuable contributions to its content. Grateful acknowledgements are\nalso made to the British Aircraft Corporation, Aerospatiale (S.N.I.A.S.), Centre d\'Essais\nAeronautique de Toulouse (C.E.A.T.), and Sulzer Brothers (London) Limited for their help\nwith some of the illustrations.\nRESEARCH ON THERMAL-CYCLE EFFECTS\nBroad Pattern of Research\nOne of the first engineering tasks was to evaluate a suitable material for the aircraft\nstructure. Aluminium alloy was a desirable choice since its aircraft production capabilities were well understood and it would be able to withstand the thermal effects over almost\n8\n\nall the airframe. In a few areas where the temperatures were greater, such as near the\nengines, steel, titanium, or nickel alloys could be used. The task was therefore to choose\na suitable aluminium alloy to give the best overall performance. Several were evaluated\nand the present Concorde material was evolved from an aluminium alloy which originally\nwas developed to withstand the rigours of use in an aircraft engine. An important criterion in the choice of this material was its creep behaviour, which is superior to that of\nother aluminium alloys currently being used in subsonic aircraft. In parallel with the\nwork on metallic materials, a similar programme was conducted on nonmetallic materials.\nIt is not possible within the scope of this paper to tell the story of all the research\nand development work. A tremendous amount of work has been done in both countries, is\nbeing continued, and will be continued right through the certification test programme to\nprovide the necessary backup knowledge for planning and interpreting that programme.\nQuite early, two things became apparent from the work on the Concorde aluminium\nalloy:\n(1) Overall creep distortion was unlikely to be a hazard; that is, creep distortion at\nstresses to be used in the design would not reach the 0.1-percent limit set to avoid\nunacceptable distortion of the aircraft;\n(2) Overageing had little effect on static strength; that is, the reduction in static\nstrength due to prolonged time at elevated temperature was small and could easily be\ncontained by a small factor in the allowable design stresses.\nThe next step was to see whether exposure to heat, with or without load, affected\nthe fatigue performance of the material in structural configurations and to find out if\nstresses arising from temperature differences across the structure (thermal stresses)\ncould be regarded simply as equivalent in effect to the same stresses arising from externally applied loads in accumulation of fatigue damage. Clearly at this stage in design,\nit would not have been practical to await results of tests in real time and temperature conditions; therefore, much of the early work was conducted under accelerated conditions on\nthe basis of Fisher\'s parameter which gives a relationship of the form\ntl\nlog t2\n\nT 2 - T1\n= C T1T2\n\nwhere t l and T 1 are, respectively, the exposure time and absolute temperature in the\nreal environment, t 2 and T 2 are the corresponding times and temperatures in accelerated conditions, and C is a constant (approximately 8200 0 K for the material concerned). On this basis the anticipated service environment was represented in much of\nthe early work for Concorde by exposure times of 1000 hours at 150 0 C, which gives an\n9\n\nequivalence of 30 000 hours at 120 0 C or 400 000 hours at 1000 C. At the same time as\nthe accelerated test programmes were initiated, tests were begun using temperature and\ntime exposures close to real service conditions; such tests span several years, and it is\nonly recently that results have started to accrue.\nIn planning the research programmes, it was also borne in mind that both under the\nspecial conditions of the full-scale fatigue test and under the actual service environment,\nthere would be considerable deviations at different points in the structure from the nominal stress and temperature conditions. To meet this situation, the general policy was to\nconcentrate the more detailed investigations on the nominal conditions and to explore\ndeviations to either side with a comparatively light coverage of test conditions. This\napproach would give sufficient information to enable correction factors to be derived under\nsuch deviating conditions, and these correction factors would be of vital importance in\ninterpreting any failures occurring during the full-scale tests.\nIn the majority of the early programmes, attention was centred primarily on the\neffect of heat exposure on cycles (or "flights") to failure, but as the research and development programmes built up, increasing attention was paid to examining the effects of\nheat exposure on the crack-nucleation phase of damage growth and on the subsequent\ncrack-propagation phase since there was no presupposed reason to assume that both\nphases of damage growth would be equally affected. This aspect had to be explored both\nunder accelerated and real-time conditions so that, for example, crack-initiation times\nobserved during the full-scale fatigue test could be interpreted in terms of true\nenvironment.\nAn enormous programme of work has been done and is continuing to obtain information on the foregoing problems; many types of specimens are being used, ranging from\nsimple notched and riveted-joint coupon specimens to large structural components.\nLoading and environmental conditions have varied from simple sinusoids with a block of\nheat representing the total service exposure introduced at some point in the fatigue test\nto elaborate representations of a flight cycle of mechanical loads with appropriate heating\nand cooling conditions to induce representative thermal stresses.\nAll this work is giving an empirical understanding of the behaviour of the structure\nunder the thermal environment. More fundamental work is also being done to try to\nunderstand the metallurgical phenomena involved.\nExamples of Research\nIt is beyond the scope of this paper to attempt full presentation of the results\nobtained so far, but some results are outlined subsequently. These serve to illustrate the\nkind of work that has been done and the nature of the answers that have been obtained.\nThree examples have been chosen. They show how this work has given understanding and\n10\n\ndata for design, and also, particularly in the context of this paper, how this work provides\nessential information for planning and interpretation of the full-scale fatigue test.\nEffect of repeated application of heat on fatigue life.- This first example shows the\ntrends which have emerged from fatigue-heat interaction tests on Concorde material.\nThe variation in the ratio of life with heat exposure to life cold with temperature during\nheat exposure and the creep stress is illustrated in figure 5. The results on which these\ntrends are based were mainly obtained from tests in which periods of heat, with or without mean stress application, were applied periodically during the fatigue life; the mechanical loading patterns included a simple representation of the gust loading and the groundair-ground cycles. It is considered unlikely that significant thermal stresses were\ninduced in any of the specimen types. It should also be borne in mind that in grouping\nthese data, results were put together from tests having considerable detail variations\nin loading patterns and numbers of heat interspersions during life. Nevertheless, the\ntrends give a qualitative indication of behaviour, and the following conclusions may be\ndrawn:\n(1) Performance reduces as the temperature rises from 1200 to 180 0 C.\n(2) Performance is better with tensile creep stress than with zero creep stress,\nthough the improvement is seen to be falling off for the riveted joints at the higher creep\nstresses.\n(3) Performance appears to improve in moving from the simple notched specimen\nto the riveted-joint specimen and, again, to the relatively complex fabricated box; reasons\nwhy this may be so are discussed subsequently.\nEffect of heat on nucleation and crack-propagation phases of fatigue life.- This\nexample has been chosen to illustrate one of the more fundamental research studies. The\nwork was undertaken to obtain an understanding of the modifying effects of heat on the\ngrowth of fatigue damage at different stages in the life of a specimen under test. In all\nthe tests, fatigue cycling was carried out at room temperature under fluctuating tensile\nloading. After a mean (nominal) life to failure was established, a single application of\nheat was introduced at a certain percentage of nominal life; the fatigue cycling was\nstopped during this period, and the mean load was adjusted to give tensile, zero, or compressive creep. After cooling, the fatigue cycling was then resumed, and from consideration of the total fatigue life to failure, the damaging or beneficial effect of the heat exposure was assessed. In the majority of the tests, the heat exposure was 150 0 C for\n1000 hours, but the work also included a small number of long-term tests in which the\nexposure was 120 0 C for 20 000 hours. The tests were carried out on notched, pinnedlug, and clamped-lug specimens. Some of the results for the notched and pinned-lug\nspecimens are shown in figure 6. It is evident from the results of the tests on the notched\nspecimen that\n11\n\n(1) Exposure to heat without load during the first half of the fatigue life has a detrimental effect on fatigue performance.\n(2) This detrimental effect is to some extent alleviated by tensile creep, and\nconversely.\n(3) Compressive creep increases the damaging effect of heat alone.\n(4) Exposure to heat during the crack-propagation phase has a relatively small\neffect.\nThe foregoing test results, supported by examination of the fracture surfaces, have\nled to a general explanation of the effects of heat and creep on the growth of fatigue damage. The effect of heat alone is to speed up the development of fatigue damage nuclei and\nhence to reduce the crack-initiation period; a marked reduction in scatter in endurance\nhas been noted after heat exposure, which is in keeping with this explanation. Until comparatively recently, the more rapid appearance of damage nuclei was explained in terms\nof the relaxing effect of the period of heat on beneficial residual compressive stresses\nwhich are often inadvertently introduced at the notch surfaces during manufacture.\nRecent metallurgical studies have shown that another, and perhaps more important,\nchange takes place in the surface material at the notch during heating.\nIt has been found that machining leaves behind a work-affected zone some 50 \xc2\xb5m\ndeep having a hardness approximately twice that of the interior material. In "as\nreceived" specimens, fatigue cracks, in fact, initiated below this zone. The heat exposure was found to reduce the surface hardness to that of the interior material, and cracks\nthen developed from the surface. This phenomenon, combined with some relaxation of\nresidual manufacturing stresses, is believed to explain the observed reduction in crackinitiation time; the biggest reductions, of course, were observed when heat preceded\nfatigue cycling. When load is applied during heating, plastic deformation of the material\nin the vicinity of the notch will be encouraged; that is, tensile loading will tend to induce\ncompressive residual stresses at the notch so that after the heating period, the local mean\nstress will be reduced with consequent improvement in fatigue life relative to the heatwithout-load condition. The reverse will be true with compressive load with heating.\nIt may be noted that results for the notched specimen under long exposure times at\nlower temperatures, 20 000 hours at 1200 C, which have recently become available from\ntests for heat without load, confirm the appropriate pattern of behaviour. The results of\ntests on the pinned-lug specimens correspond to anticipated results, bearing in mind that\nthe crack-initiation period is a much smaller percentage of the fatigue life in this type of\nspecimen because fretting promotes early formation of surface cracks. As would therefore be anticipated, the effects of heat are considerably less in such specimens than in\nsimple notched specimens. The general patterns of behaviour observed in the foregoing\nfundamental studies have been shown also to apply to the observed behaviour of more com12\n\nplex specimens such as fabricated box beams containing riveted joints, cutouts, and so on.\nThis basic understanding will be of great help in the full-scale fatigue test, both in indicating areas of structure where heat is likely to promote relatively early initiation of\ndamage and in assessing the significance of failures that may develop.\nAcceleration of tests under combined thermal and mechanical cycles.- The third\ntype of investigation chosen to illustrate backup research and development work is concerned with the problem of accelerating the full-scale fatigue test, in which both thermal\nfatigue stresses and stresses arising from external loading actions contribute to the\ngrowth of fatigue damage. In order to keep the laboratory testing ahead of aircraft in\nservice, the full-scale fatigue test must be accelerated to accumulate fatigue damage\nmore rapidly than the real-time flight experience. This would present no problem if the\nloading actions were associated solely with externally applied mechanical loads because\nthe frequency of application of such loads could easily be speeded up relative to real-time\nexperience. It is the speeding up of the thermal-stress loading action that presents a\nproblem since hot and cold soak times, for example, are controlled by the heat-transfer\ncharacteristics of the structure and cannot be hastened simply. This problem is discussed in more detail subsequently.\nSome results of tests to give an assessment of one approach to this acceleration\nproblem are shown in figure 7. The acceleration technique explored in this case was to\nconduct the accelerated test using a wider temperature range than used in the "real-time"\ntest. The aim of this test was to attain the condition in which the increased range of the\nthermal-stress cycle would give twice the normal amount of fatigue damage in each test\ncycle. The accelerated test cycle included twice the number of mechanical loads experienced in one flight. Thus, each accelerated test cycle should give damage appropriate to\ntwo flights. The results given were obtained from tests on box beams (figs. 8 and 9)\nwhich were tested in four-point bending. The loading action applied resulted in mechanical and thermal stress conditions in the tension-compression surface of the specimen\ncorresponding to those in certain areas of the pressure cabin to which gust loadings,\ncabin pressurisation, the ground-to-air cycle, and thermal-gradients contribute. It\nshould be noted that in this exploratory work the severity of all the loadings was scaled\nup somewhat so that answers both in "real time" and accelerated conditions could be\nobtained in months rather than years. It will be seen from figure 7 that encouraging\nresults were obtained. Damage rate, assessed on the basis of the time to first crack,\nwas accelerated by a factor close to 2.\nThough only two specimens were tested in each condition at this stage, the indications were that scatter was low, and therefore the results could be treated with considerable confidence. Low scatter has been found to be a characteristic of much of the background research and development work entailing heat application. This preliminary work\n13\n\nis being followed up in a major programme of tests on box beams of similar dimensions\nbut of detail design representing much more closely the Concorde structure. The tests\nare being run in conditions corresponding closely to those envisaged both in service and\nin the full-scale test. In addition to providing information on acceleration conditions,\nanalysis of the results also provides understanding of the equivalence of thermal and\nmechanical stresses in cumulative damage.\nDESIGN DEVELOPMENT TESTS\nLarge Component Specimens\nQuite early in the design of an aircraft, it is prudent to build representative sections\nof the structure to see how ideas work out in practice. This is particularly necessary for\nthe supersonic transport aircraft with all the implications of the interaction of thermal\nand mechanical effects. Therefore, two sections of fuselage were built initially for the\nConcorde. Each had about a 15-foot length of representative structure. One was tested\nin France and the other in the United Kingdom (specimens 2.1 and 2.2 of fig. 10).\nAs the design took shape, actual components of the aircraft, such as parts of the\nwing and fuselage, have been made and are being tested to assist in design development.\nThese specimens make almost a complete aircraft. (See fig. 10.) Again, these tests are\nbeing shared with the French. A wide range of tests are being done on these component\nspecimens. They include the exploration of temperature and stress distributions under\nvarious design conditions, static tests to demonstrate the strength of the structure under\nextreme conditions, fatigue tests to show its behaviour under the recurring loads in service, and fail-safe tests to show that the structure is capable of withstanding safely damage or failures in service.\nFor this paper, two tests have been picked as examples of the work which has been\ncovered on the large component specimens.\nCentre Wing and Fuselage Specimen at C.E.A.T.\nSpecimen 2.813 (figs. 10 and 11) is a large section of the centre wing and fuselage\nand contains the important cutouts for the main undercarriage. It is an early prototype\nstandard and has completed its test programme at the Centre d\'Essais Aeronautique de\nToulouse (C.E.A.T.). It has been used to check the static strength of the aircraft and has\ngiven useful experience in preparation for the static test of the complete airframe, which\nis now being tested in the same laboratory.\nThe specimen weighed about 15 tons fully equipped and was approximately 35 feet\nlong with a span of 44 feet. Kinetic heating effects were simulated by the use of 5000\nradiant heaters, and cooling was simulated by ambient air and air cooled by liquid nitrogen\n14\n\ndrawn over the specimen at low speed by extractor fans. (See fig. 12.) The specimen\nwas equipped with 1500 strain-gauge points and 2000 thermocouples. The effect of fuel in\nthe tanks was simulated by using Gilotherm, a fluid which has similar characteristics to\nkerosene but is noninflammable. The mechanical loading was done with hydraulic jacks.\nOne of the earliest tests was to measure the influence coefficients across the specimen. Thence followed a thorough investigation of the strain and temperature distribution\nthroughout the structure under typical loading conditions. A number of design cases were\ntaken to limit load. The residual strength of the structure was demonstrated by removing\nmembers and unbolting joints to simulate fatigue and other damage. Finally in this group\nof tests, the wing was taken to ultimate load in a flight case. To see how far cracks propagated, the simulated fuselage was pressurised and struck with a guillotine blade; the\nimpact sites were such that the skin was cut between frames, or both the skin and a frame\nwere cut.\nForward-Fuselage Specimen at R.A.E.\nSpecimen 2.4/2.5 (figs. 10 and 13) is the forward part of the fuselage and is being\ntested at the Royal Aircraft Establishment (R.A.E.). It is about 70 feet long and comprises the flight deck and forward part of the passenger cabin. The droop nose is included\nand also a dummy nose undercarriage. The specimen is made to preproduction standards.\nThe rig provides facilities for static, fatigue, and fail-safe tests and gives experience for\nthe fatigue test on the complete airframe which will use many of the same test techniques.\nThe specimen is cantilever mounted in the test frame at its aft end and is loaded by\n19 hydraulic jacks. It weighs about 8 tons fully equipped. Kinetic heating and cooling\neffects are simulated by convective means. Hot air is blown over the specimen to heat it\nfor the climb and cruise conditions, and cold air is blown over it to cool it for the descent\nand recovery conditions. The specimen is enclosed in a duct with about a 4-inch annular\ngap. The duct is articulated in sections on gimbals to allow for specimen movement.\nNormally, the specimen and duct are in a closed circuit in which the air can be heated by\nelectrical resistance heaters in the airflow or cooled by the injection of liquid nitrogen.\n(See fig. 14.) The circuit can however be opened to allow the specimen to be cooled initially with ambient air which has sufficient cooling potential for the first part of the\ndescent.\nThis method of convective heating and cooling was developed specially by the R.A.E.\nfor the component specimen tests and will be used for the major fatigue test. It provides\na very simple testing technique, and one which is inherently safe since rapid and dangerous temperature runaways are impossible. The principle used is that the heat-transfer\nconditions which are set up on the aircraft at high speed in the rarefied air at altitude can\nbe reproduced in the laboratory by blowing the denser air at ground level at slower speeds\n15\n\nand heating or cooling it to the required temperature. In this test a specimen temperature range of 150 0 C to -350 C can be achieved, and the maximum air speed required is\nabout 170 ft/sec. Control therefore is extremely simple; all that is necessary is to regulate the air speed and the air temperature. Good representation along and around the\nspecimen is obtained.\nThe cabin is pressurised and air-conditioned to represent the conditions in flight.\nAdditional electrical heaters are provided in the cabin to simulate the heat input from the\nelectronic equipment in the aircraft. The whole test is controlled by an interesting development of on-line computer control. Two KDF7 computers are used. The first controls\nthe test, by giving the instructions for mechanical loading, temperature, airflow, and so\nforth, against the required test programme; the second monitors the test by reproducing\nthe same programme and comparing the results achieved by the first computer. Two levels of discrepancy are identified. Those differences below the lower level are within the\nacceptable test tolerances and are ignored. Those between the lower and upper levels are\nprinted out so that the test control staff is informed. Any discrepancies above the upper\nlevel automatically cause the test to stop. By this method the test programme can be\nagreed upon, internationally, before it is commenced. High reliability is achieved because\nof the built-in checking systems and because elaborate recording with subsequent analysis\nis avoided.\nThe specimen is fitted with about 1400 strain-gauge points and 500 thermocouples.\nThe initial tests investigated the strain and temperature distributions throughout the\nstructure under typical loading cases. As a quick check on its integrity, the cabin structure was pressurised 5000 times. The specimen was then rigged for a fatigue test under\nthe full mechanical and thermal environment. The test was done on a flight-by-flight\nbasis, but each test cycle was made slightly more severe and shorter than aircraft flight\nconditions in order to shorten the testing time for a given amount of fatigue damage. The\nproblems associated with this are discussed more fully for the major fatigue test later in\nthis paper.\nThese tests were interrupted to obtain early design development information on the\nfail-safe behaviour of machined skin panels. Soon the specimen is to be modified to bring\nit up to production standards, and then it will be used for the certification fail-safe tests\non this part of the structure. In these tests, natural cracks or artificially induced cracks\n(or damage) will be propagated under the full environmental conditions for a given period,\nand then the specimen will be loaded to limit load to check its residual strength.\n\n16\n\nCERTIFICATION TESTS\nOutline of Programme\nWhen the aircraft has reached its production design standard, the aircraft must be\nshown to merit a Certificate of Airworthiness. Each country has its own certifying\nauthority, in the United Kingdom it is the Air Registration Board, and each country must\nbe satisfied that its particular regulations for this type of aircraft are met.\nIn the early days of the Concorde project, the French and British Governments\nagreed that the Concorde aircraft must qualify for both French and British Certificates of\nAirworthiness. The two airworthiness authorities therefore agreed jointly to produce new\nairworthiness requirements for supersonic transport aircraft which are now known as TSS\nstandards. These contain the parts of the French and British national requirements which\nwere applicable and such new requirements as were necessary to meet the special conditions arising for a supersonic transport aircraft. These TSS standards thus became the\nbasis for the design of the Concorde.\nThe United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has also produced a new\ndocument entitled "Tentative Airworthiness Standards for Supersonic Transports" (ref. 3).\nThese standards have also been taken into account in the Concorde design and test\nprogramme.\nCertification of the aircraft will be based partly on calculation, but most emphasis\nwill be placed on the major acceptance tests. Thus static, fatigue, and fail-safe tests are\nto be done on the whole airframe. The tests in more detail are\n(1) The major static test on a complete airframe less the nacelles at C.E.A.T.\n(France)\n(2) The major fatigue test on a complete airframe less the nacelles at R.A.E. (U.K.)\n(3) Static and fatigue tests on the nacelles at the British Aircraft Corporation (U.K.)\n(4) Drop tests, static, and fatigue tests on the nose and main undercarriages at\nC.E.A.T. (France)\n(5) Fail-safe tests on component specimens in the country of manufacture\nIn planning the acceptance test programme, it was necessary to select appropriate\nairframes from the manufacturing sequence. The first two airframes to be made were\nused for the two prototypes, 001 and 002. The third airframe was chosen for the major\nstatic test so that the test results would be available in time for the certification of the\naircraft. The airframe is to preproduction standard, and it was agreed that the test\nresults would be reinterpreted to take account of any differences between preproduction\nand production aircraft. The next two airframes to be made are being used for the preproduction flight aircraft, 01 and 02. The sixth airframe was chosen for the major fatigue\n17\n\ntest so that it should be closely representative of production standard and yet should be\navailable sufficiently early for the test to have started before the certification of the\naircraft.\nThe following paragraphs discuss the techniques and facilities used for the major\nstatic and major fatigue tests. Although the nacelle tests are not described in detail, the\nprocedures used to reproduce air pressure loading and convective heating and cooling are\nsimilar to those used for the major fatigue test. Finally, some comment is given on the\nfail-safe test programme, as Concorde will probably be the first aircraft to satisfy the\nnew FAA requirements for supersonic transport aircraft.\nMajor Static Test\nThe purpose of the static test is to show that the structure is capable of withstanding extreme conditions which might arise in service and has an adequate margin of\nstrength as laid down by the airworthiness authorities. A range of test cases has been\nselected to cover all the loading patterns which the aircraft will experience in service.\nThe tests have been grouped so that those without heating are done first. Currently, the\nspecimen is being rigged ready for the commencement of the hot tests.\nThe programme commenced with fuselage pressurisation tests and tests to check\nfuel-tank pressurisation and sealing. Then a number of tests were made to cover the\ntake-off and landing conditions. Two flight cases at the beginning of the climb \xe2\x80\x94 the\nsteady pullout case and the checked manoeuvre case \xe2\x80\x94 were also made. These tests were\nfollowed by a number of partial tests on local parts of the specimen covering various conditions arising from the nose undercarriage, tail bumper, engine loads, fin, flight controls,\nand the main undercarriage doors. In the next phase, the whole specimen will be subjected\nto the cases which are critical with the thermal cycle, such as a manoeuvre at the end of\nthe climb, a pull-out at the end of the cruise, and gusts during the descent.\nThis large and comprehensive test is being made at C.E.A.T. in a test facility built\nfor the Concorde tests. (See fig. 15.) The main test hall has a strong floor with underfloor ducts for cables, hydraulic pipes, and so forth. Portal frames provide support for\nthe overhead and side loading. The loads are applied by hydraulic jacks, servocontrolled\nby Moog valves from a computer. Forty-eight separately controlled loading channels are\navailable, and each can control more than one jack if required. Double-bridge load cells\nare used to control and monitor the loads.\nThe kinetic heating effect will be simulated by radiant heaters supplied by thyratron\nregulators controlled by the computer. One hundred and fifty channels are available, some\nof 200 kVA and some of 50 kVA capability. Air will be blown over the specimen at about\n20 ft/sec during the heating phase, and increased to about 50 ft/sec in the cooling phase.\nCooling will be obtained by the injection of liquid nitrogen into the airstream. The cabin\n18\n\nwill be pressurised, air conditioned, and filled with polyurethane foam blocks to reduce\nthe explosive risk.\nThe digital computer controls the sequencing of the whole test and also records the\ntest data. Some 2000 strain gauges and 1500 thermocouples are installed on the specimen, and about 2000 selected inputs can be recorded and processed by the computer in\nreal time. The transducer data are printed every 10 seconds to detect any transducers\nwhich may be outside of expected limits.\nThe load in each test case is built up in a series of steps in the usual way, and full\nuse is made of the computer to examine strains and deflections at each step and to compare them with expected values. It is hoped by this means to be able to detect the onset\nof failure and to stop the test before catastrophic damage occurs. The inclusion of kinetic\nheating and cooling in the static tests produces problems of sequencing. For example, it\nwould not be satisfactory to hold the specimen at a high load for a long period while the\nthermal cycle was applied. It would also be very time consuming to perform a thermal\ncycle for every load level in every case. Thus an optimum sequence is being worked out\nfor conducting the tests. Care has been taken to install in the specimen strain gauges and\nthermocouples at corresponding points to those on the flight-test aircraft so that full comparison can be made of conditions measured in flight and reproduced in the test laboratory.\nThe test will be completed before certification of the aircraft. All the important\nstatic design conditions will have been covered, and the tests will demonstrate that the airframe is capable of withstanding extreme conditions which might arise in service.\nMajor Fatigue Test\nThe purpose of the fatigue test is to subject the specimen to the whole structural\nload environment the aircraft would experience in service. The specimen is taken through\na series of flight sequences in the laboratory and subjected to the environmental conditions\nit would encounter in typical flights. These conditions include the external loading actions,\nsuch as taxying loads, take-off loads, gust loads, kinetic heating and cooling, and the internal loading actions, such as cabin pressurisation, air-conditioning, and fuel handling.\nThese loading actions must be applied to the specimen flight after flight to build up in the\nspecimens all the fatigue structural experience which the aircraft will accumulate in\nservice.\nBy their very nature, fatigue tests must take a long time. However, for subsonic\naircraft, it has always been possible to compress the loading actions so that a test cycle\nin the laboratory was considerably shorter than the flight it represented. The problem is\nvery much more difficult for a supersonic transport aircraft, since the effects of the\nthermal cycle are time dependent. Nonetheless, it is essential to find a way to shorten\nthe test time so that the tests may keep ahead of aircraft in service with an adequate\n19\n\nsafety margin. The fatigue lives of nominally identical structures are often quite different. Consequently, the Concorde tests are designed so that the specimen will always\nhave at least three times as much fatigue damage (or three times the equivalent loads\nand thermal cycles) as any aircraft in service. In order to do this, the test must be\naccelerated, that is, it must represent the aircraft conditions in a shorter time. The test\nwill be run 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, but there will need to be pauses to inspect\nthe specimen and to maintain it, for the essence of this test is to find the fatigue damage\nwhile it is still very small so that early preventive measures can be applied to the aircraft in service.\nIn this part of the paper, broad details only are given of the test techniques and procedures. These are amplified considerably and the practical problems discussed subsequently. The test is being done in the structural test laboratories at R.A.E. (See figs. 16,\n17, and 18.) Mechanical loading is being applied by hydraulic jacks. Convective heating\nand cooling is being used to simulate the external thermal conditions. Because of the\nneed to shorten the time of the test, additional forced heating and cooling systems are\nneeded for the internal structure and the fuel. All this requires a considerable amount\nof plant to provide the heat and the cold. The test itself and the plant are controlled by\ntwo process computers and one monitor computer with a data logging and display system.\nCurrently the construction of the specimen in the test frame is about complete, and\nthe test rig is being installed. When all this has been completed, the assembly will be\ncalibrated initially by running a number of flight cycles in real time and comparing the\nachieved strains and temperatures with those measured in corresponding positions in\nflight. The problem then of accelerating the test will be tackled by shortening the test\ncycle and by making each test cycle represent more than one flight. This acceleration\nwill be taken in steps, working down from the real-time cycle to ensure that the accelerated test cycle is meaningful. The chosen aim is to do each test cycle in 60 minutes and\nto make it represent two supersonic flights. Interspersed in the pattern of hot test cycles\nwill be some without the thermal cycle to represent the subsonic flights which are\nexpected to total about 20 percent of the service experience. The use of computer control ensures overall flexibility in the test, and advantage will be taken of this to vary the\ntest cycles as appropriate to represent flight in different degrees of turbulence, at different gross weights, and with different flight patterns.\nThe engineering tasks involved in this test are considerable. The specimen weighs\nabout 40 tons and the fuel about twice this amount. This entire mass has to be heated and\ncooled through the appropriate temperature range of each test cycle. Two major plants\nare required, one for external heating and cooling and the other for internal heating and\ncooling with all the special forcing systems included. The duct over the specimen is itself a major piece of engineering design. Then there is the mechanical loading system\nwhich must be capable of applying a multiple range of loads in a relatively short time.\n20\n\nFinally, the overall control system for the test must itself have high integrity and be able\nto control and monitor all functions so that the test as a whole achieves high reliability\nwith safety.\nSpecial attention has been paid to the need for extreme reliability of all parts of the\nrig, and wherever possible, well proven designs and techniques have been used. The\ntests will be continued for many years over many thousands of cycles to represent the\nservice life of the aircraft with adequate margins. It is imperative therefore that the rig\nshould be trouble free so that the only interruptions in the testing programme are for\ninspection and repair of the specimen.\nWhile the equipment for the test is impressive, the technical judgement which lies\nbehind it is more significant. The test must be meaningful. It must be possible to interpret the failures and apply preventive measures to aircraft in service. Much is being\nlearned now from the research and development programme to give the necessary basis\nfor this technical judgement. It is planned that the test will start before certification of\nthe aircraft. The test specimen will then keep well ahead of the aircraft in service and\nwill give practical demonstration that the airframe is capable of withstanding the recurring loads which make up its service experience.\nFail-Safe Tests\nThe Anglo-French TSS standards (ref. 4) call for analysis and substantiating tests\nto demonstrate the fail-safe characteristics of the structure. The tests are to be taken\nto limit load in combination with appropriate temperature effects and normal cabin operating pressure, if applicable.\nThe American FAA standards (ref. 3) go a little further than this. They require\nthat all primary structure shall be designed fail-safe and that it shall be shown that adequate residual strength is provided to ensure that any partial failure will be detected\nbefore a hazardous condition develops. This involves showing that the structure remains\ncapable of supporting the expected repeated loading and temperature spectrum and critical\ndesign limit loads without catastrophic results during the period after any fatigue failure\nor partial failure has progressed to obvious proportions and prior to detection by inspection. The intention is to cover the situation in which cracks or accidental damage might\noccur immediately following an inspection and then remain undetected in service until the\nnext inspection, during which period they might be subjected to limit load. Thus, in a\nfail-safe test, it is necessary to cut the structure to simulate damage or to grow a crack,\nthen to subject it to fatigue loads under the full environmental conditions for the equivalent\nof an inspection period, during which the damage may propagate, and then to show that it\nwill withstand limit load. The results of these tests are required for type certification.\n\n21\n\nThis fail-safe testing involves quite a large test programme to cover all aspects of\nthe structure. The tests too are complex and time consuming because fatigue testing\nunder full environmental conditions is required. For Concorde, it is planned to do these\ntests on the major component specimens, supplemented where necessary by tests on\nsmaller specimens to cover design changes made since these specimens were made.\nThus results will be available for type certification. In addition, check tests will be made\non the major fatigue test specimen towards the end of its programme. These check tests,\nof course, will be made after the initial Certificate of Airworthiness tests are completed,\nbut it is not thought practical to mix fail-safe tests with the major fatigue test, as the\napplications of limit load to check residual strength, necessary for the fail-safe tests,\ncould affect crack initiation in the fatigue test.\nTHERMAL CYCLE IN MAJOR FATIGUE TEST\nImportant Thermal Effects in Fatigue Test\nBefore going into the practical details of how this test is to be done for the Concorde,\nan examination of why a fatigue test is to be done at all and what the main parameters are\nwhich dictate its complexity is appropriate.\nA fatigue test is a firm requirement of the British and French certifying authorities.\nThey specifically state in the TSS standards (ref. 4) that "A full scale complete airframe\nfatigue test programme shall be carried out under representative loading, pressure, heating, and cooling conditions." There is good reason for this. Experience, over many\nyears, has shown that the fatigue test can reveal unexpected weaknesses and enable corrective action to be taken early, thus preserving safety. In safe-life designs, the fatigue\ntest can reveal failures which would not have been found by inspection until they had\nbecome catastrophic. In fail-safe designs, the fatigue test shows where to make the\ninspections and gives guidance on their frequency, based on the rate of crack propagation.\nIt has even been known to show that some structures designed to be fail-safe had unexpected weaknesses with safe-life characteristics. Thus it is extremely desirable for a\nfail-safe structure to be fatigue tested for its full life with an adequate factor to cover the\npossibility of unexpected safe-life failures. As well as the safety aspect, the early knowledge of possible fatigue damage in service has important warranty considerations.\nHaving established that a fatigue test shall be done, there is no doubt that the best\nand most up-to-date methods of simulation of the mechanical loads must be used, and this\nis no real difficulty with modern servo-hydraulic loading systems and on-line computer\ncontrol. The major question, which governs the complexity of the test, is the manner in\nwhich it is necessary to include the thermal effects in order to do a meaningful test.\nThere are a number of significant thermal effects including\n22\n\n(1) The thermal stress loading cycle produced by the thermal cycle, that is, heating\nand cooling each flight\n(2) Creep arising from prolonged time at temperature under load\n(3) Overageing arising from prolonged time at temperature and giving a reduction\nof static strength\n(4) The interaction of all these thermal effects on each other and on the fatigue\nbehaviour of the structure under mechanical loads.\nOf these, the first is of overriding importance in determining if or how the thermal effects\nshould be included in the test. Also intermittent heating is probably important because of\nits interaction effect on fatigue behaviour under mechanical loads.\nIt was shown previously that the difference in internal and external structural temperatures arising from the supersonic climb to altitude produced a thermal stress, which\ndied away as the structural temperature equalised during the cruise. The process was\nrepeated during the descent, giving rise to a thermal stress of the opposite sign. These\nthermal stresses are likely to be characteristic of all supersonic transport aircraft having\na long range and to be an important part of the fatigue-loading environment. For the\nConcorde they are of comparable magnitude to the direct stress. They cannot therefore\nbe ignored in a fatigue test. They might be simulated by mechanical means, but although\nthis may be feasible in simple specimens, it is not thought to be practicable in the complex structure of a complete airframe. By their very nature, thermal stresses arise\nfrom the differential expansion or contraction of adjacent structure and have a varying\npattern throughout the structure depending upon the temperature differences set up with\ntime. It therefore is regarded as essential that the thermal stresses should be obtained\nin the fatigue test by the application of the thermal cycles.\nThe other thermal effects then need to be fitted into the test cycle. Not all of these\nnecessarily involve intermittent heating and cooling for adequate representation. But they\nshould be included in the test somehow, and can be included more easily if the thermal\ncycle is applied in the test. More details about thermal effects are given in the following\nsections where the problem of accelerating the test is considered.\nAccelerating the Test\nConcorde is being designed to have a service life of 45 000 hours. The maximum\nutilisation for any particular aircraft is expected to be between 3000 and 4000 hours per\nyear. Now, as mentioned previously, the aim is to run the fatigue test so that the specimen will always have achieved at least three times the fatigue life of any aircraft in service. This factor of three allows for the scatter in fatigue performance between nominally\n\n23\n\nidentical structures, and allows for the variation between the test specimen and service\naircraft. Hence, as much as 12 000 hours of flying may need to be represented in a year.\nHowever, there are only 8760 hours in a year, and even by testing 24 hours per day,\n7 days a week, it is unlikely that more than 4000 hours of actual test running can be\nachieved as time must be allowed for inspection of the specimen, maintenance, and so\nforth. Thus, the test has to be accelerated by a factor of approximately three, and it\nwould be prudent to achieve rather better than this to allow provision for long delays\nwhich would inevitably occur if a major failure took place in the test.\nNormally, it is quite a simple matter to accelerate a fatigue test as the mechanical\nload effects are amenable to grouping and can be represented in a much shorter time in\nthe test than in a flight. This grouping has become a well-established technique, although\nsome workers have slight doubts whether it would not be better to include more dwell\nperiods between loading than is currently done. It is much more difficult to accelerate a\ntest cycle including thermal effects because most of these effects are time dependent.\nThe present plan is to accelerate the hot test cycle in two ways:\n(1) By making each thermal cycle as fatigue damaging as two supersonic flights\n(2) By shortening the thermal cycle to as near 60 minutes as practicable.\nIn planning the fatigue test, it has been assumed that\n(1) The average length of a supersonic flight is 2.5 hours.\n(2) The average length of a subsonic flight is 1.0 hour.\n(3) On the average the ratio of supersonic flights to subsonic flights is 4 to 1.\nThe current plan is to run the fatigue test in a sequence of two hot test cycles and one cold\ntest cycle. The hot test cycle will represent two supersonic flights and will contain one\naccelerated thermal cycle equivalent to two supersonic flights and two groups of mechical loads each equivalent to one flight. The cold test cycle will contain all the mechanical\nloads equivalent to one flight. The aim is to do the hot cycle in 60 minutes and the cold\ncycle in 15 minutes. If this is achieved then the sequence of two hot cycles and one cold\ncycle will take 2.25 hours and represent four supersonic flights plus one subsonic flight\ntaking 11 hours. Thus, the time has been compressed by a factor of almost five.\nWithin this broad format, the individual test cycles will take account of flights in\ndifferent degrees of turbulence, at different gross weights, and for different flight patterns.\nNo test, however complicated, can provide a perfect representation for all aircraft in service, and a means of interpretation is necessary to relate the test results to service as\npreviously mentioned.\nShortening the hot cycle brings a number of tricky problems to fit all the mechanical\nloadings into the time available, especially as each of these cycles is to represent two\n24\n\nflights. Basically, the plan is to associate one set of mechanical loadings with their\nappropriate place in the test cycle and then to add another set towards the end of the cycle\nwhile the specimen is recovering temperature equilibrium ready for the next test cycle.\n(See fig. 19.) The alternative plan would have been to have put in one set of mechanical\nloadings, but at a higher level to take account of the acceleration. This plan was rejected\nhowever, mainly because of the possible unrepresentative effect on crack propagation.\nThe time available for mechanical loading thus becomes critical in the shortened\ncycle; and therefore, great care needs to be taken in choosing the levels of loads to be\nused, particularly within the taxi and gust load spectra. Especially, it is necessary to\nensure that sufficient small loads are applied to reproduce the effects of fretting, even\nthough these small loads take a disproportionate testing time compared with their direct\ncontribution to the fatigue damage. The computer-controlled hydraulic servo-loading system gives great freedom of choice of loading levels, and full advantage can be taken of this\nto pick an optimum combination of frequencies and levels.\nAnother advantage arising from this flexibility is that random loading can be used if\ndesired. Random loading, of course, more nearly represents what happens in service, and\nits use reduces the number of assumptions necessary in setting up the test programme. A\npossible disadvantage is that it might make it more difficult to trace the progress of failures on the fracture surfaces. Some work is currently in hand to investigate this in laboratory specimens and also the possibility of arranging the random loading to include\nmarker loads which could be found on the subsequent fracture. Certainly, it is an advantage to be able to trace the progress of a fracture, but experience shows that this is often\nnot possible except in simple loading cases and advantages of random loading may well\noutweigh the disadvantage which might arise in this particular aspect.\nAccelerated Thermal Cycle\nAs previously mentioned the thermal cycle is to be accelerated by making it represent more than one flight and by shortening it. The most important part of the thermal\ncycle is the representation of the thermal stress, although the effects of creep and overageing and of their interactions are not to be ignored. The thermal stress arises from\ndifferential expansion due to the temperature difference between the skin and the internal\nstructure. This stress is proportional to the temperature difference, and hence by\nincreasing this difference a corresponding increase in thermal stress is obtained. This\nincrease, in turn, is related to life through the appropriate S-N relationship, and an\nincrease in temperature range can be chosen to give in one test cycle the fatigue damage\nfrom thermal stress approximately equivalent to that occurring in two supersonic flights.\nFor illustration, a simple example of a hypothetical piece of deep structure which\nfollows certain assumed conditions will be considered. In particular, it is assumed that\n25\n\n\t\n\nthe skin and the deep structure start the climb at the same temperature and that the deep\nstructure has warmed up only negligibly by the time the skin temperature has reached its\ncruise value. This would then give the condition for maximum thermal stress. It is also\nassumed that similar conditions apply for the descent. The comparison then becomes\nReal time\t\nTest\nconditions conditions\nThermal stress due to climb:\nSkin and deep structure temperature at start of climb, \xc2\xb0C . \t\nSkin temperature at end of climb, \xc2\xb0C . . . . . . . . . . . .\t\nDeep structure temperature at end of climb, \xc2\xb0C . . . . . . \t\nSkin temperature range, 0 C . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\t\nIncrease in skin-temperature range over real-time conditions,\n\npe rcent\n\n15\t\n100\t\n15\t\n85\t\n\n22\n130\n22\n108\n\n. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\t\n\n27\n\n\tThermal-cycle time-compression factor . . . . . . . . . .\t\n\n--2\n\nThermal stress due to descent:\nSkin and deep structure temperature at start of descent,\no C\t\n\tMinimum skin temperature during descent, 0 C . . . . . . .\t\nDeep structure temperature at same time, \xc2\xb0C . . . . . . .\t\nSkin temperature range, o C . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\t\nIncrease in skin-temperature range over real-time conditions,\npercent. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\t\n\tThermal-cycle time-compression factor . . . . . . . . . . \t\n\n100\t\n\n130\n\n-20\t\n100\t\n120\t\n\n-25\n130\n155\n29\n\n^2\n\nThe example is imprecise because clearly all the assumed conditions are not exactly\nmet. Nonetheless, it illustrates that practical test conditions can be found which for deep\nstructure will enable the thermal cycle to be accelerated by approximately two, that is, to\nrepresent two real flights. Clearly, a wide range of test conditions could be chosen to\nachieve this effect. The particular combination of a top temperature of 130 o C, a bottom\ntemperature of -25 0 C, and an ambient temperature of 22 0 C is a reasonable compromise\non plant requirements, consistent with minimum effect on material properties of the specimen, particularly at elevated temperature. There are, of course, varying depths of deep\nstructure throughout the aircraft. Because only one external temperature distribution can\nconveniently be prescribed for the whole aircraft, each portion of the structure will experience a different acceleration, depending upon its depth within the total structure.\nA similar approach to accelerate the conditions for shallow structure is possible by\nincreasing rates of heating and cooling, and a useful compromise is to cover the new tem-\n\n26\n\nperature range in the original time. Again the resulting acceleration pattern is not uniform throughout the structure.\nThe second part of the problem is what can be done to shorten the test cycle. It has\nalready been said that the most important reason for including the thermal cycle is to\nrepresent the thermal stresses, and for these it is important to represent the climb and\ndescent phases in approximately real time. Thus, the only hope for shortening the test\ncycle lies in shortening the cruise and recovery phases. There are however two important constraints, namely, that the structural temperatures must be correct at the start of\nthe climb and at the start of the descent so that the conditions are right for the generation\nof the thermal stress. If these conditions can be achieved artificially, the cruise and\nrecovery phases can be shortened. Incidentally, a shorter cruise at higher temperature\nis compatible with maintaining the correct creep and overageing damage rates.\nIn cruise, the important criterion is that the structure reaches the conditions at the\nend of the cruise phase before the descent phase is started. Shallow structure will follow\nquite closely the temperature of the skin. Deeper structure will lag behind because of the\ntime it takes for the heat to be conducted to it. The amount of lag will vary considerably\nthroughout the structure. Most of the structure will, however, have reached a stable temperature by the end of the cruise phase. The problem, therefore, of shortening the cruise\nphase is to identify the structure which will not have reached a stable temperature in the\nshortened time and to force heat it in the test so that it does. The forced heating can be\nstarted as soon as the peak thermal stress has been reached in the climb. This peak\nwill be reached at the end of the climb for deep structure and earlier for shallow\nstructure.\nSimilar arguments for forced cooling apply to the shortening of the recovery phase.\nForced cooling can be started as soon as the peak thermal stress has been reached; the\npeak thermal stress occurs at or before the time at which the skin reaches its minimum\ntemperature. The situation is complicated by the fact that the final ambient temperature\nis higher than the skin temperature and lower than the temperature of the bulk of internal\nstructure. Therefore, the forcing potentials are less than those obtained at the end of the\ncruise. The forced heating and cooling is being done by circulating hot and cold air and\nhot and cold fuel and is an extremely complex process.\nFor Concorde the chosen aim is to do the complete test cycle in 60 minutes, made\nup approximately of take-off and climb, 11 minutes; cruise, 20 minutes; descent and landing, 9 minutes; and recovery, 20 minutes. Initially test cycles will be run in real time,\nand results compared with measurements in flight. These have become known as "witness\ntests." Tests under accelerated conditions will then be made with the cycle time gradually\nbeing reduced, but ensuring always that the shortened test cycle remains meaningful. A\ncomparison of the proposed accelerated thermal cycle with the flight cycle is shown in\nfigure 20.\n27\n\nInterpreting the Test\nThe presence of the thermal cycle adds a number of difficulties in interpreting the\ntest. For the fatigue test of a subsonic aircraft, numerous simplifying assumptions have\nto be made to set up the test, and means have to be devised to interpret the failures and\nto apply them to aircraft whose service history differs from the loading spectra used in\nthe test. All this is still necessary for the supersonic transport aircraft. There is, however, the added complication of the thermal cycle and of the compromises which have been\nnecessary to include it in the test.\nIt has already been shown that compression of test time, that is, increasing the\nthermal stress damage in each test cycle, produces a nonuniform thermal-cycle timecompression factor throughout the structure. Even though the nominal value of this compression factor is 2, it is necessary to be able to calculate the actual value at any place\nwhere a failure occurs or at other points of interest.\nThe principle of the accelerated cycle is to increase the magnitude of the thermal\nstress so that less cycles are applied and time can be saved; however, these increased\nthermal stresses have to be combined with the direct mechanical stresses. In fact, the\nthermal stress can be regarded as a shift of mean stress for the alternating mechanical\nstresses since it is a slowly varying stress from zero to a maximum in one direction,\nthrough zero to a maximum in the opposite direction, finally returning to zero again. In\norder not to raise the peak stresses to too high an unrepresentative value, it was decided\nto apply the mechanical loads (real level) twice during the test cycle to compensate for\nthe acceleration of the thermal cycle. This is a complex situation. Increased thermal\nstresses are being combined with mechanical stresses at real-aircraft level. At any particular point in the structure, the proportions of thermal and mechanical stress damage\nmay not be correct since the mechanical cycles are being applied overall on the assumption of a nominal value of thermal-cycle time-compression factor of 2 whereas the actual\nvalue at that point may be different.\nIt is important that under these special conditions the form of failure should not be\naltered, or if it is, the difference should be recognised. To this end, the box tests and\nother backup research tests are being made to explore modes of failure, times to failure,\nand crack-propagation rates under combinations of mechanical and thermal stress and\nunder real and accelerated conditions.\nFortunately, shortening the thermal cycle in association with accelerating the rate\nof thermal-stress damage results in the application of higher temperatures in the cruise\nfor shorter times. Thus, in part, some automatic compensation is given for the creep\nand overageing effects, but these need to be calculated in detail throughout the structure\nto determine how much the structural properties are being changed from each of these\ncauses and comparison made with real aircraft conditions.\n28\n\nTherefore, the need to assess the cumulative damage under all of these conditions\nand relate it to aircraft conditions so that test damage can be interpreted is great. The\nprocess for correcting fatigue-test results for different service conditions is now well\nestablished for subsonic aircraft. Basically, this correction depends upon the application\nof Miner\'s law to critical parts of the structure. To this process must now be added the\nthermal stress and the interaction effects of the thermal cycle, creep, and overageing on\nthe mechanical stress. Preliminary methods are being tried and verification sought from\nthe research programme.\nHEATING AND COOLING FOR THE MAJOR FATIGUE TEST\nExternal Heating and Cooling\nThe purpose of external heating and cooling is to apply to the specimen the kinetic\nheating which the aircraft receives in the supersonic climb and cruise and the cooling\nwhich results from the descent at subsonic speeds. (See fig. 4.) The heating and the\ncooling is being done convectively with air, which is blown over the specimen at the\nrequired temperature and at suitable speeds so that the heat-transfer coefficients experienced in flight are reproduced in the test laboratory. The specimen is enclosed in a\nthermal duct which is divided into five sections, one over the fuselage and one over and\nunder each of the two wings. There are five closed circuits linking these sections to the\nheating and cooling plant. Closed circuits are used so that the air can be recirculated\nand the heating and cooling potential conserved. Each circuit contains a fan to circulate\nthe air and heat exchangers to heat and cool it.\nThermal duct.- Initially it was intended that the thermal duct should totally enclose\nthe specimen. Later for reasons of expediency, it was decided not to heat and cool the\nwing tips and the upper part of the fin. The justification for not heating and cooling these\nareas is that the thermal stresses in them are low, and what effects there are can be\nassessed by reading across from areas of similar structure which are being subjected to\nthe thermal cycle. The most important advantage is that this exclusion enables a rigid\nduct to be used since the specimen deflections can be contained within the duct spacing\nfrom the specimen. The duct can therefore be supported by rigging from the structure of\nthe laboratory. Some flow-restriction problems arise because of the specimen deflections, but these are small compared with the problems that would have arisen from the\ndesign and construction of a flexible duct or a duct with flexible joints. Even so the\ndesign of the duct is still a major engineering task. This duct has to be easily removable\nso that the specimen can be inspected at frequent intervals. It has to be airtight when\nclosed to avoid large losses of hot and cold air. It has to have a minimum of thermal\nmass so that it does not absorb heat and cold from the airstream in an unnecessarily\n\n29\n\nwasteful manner. It must, of course, be able to withstand the effects of the continuous\nrepetition of the thermal cycle.\nAs mentioned, the overall aircraft duct is divided into five main sections which are\neffectively in parallel \xe2\x80\x94 one over the fuselage and one over and under each wing. The\nwing ducts are further subdivided; the upper-surface duct splits into four parallel\nbranches to cater for spanwise variation of heat-transfer coefficient, and the lowersurface duct splits initially into four branches which merge into three in order to bypass\nthe engine nacelle. The fuselage duct is an annulus up to the wing leading edge, where it\nsplits into two branches, a horseshoe sectioned upper duct and an approximately rectangular sectioned lower duct. The two ducts continue along the fuselage and rejoin at the\nwing trailing edge.
