Near the fin leading edge, a divider takes some of the air from the\nupper duct and passes it over the lower portion of the fin before rejoining the fuselage\ncircuit in the return trunking. The ducts are shown diagrammatically in figures 21\nand 22.\nFor each wing, the upper- and lower-surface ducts join at the trailing edge to form\na plenum chamber with a static pressure common to both ducts. The return trunking for\nthe two circuits is connected to the plenum chamber, and a short distance from the chamber the lower-surface duct trunking is provided with a vent to the atmosphere. The vent\ndictates the position of atmospheric static pressure in the circuits and allows the circuits\nto breathe during temperature changes. To prevent an increasing concentration of airborne fuel simulant in the circuits due to small fuel leakages, the circuits are constantly\npurged through the vent by bleeding fresh air into the circuits at appropriate positions.\nThere are three vents, one for each wing and one for the fuselage. Provision is made for\nthe insertion of suitable gauges in the three outer ducts of each wing circuit forward of\nthe leading edge to adjust the mass flows in the ducts, and vane dampers are fitted in all\nducts at the trailing edge for fine adjustment. Similarly, for the fuselage circuit, vane\ndampers are fitted in the upper duct and small fin duct.\nThe duct depths are designed to give the required heat-transfer coefficients from\nthe Dittus and Boelter equation\nNusselt number = 0.023(Reynolds number) 0.8 (Prandtl number)0.4\nwith the overriding condition that the deflected aircraft structure shall not foul the duct.\nAverage duct depths are fuselage, 7 inches; wing upper, 8 inches; and wing lower,\n16 inches. The depth of the wing ducts is adjustable over a 3-inch range so,that the ducts\ncan be tuned to give the right temperature response in the fore and aft direction. The\nfuselage ducts also are adjustable but only in a vertical direction.\n30\n\nThe duct is mounted on a massive steel structure with chordwise beams and spanwise intercostals bridging the specimen. Much of the duct is made up of a large number\nof removable panels constructed of aluminium alloy. These fit onto the beams and intercostals of the supporting structure and react to the loading due to the duct internal pressure. The duct panels and the fixed duct structure are insulated from the airflow on their\ninner surface by insulation panels attached to them. The insulant is a semirigid slab of\nmineral wool completely enclosed in a seam-welded stainless steel skin 0.010 inch thick\nto form insulating panels 1.25 inches thick around the aircraft and 1.75 inches thick in the\ninlet and exhaust ducts. The insulation panels are sealed to prevent ingress of fuel simulant which can be present within the duct in liquid and vapour form due to leakage from\nthe specimen.\nSince the aircraft moves relative to the duct, the chordwise walls separating the\nducts from each other are flexible and constructed to extend and compress like an accordion. (See fig. 23.) The upper surface walls are coincident with chordwise rows of wingload application rods which are used to give the walls lateral stability. The lower surface walls have built-in lateral stability since there are fewer loading rods attached to\nthe lower surface. Sliding seals are provided where the wing tips protrude from the duct.\nThe structure carrying the seal is counterpoised and follows the wing movements.\nThe fin duct is the only portion of duct not fixed relative to the floor. It is attached\nto the fuselage duct by a flexible seal and is moved vertically in step with the fin movement by means of hydraulic jacks with a self-contained hydraulic supply and control unit.\nWith both fin and duct moving together, the problem of passing fin lateral loading rods\nthrough the duct is eased considerably.\nAn essential requirement of the duct is that it shall be easily removable for inspection of the specimen. To this end the duct panels are fitted with quick release devices,\nand as far as possible, the loading rods are passed through the joints between the panels.\nNonetheless, removing the panels is still a very large task since there are about 80\naround the fuselage, 32 above the wings, and 60 below the wings. Those on the fuselage\nare mainly removable, and those on the wing are mainly hinged.\nAnother major problem for the duct is the passing through it of the service pipes\ncarrying air and fuel substitute to provide the internal heating, cooling, and pressurisation. There are some 100 of these pipes ranging in diameter from 4 to 14 inches. Many\nof these pipes pass through the lower fuselage duct and have a masking effect on the fuselage structure. They also increase the pressure drop through the duct considerably. In\nsome cases it has been possible to group the pipes together and to shroud them with an\naerodynamic fairing to reduce the interference to the airstream. There is a difficulty of\nsealing these pipes to the duct to avoid leakage and yet to allow movement of the pipes with\nthe specimen as it deflects in the duct. Some pipes are fitted with corrugated fabric fairings to accommodate the movement and reduce the pressure drop and air leakage. For\n31\n\nothers, clearance holes are filled with a sliding-plate device, which shows a relatively\nsmooth surface to the airstream.\nThe temperature of the air and its mass flow are varied throughout the test cycle\nto give as near as possible the correct heat-transfer coefficient to match the corresponding flight conditions. The temperature of the air is regulated by the flow of fluids to the\nheat exchangers and the mass flow by adjusting the speed of the circulating fans. The\nheat-transfer coefficients vary during the different phases of the flight and a compromise\nhas to be achieved on the rig mainly because, once it has been set up, there is a fixed\ngeometrical relationship between the duct and the specimen. The duct panels are individually adjustable on their supports so that duct depths can be altered locally, thereby\nenabling the duct to be tuned to give the best overall compromise along the length of the\nspecimen for the chosen air temperature and mass flow. Some experience of this has\nalready been gained on the forward fuselage specimen, as mentioned previously, and it is\nconfidently expected that good temperature distributions along and around the specimen\nwill be achieved.\nExternal heating and cooling plant.- The primary heating and cooling plant consists\nbasically of the following equipment:\n(1) Axial-flow fans to circulate the air\n(2) Heat exchangers to heat and cool the air\n(3) Boilers and refrigerators for producing the hot and cold fluids\n(4) Storage vessels for all the fluids\n(5) Multitudinous pumps, control valves, and piping to distribute the fluids.\nA simplified flow diagram of the plant is shown in figure 24. The plant generates hot and\ncold fluids continuously, and these are stored in large vessels to be transferred to the\nheat exchangers as required.\nSome idea of the magnitude of the task can be gained from the facts that the structural specimen itself weighs about 40 tons and the fuel substitute about twice this amount.\nThese specimens have to be taken through the appropriate temperature ranges approximately once every hour. This thermal cycling is, however, only part of the work which\nthe plant has to do; since in circulating the air, the thermal duct, return trunking, and\nassociated equipment are all cycled through the appropriate temperature ranges. Even\nthough these are insulated as carefully as possible, they add up to the equivalent of about\nfive more specimens.\nThe axial-flow air-circulating fan in each of the five circuits is fitted with adjustable inlet guide vanes and downstream air-straightening vanes and delivers about\n3200 ft 3 /sec of air. The fan drive is through a shaft connected to a 2000-hp variable32\n\nspeed motor situated outside the circuit. The inlet guide vanes are set to give the best\nfan efficiency for the particular circuit-flow conditions. The total airflow in all five circuits is about 1250 lb/sec. The maximum air velocity is about 150 ft/sec. The fans also\nprovide a considerable input of heat to the air. This heat input assists during the heating\nphase but is an embarrassment during the cooling phase, requiring additional cooling\ncapacity from the plant to compensate for it. It may even need to be compensated for in\npart during the cruise if the heat input from the fans proves to be greater than the heat\nlosses of the circuits.\nThe heat-exchanger fluids are water and ammonia, which are each stored at two\ndifferent temperatures: water at 180 0 C and 5 0 C and ammonia at -62 0 C and 35 0 C.\nThere are two heat exchangers in each air circuit, one for water and the other for ammonia. The water heat exchanger, immediately downstream of the fan, heats or cools the\nair when supplied with water at 180 0 C or 50 C, respectively. The ammonia heat\nexchanger supplies the cooling necessary to produce below-zero air temperatures and is\nso constructed that air can either flow through or bypass the exchanger matrix elements.\nThe eleven elements of the heat exchanger are mounted one above the other with ten intervening gaps. Hydraulically operated shutters over the element inlets and gaps are so\narranged that when the element shutters are open, the gap shutters are closed, making\nthe air go through the elements. With the element shutters closed and the gap shutters\nopen, the heat exchanger is virtually bypassed. The ammonia heat exchanger is bypassed\nwhenever the circuit contains hot air; this bypass reduces the loss of heat into the\nexchanger mass, and in addition, the heat-exchanger mass is kept at a constant temperature by flowing ammonia at 35 0 C through its elements.\nIt is extremely important that the air leaving the heat exchangers and entering the\nthermal duct shall be uniformly heated or cooled over its cross section. The fluid flow\nacross the heat exchangers has been specially designed with this in mind. In addition, the\nfluid in the heat exchangers is constantly recirculated so that it is at a uniform temperature. Fluids from the bulk storage are fed into these circuits to give the required air\ntemperature.\nThe sequence of heat exchanger actions during a thermal cycle is\n(1) Climb: The temperature of the water circulating through the heat exchanger is\nincreased progressively by the addition of hot water at 180 0 C. Warm ammonia at 350 C\nis circulated through the bypassed heat-exchanger elements.\n(2) Cruise: The hot water is gradually decreased and is cut off if the heat input of\nthe fan is greater than the heat losses of the circuit; if this occurs, chilled water at 5 0 C\nis fed to the heat exchanger.\n(3) Descent: The chilled water supply is increased progressively until it is no\nlonger able to maintain the required air-cooling rate. Before the chilled water reaches\n33\n\nits maximum supply rate, the shutters over the ammonia elements open and cold ammonia, at -620 C, is fed into the ammonia heat exchanger. The chilled water continues to\nact as a precooler until the air temperature entering the water heat exchanger drops\nbelow the chilled water temperature. At this stage, hot water is fed to the heat exchanger\nto prevent freezing.\n(4) Recovery: The supply of ammonia at -62 0 C is stopped and the air temperature\nincreases to its datum. If the fan heat input is too large, chilled water will be pumped\nbefore the end of the cycle to keep the air at its datum temperature. At the end of the\nrecovery phase, the ammonia element shutters are closed and the gaps opened to bypass\nthe air.\nThe heating and cooling phases demand large amounts of energy in relatively short\nperiods of time, and in order to spread the requirements of the plant over a complete\ncycle, the heat-exchanger fluids are generated continuously and stored.\nThe hot water is heated by two oil-fired boilers with a total output of\n36 x 10 6 Btu/hr. The water is heated to 180 0 C, and some 100 tons are stored in the\ninsulated storage vessel. The upper part of the vessel serves as an expansion chamber\nand is filled with nitrogen at 180 lb/in 2 to enable water temperature to be attained and to\nprevent cavitation in the water system.\nChilled water at 50 C is provided by an ammonia refrigerating machine with a twostage piston compressor, condenser, and evaporator. The plant has a cooling capacity of\n13.5 x 106 Btu/hr. About 300 tons of chilled water are stored in two insulated vessels\nunder the same pressure as the hot water so that either can be fed to the water heat\nexchanger.\nAmmonia liquid at -62 0 C is generated by two identical multistage turbocompressors working in parallel and having a total capacity of 14.3 x 10 6 Btu/hr. Each turbocompressor uses three stages of flash evaporation. About 145 tons of the cold ammonia is\nstored in two insulated vessels which are interconnected with expansion vessels containing ammonia at 35 0 C. These hold the system at the vapour pressure of ammonia at\n350 C, which is approximately the same as the pressures used in the hot and chilled water\nsystems. The expansion vessels also serve as storage for the supply of ammonia at\n350 C for the heat exchangers while they are bypassed during the heating phase.\nA considerable quantity of cooled water is also required throughout the plant. It is\nused for\n(1) The initial cooling of the chilled water supply\n(2) The condensers of both refrigeration plants\n(3) Maintaining the liquid ammonia below 35 0 C in any parts of the plant where this\ntemperature could be exceeded\n34\n\n(4) Cooling the fan-motor speed controls, which are electrolytic resistors\n(5) Cooling the fluid coupling of the turbocompressors to their electric motors\n(6) Cooling pump glands and other similar applications.\nThe water is cooled from 271 C to 220 C in a two-cell cooling tower, having a total cooling capacity of 70 x 10 6 Btu/hr and a cooling water flow rate of almost 0.8 x 10 6 gal/hr.\nThe circuit of the fans, heat exchangers, and thermal duct is completed by the\nreturn trunking. This is constructed as a double shell, the inner lining being fabricated\nfrom 25 SWG (0.02-inch) stainless steel sheet and having an internal diameter of 6.5 feet.\nThe outer cladding is fabricated from 19 SWG (0.04-inch) aluminium sheet and is separated from the inner lining by a 2-inch thick layer of mineral-wool insulation. Sections\nof the trunking are joined together by stainless steel bellows and cascaded .corners are\nused to assist the airflow. The assembled trunking is completely air and oil tight. The\ntotal lengths of the five circuits vary slightly; the shortest is 590 feet and the longest\n680 feet.\nAll of the plant for the external heating and cooling of the specimen is contained in\na plant house 240 feet x 130 feet x 50 feet high located at the forward end of the test frame.\n(See figs. 17 and 25.) Inside this building is also the control room for the external plant.\nThis is a strong room protected against dangers which might arise from explosion in the\nspecimen or plant. The plant is started and monitored from this control room and, in\nnormal operation, is controlled automatically from the computers. However, individual\nitems of the plant can be run from this room for commissioning and checking purposes,\nand if necessary, a thermal cycle of the whole plant can be run. The plant house is heavily\ninsulated so that noise from the equipment does not seriously disturb work in the adjacent\noffices or destroy the tranquility of the surrounding townships in the quiet of the night.\nInternal Heating, Cooling, and Pressurisation\nAs the name implies, the basic functions of the internal facility are to thermally\ncondition the inside of the specimen and to pressurise the specimen. These are two\nmethods by which these functions may be performed: heating, cooling, and pressurisation\nwith circulated air and heating and cooling with circulated fuel substitute, which for safety\nreasons is used in place of aircraft fuel. In more detail, the tasks needed to be performed\nare\n(1) To represent the normal air conditioning and pressurisation of the fuselage\n(2) To force heat and cool those areas of the structure which would not reach their\nrequired conditions in the shortened accelerated test cycle. This forced heating and cooling is done as appropriate with air or the fuel substitute. This is the major task of the\ninternal plant.\n35\n\n(3) To heat, cool, and load by pressure that area of the underside of the wing normally covered by the nacelle. In the test the real nacelle is not fitted, and all loading\nactions are applied to the wing by a dummy nacelle.\n(4) To correct the thermal condition arising in the wing tips because these are not\ncompletely covered by the external thermal duct. This discontinuity in the external heating and cooling could give rise to unrepresentative loading in the specimen, and to correct\nthis, special treatment is given to the fuel tanks and other structure in this area.\n(5) To pressurise certain of the fuel tanks to represent inertia loads arising on the\nfuel during parts of the test cycle.\nThe whole internal facility divides into three groups, air circuits, fuel systems, and\na background plant which supplies the heating energy, cooling energy, and pressurisation\nair to the primary systems. The major part of the internal plant is housed in a specially\ndesigned plant house, measuring 150 feet x 90 feet x 50 feet high, erected on the starboard\nside of the test frame. (See fig. 17.) The plant house contains the control room for the\ninternal plant, from which the equipment is started and monitored. The plant is normally controlled by computers, but it can, if necessary, be run from this control room\nfor commissioning or checking. Because of the extremely high noise level expected\nfrom the installed plant, the building is of massive construction to provide the necessary sound absorption qualities to avoid disturbance of the neighbourhood.\nThe major components of the primary circuits and systems are connected to the\nspecimen via a very complex and congested system of piping traversing between the plant\nhouse and the main test frame.\nAir circuits.- The areas conditioned by the air circuits are shown in figure 26.\nThese cover the fuselage air-conditioning and pressurisation, the areas to be force\nheated and cooled by air, and the nacelle-wing areas. Among the force conditioned\nareas are fuel tanks 9 and 10, which are emptied in flight before the supersonic phase\ncommences and hence do not need to be filled with fuel substitute in the test. All these\nareas are grouped into 16 zones, some duplicated on port and starboard sides of the aircraft. Zones which have similar thermal and pressure requirements are further grouped\ntogether to give seven primary air circuits.\nThe air circuits are all basically similar; each consists of a Roots blower, one or\nmore heat exchangers, a number of control valves, and connecting piping. A typical circuit circulates about 14 pounds of air per second at a temperature of 130 0 C in the heating\nphase and at 150 C during the cooling phase. The blowers are driven by electric motors\naveraging about 700 hp each. Roots type blowers were chosen as air-moving machinery\nbecause of considerable pressure drops involved in each of the air circuits. Centrifugal\n\n36\n\nfans would have been inadequate and centrifugal compressors were not economically competitive in the sizes required. A typical air circuit is shown in figure 27.\nEach circuit is a closed loop, the air being circulated by means of the Roots blower\nthrough the conditioning system to the various zones of the specimen and then back to the\nsuction side of the blower. The air is heated to the required temperature (130 0 C in most\ncircuits) by a heat exchanger fed with water at 180 0 C from the background plant. For the\ncooling phase, the air passes through two coolers; the first, using cooling-tower water at\n220 C, cools the air to about 35 0 C, and the second, using chilled water at 5 0 C, further\ncools the air to about 15 0 C. Selector valves control the passage of the air to the appropriate heat exchangers.\nThe total mass flow to the specimen is controlled by regulating the valve in the\nblower bypass which bridges the delivery and return pipes across the blower. This flow\nis subdivided in the appropriate circuits by setting inlet trimming valves to apportion the\nflow to each individual zone.\nA bypass is provided between the inlet and outlet pipes to each zone to enable temperature preconditioning of the delivery pipes between phases if required and thereby\nallow a choice of initial air temperature into the specimen. A valve in the bypass prevents flow when not required. The specimen inlet valve dictates whether flow is allowed\nthrough the specimen.\nSome circuits where the zone is not airtight are vented to atmosphere at the specimen; the remaining circuits servicing airtight zones are vented from outlet pipes adjacent\nto the specimen. In all instances therefore the return pipes operate at a subatmospheric\npressure except when a circuit is pressurised. Circuits 1, 3, and 6 are required to be\npressurised during certain phases of the test cycle and are individually supplied with air\nat either 7 or 14 lb/in2 from the background plant via an inlet valve which regulates the\nsupply when an increase of pressure is required. A separate valve decreases the pressure on command by controlled venting to atmosphere. Safety valves are provided at\neach specimen inlet to safeguard against overpressurisation and also at each specimen\noutlet to prevent negative pressure occurring within the specimen.\nEach circuit is fitted with an impingement liquid separator to remove any fuel substitute which may have leaked into it. This is to avoid fouling of the heat exchangers,\nwhich would reduce their efficiency. A mist detector is installed in each circuit to give\nadequate forewarning should the air-fuel substitute ratio become an explosive hazard.\nFire detection and suppression systems are also provided.\nThe Roots blowers are constructed with close running tolerances on their rotors,\nand it is necessary to protect them from harmful temperature fluctuations. Thus, in five\nof the circuits, where the temperature of the air can reach 130 0 C, a heat exchanger is\n37\n\ninstalled at the blower inlet to precool the air returning to the blower. The air temperature in the other circuits does not exceed 60 0 C.\nThe blowers and heat exchangers are installed in the internal plant house on the\nstarboard side of the specimen (fig. 17), and there is therefore a considerable length of\npiping to bring the air to and from the specimen. In a typical circuit, the distance from\nthe heat exchangers to the specimen is about 150 feet, and considerable care has had to\nbe taken to keep the thermal mass of the delivery pipes to a minimum to ensure the\nrequired air temperatures at the specimen. The pipes have a wall thickness of only\n0.04 inch and are covered with 2-inch-thick insulation of low density. The pipes vary in\ndiameter between 6 inches and 24 inches according to the circuit.\nAttaching these pipes to the specimen is also a major problem because of specimen\nmovement caused by the mechanical loading and thermal distortion. There are about 80\nof these pipes, and most of them have had to be fitted with a sliding joint to provide the\nnecessary flexibility. The problem for those carrying pressure is even more severe as\nthe end loads from these could provide unacceptable spurious loads on the specimen.\nThis problem has been overcome by the design of special balanced fittings.\nHaving brought the air to the specimen, there is still the mammoth task of distributing it to all the zones requiring conditioning. Essentially this is done by a gallery system with air-distribution points along its length. A typical one for the fuselage airconditioning is shown diagrammatically in figure 28. A similar gallery system is used\nto collect the air and return it to the plant. All pipes are taken into and out of the structure through existing holes wherever possible so that the primary structure of the specimen is not affected.\nFuel systems.- The layout of the fuel tanks is shown in figure 29. As mentioned\npreviously, tanks 9 and 10 are conditioned with air, but all of the remainder need to be\nfilled with fluid in the test to represent the fuel. The choice of a suitable simulant for\nthe fuel has been a very difficult task. The use of kerosene itself would have been too\ndangerous and its repeated use through the many thermal cycles and long periods at\nelevated temperature would have presented deterioration. The main features that have\nbeen looked for in a simulant are\n(1) A sufficiently high flash point to avoid fire and explosion risks\n(2) Acceptable heat-transfer characteristics so that representative thermal conditions can be achieved in the specimen tanks\n(3) Compatibility with the constructional materials of both specimen and plant\n(4) Slow appreciation of acidic level and general stability when thermally cycled or\nmaintained for long periods at elevated temperature\n(5) Low cost.\n38\n\nThe fuel simulant chosen, Shell 7305c, is a mineral oil with antioxidant additives.\nExtensive tests have been made to develop the fluid and to show that it meets the previously mentioned qualifications. In the following description of the plant and the installations in the specimen, the fluid is referred to simply as fuel.\nIn the aircraft itself, there are varying levels in the tanks as the fuel is used up.\nThese varying levels could have been represented in the test, but it was decided to simplify the procedure by using a constant quantity of fuel in the tanks. By carefully choosing the quantity of fuel and its temperature programme during the test cycle, it has been\npossible to achieve a close representation of the critical thermal stresses in the tank\nstructure. Most tanks are about 75 percent full with some 90 percent full. Great care\nhas been taken with the filling system so that the specimen shall not be damaged. The\nlarge fuel-circulating pumps cannot be used for this task, and a special small pump\n(25 gal/min) has been provided for the purpose. It is under manual control monitored\nfrom the computer. Thus the quantity of fuel in each tank can be chosen before cycling\nstarts. Since each tank is in its own closed circuit, the quantity of fluid in the tank\nremains constant, apart from leakage, which may occur as the specimen is tested. One\nof the functions of the monitoring computer is to check these quantities and initiate shutdown if they go outside acceptable limits.\nSpecial provision is available to change the level of fluid in the tank during the test\ncycle in order to simulate flight usage for the special witness tests in real time in which\nmeasurements on the specimen are compared with flight measurements. Varying this\nlevel, of course, changes the weight of the specimen during the cycle and has implications\non the hydraulic loading and control systems.\nIn total there are thirteen separate fuel systems, each one serving a single tank\nwithin the specimen. Ten of the systems are temperature conditioned. Each system\nincludes a pump, one heat exchanger, and control valves; these components are sized to\nmeet the requirements of each particular tank. Two of the remaining three systems provide for fuel circulation only, while for the last tank provision is made for filling and\nemptying only. (See fig. 29.)\nA typical specimen tank contains about 1800 gallons of fuel and requires a pumping\nrate of 350 gal/min through pipes of 5-inch diameter against a system resistance of\nabout 120 lb/in2 . Each system is vented at the specimen tank, and the pump is located\nin the main test frame to prevent cavitation at the inlet. A typical temperature conditioned system is shown in figure 30.\nDuring normal cycling operation, the fuel is pumped from the specimen tank through\nthe single heat exchanger located in the plant house and then back to the specimen tank.\nThe flow rate in the system is controlled by a closed-loop servocontrol operating on the\nthrottling valve.\n39\n\nDuring the heating phase, the fuel is progressively heated until that in the specimen tanks reaches the required temperature (usually 90 0 C). The heating is obtained by\nfeeding hot water at 120 0 C to the heat exchanger at a preselected rate. Similarly in the\ncooling phase, the fuel is cooled until that in the specimen tanks reaches the required\ntemperature (usually 25 0 C). The cooling is obtained by feeding chilled water at 5 0 C to\nthe heat exchanger at a preselected rate. Between these phases the fuel may continue to\nbe circulated, if required, with the energy supply to the heat exchanger interrupted to\nprevent further unwanted temperature increase or decrease, which prevents temperature\nstratification within the tank due to heat transfer through the skin from the external heating and cooling system.\nConsiderable attention has been given to the design of an efficient distribution system inside each specimen tank with the objective of ensuring 100-percent mixing of the\ningoing fuel with the bulk. Internal pipes extend to the extremities of each tank and the\ningoing fuel is injected at a pressure of about 20 lb/in g through a large number of small\nholes drilled along the length of the internal supply pipes.\nPlate heat exchangers are provided because of their considerably superior heattransfer qualities at the existing low Reynolds numbers. They have the additional advantage of being easy to dismantle for inspection and cleaning. Each system includes a small\npump to maintain the water flow required through the heat exchanger to provide stable\nflow and heat-transfer characteristics.\nSpecimen considerations dictate that the acidic level of the fuel should not exceed\na very low level; to this end chemical filters are provided in each system. Each filter is\nlocated in a bypass fed by a metering pump through a separate heater to provide continuous filtering at 30 gal/hr. All pipes and components with large surface areas in contact\nwith the fuel are manufactured from stainless steel to minimise fuel contamination.\nThe total quantity of fuel in the system is a little over 20 000 gallons, and a storage\ntank of 25 000 gallons is provided to hold the fuel when it is removed from the specimen\nfor structural inspections. The tank is lined with epoxy resin to prevent contamination.\nBackground plant.- The background plant consists of the heating plant, refrigeration\n\nplant, cooling tower, and pressurisation plant. An oil-fired boiler of 16 x 10 6 Btu/hr output is provided to meet the overall heating demands of the primary air and fuel systems,\nthe demands of which are about equal. The boiler produces water at 180 0 C and operates\nat a pressure of 180 lb/in g . This water is used directly in the heat exchangers of the air\ncircuits, but for the fuel systems the water is reduced to a lower temperature through a\nheat exchanger which produces water at 120 0 C.\nAlthough the heating demands of the facility are cyclic with a maximum rate of\ndemand of approximately three times the average, it was not considered economically\n40\n\nadvantageous to reduce the size of the boiler and install a storage system for the hot\nwater. The boiler output will meet the demand on line for most of the cycle, the remainder being supplied from some spare capacity existing in the external plant.\nRefrigeration energy is provided by means of a four-stage turbocompressor of\n13 x 10 6 Btu/hr capacity using freon as a transfer agent. It is driven by a 1000-hp electric motor and produces chilled water at 5 0 C for cooling in the air and fuel systems.\nThe chilled water is generated continuously and stored in an insulated vessel of\n28 000 gallons capacity (about 125 tons).\nA single-cell tower cools almost 0.5 x 10 6 gallons of water per hour from 27 0 C to\n220 C, thereby dissipating about 40 x 10 6 Btu/hr. This tower provides the eventual heat\nsink for all the energy going into the facility.\nA battery of six Roots blowers with a total output of 18 pounds of air per second and\na total power of 1500 hp provides the air for pressurisation on line when required. The\nair is pressurised in two stages, from ambient to 7 lb/in 2 gage and then from 7 to\n14 lb/in2 gage. Between stages the air is cooled to lo o C in a cooler using chilled water\nand the precipitating droplets are removed in a separator; the dewpoint then corresponds\nto 50 C at ambient pressure.\nSafety Precautions\nThe safety of the specimen is, of course, a major consideration in any full-scale\nfatigue test; for the Concorde it is even more important because of the very long time of\ntesting involved. If this specimen were lost after some years of testing, it would be\nimpossible to catch up the programme and to achieve the desired aircraft safety requirement. The specimen must always be tested to at least three times the life of any aircraft in service. Extensive safeguards against a number of hazards arising from different sources are therefore essential.\nExcess-air-pressure safeguards.- Pressure within the specimen is measured by a\ntransducer in all discrete compartments connected to the air system, whether they are\nnormally pressurised or not. Areas normally unpressurised are included since the\npower of the circulating pumps is such that a blockage in the circuits could produce a\nhazard to the specimen. Some 40 measurement points are fitted and are checked at all\ntimes by the monitoring computer, which informs the operator of significant deviations\nfrom the required values and in extreme cases initiates automatic shutdown.\nA mechanical direct-operating safety valve is fitted on the inlet pipe to each zone.\nSimilar valves are fitted on the pressurisation feed pipes of the circuits that are pressurised. In addition there is built into each compartment, including all the fuel tanks, a\ndirect-operating pressure-relief valve.\n41\n\nAntivacuum safeguards.- Pressures measured in all compartments are checked by\nthe monitoring computer to ensure that a malfunction of an air-conditioning system does\nnot create a subatmospheric condition within the specimen. A mechanical directoperating safety valve is fitted on the outlet pipe from each zone.\nFuel-level surveillance.- The fuel level in each fuel tank is measured by a transducer and checked against the expected level by the monitoring computer. An increasing level could ultimately result in excess pressure and a decreasing level would indicate\nthat fuel simulant was escaping, thereby creating a potential explosive hazard.\nExplosive-hazard safeguard.- By the very nature of the test, it is likely that at some\nstage fuel simulant will leak from the specimen and will enter the air circuits. If it does\nso, there is a danger that in the fast-moving airstream of changing temperature, it will\nform a potentially dangerous fuel mist. To meet this possibility, a mist detector is\ninstalled in each of the external and internal air circuits to give adequate forewarning\nbefore the mist becomes an explosive hazard.\nFire detection and suppression.- Infrared and smoke detectors are installed both\ninside the specimen and in the external thermal duct surrounding the specimen. The\ndetectors are connected to a bulk-storage CO2 suppression system which will automatically flood the external ducts and the specimen should a detector become activated.\nExtensive fire detection devices are also fitted in the test laboratory and plant houses.\nAmmonia detection.- To safeguard against the possible corrosion of the specimen\nshould ammonia leak from a heat exchanger into an external air circuit, an ammonia\ndetector is installed in each circuit. Further detectors are located in the external plant\nhouse to give adequate warning to personnel.\nMECHANICAL-LOADING SYSTEM FOR MAJOR FATIGUE TEST\nThe mechanical loading is applied by a conventional linkage system from hydraulic\njacks, servocontrolled from the computer system.\nLoads and Reactions\nThe test laboratory, approximately 200 feet x 100 feet x 40 feet high, is effectively\na strong box, so that vertical and side loads can be reacted directly to the building. It\nwas designed as a general purpose test frame. The floor is strongly reinforced with steel\nbeams with frequent attachment points, and a series of overhead moveable bridges can be\nplaced at convenient locations to react the up loads. For the Concorde these are supplemented by portal frames over the wing tips and fuselage nose.\nThe loads are applied to the specimen by conventional means. Swivel loading points\nare bolted to the upper and lower surfaces of the wing and to each side of the fin. Groups\n42\n\nof loading points are connected together by a "Christmas-tree" linkage to hydraulic jacks.\nFuselage loads are applied to bulkheads or distributed to the floor beams by a system of\nloading beams inside the specimen. These are linked by rods to a number of hydraulic\njacks outside the specimen. Dummy undercarriages and dummy nacelles are fitted to the\nspecimen, and through these, undercarriage and engine loads can be applied.\nFor the ground tests the specimen rests on the dummy undercarriages and is loaded\nthrough the hydraulic jacks and linkages to give the correct overall distribution. For the\nflight tests the specimen is balanced in its linkage system, but a number of constraints at\nthe undercarriages restrict its movement. All of these constraints are fitted with load\nmeasuring devices and record either balancing reactions or zero load as appropriate.\nTable II and figures 31 and 32 give more detail of the loading system.\nHydraulic System\nEach hydraulic jack is set in a simple load-control circuit, which is made up of a\nload cell, electrohydraulic servo valve, and control module, which holds the load under\nanalogue control until a new set point is given it from the overall control system. All the\nloading jacks are controlled by a PDP8/I computer.\nThe jacks mainly act in tension, although some act in tension and compression.\nThey have been sized so that they can apply proof loads to the specimen as required for\nfail-safe testing towards the close of the fatigue test. They are fitted with PTFE seals to\nkeep the friction low enough to avoid stick-slip effects in the system when small loads are\nbeing applied.\nThe load cells have two measuring bridges. One output is fed back to the control\ncomputer and is used to set up the required load; the other is fed back to the PDP10 monitor computer, where it is compared with the requested load level. Small, but significant,\ndeviations from the required load are printed out and larger deviations initiate shutdown.\nFuller details of the monitoring procedures are given subsequently.\nMoog electrohydraulic servovalves are used throughout the system. These valves\nare two stage. The first, a preamplifier stage, uses a torque motor to convert the electrical input signal to a hydraulic signal, which drives the second, or power, stage. The\ntorque motor operates a flapper which pivots between two hydraulic nozzles forming two\nvariable orifices. Fluid under pressure is supplied to these nozzles through two fixed\norifices, and the pressures between the orifices and the nozzles are applied to the ends\nof the spring-centred second stage, or main, spool. The flow through the valve is proportional to the main spool displacement and, thus, to the input electrical signal for a\nknown pressure drop across the valve. Where higher flows are required, two servovalves\nare operated in parallel or a much larger valve is used.\n\n43\n\nThe jack load is controlled by a simple error-signal device, which compares the\nrequired signal with the measured signal from the load cell. The error signal is amplified and drives the electrohydraulic servovalve to correct the load and so reduce the\nerror signal to zero. This load is then held until a new set point is input to the system.\nEach hydraulic control module has a number of local safety devices which are additional to the overall surveillance exercised by the monitoring computer. These local\ndevices limit the maximum load and travel available at the jack. A typical hydraulic\nmodule circuit for a single acting tension jack is shown in figure 33. The differential\npressure switch (DPS) initiates a fail-safe shutdown if the differential pressure across\nthe jacks exceeds that set on the switch; the differential pressure relief valve (DPRV)\nvents high-pressure oil from either side of the jack to the other if the differential pressure exceeds a preset limit, these valves act as a backup to the differential pressure\nswitches and prevent excessive loads on the specimen. When any safety device is activated, the isolating valves (LV) isolate the jack from the servovalve and ensure controlled\ndumping through the dump valves (DV). In addition, limit switches are used to sense\nexcessive deflection of the jack rods and these also initiate shutdown.\nThe hydraulic power is supplied by 20 variable delivery pumps. Each pump is\ndriven by a 30-hp motor and delivers 14 gallons per minute at 3000 lb/in 2 pressure. The\npumps are arranged in banks of 5, each bank controlled by its own master control valve.\nThis arrangement permits the independent shutdown of a bank of pumps if necessary.\nThe pumps are supplemented by a battery of 8-gallon accumulators to provide for any peak\ndemands of fluid in excess of pump output and to absorb any line pressure surges.\nHydraulic fluid for the system is contained in two 750-gallon reservoirs. The temperature of the fluid (OM33) is maintained at 38 0 C by a thermostatically controlled immersion\nheater in each reservoir. Fluid is distributed from the pumps to hydraulic control modules situated in the various loading areas by a complex system of piping, which is located\nin trunking to contain any leakage.\nConsiderable attention has been given to achieving a high degree of cleanliness in\nthe fluid. This cleanliness is necessary because of the small clearances and orifice\ndiameters within the servovalve. These are susceptible to the fine particles which can\ncause silting or erosion of the orifices and hence alter the performance of the servovalve\nand ultimately possibly result in failure of the valve. Filters are fitted at the pump inlet\n(0.005-inch rating), at the pump outlet (10-micron rating), and at the inlet to the servovalve\n(1.5-micron rating).\nLoading Sequences\nThe weight of the specimen, fuel substitute, and rigging is carried by the loading\njacks, and account has to be taken of this in determining the loads to be applied by the\n44\n\ncomputer. Prior to starting a test cycle, the whole system is set up to a "weightless"\ncondition. Small pretension loads are included where needed to remove slackness from\nthe linkage. Under these conditions, all the load cells at the reaction points should read\nzero.\nThe test cycle commences with the ground loads, including the following conditions\n(1) 1g standing on the ground\n(2) Engine runup\n(3) Taxying loads\n(4) Take-off.\nThe appropriate reaction-point loads are checked throughout to ensure that the required\n\nloading pattern is being applied.\nThe loading is then adjusted to the various phases of the flight including\n(1) lg climb\n(2) Gusts during climb\n(3) Manoeuvre during climb\n(4) lg cruise\n(5) Gusts during cruise (including lateral gusts)\n(6) lg descent\n(7) Gusts during descent and stand off.\nThis is followed by the landing and final taxying conditions including\n(1) Landing (including nosewheel "abattee" conditions)\n(2) Braking\n(3) Reverse thrust\n(4) Taxying\n(5) lg standing on the ground.\nThroughout these sequences, the loading has to take account of changes in the aircraft weight as the fuel is used up and of changes in the air-load distribution in subsonic\nand supersonic flight, together with the fuel transfer necessary to compensate these\nchanges. The programme includes flights with different gust severities (rough flights and\nsmooth flights) and similarly takes account of rough and smooth airfields and different\nlanding conditions to represent real-service conditions.\n\n45\n\nMechanical-Loading Letdown System\nIf for any reason a test cycle has to be aborted while the specimen is under load,\nit is necessary to have a safe system to return it to the no-load condition. For the\nConcorde this is done by a controlled letdown procedure. On receiving a failure signal,\nthe monitor computer deenergises a shutdown relay which in turn deenergises the following equipment:\n(1) The pilot control valves on each jack module, which momentarily lock the specimen in position\n(2) The main solenoid valves in both pump rooms, which divert oil in supply lines\nto reservoir tanks\n(3) The air-operated solenoid valve, which in turn vents pressure from the diverter\nvalves in the return lines thereby directing returning oil to the letdown tank instead of the\nreservoir tank\n(4) The main hydraulic and pilot pressure pumps, which stop oil flow\n(5) The electrohydraulic servovalves, setting them to open circuit\n(6) The dump valves on each jack module, which initiates the letdown of the applied\nloads to zero.\nThe basic design of the letdown system is to separate the hydraulic jack return lines\ninto 5 discrete groups which are\n(1) Over-specimen vertical jacks\n(2) Under-specimen vertical jacks\n(3) Fuselage and fin lateral jacks\n(4) Engine-nacelle jacks\n(5) Undercarriage jacks.\nThese groups are chosen so that a balance between port and starboard will be maintained during letdown. All jacks in groups 1, 2, and 3 have collapsible linkage of length\nsuch that compression loads cannot be transmitted to the specimen. In groups 1, 2, 3,\nand 4 when the dump valves are deenergised, the annulus side of all jack pistons in each\ngroup is connected to a common return pipe through a preset restrictor to the letdown\ntank. The restrictor flow can be varied between 0.25 and 15 gallons per minute. This\nflow rate determines the rate of letdown. All the undercarriage jacks (group 5) are equal\narea double rodded types, and during letdown, pressure is vented from one side of the piston to the other.\n\n46\n\nIn general, loads are controlled by the specimen returning to its natural no-load\nposition. Excessive pressure or load is prevented by the differential pressure relief\nvalves fitted in the hydraulic control module for each jack.\nInteractions With Multichannel Systems\nWhen a single loading channel is controlling the load being imparted to a structure,\nit is relatively easy to determine the characteristics of the complete system (including\nthe structure) and to achieve optimum response from the system. In the case of a multichannel loading system used for the fatigue testing of a large structure, it is necessary to\nensure that all the loading channels are kept in phase and apply the correct loads. Each\nloading point in a multichannel loading system has different mechanical parameters, such\nas stiffness and inertia. Such a system is a compound one, with many subsystems or\nchannels so interconnected by the test structure that they influence each other. The\ndegree of this influence or interaction is dependent both on the strength of the coupling\nbetween respective channels and on the mechanical parameters of each channel. For\nexample, there would be little interaction between two channels with high inertias which\nwere weakly coupled; this type of compound system would show characteristics similar to\nthose of the individual channels. On the other hand, if the coupling were strong, the characteristics of the compound system would be very different from those of the individual\nsystems acting alone.\nThe magnitude of spurious loads caused by interaction depends on a number of factors. It will depend, firstly, on the degree of coupling between the channels and on the\nmagnitude of the mechanical parameters of each individual channel; secondly, on the speed\nof application of loads; and thirdly, on the response characteristics of the individual channels. In many instances, the effects of interaction are minimal and can be ignored.\nSometimes, however, significant errors arise because of interaction, and then it must\neither be counteracted by test techniques or, if this is impossible, taken into account in\nthe analysis of the results.\nSince the magnitude of the interaction loads is dependent on the speed of application\nof the loading, it can be diminished by slowing the rate of loading. It can also be diminished by increasing the response of the affected channel. Both these methods have their\nlimitations, the first because of the time scale of the test being conducted and the second\nbecause by increasing the response, the stability margin is decreased, and unwanted oscillations can result. These oscillations can cause problems as great as the one eradicated.\nClearly, these problems are intimately connected with the particular characteristics\nof the specimen and system involved. They are difficult to predict. They produce further\nproblems in the commissioning of the system which frequently has to be done channel by\nchannel on a separate rig. Great care must therefore be exercised in the interpretation\n47\n\nof the results from such rigs when applying them to real structure. Small multichannel\ntests are being done for the Concorde system using dummy specimens of representative\nstiffness.\nCONTROL AND MONITORING SYSTEMS FOR MAJOR FATIGUE TEST\nBasic Requirements\nThe requirements imposed upon the control and monitoring systems divide into\nthree main categories: control of the test, monitoring, particularly concerning the safety\nof the specimen, and collection of data, mainly from the specimen itself. Beside these\nexplicit requirements, there are others, such as the need to achieve high reliability and to\nhave a configuration giving a good margin of operational flexibility.\nThe requirements for the control function are, of course, dictated by the task which\nhas to be performed. Essentially, this is in two parts, control of the heating and cooling\nplant and control of the mechanical loading system. There are about 50 channels of plant\nrequiring continuous control with nearly 160 switching channels. The continuous control\nchannels involve a complex thermal plant, where nonlinearities and significant time delays\nabound, making this an ideal application for the potential power of direct digital control.\nThe mechanical loading system has a capacity for 150 channels of which currently about\n100 are being used to control the hydraulic jacks, which because of their speed of response\nwould impose a formidable task to control in a direct digital mode. These channels are,\ntherefore, controlled by force feedback on continuous data control loops which only require\nupdating with voltages proportional to the demand loads.\nBecause of the large number of components in the overall plant and in the control\nsystem itself, there is a very real chance that the specimen might be damaged as a result\nof a system failure. Hence, very careful monitoring must take place of all the systems,\nand automatic action must be taken if system failure develops. The cumulative nature of\nthe fatigue process makes it acceptable to shut down the test when any failure is detected,\nalleviating any need to take over control. The provision of a failure detection system\nmust aim at reducing to a very low probability the chance of applying an incorrect condition to the test specimen, during its several tens of thousands of hours of testing.\nAnything less than a completely independent monitoring system relies on the ability\nto predict all the possible forms of failure of a shared component. Since the difficulty of\nachieving this independence increases rapidly as the shared component becomes complex,\nthe only prudent solution is the totally independent system. This totally independent system will have a finite probability of failure; therefore, the chance of applying an unacceptable condition to the specimen is directly related to the probability of both the control and\nmonitoring systems failing within an interval which is sufficient to allow a runaway chan48\n\nnel to deviate unacceptably. It can be shown that even with mean time between failures\nfor the whole system of as low as a few tens of hours and checking rates of approximately\nonce per second, the probability of dual failure is very low. Thus separate control and\nmonitoring systems have been chosen to take care of the test environment. (See fig. 34.)\nAlthough the system is primarily designed to run as a complete entity, the control computers may be run individually on their respective systems. Equally, it is possible to use\nthe surveillance of the monitoring computer when parts of the overall testing facility are\nbeing run on their own hardware control systems.\nA special peripheral unit housed in the monitoring computer is responsible for providing the time base for all the computer systems and at the same time checking that they\nare running in close synchronism. It consists of two separate crystal clocks, one of\nwhich produces pulses at a rate of 1 hertz and the other at rates of 1000 hertz and 1 hertz.\nBasically, each processor is made to count the 1000-hertz pulses and check them against\nthe 1-hertz pulses; the safety of the system is preserved by having the two sources of\n1-hertz pulses.\nThe effect of the test on the specimen is measured through attached strain, temperature, and deflection transducers. In all, these number about 3500 and require to be scanned in less than 10 seconds. Facilities are needed to scan subsets of the total number of\ntransducers and to perform various degrees of processing on the recorded data. A data\nlogging system associated with the monitoring computer performs this task.\nHardware and Its Operation\nOverall hardware configuration.- The overall hardware configuration is shown in\nfigure 35 and may be summarised as follows:\nPDP10 monitoring computer:\nSize of computer word, 36 bits\n32K of 1.6 microsecond core store\n16K of 1 microsecond core store\nTwo 512K fixed head disc stores\nFour DEC tape controllers\n300 lines per minute line printer\nDigital XY plotter\nVB10 visual display\nVR12 slave display\nTwo British standard digital data interfaces\n240 channel analogue multiplexer\n174 digital inputs\nTwo 10-8 data link interfaces\n1000 ch/sec paper tape reader\n49\n\n300 ch/sec paper tape reader\n150 ch/sec paper tape punch\n50 ch/sec paper tape punch\nFour KSR 35 teletypes\nOne ASR 33 teletype\nK70 plant control computer (incorporating a PDP8/I computer):\nSize of computer word, 12 bits\n20K of 3 microsecond core store\n32K fixed head disc store\n48 channels of direct digital control input/output\n190 digital outputs\n63 digital inputs\nASR 33 teletype\nShared 1000 ch/sec paper tape reader l\nShared 150 ch/sec paper tape punch J) With loading computer\n8-10 data link interface\nPDP8/I loading computer:\nSize of computer word, 12 bits\n8K of 3 microsecond core store\n256K fixed head disc store\nExtended arithmetic unit (hardware multiplier)\n5 digital outputs\n2 digital inputs\n150 jack output cards giving t5 or +10 volt output\nASR 33 teletype\nShared paper tape punch and reader\n8-10 data link interface.\nGeneral operational principles.- After the computers have been switched on and have\nhad their programs loaded, they first have to be synchronised. They are each informed of\nthe real time at which they will expect to see the first clock pulse from the special clock\nunit situated in the PDP10. When this unit is switched on the appropriate parts of the programmes count up time to give each computer a real-time base on which to operate its\nplant control and monitoring functions. All control information or instruction to the computers is input via one or more of the teletypes attached to the machines. The next stage\nof operation involves the input of the engineering data giving the magnitudes of the functions to be performed which have already been defined, in principle, by the application\nprograms written to make the computers perform the dedicated tasks associated with the\ntest.\n50\n\nThe engineering data are prepared in advance, in duplicate, by two independent\npunch operators from the carefully checked manuscript information formulated around\nthe structural demands of the test. These identical punched paper tapes are then input to\nthe control and monitoring computers; load information only is put into the loading computer and process information into the K70 machine. The computers then transform the\nengineering data into special internal machine formats and check the data for consistency\nwith respect to both the hardware and the software. In a later stage of the startup procedure, the data are cross-checked within the computer system using the data links which\nconnect the control machines to the PDP10. By this means it is possible to be sure that\nthe information has been input correctly. Once the data have been input and the expected\nconfiguration of the plant has been defined to the computers, the computers can accept the\nvarious parts of the plant for control. This step is necessary because on certain occasions only limited parts of the plant may be run, especially during commissioning.\nAs and when the plant engineers request startup of each major unit of the plant,\nwhich has direct control over the conditions at the specimen, these requests are ratified\nby the control and monitoring computers and relayed back to the plant initiating startup\nof that unit. If the various units are started up in the previously defined order, it should\nbe possible to take the whole of the specified plant onto control with its associated checking through the monitoring computer. During or after this stage, all the control points\nmay be instructed to move to their precycle conditions. The whole of the test rig can\nthus be made ready for cycling, which it will commence on receipt of an instruction defining the start time. The actual programme that is then followed is inherent in the data\ninput to the computers and is executed entirely automatically unless terminated prematurely. Various instructions exist to enable an operator to override the automatic\nsequence previously defined; these allow premature termination of a cycling sequence or\nalteration of its contents or a return to static conditions at the end of the current cycle.\nThroughout the test rig, inner and outer limits are set for the variables, and these\nare checked by the monitoring computer through independent transducers by comparing\nmeasured values with expected values. The inner limits are set such that small deviations which would not significantly affect the accuracy of the test or prejudice its safety\nare permitted. Outer limits are set at levels which would be prejudicial to the test and\nexceedance of these automatically causes shutdown. Any variation between these two\nlimits is recorded on teletype for the immediate information of the operator and also on\npaper tape for subsequent analysis. By these means the control of the test is virtually\nautomatic and follows a prescribed plan; the burden imposed on the operators is thereby\ngreatly minimised. If current information is required about any of the controlled conditions, instructions are available to allow the operator to display these on the cathode-ray\ntube, giving all relevant data to allow an assessment of the operating status of the test\nrig. In a similar way, the data logger may be instructed to survey a prescribed set of\n51\n\ntransducers and print the resulting information in an engineering format on one of the\nteletypes. For larger data-collection surveys, the transducers to be scanned may be\ndefined on punched paper tape, together with the times when they are to take place. The\nlogging will take place automatically at the prescribed times, and the results may be output for subsequent processing on another machine.\nSelective shutdown is possible on a predefined basis. This avoids shutdown of the\nwhole of the plant when one small area is subject to failure and is not potentially damaging\nto the specimen. Later, this shutdown part of the plant may be brought back onto control\nduring an artificially imposed pause in the cycling.\nControl of Air- and Fuel-Conditioning Plant\nExternal-air systems.- Two parameters in each of the five circuits of the external\nconditioning systems are controlled by the K70 process computer in a direct digital control mode. They are the air temperature and the circulating fan speed. The air temperature is controlled through a cascaded loop which involves feeding the heat-exchangerfluid temperature back to the computer as well as the air temperature itself. A hybrid\ncomputer simulation showed that this technique should be sufficient to give the required\naccuracies throughout a fatigue cycle without having to change the control algorithm;\naccuracy is improved significantly if it is accepted that the measured value is delayed\nfrom the set point by approximately 4 seconds. If during commissioning it becomes\nobvious that there are significant errors, then as a first step, it is possible to programme\ntime-varying control parameters. There is an added virtue in having a measure of the\nheat-exchanger-fluid temperature within the computer, since it assists restarting particularly if a test cycle has been aborted at high temperature. It then becomes necessary\nto pick up the specimen at its elevated temperature and to force it back to room temperature conditions without inducing large temperatures differences. This procedure requires\nthe heat-exchanger temperature to be controlled at the current specimen temperature\nbefore the circulating fan for that duct is switched on.\nThe control of the speed of each circulating fan is based on measurements of the\nfan speed using a tachogenerator and is obtained by altering an electrolytic resistance in\nseries with the rotor of the fan motor.\nInternal-air systems.- There are seven circuits air-conditioning the internal structure of the specimen, each of which has one or more parameters under direct digital control using the K70 computer. These systems are all based on similar principles, but\nsome circuits provide more facilities than others. One of the more complex ones controls two mass flows, one temperature, and eight pressures. Like the controlled parameters of the external circuit, the set points may be specified as a series of points varying\nwith time which are then interpolated by the computer to derive the once-per-second\n52\n\nvalues required for control. By this means it is possible to make significant economies\nin the amounts of input data which have to be prepared by hand. This facility is further\nenhanced by the provision of editing software making it possible to alter small amounts\nof data through a typewriter keyboard directly connected to the computer.\nInternal-fuel systems.- The temperature in twelve of the thirteen tanks is controlled continuously through regulation of a single parameter per tank, namely, the fuel\ncirculation flow. In the ten circuits which are temperature conditioned, this continuous\ncontrol is achieved by an open-loop technique where the appropriate hot or cold fluid is\nswitched into the heat exchanger; no temperature feedback is used, the method relying on\nthe repeatability of conditions.\nJack Loading Computer\nSynthesis of net jack load.- Because of the overall requirement to retain the maximum flexibility in the test system combined with economy of storage space in the computers, the net load on any jack is built up from its fundamental components. Broadly,\nthere are two components consisting of a slowly varying or steady load due to aerodynamic\nlift in flight or weight of the aircraft on the ground and a second, more rapidly varying,\ncomponent due to turbulent conditions and manoeuvres in flight or taxying bumps on the\nground. The second component may be further subdivided into a part which defines the\nmagnitude of the gust or bump on the aircraft as a whole, for example, a gust of 10 ft/sec\nat a specified time or a bump of 0.1g at another time, and another part specifying the load\nin that particular jack due to a unit gust or bump; this latter part defines the load distribution between jacks which may vary for the different loading conditions. In algebraic\nterms this becomes\nL=S+WG\nwhere\nL\t\n\nthe load on a particular jack\n\nS\t\n\nthe steady component of load for that jack\n\nG\t\n\nthe gust or bump magnitude for the aircraft as a whole\n\nW\t\n\nthe distribution factor defining the load seen by the jack per unit gust or bump\n\nBy this means it is possible to build up a large repertoire of flights from a relatively\nsmall amount of data.\n53\n\n0.^\n\nTest cycles are quantised into phases where either or both the steady load and set\nof weighting factors W are constant. Gusts and bumps are required to be applied in\nsynchronism throughout the specimen and to a constant waveform. In certain circumstances the waveform is extended in duration to limit the acceleration forces on the test\nspecimen.\nJack set-pointing system.- The jack computer provides set-point voltages for up to\n150 jack control channels, the force feedback control loops being entirely external to the\ncomputer. A flow diagram of the system is given in figure 36 which shows the basic\ncomputer, a PDP8/I, driving through a standard Kent processor interface to a special\njack-driver interface through to the analogue output cards. It produces t5-volt or 0- to\n10-volt signals for bidirectional and unidirectional jacks, respectively, the particular\nvoltage being selected by a simple shorting link on each output card. As may be seen,\nthe hardware makes use of load synthesis as detailed in the previous section. The isolation of the computer central processor from the electrohydraulic control channels occurs\nat the input of the jack-driver interface and is implemented through optical coupling; it\nachieves a high standard of isolation allowing the use of separate power grounds, thereby\nhelping to protect the computer from noise likely to produce malfunction.\nA sample-and-hold circuit accepts the current steady-load voltage and holds it for\none-half second until the next update, thereby restricting steady-load changes to a maximum rate of twice per second for small increments. Step changes of more than the odd\nleast significant bit (the steady load is set up to a resolution of 9 bits plus sign) are unacceptable to the jack control system, so a special procedure is adopted for substantial load\nchanges. For these changes the steady load is updated at a rate of 20 times per second\nduring the change giving a fine linear staircase type of output. To create the gust component, a constant amplitude waveform representing a half gust is input to the jack output\ncard. This is again to a resolution of 9 bits plus sign updated at the rate of 1000 times\nper second. Half gusts may be only initiated at 1-second bounds when the steady load\nis updated and the software imposes a constraint that the component be zero for the first\nand last 25 milliseconds of the half-gust period. Normally, the half-gust duration is\n2 seconds, but it may be requested up to 16 seconds with an overall restriction that it be\nsymmetric about the quarter-gust point. The constant-amplitude gust is scaled by a third\ndigital input to the jack card which is to a resolution of 9 bits plus sign to select whether\nthe half gust be positive or negative going.\nA single jack card is set up within 160 microseconds giving a maximum delay\nbetween channel 1 and channel 150 of 24 milliseconds for the steady-load component. The\ncomparable delay on the gust component is less than 2 milliseconds.\nDroop nose.- The droop nose is activated by two digital outputs from the jack computer, the first switching on the hydraulic pump to generate supply pressure and the second switching the control valve to stroke the droop jack.\n54\n\nPlant Monitoring\nGeneral principles.- As mentioned previously, there is a need for a failure detection system; this system is provided by the PDP10 computer and its peripheral devices.\nStrictly, it is an independent system which together with the control computers is able to\nindicate a lack of consistency between control and monitoring. By software its use is\nextended into a discriminating recording facility, where it disregards information which\nis consistent with correct operation, and promotes shutdown when there are gross errors,\nbut stores and subsequently outputs data values between these two extremes. This technique avoids the vast quantities of redundant information which would be created by a\ncontinuous, conventional recording system. To be successful, the system depends upon\nthe levels of discrimination being set up with great care; information which is intended to\nbe disregarded must not have a significant effect on the test result, and that which initiates\nshutdown must preserve the safety of the specimen and the meaningfulness of the test.\nIn most cases the parameter which is controlled by the control computer is also\nmonitored by the PDP10, but within the internal plant there are several exceptions.\nThese exceptions occur either because the control function may be open loop or because\nthe parameter of direct interest is only implicitly related to that which is directly controlled. Typically, in the internal air circuits the air temperature near the energy\nsource and mass flow are controlled, but it is considered sufficient to monitor the temperature much nearer the specimen together with the state of any air distribution valves\nin that circuit. Because the digital computer inputs associated with valve monitoring are\nconsiderably cheaper than the analogue inputs for, say, mass flow, considerable economies\ncan be achieved. There are complementary savings in computer time and storage.\nTypes of checking and their frequency.- Apart from the load channels, all checking\nis carried out at the same frequency as the related control functions are updated, that is,\nonce per second. Analogue parameters are checked against inner and outer, upper and\nlower limits. Valve positions, which are input on a pair of digital inputs, are checked for\nthe correct state, for example, binary 10 for off, 01 for on, and 00 for the transient state,\nwhich is allowed a preset time.\nSince the loading channels can deviate more rapidly to an unacceptable level, their\nchecking is conducted at a considerably higher rate, directly related to the required bandwidth necessary in control to produce the planned gusting rates and accuracies. Outer\nlimits are checked twenty times per second and inner limits once per second unless\nextended duration gusts are being executed; then inner limits are only checked at the\nquarter cycle points.\nTypes of output.- There are three basic types of output available from the monitoring computer:\n\n55\n\n(1) Typed output on teleprinters\n(2) Paper tape output\n(3) Visual display output\nThe first two are produced automatically when a variable exceeds inner limits. The purpose of the typed output is to draw the attention of the test controller to the current test\nsituation, namely, that one or more channels are deviating from their expected conditions,\nso that a close watch can be kept on any developments. If more than a prescribed number of printouts occur, shutdown takes place automatically. This limit would normally be\nset at the number which can be output in any one test cycle so that there is not a steady\naccumulation of results. If the deviation on a channel does not change, it does not repeat\nprintout; thereby, the output capacity is preserved.\nThe paper-tape output provides a record of the exceedances of the inner limits in a\nform which can subsequently be fed to a computer for further analysis.\nThe third form of output is via the visual display which can give rapid access to any\nof the monitored variables at a request through a keyboard input message. Up to two\nvariables may be displayed concurrently against a time axis; and a data table giving the\ncurrent measured values and the expected values of the inner and outer limits may accompany them. It may also be used for the display of logged information if a user program is\nwritten to interface with the display servicing software.\nData Logger\nMultiplexing configuration.- In order to achieve consistent measurements from\nstrain gauges attached to specimens operating in unfavourable conditions, it is necessary\nto avoid pressure-type electrical contacts within the normal bridge measuring system.\nThus small groups of gauges are collected into terminal units in which the bridge is\nformed using all soldered joints. Any initial imbalance of the bridge is catered for by\nextending the range of the recording apparatus. The terminal units are sited as near to\nthe group of gauges as possible to minimise the effects of leads in the arms of the bridge.\nUp to 16 of these terminal units are then collected via cables into a sampling unit where\nthey may be successively sampled by reed switches and the resulting signal amplified\nand fed to the recording console. Each terminal unit may accommodate up to 10 gauges\nwith a further two calibration points available. Similar units containing cold junction\ncompensators are used for collecting thermocouple signals.\nThe main console can accept up to 30 sampling boxes which are sampled through a\nhigh-speed solid-state multiplexer into a successive approximation analogue-to-digital\nconverter. This converts the measured signal into digital form with a resolution of\n12 bits (1 in 4096) when it is then transferred to the PDP10 computer through one of its\ntwo British standard digital data interfaces.\n56\n\nBritish standard interfaces.- Two of these units are attached to the memory buss\nof the PDP10 computer; each is capable of handling 8-bit words at transfer rates of\nmore than 100 kilohertz. One is used for transferring control information to the logger\nmain console while the other collects the resulting data; a useful feature of this arrangement is that the interfaces may be directly linked for fault diagnosis. An extension to the\ninterfaces, on the logger side of them, provides isolation of the logger from the computer\nprocessor through an opto-electronic link for the reasons stated previously.\nBasic operational facilities.- A total scan of all points on all the sampling boxes can\nbe made in 6 seconds. The sampling time on each point is about 30 milliseconds, which is\nachieved by sampling all the sampling boxes concurrently. This concurrent sampling\nallows ample time to filter off any electrical noise at frequencies equal to or higher than\nthe frequency of ac line voltage by a combination of analogue and numerical techniques.\nBy using this method, it is possible to have available in the computer a measure of this\nnoise level on each channel during sampling giving a useful guide to the effectiveness of\nany measurements. The diagnostic capability of the measuring system is further\nextended by having computer controlled grounding alternatives of the strain-gauge\nbridges. By this means it is possible to assess the electrical leakage between the gauge\nand specimen (a common cause of errors in elevated temperature strain measurement).\nIntegration of the logger with the computer gives a high degree of software control\nover its scanning ability from both conversational and preprogrammed input. By using\nthe latter facility, logging can be made synchronous with the process control and loading\nfunctions. Input may be in either logger-channel-number format or gauge-code format.\nVarious types of output are available, their extent only being limited by the ingenuity\nof the programmer and the spare core store. Conversational type input normally results\nin a processed output in engineering terms, rather than machine code. Further processing and analysis of results is possible when the machine is dedicated to this task, that is,\nwhen fatigue cycling is not functioning. Alternatively, the raw data may be output on any\nof the output media to be subsequently processed on another computer.\nOperation for Testing\nStartup and shutdown.- The requirements of both startup and shutdown necessitate\nthat the computer controlled plant be partitioned into blocks that can be independently\nstarted and stopped. Whereas the former state will be initiated by a plant engineer when\nhe considers that the correct conditions have been satisfied, the latter action will normally\nbe taken automatically by the computer or plant hardware. To satisfy these demands,\neach section of the controlled plant is coupled to its appropriate computer and the monitoring computer by an interlock loop which operates as shown by the following example.\n\n57\n\nConsidering one of the external air circuits and assuming that the appropriate background conditioning plant is running and that the K70 and PDP10 computers are operating\nand loaded with their correct programs, the startup sequence commences with the plant\nengineer pushing a button to start the air-circulating fan. If the associated background\nplant is ready, a request will be sent to the PDP10 for permission to start. When the\ncomputer has checked to see if this is a legitimate request, it will start upper limit checking and also relay the request on to the K70 computer. The K70 computer, in turn, will\ncheck for legitimacy and initiate control action at the same time as sending a signal to the\nplant confirming the startup request. The fan should then start; this action will consolidate the engineer\'s request to start and therefore latch the interlock loop. Thereafter, if\neither the plant or the two computers fail to activate the interlock loop, it will open and\nhence produce shutdown of the controlled plant on that loop.\nThe following sections of plant have interlock lines to the computers:\n(1) Each of the external circulating fans\n(2) Each of the internal circuit circulating blowers\n(3) One from the set of pressure blowers\n(4) One from the electrohydraulic loading system\n(5) One from the droop nose system\n(6) Each of the thirteen fuel systems.\nThis partitioning of the plant allows batched shutdowns where, under certain circumstances, only part of the plant is shut down if the outer limits of a monitored variable are\nexceeded.\nData input and cross-checking.- Before a test is started, the input data for control\nand monitoring functions have to be input to the computers. These input data are oriented\ntowards user formats and in engineering units; therefore, they have to be processed to\ncompressed computer formats after initial input. Following this it is necessary to check\nthat the data have been input correctly into the stores of the computers. To facilitate the\noperation, the same data are input to both the control computer and the monitoring computer and then cross-checked through the data link between them.
