At this point, the monitoring data in the control computer and the control data in the monitoring machine may\nbe discarded.\nAs the load data are input in a derived form, as discussed previously, an additional\nfunction of the programme is to calculate all the jack loads and print them out for comparison with the original data.\nFacilities for commissioning.- The configuration of two control computers was\nadopted to add flexibility for the commissioning stages of the project. Each control com58\n\nputer can be operated independently of the other and of the monitoring computer. Thus,\nfor example, parts of the plant or loading system can be commissioned independently.\nIt would not be desirable however to operate on the specimen without the monitoring computer in use, as the fail-safe properties of the complete system would be absent.\nIn general, the software has been designed to allow almost all the quantitative data\ndefining the conditions of a test cycle to be replaced very quickly. For example, the\nstandard three-term control algorithms available to control the plant may have their\nparameters changed, via the K70 console, by push buttons. Special provisions have also\nbeen made on the loading computer for a conversational type programme to control loads\non up to 10 jacks. With these facilities, it is considered that most of the special problems\nwhich may arise during commissioning can be accommodated.\nREFERENCES\n1. Mann, J. Y.; and McMillan, I., eds.: Aircraft Fatigue \xe2\x80\x94 Design, Operational, and\nEconomic Aspects. Programme of 5th ICAF Symposium (Melbourne, Australia),\nMay 1967.\n2. Ripley, E. L.: Structural Tests for the Supersonic Transport Aircraft. Paper presented at 11th Anglo-American Aeronautical Conference (London), Sept. 1969.\n3. Anon.: Tentative Airworthiness Standards for Supersonic Transports. Flight\nStandards Service, FAA, Nov. 1, 1965.\n4. Anon.: TSS Standards. Air Registration Board (England) or Secretariat General a\n1\'Aviation Civile (France), July 28, 1969.\n\n59\n\nSION FACTORS\n\nactor\n\nSI unit\n\nSupplementary Kt is stress-concentration factor.\n\n65\n\nJ\n\nQ\n_U\nZ\n\nOZ\nN^\n\nN\t\n\nQ^\n\nN\n\nu\n\nw\n\n^i\n\nY\nU\nQ\n\n9\n\nO\n\na^\n\nw\na\n\nJ\n2\n\n0\n\n0\n0\nO\n\nO\n\nO\n\n+\n\nM\n\nLA\n\na\n\nin\n\nO\n\nO\n\n(D r\n\n0\nO\n\nw\n\nl\t\n\n0\n\nf\n\nO\n\nW\n\nd\n0^\n\n0\nK\nW\ntD\n\nZ\n\nQ\nly\t\nw Q\n\na ^\nE\nw\n\nw\n\nw\n^\n\nLAJ\n\nu ^\n\nU\n\nN Y\nW U\nJ Q\n\n^\nr\n\n0\n\nN\n\nN\n\n0\n\nI\t\n\n+\n\nNO\n\n0 0\n\nr\n\nO\n\n_\n\nl0\n\nN\na\nL- r r\n0\n\n= u\n^F\t\n\nY\nU\n\nQ l7\nLi Z\n\nU\n\nW co\n\nQ:\nW\n\nw\n\nU\n\nU Y\nU\nW Q\n0\'\nJ\t\n\nLL\n\nA\n\n- )\n\nx\n\n0\n\nw Z\n\nF\n\nJ\n\np\n\n4 N\n0 p\nW\nW\n\nw\n\nu\n\nO\n\n(n\n\nU J\n\nQ\n\nJ l7\n\nQ\n\nY J w\nU li J\nU\n\t U\nw\n\n\xe2\x80\x94\t\n\n0\nF-\n\nc\n\nE\nd\na\nE\niv\n\n0\n\na\xc2\xb0\n\na>\nv\na>\nio\na^\nu\nu\n\nd\n\n9\nC\n^O\n\nE\n\nm\n\nm\n\nR:\n\nl iu. I\n\nY\n\nI\n\n.rr\n\np\t\n\nE\na^\n\nL_\n\n3\n\nL_\n\na^\na^\n\nC\n\nE\n\na\nE\na^\nX\nO\ntr]\n\n00\n\nO^\n\n67\n\n68\n\n\'.\n\n\t\n\nI\n\nO\t\n\nV\t\nO\t\n\nC\t\n\nZ\t\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\na\nN\n\nV\t\n\nE\t\n\nC\nO\t\n\nN\n\nD\nS\nC\n\nE_\n\nV\nCD\n\nd\nN\n\nE\n\nc\nU\n\nLL\n\na^\n\nO\n\n0\n\nE\nU\n\na\n\na^\nc\n0\n\na>\n\na a\n\nN\n\nD\nc\nN E\n_\t\n\nco\t\n\n69\n\n1.\n\nas\nN\nC\nN\nU\nQJ\n\nd\nN\n\nQJ\n\nd\n\nC\nry\n\na^\n\nm\nC\n.3\n\nc\na^\n\nU\n\nN\n7\nrn\nii\n\nfx,Li:lkp ^-A - M\nl;l I.\n\n72\n\nIII\t\n\noil\n\nIz\n\n.\n\nE\n0\n0\n\nU\n\n0\n\nO\n\nO\n\nCL\n\noa\n\n73\n\n74\n\nU\n\nC\nDJ\n\nd\n\nLL\n\nC\nd\n\nU\nd\nd\nQJ\nJ\nQ^\nL^\n\nN\n7\no^\nL^\n\n75\n\n76\n\n0\ne\n\ns\n\nP lF\n\'^ ddd\t\n\nit \'iii\t\n\n`\t\n\n11,^\t\n\n1p\n\n^ s t ^\t\n\nr f ,fit\n\n\'\'^1\t\n\n^\' Gr i,\n\nfi r\xe2\x80\xa2\t\n\n_\t\n\nr.\n\nr\n\n^\t\n\ni\n\n^..\n\n.Qt\n\nTHERMAL CYCLE\n\nTEMPERATURE I\t\n\nwl\t\n\n=^\n\n`"\n\na\no O\n\n^\n\ns\n\no\n\n<\n\n--------------\n\nT\n\nE\nQ1\nC\nO\nC\nO\n\nE\nc\n0\nC\n\nO\nu\n0\nE\n\na\n3\n\n_o\nLL\n\nN\n\n[^l\n\nPDP 8/1\n\xc2\xb1 5 VOLTS OR\n\nCOMPUTER\n\n0-10 VOLTS\nPROCESSOR INTERFACE\n\nJACK DRIVER INTERFACE\t\n\nJACK OUTPUT CARD Y\n\nI\t\n\nSUM\n10 BIT\nDATA REGISTE R\n\nGUST SHAPE\t\n\nD A CONVERTER\t\n\nMULTIPLY\n\nREGISTER\nGUST SCALE FACTOR\t\n15 BIT\n\nREGISTER\nI\n\nREGISTER\n\nOPTO-ELECTRONIC\nINTERFACE\n\nD A CONVERTER\t\n\nSTEADY LOAD\t\n\nSAMPLE\nIAND HOLD\n\nREGISTER\nCHANNEL\nADDRESS\t\n\n-^\t\nDECODER\t\n\nI\t\n\nI\n\nDECODE\t\n\nf\n\nFigure 36.- Loading computer system.\n\n91\n\n,\nPREMING PAGE BLANK NOT VTT,VM\n\n/) 7a a\n\nFATIGUE EXPERIENCE FROM TESTS CARRIED OUT WITH FORGED\nBEAM AND FRAME STRUCTURES IN THE DEVELOPMENT\nOF THE SAAB AIRCRAFT VIGGEN\nBy S. E. Larsson\nSaab-Scania Aktiebolag\nLinkoping, Sweden\nSUMMARY\nA part of the lower side of the main wing at the joint of the main spar with the\nfuselage frame was investigated. This wing beam area was simulated by a test specimen consisting of a spar boom of AZ 74 forging (7075 aluminum alloy modified with\n0.3 percent Ag) and a portion of a honeycomb sandwich panel attached to the boom\nflange with steel bolts. The cross section was reduced to half scale. However, the\nflange thickness, the panel height, and the bolt size were full scale.\nFurther, left and right portions of the fuselage frame intended to carry over the\nbending moment of the main wing were tested. Each of these "frame halves" consisted of a forward and a rear forging (7079 aluminum alloy, overaged) connected by\nan outer and inner skin (Alclad 7075) creating a box beam. These test specimens\nwere full scale and were constructed principally of ordinary aircraft components.\nThe test load spectrum was common to both types of specimens with regard to\npercentage levels. It consisted of maneuver and gust loads, touchdown loads, and\nloads due to ground roughness. A load history of 200 hours of flight with 15 000 load\ncycles was punched on a tape. The loads were randomized in groups according to the\nflight-by-flight principle. The highest positive load level was 90 percent of limit load\nand the largest negative load was -27 percent. A total of 20 load levels were used.\nBoth types of specimens were provided with strain gages and had a nominal stress of\nabout 300 MN/m 2 in some local areas.\n\nAs a result of the tests, steps were taken to reduce the risk of fatigue damage\nin aircraft. Thus stress levels were lowered, radii were increased, and demands on\nsurface finish were sharpened.\nINTRODUCTION\nIn designing aircraft structures against fatigue, a practice that has been used\nfor many years at Saab can be described as follows: Reasonably low stress levels\nare applied and structural elements and units are carefully shaped on the basis of\n93\n\nload-spectrum estimates, stress analysis, fatigue testing of small specimens, and fatigue\ncalculations. By these means costly fatigue tests on complete aircraft structures have\nbeen avoided.\nAfter thorough consideration, this practice was also applied to the Viggen aircraft.\nLater, however, conditions changed: An extended service life was desired, and the static\nfull-scale test showed a somewhat more severe stress distribution than had been\npredicted \xe2\x80\x94 in the spar boom flanges of the main wing, for example. These new conditions necessitated some sort of fatigue testing in a late development stage. In considering time, cost, the desire for easy repeatable testing, and the possibility of introducing\nmodifications, something intermediate to conventional full-scale testing and simple\n(small-specimen) testing was chosen.\nBefore proceeding with the description of current test specimens and testing, attention should be focused on. the fact that several basic fatigue studies have been done at Saab\nfor use in the design of aircraft structures. A study of fatigue strength of aluminum lugs\n(ref. 1), which was presented at the 4th ICAF Symposium in Munich in 1965, can be mentioned. Block-program fatigue of riveted joints and lugs has been studied in cooperation\nwith The Aeronautical Research Institute of Sweden (FFA). These test results, correlated\nwith experience from the literature, have been the basis for selecting values of E(n/N)\nfor different conditions in designing. The stress engineer looks forward to data based on\nrandomized load testing.\nSYMBOLS AND UNITS\nd\t\n\ndiameter, mm\n\nf\t\n\nlife-reduction scatter factor\n\nKIC\t\n\nplane-strain fracture toughness, N/mm3/2\n\nKt\tstress concentration factor\n1\t\n\nlength of crack, mm\n\n1*\t"total" length of crack (see fig. 20 for defining sketches), mm\nN\t\n\nnumber of cycles to failure at constant stress level\n\nn\t\n\nnumber of cycles applied at constant stress level\n\n94\n\nP\t\n\nload, kN\n\nr\t\n\nnotch radius, mm\n\nT\t\n\ntime, h; equivalent flying time, h\n\nTs\tservice life, h\nt\t\n\nthickness of material, mm\n\nv\t\n\ncrack propagation rate, dl*/dT, mm/h\n\nb\t\n\ndepth of crack, mm\n\n55\t\n\nelongation, percent\n\nP\t\n\nroot radius of milling step mark, mm\n\na\t\n\nnormal stress, MN/m2\n\nomax\t\n\nmaximum value of stress, MN/m2\n\nCrmin\t\n\nminimum value of stress, MN/m2\n\nou\tmaterial ultimate tensile strength, MN/m2\n00.2\t\n\n0.2-percent-offset yield strength, MN/m2\n\nSubscripts:\ny\t\n\nspanwise direction\n\nz\t\n\nvertical direction\n\n95\n\nConversion factors for the units used in this report are given in the following table:\nPhysical quantity\nLength\n\nSI unit\n(*)\nmeter (m)\n\nConversion factor\n(**)\n39.4\n\nForce\n\nnewton (N)\n\n0.225\n0.102\n\nlbf\nkp\n\nStress\n\nMN/m2\n\n0.145\n0.102\n\nksi\nkp/mm2\n\nCustomary unit\nin.\n\n* Prefixes to indicate multiples of units are as follows:\nPrefix\n\nMultiple\n\nmega (M)\nkilo (k)\nmilli (m)\n\n106\n103\n10-3\n\n** Multiply value given in SI units by conversion factor to obtain equivalent value in\ncustomary units.\nAIRCRAFT PARTS AND TEST SPECIMENS\nIn its present design the Saab Viggen is primarily an all-weather attack aircraft.\nIts configuration is unconventional, with one pair of front wings and one pair of main wings.\nFigure 1 shows the location of the parts that have been the object of the investigation\nreported: the wing beam and the fuselage frame in the main-wing region. A rear view of\nthe wing beam and fuselage frame assembly is shown in figure 2.\nA part of the lower side of the main wing at the joint of the main spar with the fuselage frame was investigated. This wing beam area, indicated in figure 2, was simulated\nby test specimens Al, A2, and A3. Section I-I shows the aircraft design in this part, a\nhoneycomb panel joined to the boom flange by steel bolts in two rows.\nLeft and right portions of the fuselage frame intended to carry over the bending\nmoment of the main wing were also tested. These "frame halves" are denoted test specimens BI and B2 in figure 2. Specimens B3 and B4, used in a complementary test going\non when this paper was prepared, are discussed in the appendix. Section II-II in figure 2\nshows the wing joint with the attachment of the two-pronged beam lugs to the forward and\nrear frame forging and to the intermediate part, e. The purpose of the latter component\nis to get some load diffusion in a compact design. Part e is not included in the test speci96\n\nmen but its attachment forces are taken into account. The upper area of the frame, made\nup of separate forgings, was not represented in the test.\nFigure 3 shows a test specimen of type A, consisting of a spar boom of forged AZ 74\n(designation according to Otto Fuchs, Metallwerke, Germany, and equal to 7075 aluminum\nalloy modified with 0.3 percent Ag) and a portion of a honeycomb sandwich panel attached\nto the boom flange with steel bolts in one row. The cross section was reduced to half\nscale. However, the flange thickness, the panel height, and the bolt size were full scale.\nThe first few bolt holes in the boom flange were thought to be the most critical points,\nbut the tests showed the flange notch to be of equal importance.\nThe bolted joint was provided with a sealing compound in the attachment of the panel\nto the boom flange. The bolts (noninterference) were treated with dry MoS 2 . From the\nbeginning the boom was anodized in a chromic acid process over its entire length, but\nlater on, highly stressed areas were modified. They were polished and chromated (in the\naircraft they are also protected by a primer). The primary boom lug for axial loading of\nthe test specimen and the transverse lugs for stabilizing it were not representative of the\naircraft structure. The limit load was 711 kN and the outer force system was\nnonredundant.\nGeometric differences between specimens Al, A2, and A3 will be referred to in the\nreporting of fatigue test results. The test specimen booms were taken from three separate beam forgings in almost correct positions. Their strength properties are shown in\nthe following table (y and z denote spanwise and vertical directions, respectively):\n\nSpecimen\n\n(o0.2)y\nMN/m2\n\n(uu)y\nMN/m 2\n\n(o0.2)z\nMN/m2\n\n(ou)z\nMN/m2\n\nAl\nA2\nA3\n\n496\n\n551\n\n427\n432\n427\n\n491\n507\n497\n\nThe test specimens of type B are shown in figure 4. Each specimen consists of a\nforward and a rear forging of 7079 aluminum alloy, overaged, connected by an outer and\nan inner skin (Alclad 7075) creating a box beam. These test specimens were made up in\nfull scale of essentially ordinary aircraft components.\nThe continuity of the outer skin is broken by a long opening in the joint area for the\ninsert of the wing beam lugs. This is shown in section I-I and view U-II of figure 4. The\ninner skin has openings in the same area for the purpose of load transmission by the linkage system used in testing.\n\n97\n\nThe skin was attached to the forgings mainly by countersunk aluminum screws\ndeveloped for blind attachment of thick skins to extrusions and forgings. The threaded\nscrew holes in the forgings were supposed to be critical points of the fatigue specimen.\nThe countersunk holes in the inside Alclad sheet seemed also to be critical. Test specimens B1 and B2 did not include the intermediate forging (e in fig. 2). However, at the\nattachments a and d the test frames were clamped together with ordinary bolts and special distance elements. The frame forgings were anodized in a chromic acid process.\nThe shear bolts in the principal lug joints (b and c) were mounted with sliced taper\nsleeves in bushings, which were prepared with bonded dry MoS2.\nFor the right "frame half" in figure 4, forces are indicated by arrows in proper\nscale. The applied jack force had a limit load value of 313 kN. The force system was\nchosen so that joint loads correct in value and direction would be simulated at b and c,\nand so that the bending moment would be representative in highly stressed parts of the\nframe assembly.\nThe basic material properties of the forgings of B1 and B2 have not yet been determined. General material properties for 7079, overaged, can be found in the section entitled "Materials and Small-Specimen Testing."\nLOAD SPECTRUM AND TEST PERFORMANCE\nThe load spectrum used in testing is shown in figure 5. This total spectrum, which\nwas used for both type A and type B specimens, includes maneuver and gust loads, touchdown loads, and loads due to ground roughness. Different kinds of loads were originally\npresented in separate load spectra, which made up the basis for computer randomization\nof loads in groups according to the flight-by-flight principle. Both the severeness level\nof the flights and the sequence of the individual loads of the same kind were randomized.\nAn example of load sequences in the randomized flight-by-flight program is shown\nin figure 6. A load history of 200 hours of flight with 15 000 load cycles was punched on\na tape for the purpose of unlimited repetitions. The highest positive load level was\n90 percent of limit load and the largest negative load was -27 percent. A total of 20 load\nlevels were used.\nA diagram of the test equipment is shown in figure 7. This system was based on a\nmodified unit for numerically controlled milling machines, a hydraulic pump with variable\nflow governed by the stroke, hydraulic jacks with low-friction seals of Teflon, and pressure transmitters for controlling the oil pressure in the jacks. The mean value of the\nfrequency was 0.5 cps.\nThe arrangement of test specimens is shown in figure 8. The two test groups A\nand B were loaded by separate jacks that were only hydraulically connected. They could\n98\n\nwork either simultaneously or separately. The somewhat odd link and lever system at the\nleft portion of the frames in figure 8 was made up in order to get a proper redistribution\nof the principal outer reaction force in this part.\nThe test specimens were provided with strain gages for calibration and monitoring\nof loads. Each test started with loading to 90 percent of limit load. This load level will\nalso be applied once during the delivery control flight of every aircraft.\nCrack searches with a fluorescent penetrant ( Ardrox P1) and crack-length studies\nwere performed especially on the A specimens while loaded to 40 percent of limit load.\nA search for new cracks was made every 600 h. Visual observations of crack length\nwere made more frequently but irregularly.\nTEST RESULTS FROM SPECIMEN A (WING BEAM)\nTable I presents a summary of test results from specimens A. The strain gages\n(01, 02, and 03) were applied to specimens Al, A2, and A3 in the same areas. They are,\nhowever, shown only on A2 in figure 10. From the location of the strain gages and the\nvalues in table I(a) the nominal stress at the flange notch and bolt hole 1 is estimated to\nhave been 280 to 300 MN/m 2 at limit load, depending somewhat on definition.\nTable I(b) shows equivalent flying hours (hours read on the punched tape) for observations of the state of cracks. Cracks 11 and 12 occurred in specimen Al, cracks 21, 22,\nand 23 in A2, and cracks 31 and 32 in A3.\nIt can be seen in table I(b) that cracks appeared in specimen Al after only 3400 h.\nThese cracks, no. 11, are shown in figure 9. One crack started where a radius r = 3 mm\ninteracted with the principal notch radius r = 10 mm. Another crack started from the\nopposite side in a rough edge of the notch. Many very small cracks were also found in\nthe anodized surface of the flange notch area.\nThe specimen in this original shape was not quite representative of the aircraft\nstructure, and it became less representative because the specimen was modified to\nremove the cracked material. However, the test was continued in order to study the area\nwith bolt holes in the boom flange \xe2\x80\x94 that area which originally had been thought to be the\nmost critical. For this case the cracked material was milled off, and the shape was modified to that marked with the dashed lines. Besides cracks in areas not considered significant, no new damage was found until crack 12 appeared in bolt hole 1 at about 21 000 h.\nThe test was finished at 24 100 equivalent flight hours without a limiting failure.\nTest specimens A2 and A3 were like the modified form of Al. They were polished\nand chromated in highly stressed boom portions.\n\n99\n\nFigure 10 shows specimen A2 in a late stage with the cracks fully developed.\nCrack 21 was found after 8400 h, when it had a length of 1 = 1 mm. Its slow propagation\nwas studied and it was under control until the test was ended as a result of bolt failure in\nhole 1 at 15 200 h. The crack propagation history can be followed in figure 20 (which\nincludes sketches defining 1 and 6). Figure 11 shows details of the cracked\nspecimen A2.\nFigure 12 shows fully developed cracks in specimen A3. The nature of crack 31\nwas about the same as that of crack 21 in figure 10. Crack 31 was found at 7700 h, when\nit had a length of 1 ^ 5 mm. It propagated somewhat more rapidly than crack 21.\nThe most interesting crack in specimen A3 was the crack designated 32. This\ncrack was seen for the first time at 10 500 h (not seen at crack search 600 h earlier).\nWhen discovered it had a visible length of about 10 mm (about 12 mm was hidden under\nthe panel). From this stage it propagated rapidly (a rate of about 0.02 mm/h) and then\nmore slowly. The same tendency toward crack development from bolt hole 1 can be seen\nin figure 10. The new results, however, are the rapid propagation of crack 32 and the\ncomplicated interaction with crack 31.\nFigure 13 shows the features of the locally developed fatigue fracture surfaces of\nthe cracked area in specimen A3. The slightly concave boom-side surface of crack 32\nis thought to be the result of "Stage I" crack growth according to reference 2. The 450\ndirection is pronounced, and no unusual material properties or defects have been found.\nThe surfaces were rubbed and could not give adequate information. At the stage of figure 13, crack 32 shows a tendency to change over to a 90 0 fatigue fracture. Figure 13\nalso shows that crack 32 must have been present when crack 31 passed through its area.\nThe less interesting surfaces are not numbered.\nThe fatigue test of A3 was finished at 11 700 h by a boom fracture due to fatigue\ncracking from the root of a transverse lug, not significant for the aircraft structure. No\ndamage to the panel could be found in the three specimens tested.\nTEST RESULTS FROM SPECIMEN B (FUSELAGE FRAME)\nTable II presents a summary of test results from specimens B. Strain gages F-01\nand F-02 were located on the forward frame and strain gages R-01 to R-04 were located\non the rear frame. (See fig. 17 and table II(a).) Table H(a) shows frame stresses of\napproximately 260 to 320 MN/m 2 at limit load.\nTable II(b) shows equivalent flying hours for occurrence of cracks and ultimate failure. The letters S, F, and R in the crack designations refer to sheet, forward forging,\nand rear forging, respectively. Cracks 11 to 14 occurred in specimen 131, and cracks 21\nto 23 occurred in specimen B2.\n100\n\nFrom table II(b) it can be seen that cracks appeared at screw holes in the inner\nsheet of the frame assembly after 4300 equivalent flying hours. Their propagation was\nobserved, and in some cases they were stopped by the use of a blind rivet with d = 4.8 mm\nor plug with d = 5 mm (sheet thickness t = 3 mm).\nUltimate failure of specimen B 1 occurred at 5300 h by fracture from an unexpected\nfatigue crack in web O of the rear forging, shown in figure 14. No crack search with\nfluorescent penetrant had been done in this area before failure. Afterward, however, four\nother cracks of about the same kind were indicated in three forgings of specimens B1 and\nB2. The B2 test was also ended. An inspection made clear that the surface finish of the\nweb areas of the milled frame forgings was worse than specified.\nFigure 14 shows test specimen Bl with fatigue cracks and the location of failure\nindicated. Figure 15 shows the fractured area of specimen B l with a sketch of the fatigue\nfracture surface, which represented -390 mm 2 , or ^10 percent of the whole area of the\nsection. Figure 16 shows the surface shape of the fatigue crack that caused failure in Bl.\nIt is representative of a number of web areas in both Bl and B2. The root radius p of\nthe milling step marks was about 0.5 mm.\nFigure 17 shows specimen B2 with the location of cracks and strain gages indicated.\nFigure 18 shows the area with cracks in the inner sheet of the frame assembly. This area\nis not very representative of the aircraft because of the large unreinforced openings.\nWhen the fatigue test was finished, specimen B2 was provided with complementary\nstrain gages for comparison with a simultaneous study of stress levels in a loaded complete fuselage. It was found that the fatigue test specimens had been loaded to stress\nlevels about 20 percent too high in critical areas. The reasons were, in the first place,\nunavoidable differences between specimen and fuselage due to "skin load diffusion conditions," and in the second place, some lack of effectiveness of the frame forgings due to\nbad stabilization of the cross section in bending. A fourth to a half of the 20 percent difference was recovered in a modified set of specimens, B3 and B4, with better stabilization provided by two ordinary bulkheads, reinforcement of the inner skin, and smaller\nopenings for the linkage system. These specimens are discussed in the appendix.\nDISCUSSION\nMaterials and Small-Specimen Testing\nA decision was made to change from the earlier standard aluminum alloy (the overaged 7079 with Saab-Scania designation 3624-5) to AZ 74 (Saab-Scania 3633-5) as material\nfor some primary aircraft forgings. The reason was the better resistance to stress corrosion cracking of the latter alloy. This change was made gradually, and therefore both\n\n101\n\nalloys were used in this investigation. When forgings of AZ 74 were not available for\ntest specimens, the 7079 (overaged) was used.\nThe composition of the alloys and the aging conditions prescribed by Saab-Scania\nstandard specifications are as follows:\nAlloy\n\nZn\n\nMg\n\nCu\n\nAg\n\nAZ 74\n\n6.0\n\n2.5\n\n0.9\n\n0.3\n\n7079 (overaged)\n\n4.3\n\n3.3\n\n0.6\n\nAging\n\nI\t\n\n1200 C for 12 to 24 h and 170 0 C for 4 to 7 h\n1600 C for 8 h\n\nSome material properties from Saab-Scania specifications and mean values from\ntests of specimens from wing beam forgings are shown in the following table (values\nrefer to large-size forgings):\nLongitudinal direction\nAllo y\n\nTransverse direction\n\nQ\nQ\nu\' b 5\' KIC\'\nu\' 6 5\' KIC\'\n0.2\'\nMN/m 2 MN/m 2 0/0 N/mm 3/2 MN/m2 MN/m 2 \xc2\xb0Io N/mm3/2\n\na0.2\'\n\nQ\n\n390\n\n470\n\n440\n\n510\n\n12\n\n430\n\n500\n510\n\n11\n\n450\n\n410\n\n490\n\n10\n\n480\n\n3\n\n440\n\n500\n\n10\n\nPreliminary\nspecification\n\n4\n\n410\n\n6\n\n440\n\n380\n\n7\n\nAZ 74\n\n7079\n(overaged)\n\n1090\n\n1010\n\nSource of\nvalues\n\n850\n\nTest series\n(mean values)\nSpecification,\nt `_ 150 mm\n\n780\n\nTest series\n(mean values)\n\nFrom the fatigue data in figure 19, which are for constant-amplitude tests, it can\nbe seen that AZ 74 has about 10 percent higher fatigue strength than 7079 (overaged).\nThese tests were carried out with small round specimens with diameter d = 8.5 mm\nand notch radius r = 0.65 mm.\nFatigue tests were also carried out with small specimens of various shapes in\norder to study other problems in connection with the main investigation. The aluminum\nblind-screw element used in specimens B (fuselage frame) was tested at constant amplitude in jointlike test pieces. Its fatigue behavior was good at stresses near limit stress\nbut the behavior for long lives should be studied further (with regard to fretting, for\nexample).\n102\n\nThe "hard point effect" at bolt hole 1 in specimens A (wing beam) was simulated in\na test series. A simple program of three-level tests was carried out on plain specimens\n"reinforced" by straps fastened to them with wing-panel attachment bolts. The intent was\nto find the effect of bolt fit in the boom flanges and ballizing of flange holes on the fatigue\nlife. Ballizing was better than "easy" interference fit alone, which was better than the\noriginal small-clearance fit. However, differences were small and no change of design\nprinciple was made.\nCrack Propagation and Fractures\nPropagation of the cracks in the AZ 74 boom flanges of specimens A 2 and A3\n(cracks 21 and 31) is shown in figure 20. Values of 1 * (total visible crack length) were\nplotted against the number of equivalent flying hours T. The dashed lines make up a\nmean curve, visually estimated. This curve indicates that crack propagation, on the average, might be slow between T = 7000 h and T = 11 000 h. The mean crack propagation\nrate is v l = 0.0025 mm/h in this time interval. (Environmental conditions, not considered in the tests, must also be accounted for when estimating the probable damage tolerance of the aircraft structure.)\nThe crack in specimen A 3 that caused the ultimate failure of the boom section at a\nnonrepresentative transverse lug had a fatigue-cracked area of =650 mm 2 , or --25 percent\nof the total boom cross section. The residual strength of this section, when it failed ultimately at 83.5 percent of limit load, and that of the cracked area in specimen B1, when it\nfractured at 90.1 percent of limit load, have been controlled with respect to fracture\ntoughness behavior. Current combinations of stress levels, geometry, and K IC values\n(from the table of material properties presented previously) could in both cases explain\nactual failures.\nSurface Conditions and Damage\nSome problems with surface roughness and anodizing as detrimental factors in\nfatigue of wing beam specimen Al were reported. Fretting was found in the boom flange\nof specimens A in bolt holes and on the surface that makes contact with the panel. Mainly,\nhowever, the fatigue quality of the bolt-hole area of the flange was as good as wanted. The\ndry film lubricant and the sealing compound have certainly been positive factors.\nThe main surface problem with the frame specimens B 1 and B2 was the milling step\nmarks shown in figure 16. In highly stressed areas, these milling marks and other surface imperfections on parts of the aircraft were eliminated by surface-improving procedures followed by adequate corrosion protection.\n\n103\n\nThe test of specimen Al and other recent tests indicated that serious fatigue problems are sometimes associated with anodizing on aluminum parts. Thorough studies of\nthese problems are being made.\nCalculation Study\nA recently developed computer method for fatigue calculations based on the linear\ncumulative damage theory was tested on specimens A and B and their fatigue-test results.\nThe diagram in figure 21 shows calculated S-N curves for various K t values based on\nthe constant-amplitude fatigue data from figure 19, slightly reduced. The curves in figure 21 are for the specimen A material, AZ 74, the test load spectrum, and E(n/N) = 1.\nThe nominal stress at limit load is plotted against calculated equivalent flying hours. The\nfatigue test result, Q = 290 MN/m 2 and T = 9000 h, is plotted and found to correspond\nto Kt = 2.7. (The chosen time, 9000 h, corresponds to a 5-mm fatigue crack in the flange\nnotch, according to the mean curve in figure 20. This time, however, is also supposed to\nbe representative for the bolt-hole cracks.)\nThe value Kt = 2.7 is larger than expected for the flange notch, but less than\nexpected for the first and second bolt holes. This calculated result and the corresponding\nresult for specimen B (overaged 7079 and rougher surface in the web case) are shown in\nthe following table:\n\nSpecimen\n\nStress at\nlimit load,\na, MN/m2\n\nA\n\n290\n\n9000\n\n2.7\n\nFlange notch and bolt holes\n\n280\n\nz5000\n\n2.4\n\nWeb Ol\n\n310\n\n>5000\n\n<2.4\n\nT, hr\n\nKt\n\nLocation of crack\n\nB\nForging inner boom\n\nIt should be noted that in the case of residual tensile stresses from heat treatment\nand material removal by machining, the calculation result K t = 2.4 for the frame forging\nweb will be changed. The fatigue failure corresponds to Kt = 2.0 if a residual tensile\nstress of 50 MN/mm 2 is assumed. Thus, residual tensile stresses in forgings may play\na role not only in stress corrosion damage but also in fatigue life.\nStress Concentrations\nProblems caused by interacting stress concentrations frequently occur in connection\nwith forging design. Interacting notch radii in critical areas have been observed in both\nspecimens A and B.\n104\n\nIn order to get a better collection of data as a basis for design and for making up\nsome estimation rules, fatigue testing has been performed and is planned to progress with\nspecimens of various shapes. Figure 22 shows two typical configurations, representing\nthe. problem of a hole in a radius (bolt hole in a part with variable cross section) and the\nproblem of simultaneous area variation in perpendicular planes.\nReduction Factor on Life\nWhen testing a small number of safe-life aircraft components with proper load history, a life-reduction scatter factor of f = 4 is often applied to the mean test life. If\nspecimen A, the wing-beam part of this investigation, is studied in this way, an overall\nservice life under current test conditions can be determined. Specimen Al, which was\nnot representative in the flange notch area, is neglected in spite of its information about\nfatigue life of the bolt-hole flange area. The mean value obtained from specimens A2 and\nA3 is\nT = 2 (15 200 + 11 700) = 13 450 h\n(In fact, the life of A3 is based on a secondary-type failure.) Reduction with a factor\nf = 4 gives an overall service life of\nT s = 4(13 450) = 3360 h\nThe crack propagation rate is larger outdoors than indoors, as was observed by\nSchijve and De Rijk in tests on sheet specimens of 7075-T6 (ref. 3). This fact could be\naccounted for by using a higher reduction factor on the average time during which visible\ncracks exist; for example, f = 6 on the time after T = 7000 h (fig. 20) :\nTs = 4(7000) + 6(13 450 - 7000)\nT s = 1750 + 1075 = 2825 h\nApplication of test results for wing-beam specimens of type A to the real wing-beam\nstructure of aircraft must take into consideration differences in geometry, size, and so\nforth. The real aircraft structure has greater three-dimensional complexity than the\nspecimens. Therefore stress levels can differ and new points may be critical. In proper\ndesign, however, constraints reduce secondary deformations, make section areas more\neffective, and usually lower the stresses.\n105\n\nThe half-scale cross section tested had full-scale flange thickness, panel height,\nand bolt diameter. However, the two rows of bolts actually used for panel attachment\nwere simulated with one row only, which must be conservative according to flange bending\nbehavior. The testing of specimens B 1 and B 2 happened to be more conservative than was\noriginally intended (higher stresses). Consequently the fatigue life became short and further study of it by use of such things as reduction factors is without meaning.\nC ONC LUSIONS\nThe test method has turned out rather well and can be looked upon as an inexpensive\nand flexible alternative to conventional full-scale fatigue testing, for the purpose of structural development. However, specimens must be very carefully designed in order to represent actual load distribution on aircraft parts.\nThe fluorescent penetrant effectively indicated cracks at 40 percent of limit load,\nthe inspection load used in this test.\nThe test results for type A (wing beam) specimens indicate an overall service life\nof 3360 hours if a scatter factor of 4 is applied on the mean total test life of two specimens. Many other factors, such as geometry, scale factor, and environment, could be\ntaken into consideration.\nThe specimens of type B (fuselage frame) sustained a shorter total test life than the\nwing beam specimens. However, comparison with strain measurements on a complete\nfuselage showed the stress levels of the frame specimens to be too high. Further, the\nsurface finish of the milled frame forgings happened to be worse than what is normally\npermitted. A new test with slightly modified specimens and load levels is going on with\nanother two frame halves.\nAttention has been focused on the problems of anodizing, surface roughness, interacting stress concentrations, and fretting.\nAs a result of the tests, steps were taken to reduce the risk of fatigue damage in\naircraft. Thus, stress levels were lowered, radii were increased, and demands on surface finish were sharpened.\n\n106\n\nAPPENDIX\nWORK IN PROGRESS\nA complementary fatigue test with "frame half" specimens B3 and B4, indicated in\nfigure 2, is in progress as this paper is being prepared. These specimens also have\nforgings of 7079 (overaged). They are, relative to B1 and B2, constructed with better\nstabilization of the frame parts by two ordinary bulkheads, with reinforcement of the inner\nskin, and smaller openings for the linkage system. They are also polished in critical\nforging areas.\nThe test load spectrum has been slightly changed according to new conditions. Further, critical stresses are lowered 5 to 10 percent by a more favorable stress distribution in the modified specimen and 12 percent by a decrease of the jack load over the entire\nspectrum. Consequently, the total lowering is =20 percent. All these changes have been\nmade in order to get a better load distribution with more correct stress levels for the\nproper simulation of aircraft structural fatigue conditions.\n\n107\n\nACKNOWLEDGMENTS\nThe author is indebted to Saab-Scania Aktiebolag for permission to prepare and\npublish this paper. Many persons involved in the reported investigations have kindly\nassisted with basic data for this paper. Invaluable assistance with the preparation of the\nmanuscript has been given by Mr. E. Persson, senior stress engineer, fatigue branch,\nSaab-Scania.\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Larsson, S. T, h\n\n12\n\nFigure 20.- Crack propagation at flange notch in specimens A2 and A3.\n\n11.\n\n16 x 103\n\n0\n\n0\n\n10-3\n\n-11-\n\n320\n\n300\n\n280\n\nNominal stress\nat limit load,\n260\n\nC^ MN/m2\n\n240\n\n220\n\n200\n\nFigure 21.- Results of a cumulative damage calculation for specimen A material, AZ 74.\n\nFigure 22.- Examples of interacting stress concentrations.\n\n126\n\nTHE BOEING 747 FATIGUE INTEGRITY PROGRAM\nBy Max M. Spencer\nThe Boeing Company\nEverett, Washington, U.S.A.\n\nCq\n\nINTRODUCTION\nThe Boeing 747 is designed and certified as a fail-safe airplane. (See ref. 1.)\nThe fatigue integrity program was established to insure economic operations and to\nprovide foundation data for inspection and maintenance. Significant features of the\n747 fatigue integrity program are\n1. Fatigue analyses which are continually updated to reflect design changes,\nfatigue test results, and static and flight load survey measurements\n2. Material selection and detail design by using initial fatigue analyses, service experience, and testing\n3. Fatigue testing to check detail design quality and to verify the analyses,\nculminated by the test of a structurally complete airframe\nThese three features are interrelated during all program phases of conception, design,\ndesign check, production, and operation.\nDesired fatigue reliability levels are established by using data from statistical\nstudies on military as well as commercial fleets. Appropriate fatigue reliability factors (scatter factors) are considered in the fatigue life evaluations. Essential fatigue\nanalysis factors are fatigue loading environment, load-stress relationships, fatigue\nperformance data (S-N curves), and cumulative damage theory.\nThe 747 fatigue loading environments were established by using NASA, military,\nand Boeing data, in conjunction with aircraft aerodynamics and loads data, customer\nroute structure analyses, and flight load surveys. Because of the airplane size and\nthe complex landing-gear system, the 747 ground-handling and landing load spectra\nreceived special attention.\nFatigue stress analyses were performed with the aid of experimental as well as\nanalytical procedures. Extensive application was made of the stress severity factor,\ndeveloped at Boeing, for evaluating peak stresses in complex joints.\nA frame of reference was established by families of structural fatigue performance curves (S-N curves) encompassing the range of materials and fatigue qualities\nanticipated for the 747 airplane design. Modifications to the endurance limit and the\nlow-stress region of the curves were made by using service experience and structural\n127\n\ncomponent and full-scale fatigue tests. These modifications were necessary to account\nfor the inherent shortcoming of Miner\'s method for predicting fatigue life for spectrumloaded structures by using constant-amplitude generated S-N curves.\nEach family of fatigue performance curves was assigned a fatigue quality identified\nby a fatigue performance index (FPI). The FPI of structural details was estimated by a\nsemiempirical relationship.\nThe most significant factors in attaining satisfactory fatigue quality are detail design\nand material selection. From previous airplane experience and initial fatigue analyses,\nmaterial was selected which satisfied the static, fatigue, and fail-safe requirements.\nCareful consideration to detail design with respect to fatigue and fail safety was given to\nall primary structural components.\nAll major details on the airplane were analyzed by using the technique outlined\nabove. These analyses were verified by extensive full-scale and component tests.\nFatigue developmental and verification tests conducted specifically for the 747 airplane\nincluded\nQuonset-hut tests\nWing, body, and nose landing-gear testz\nOutboard-flap functional and fatigue tests\nFull-scale horizontal-tail tests\nFuselage crown stringer splice tests\nSide-of-body rib-component tests\nNumerous small-scale specimen tests concerning \xe2\x80\x93\nShot peening\nFastener development\nCold working\nWing\xe2\x80\x94side-of-body joint configuration\nWindow forging configurations\nIn addition, a full-scale airplane fatigue test is in progress. This test utilizes a\nflight-by-flight load spectrum including pressure cycles applied in a manner to represent\nthe fatigue loading during a typical flight. The test objectives are to\n1. Locate any fatigue-critical areas early in production\n2. Provide test data for analytical service-life prediction\n\n128\n\n3. Help develop inspection and maintenance procedures\n4. Evaluate fail-safe characteristics of major structural components and\nassemblies\nThe 747 fatigue integrity program provides a high degree of confidence in the ability\nof the structure to withstand service loads. Safe and economic operation is insured by\nthe continual updating of analyses to reflect design changes and fatigue test results.\nSYMBOLS\nD\t\n\ndrag load\n\nd\t\n\ndiameter, inches\n\nFMEAN mean stress\ng\t\n\nacceleration due to gravity\n\nKt\t\n\nstress concentration factor\n\nKt,b\n\nbearing stress concentration factor\n\nKt I g\n\ngross-area stress concentration factor\n\nOP\n\nload transferred\n\nP - OP\n\nbypass load\n\nS\n\nside load\n\nT\n\ntorque\n\nt\n\nthickness, inches\n\nV\n\nvertical load\n\nw\n\nwidth, inches\n\nC1\n\nhole condition factor\n129\n\n0\t\n\nhole filling factor\n\n77\t\n\nsemispan station measured from root (see fig. 6)\n\n6\t\n\nbearing distribution factor\n\na\t\n\nstress\nABBREVIATIONS\nairplane\n\nAIRP, A/P\nBS\n\nbody station\n\nt\n\ncenter line\n\nDMF\n\ndynamic magnification factor\n\nFLT\n\nf light\n\nFPI\n\nfatigue performance index\n\nFRF\n\nfatigue reliability factor\n\nFWD\n\nforward\n\nGAG\n\nground air ground\n\nGRND\n\nground\n\nIHL\n\nintermittent high loads\n\nINBD\n\ninboard\n\nLE\n\nleading edge\n\nMED\n\nmedium\n\nML\n\nmarker loads\n\n130\n\nOUTBD\t\n\noutboard\n\nSL\t\n\nsea level\n\nSSF\t\n\nstress severity factor\n\nTE\t\n\ntrailing edge\n\nW/O\t\n\nwithout\n\nFS\t\n\nforward spar\n\nSTA\t\n\nstation\n\nUNSYM\t\n\nunsymmetrical\nAPPROACH\n\nThe service-life objective of current Boeing commercial airplanes is 20 years. In\npursuing this objective on the 747, a program consisting of analysis, material selection\nand detail design, and testing has been followed. There is an obvious overlap and interdependence of these elements in design, development, and maintenance of aircraft. Delineation of specific subelements, such as analysis or testing, is done simply to affirm that\nmany techniques may be used in designing for fatigue and to emphasize that several techniques have been applied in parallel as a check-and-balance approach on the 747.\nAnalysis\nEssential fatigue analysis factors include fatigue loading environment, load-stress\nrelationships, fatigue performance data (S-N curves), and a cumulative damage theory.\nIn defining expected aircraft fatigue loading, both usage (flight profiles) and environment\n(gust, maneuver, etc.) are required (table 1). Fatigue loadings were established by using\nmilitary, NASA, and Boeing data for taxi, gust, maneuver, landing, and ground-handling\nenvironments. A peak-to-peak definition of the ground-air-ground cycle was used.\nExtensive route structure analysis of expected 747-100 operation resulted in the\nflight length distribution illustrated in figure 1 and a 20-year usage goal of 60 000 hours\nfor each airplane. To encompass the wide range of flight lengths from this study, the\nflight profiles shown in figure 2 were developed. The average flight length of the three\nsimulated commercial flights is 3 hours, the average expected over a 20-year service\n131\n\nlife. Four percent of the total 60 000 hours usage is expected to be consumed in training\nand is represented for analysis by 600 4-hour, zero-payload flights, also shown in\nfigure 2.\n\nFuel consumption data are applied to all flight profiles to determine gross-weight\nvariation within each flight. Each flight is subsequently divided into appropriate segments\nas shown in figure 3. Climb and descent portions of the flight are actually covered by\nnumerous altitude segments to account for the very large variation in gust environment\nstatistics with altitude. Flight mean loads, dynamic response to gust, and response to\nmaneuver are determined from aeroelastic analysis for each flight segment.\nAnalytical techniques include engineering theory and finite-element methods; experimental techniques include photostress and strain gages. These analytical and experimental techniques are used to convert external airplane loads into the stresses required\nfor fatigue analysis: 1g stress, stress response to gust, and stress response to maneuver. In addition to conventional stress analysis, the stress-severity-factor technique is\nused (ref. 2). This technique was developed primarily to evaluate load and stress distributions in multifastened joints. It is also used to locate fatigue-critical locations, establish fatigue performance estimates, and evaluate possible design improvements. The\nstress severity factor includes the effects of geometric stress concentration factor Kt,\nfastener load distribution, type of fastener, bearing stress distribution, hole surface condition, and residual stresses. The equation for the stress severity factor is\nSSF = \'peak\n\'ref\n1\n\nR\n\n\'ref [load transfer + cbypass]01\n\nP - OP\t\na\nP\t\n_ 1\n^td\t Kt,bB + tw K t g]a\n\'ref\n\nBecause of its ease of application and relatively good agreement in analyzing airplane structure (ref. 3), Miner\'s theory of cumulative damage is used. Two shortcomings of Miner\'s method have been observed in laboratory testing. One is the inability to\naccount for damage from stress amplitudes below the constant-amplitude endurance limit:\nthe other is the so-called sequence effect where in block-type loading, a substantial difference in life has been observed in some tests in which the order of application of high\nand low load blocks has been varied. The second shortcoming is somewhat academic for\n132\n\nevaluating flight structure since relatively few parts, if any, are subjected to two-step\nhigh-low or low-high block loads in service. The sequence effect is of course very real\nin simulated flight testing and is the primary reason that flight-by-flight testing is\npreferred.\nTo correct Miner\'s method to account for damage below the constant-amplitude\nendurance limit, two techniques are available. One is simply to translate (reduce) the\nS-N curve linearly on life at each alternating stress level (ref. 4). The other is to\nreshape (change the slope of) the S-N curve. The latter course has been followed in\nthis work and is illustrated in figure 4. The level to which the S-N curves have been\nreduced at infinite life is the nonpropagating crack threshold stress. The shape and\nlocation of the upper portion of the S-N curve are essentially unaltered, which retains\nthe advantage of fatigue quality determination from constant-amplitude testing. The\nresulting curves, which are then termed fatigue performance curves, are mathematically\ndefined with a Stuessi type equation (ref. 5) and verified with fleet analysis and flight-byflight spectrum tests.\nIn the early stages of airplane configuration development (prior to built-up structure tests), the fatigue quality of a given design may not be known with high confidence.\nTo preclude having to rerun fatigue analysis whenever a slight change in detail geometry\nis made, as well as to provide a frame of reference for fleet analysis, a family of fatigue\nperformance curves was developed for each of the materials used on the 747. The reference curve for each was that for basic structure (which is defined as skin-stringer\nconstruction having no significant load transfer between skin and stringer). The basicstructure curve was based on built-up structure fatigue performance data which were\navailable for the material and type of construction in question. It should be noted that\nsimple coupon (Kt) data are not used to estimate life of aircraft structure directly (refs. 6\nto 9). With the basic-structure curve as a reference, the remainder of the family of\nfatigue performance curves for each material was developed by using the variation of\nlife with quality from past tests (refs. 10, 11, and 12).\nThe term used to identify fatigue quality is the fatigue performance index (FPI), and\neach of the many curves is identified with a fraction corresponding to the familiar 1/Kt\nform. (Basic structure, for example, was initially identified as FPI = 1/2.5.) An example of curves used for analysis of a given detail is shown in figure 5. Fatigue analyses\nconducted in this manner are essentially parametric studies of life as a function of quality. A sufficient number of analyses are conducted to bracket the expected fatigue quality.\nCurves developed in this way, for fatigue performance indices of 0 to 1, and for each\nmaterial, were mathematically defined and programed for computerized fatigue analysis.\nTechniques for estimating fatigue quality involved stress-severity-factor analysis,\nprevious airplane tests, or fleet data. The factors accounted for in the estimating tech133\n\nnique are geometric stress concentration, load transfer, type of fastener (interference,\ndesign, and modulus of elasticity), bearing stress distribution, hole surface condition,\nresidual stresses, and material. Constants were determined which provided the best fit\nof estimated life versus test- or fleet-demonstrated life from approximately 2000 assessments. The sequence of analysis, test, and fatigue performance estimation is discussed\nin the section entitled "Typical Results."\nFigure 6 illustrates the scope of the fatigue analyses conducted on basic structures,\nand figure 7 illustrates typical details selected for analysis.\nFatigue reliability factors (scatter factors) accounting for fatigue performance\nvariability, possible load environment variability, and the number of tests conducted on\nrepresentative built-up structures are included in each basic structure or detail fatigue\nanalysis. The magnitudes of the fatigue reliability factors varied from 2 to 4, with 4\nbeing used in preliminary analysis when the least built-up structure data were available,\nand 2 being used when large numbers of representative built-up structure tests were\ncompleted.\nMaterials Selection and Detail Design\nThis facet of the 747 fatigue integrity program is intended to cover fatigue improvement activities which parallel the basic analysis. Fleet experience, for example, can\nplay a major role in complementing preliminary fatigue analysis, that is, as a check and\nbalance. Fleet experience with similar parts can augment conventional fatigue analysis,\nprovide positive assessment of detail design quality, even derive new model fatigue performance providing usage, stress, and detail design are not substantially different.\nDuring the design stage, guides for satisfactory fatigue design (or at least guides\nfor identification of possible problems such as given in ref. 13) are of value. The best\nexperience of course is fleet experience, and listings of previous industry airplane problems (cause and effect) were used as design background on the 747. These types of activities, together with preliminary fatigue analysis, resulted in numerous design improvements, a few of which are shown in figures 8, 9, and 10, and in the following materials\nsection:\nWing lower surface \xe2\x80\x94 2024 skin and stiffeners\nWing upper surface \xe2\x80\x94 7075 skin and stiffeners\nBody skin \xe2\x80\x94 primarily 2024\nBody frames and stiffeners \xe2\x80\x94 7075\nEmpennage \xe2\x80\x94 7075\n\n134\n\nLanding gear \xe2\x80\x94 primarily 4340 steel heat-treated to yield an ultimate strength\nvarying from 270 to 300 ksi\nForgings \xe2\x80\x94 7075-T73 (stress corrosion is a prime consideration)\nTesting\nAnalysis and past experience are very important in establishing preliminary design\ngeometries, materials, and allowable stress levels. The proof of fatigue quality, however,\nmust come from test or flight experience. Since the objective of the fatigue integrity\nprogram is to minimize early flight fatigue experience (i.e., cracks), early testing is a\nkey element (refs. 14 and 15). An extensive verification test program was conducted on\nrepresentative sections of the entire airplane (figs. 11 to 17) . All these test structures\nwere constructed with the same finishes, fasteners, and geometries as were planned for\nproduction airplanes. Both constant-amplitude and flight-by-flight spectrum tests were\nrun. In addition to the panel and pressurized fuselage test program summarized in figures 11 to 17, numerous small-scale development-type tests were conducted. Majorcomponent tests, including landing gears, trailing-edge flaps, and horizontal stabilizer,\nare discussed in the section entitled "Tests of Major Components." The culmination of\nthe 747 fatigue test program is the full-scale fatigue test, which is discussed subsequently.\nTYPICAL RESULTS\nTypical of the analyses conducted on the airplane is that shown in figure 18. This\nparticular analysis was conducted for three fatigue qualities and included a fatigue reliability factor (FRF) of 4.0. The analysis illustrates variation of life with spanwise and\nchordwise location as well as the approximate quality required to achieve the fatigue life\ngoal of 60 000 hours.\nTypical test quality determination is illustrated in figure 19, where fatigue quality\nis plotted against cycles to first crack. The quality associated with the number of cycles\nendured at the listed stress state is 0.361, or in 1/Kt form, FPI = 1/2.77. This quality, incidentally, is very near the initial quality estimated for basic structure FPI = 0.4\nor 1/2.5 and is near the upper end of the qualities for which the analysis in figure 17 was\nconducted.\nApplication of test-determined quality and a revised fatigue reliability factor\nFRF = 2.95 (which is appropriate after additional testing) results in the estimated fleet\nfatigue performance of stringer runouts shown in figure 20.\nAdditional examples of the type of data available from fatigue analyses are shown in\nfigures 21, 22, and 23. Since several flights were included in the basic definition of usage,\n135\n\nparametric-type analyses illustrating the influence of flight length on fatigue life are\navailable. These particular analyses have been useful in assessing fatigue life of\n747 derivatives for different kinds of usage, especially short-range operation. Zones\nof life deficiencies and stress reductions or quality improvements required to achieve\nappropriate life goals for 1-hour average flight operation, for instance, are also fallouts\nof basic airplane analysis.\nTESTS OF MAJOR COMPONENTS\nMajor-component tests include: nose, wing, and body landing gears, horizontal\nstabilizer, and outboard trailing-edge flap. Photographs and descriptions of landing-gear\ntest specimens are given in figure 24. In order to represent flight airplane structure,\ntest specimens are production parts and jig structure is designed to simulate the flexibility of airplane support structure. These specimens are subjected to block-type loadings\nshown in figures 25, 26, and 27. Each block consists of loadings equivalent to 1000 flights,\n5 percent of the one lifetime goal of 20 000 flights. The numerous environmental conditions included in analysis and test of each gear are also listed on the respective figures.\nThe outboard-flap test is illustrated in figure 28. The test consisted of stress\nsurveys, functional testing in which the flap was raised and lowered 5000 times, and\nfatigue testing the outboard flap in the fully extended position. The inboard flap and\nleading-edge flaps are tested in the fatigue test on the full-scale airplane.\nThe horizontal stabilizer is tested separately from the full-scale airplane fatigue\ntest primarily to avoid the complication of meshing with fin load systems (fig. 29). Since\nthe stabilizer is mounted in a determinate manner on two hinges and a jackscrew, a fully\nrepresentative load spectrum can be applied in both the full-scale test, through dummy\nstabilizer structure, and the separate test. An added advantage is that the stabilizer test\ncan then be conducted at a faster rate. To allow for the fin-empennage airload interaction\nwith the stabilizer, the vertical gust loads are applied in both separate and full-scale tests\nwith a \xc2\xb120-percent asymmetry. Derived spectrum loads are applied to the inboard and\noutboard elevators on the left side and through dummy elevators on the right side. Additional elevator loads representing take-off rotation and climb rotation are applied in the\ntake-off phase, and loads representing spoiler trim and landing flare are applied in the\nlanding phase.\nFATIGUE TEST OF FULL-SCALE AIRPLANE\nGeneral Description of Specimen and Test Rig\nThe culmination of the test phase of the fatigue integrity program is the fatigue test\nof the full-scale airplane (fig. 30). The test specimen is a structurally complete airframe\n136\n\nof typical production configuration. Omitted are main and nose landing gears, trailingedge flaps except left-hand inboard, leading-edge flaps except left-hand flap numbers 3,\n7, and 12, ailerons, spoilers, engine pod, and the horizontal stabilizer, which is tested\nseparately. Loads are applied through representative dummy structures for the major\ncomponents omitted from the test.\nLoads are applied to the airplane by using 86 hydraulic actuators, which are controlled by an automatic closed-loop electro-hydraulic servo system. The command or\nprogram signal is supplied to the servo systems by a digital programer. This programer\nand the data acquisition functions for the test are controlled by a Digital Equipment Corporation PDP-8 computer. The computer is also used to automate many of the operating\nfunctions of the test.\nTo prevent the test specimen from being loaded to levels that are outside defined\ntolerances, a lockup manifold is installed on each hydraulic actuator. When the lockup\nsystem is actuated, the actuator holds the load at the limit of present tolerances until\nproblem correction. Stainless-steel safety links are included in all load systems attached\nto the airplane. These are designed to yield before local airplane structure is damaged\nby inadvertent overloading. There is also a two-way relief valve installed in each load\nsystem to limit actuator pressure and thereby prevent an overload.\nLoad Spectrum Derivation\nThe main purpose of the airplane fatigue test is to better determine the true structural fatigue performance by eliminating most of the assumptions which are necessary in\nthe analysis. The specific objectives of the test are to locate as quickly as possible any\nfatigue-critical areas with a program accurately representing typical service loads, to\nprovide test data for analytical service life predictions, to help develop inspection and\nmaintenance procedures for the airlines, and to evaluate fail-safe characteristics of\nmajor structural parts. Criteria considered in developing the load spectrum are\nFlight-by-flight testing\nAverage of mixture of flights used as base\nMatch upper surface ground-air-ground stresses\nMatch upper surface taxi damage\nMatch lower surface flight segment damage distribution\nMatch lg stresses in 3-hour flight\nEquivalent gust and maneuver cycles\nOne lateral cycle for one vertical cycle in flight segments\n137\n\nLateral-load cycles quarter of a cycle out of phase with vertical-load cycles\nRepresentative cabin pressurization and depressurization\nAverage flap utilization\nMean engine thrust in each flight segment\nEquivalent landing-gear loads in ground-handling phase\nIntermittent high loads and marker loads\nTo give the correct combination of spectrum loads, cabin pressure, and ground-airground cycle loads, the test is conducted on a flight-by-flight basis. An average flight\nbased on the mixture of four analysis flights is used for deriving the test program. For\nconvenience, damage in the average flight is factored by 19 800/20 000 = 0.99 to give\n20 000 average flights in 60 000 hours of service. Therefore, each test spectrum represents 3 hours of flying in the mixture of flights.\nFrom the derived gust, maneuver, and taxi damage in each flight segment, the\nrequired test cycles are found by using the appropriate stresses from the 3-hour flight\n(fig. 2).\nIncremental stresses due to gust or maneuver and the relationship between gust\nspeed and airplane acceleration differ for each component. Therefore, the damage due\nto gust and maneuvers is considered independently and is applied to each component with\nrepresentative loads. Equivalent gust loads are factored by appropriate dynamic magnification factors.\nOn the basis of aircraft industry experience, both wing upper and wing lower surfaces are of fatigue concern. Therefore, a load program is derived which is representative for both surfaces. The wing upper surface GAG cycle (which is given by the cycle\nfrom the maximum once-per-flight tension stress on the ground, to the maximum onceper-flight compression stress in the air, to the maximum once-per-flight tension stress\non the ground) damage is matched by a slightly modified GAG cycle for the 3-hour flight.\nThis modification limits the maximum allowable tension stress in the taxi segment. To\nreduce the number of cycles, the mean stress in the taxi is reduced below the 1g level\nallowing a higher alternating stress. With this additional variable the required number\nof cycles, which was fixed at five, can be matched. Having fixed the upper surface GAG\ncycle stresses and matched the taxi damage, 97 percent of the total upper surface damage\nis matched.\n, For the wing lower surface, the GAG cycle gives approximately 30 percent of the\ntotal damage. The lower surface taxi damage corresponds to the cycles already determined for the upper surface. The small difference between the analysis and test taxi\ndamage is corrected in the GAG cycle damage to give the correct total damage. The\n138\n\nlower surface GAG stresses are determined by the same method used for the upper surface. With a representative Ig stress in each flight segment, the maximum allowable\nalternating stress, and hence the maximum equivalent alternating cycle, is limited by the\nGAG cycle stresses. To achieve the best damage match at other locations, the maximum\nGAG stresses are fixed in the same flight segments as the analysis. Maximum upper surface tension and lower surface compression stresses occur in the taxi segments. The\nmaximum upper surface compression stress occurs in the hold segment, and the maximum lower surface tension stress occurs during flaps-down climb. Gust and maneuver\ndamage is matched in each segment by finding the minimum number of cycles based on\nthe 1g and GAG stress limitations.\nFigure 31 illustrates the vertical-load program derived for the wing. Fuselage\nvertical loads correspond to the gust, maneuver, and taxi loads derived similarly to those\nfor the wing. Since it is impractical to load all the passenger and cargo floor, representative loads are applied in fore, mid, and aft body locations. The numerous other load\nspectra and the approximate phasing with vertical loads are shown in figure 32. For reference purposes, the average 3-hour flight is subdivided into eleven phases, shown by\nRoman numerals.\nFor the lateral-load program, the load magnitude is found by matching the damage\nin each segment with the same number of cycles as the vertical-load program. In the\nsegments with an even number of cycles, half the cycles are applied with a gust load distribution and half with maneuver load distribution. The cycles in the other segments are\narranged so that the total flight damage is half gust and half maneuver.\nAdditional discrete rudder loads which occur during take-off, flap extension,\napproach, and landing roll-out are applied during phase I for convenience. It is considered unlikely that the maximum lateral loads generally occur at the same time as the\nmaximum vertical loads. Therefore, the lateral-load cycles are applied one-quarter of\na cycle out of phase with the vertical-load cycles. This means the peak lateral load\noccurs with 1g vertical load and the maximum and minimum vertical loads occur with\nzero lateral load.\nCabin pressure differential varies from zero to 0.6 psi in phase IV, from 0.6 linearly to 9.0 psi in phase V, is constant at 9.0 psi in phases VI and VII, varies from 9.0\nlinearly to 0.6 psi in phase VIII, is constant at 0.6 psi in phase IX, and varies from 0.6 psi\nto zero in phase X.\nLoads representing an average utilization are applied to the leading-edge (LE) and\ntrailing-edge (TE) flaps. On the leading edge the loads are applied to flaps 3, 7, and 12\non the left-hand side. The remaining flap loads are applied through dummy flaps with\nrepresentative loads on the support structure. Loads on trailing-edge flaps are applied\nto the inboard flap on the left side with the remaining loads applied to the tracks through\n139\n\ndummy flaps. Most of the damage to TE flaps occurs during approach with the flaps fully\nextended. Therefore, the test loads are applied with the flaps in the extended position.\nAn equivalent load cycle is applied in phase III to represent the damage in the most critical track and carriage sections during take-off with flaps at 15 0 . In the analysis of the\nprimary structure on the LE flaps, most of the damage occurs during take-off. The maximum flap load during take-off occurs with the flaps extended at the end of the take-off\nrotation. Therefore, the test loads are applied with the flaps in the extended position.\nAn equivalent cycle is applied during the approach in phase X. When the LE flaps are\nretracted, the uplock load exceeds all the 1g, gust, and maneuver airloads. Therefore\nno loads are applied on the leading-edge flaps during the remaining flight stages. To\nrepresent the uplock stress which occurs during flight and the two cycles during ground\nhandling, three equivalent load cycles are applied in phase I.\nMean fore and aft nacelle loads in the 3-hour flight are applied in each phase. Maximum gross thrust during take-off and reverse thrust during landing are applied in\nphases III and IX, respectively.\nLanding-gear loads in an average flight are applied through dummy gears to the\nlanding-gear support structure. The dummy gear has a representative relative stiffness\nto give a true load distribution. In phase I ground handling the vertical, fore and aft, and\nside loads are based on the same criteria used to derive the separate landing-gear test\nprogram. The main difference between the two tests is the block loading in the gear test,\nwhich has 1000 flights in each test spectrum and flight-by-flight loading in the airplane\nfatigue test. Vertical loads in phase H taxi correspond to the loads derived for the wing.\nAverage spinup and springback loads are applied in phase XI landing.\nThe spectrum applied on the airplane fatigue test represents typical loads which\noccur in an average flight. In addition to these loads, the airframe is subjected to infrequent high loads during the 60 000-hour life of the airplane. These loads have a negligible effect on the cumulative fatigue damage but affect the damage rate and crack initiation\nand propagation. Therefore, to include this effect in the program, the loads which occur\nthree times in 60 000 hours flying are applied. These loads are termed intermittent high\nloads (IHL).\nSince any cabin pressure differential higher than the normal 9.0 psi is unlikely to\noccur, no intermittent high cabin pressure is applied.\nIn previous fatigue tests it has been difficult to establish crack initiation times,\ncrack propagation rates, and crack life prior to rapid fracture in inaccessible areas, and\nfor cracks which were not found until the test was completed. To help in establishing\ncrack data, unique loads, termed marker loads (ML), are applied during the test. These\nmarker loads are arranged in sequence with the intermittent high loads so that a definite\ntest time can be determined from the striations (table 2).\n140\n\nIn the test spectrum the cabin pressure is cycled from zero to 9.0 psi to zero once\nper flight. This gives a representative cycle for a typical flight. In the training flight\nthe airplane climbs to a varying altitude three times. To represent these pressure cycles\nand concurrently provide a ML pattern for pressure-critical components, those additional\npressure cycles from the training flights are applied.\nThe present status of the major-component and full-scale airplane fatigue tests is\ngiven in table 3. The differing test goals specified in this table are an outgrowth of the\nfatigue reliability factor criteria discussed in the section entitled "Approach." In general, critical details in landing-gear structure are single-detail-type items, for example,\na fillet radius. For these types of tests, a larger statistical factor is required to achieve\ndesired reliability levels in service.\nIn built-up structure tests such as the outboard flap, horizontal stabilizer, and fullscale airplane, several points usually are identically stressed and therefore constitute a\nlarger sample and require lower statistical factors. All major components have been\nsubjected to loads exceeding the planned requirements for the basic passenger airplane.\nMany of the tests have been continued beyond the original test goals in order to substantiate derivative airplane requirements. Pending identification of requirements more\nsevere than those currently estimated, some tests have been suspended.\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\nThe Boeing 747 fatigue integrity program provides a high degree of confidence in\nthe ability of the structure to withstand service loads. Safe and economic operation is\ninsured through fail-safe design augmented with a continually updated program reflecting\npast experience, analysis, and test-demonstrated fatigue performance.\n\n141\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Operating empty weight, 360 000 lb.\n\nCRUISE 1\n\nCRUISE 2\n\nCRUISE 3\n\nw\no\n\n~\n\n!:i\n\xc2\xab\nCLIMB\nROTATION\n\nSPEED BRAKE \\ HOLD\nAPPLICA TION\n\nPREFLIGHT\nCHECK\n.\nTAKE-OFF\nROTATION\n\nI\n\nDYNAMIC\nLANDING\n\nFLAPS DOW N APPROACH\n_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\n~LANDING\nFLARE -~\n\nTlf\\I\xc2\xa3\nFigure 3.- Typical flight segmentation .\n\nt-"\n\n""co\n\n~\n\n...\n\n.....\n\n<:.Jl\n\no\n\n18\n16\n\nFATIGUE PERFORMANCE CURVE\nFMEAN & CONSTANT\n\n14\n12\nAL TERNATING\nSTRESS KSI\n\n10\n8\n\nCONSTANT AMPLITUDE\nTESTING ZONE\n\n6\n\n\'\n4\n\n....\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2 \xe2\x80\xa2 ~S-N CURVE\n\n...\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2.........\n\n2\n\n0\nCYCLES TO FIRST CRACK\nFigure 4.- Modified Miner\'s met hod.\n\nfATIGUE PERFORMANCE INDEX (FPII\nDETERMINED BY ONE OF THE FOLLOWING:\n.fPC -
