I\n\n1\t\n\nI\nVIATXAI\n\n011Ai\n\nI\n,\n\n,\t ,\t\n\n1\n\n\'\t\n\n1\nI\n\n1\n\n1\n\nI\t\n\nI\t\n\n1\n\nI\t\n\nI\n\n1\t\nI\t\nI\t\n\n\'\t\n\'\t\n\nI\n\'\n\'\n\nI\n1\n1\n\n\'\n1\n\'\n\nI\t\nj\t\n,\t\n\n\'\t\n^\t\nI\t\n\nI\nI\nI\n\nI\t\n^\t\n,\t\n\n1\nI\nI\n\n^\t\n\ni\n\n1\n\nI\n\nI\n\n1\t\n\nI\n\n\'\n\n1\n\n\'\n\n\'\t\n\nI\t\n\n\'\n\nI\t\n\nI\n\nI\n\'\n\'\n\n,\n,\n1\n\nI\n\'\n\'\n\n,\t\nI\t\nI\t\n\n\'\t\nI\t\nI\t\n\n1\n1\nI\n\nI\t\nI\t\nI\t\n\n,\nI\nI\n\nI\n1\n,\n,\n\n\'\n\nI\t\n\n^\t\n\n\'\n\nI\n\n1\n1\n\n1\nI\t\nI\t\n\n^\t\n\n,\n1\n\n^\t\nI\t\n\n! N)F\n\nI\n\n^\t\nI\t\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\nI\n\nVINT"\n\n1\t\n1\n\n^\t\n\n^\n\nm"\n\nAA\n\nSW(\n\nI\n\xe2\x80\xa2\t\n\n1\tI\t\n\nI\'\t\'\t\nI\t\n\n1\tI\t\n\n\'\t1\t\n\nFigure 32.- 747 full-scale fatigue test.\n\n178\n\nI\nI\n\nI\t\n\n^\t,\t\n\n^\t\n\xe2\x80\xa2\t\n\nI\t\n\n^\t,\t\n\n1\n\nFATIGUE AND FAIL-SAFE DESIGN FEATURES OF THE DC-10 AIRPLANE\nBy M. Stone\nDouglas Aircraft Company\nMcDonnell Douglas Corporation\nLong Beach, California, U.S.A.\t\n\na . a_( <399\n\nSUMMARY\nThe philosophy and methods used in the design of the DC-10 aircraft to assure\nstructural reliability against cracks under repeated service loads are described in\ndetail. The approach consists of three complementary parts: (1) the structure is\ndesigned to be fatigue resistant for a crack-free life of 60 000 flight hours; (2) inasmuch as small undetected cracks could develop from other sources, such as material\nflaws and manufacturing preloads, the structure also is designed to arrest and control\ncracks within a reasonable service-inspection interval; and (3) a meaningful serviceinspection program has been defined on the basis of analysis and test experience from\nthe design development program. This service-inspection program "closes the loop"\nto assure the structural integrity of the DC-10 airframe. Selected materials, fasteners, and structural arrangements are used to achieve these design features with minimum structural weight and with economy in manufacturing and maintenance. Extensive analyses and testing were performed to develop and verify the design.\nThe basic design considerations for fatigue-resistant structure are illustrated\nin terms of material selection, design loads spectra, methods for accurate stress and\nfatigue damage analysis, and proven concepts for efficient detail design. Special\nemphasis is given to the DC-10 development test program. The initial stage of this\nprogram was a series of screening tests of candidate materials, types of fasteners,\nstress coining, surface treatments, manufacturing processes, and so forth.\nINTRODUCTION\nThe structural design goals for the DC-10, shown in figure 1, were to produce\nan airplane that is superior to the DC-8 and DC-9 and that will be operated safely and\neconomically for at least 20 years. Three complementary criteria were established\nto assure this goal:\n(1) The structure has a crack-free life of 60 000 flight hours on the basis of\ndesign, analysis, and tests in excess of 120 000 flight hours.\n\n179\n\n(2) The structure is damage tolerant. Adequate residual strength is available after\na crack has propagated, and the basic structural configuration provides for slow crack\ngrowth and arrestment before reaching critical lengths.\n(3) An inspection program has been established on the basis of a fail-safe structure\nwith adequate external detectability, as verified by component tests. In addition, the\nstart of inspection and sampling intervals were based on fatigue, corrosion, and crackpropagation resistance of the structure.\nSTRUCTURAL RELIABILITY\nA distribution is shown in figure 2 to indicate the overwhelming influence of development testing and detail design on the structural reliability of the DC-10. These two\nitems were accomplished during initial design stage; they allow true optimization of the\nDC-10 airframe by "placing the structural material where it is most effective" and\nthereby provide maximum-fatigue-life assurance. In any event, it is necessary to establish fatigue criteria, identify sensitive areas, establish fastener policies, and plan an\nearly development testing program. Without these procedures, the structural design\ncannot be successful.\nA new computer analysis system was used with a high degree of accuracy in predicting the actual working stress levels and deflections in the structural elements. Fullscale fatigue tests were used to reveal weak links and verify that proper analysis and\ndetail testing were accomplished during the aircraft design.\nFATIGUE-SENSITIVE AREAS\nOnce the fatigue-sensitive areas are recognized, proper emphasis can be given to\nthese problem areas to assure fatigue reliability. In the design of the DC-10 aircraft,\nthese areas, as shown in figures 3 and 4, were given special attention during design,\nanalysis, and testing.\nThe fatigue reliability of the wing box and fuselage pressure shell, splices, joints,\nand other discontinuities has been made equal to or better than that of the basic structural items 4, 9, and 10 of figure 3.\nANALYSIS\nEvolution of FORMAT\nIn order to assure design static and fatigue strength, actual working stresses and\ndeflections were predicted with the use of the FORTRAN Matrix Abstraction Technique\n180\n\n(FORMAT) developed by Douglas Aircraft Company over a period of 20 years (ref. 1).\nImproved computer methods and techniques, such as FORMAT, gave increased analysis\ncapability and visibility over the original DC-8 airframe, as shown in figure 5.\nThe FORMAT system is fully automatic so, even during preliminary design, structural weight is minimized and fatigue characteristics are improved by placing the material where it is most effective (ref. 2).\nDeflections\nFigure 6 shows the excellent correlation of deflections from FORMAT analysis with\ntest results. The comparison shows deflections for limit-positive-load conditions for the\nwing, fuselage, and horizontal stabilizer. The test results were obtained from a successful static-load test completed on the second production aircraft in August 1970. The aircraft was fully instrumented with strain gages and deflection transducers by using a\nsophisticated 1000-channel data system.\nStress Analysis\nFigure 7 shows the stresses in the complicated root section of the wing subjected\nto limit positive-maneuver loads (from the front spar (F.S.) to the rear spar (R.S.)) and\nthe equally sensitive fuselage section above the wing subjected to limit down-bending\nloads. The circles represent static test measurements, and the solid line indicates the\nstresses computed by FORMAT analysis. The dashed lines indicate the stresses computed by elementary beam theory which underestimates the stresses at the sensitive\nstructural areas. The excellent accuracy of the detail stress analysis allows the calculation of reliable local stress levels and assures the fatigue quality of the DC-10 structure.\nWorking Stresses\nThe working stress levels for the DC-10 wing have been carefully established on\nthe basis of the working stresses used on earlier airplanes which, since, have had proven\nlongevity (fig. 8). The working stress levels for the fuselage shell have increased mainly\nbecause of the wide-body cross section. This increase in stress has been accomplished\nwith no loss in fatigue strength through improvement in detail design.\nFatigue Quality Structure\nThe increase in working stress levels and the additional requirement for dependable\nlong-life aircraft make it mandatory to increase the fatigue quality of all structural elements. The results of several thousand constant-amplitude component fatigue tests of\nstructural elements of various configurations are summarized in figure 9. (R is the\n181\n\nmaximum stress in any cycle divided by the minimum stress in the cycle.) It is noteworthy that the basic structure has considerable longevity as attested by the DC-3, DC-6,\nDC-7, and DC-8 airframe structure. As shown, the DC-6 and DC-7 joints were critical;\nthe DC-8 joints were practically equivalent to the basic structure, and the DC-10 joints\nare equal to or better than the basic structure. The DC-10 structure incorporated the\nbest structural details gained from knowledge of DC-8 structure and DC-10 development\ntesting.\nDEVELOPMENT TESTS\nThe results of over 2000 fatigue development tests conducted on the DC-8 and DC-9\nhave been used in conjunction with an additional 1700 fatigue development DC-10 tests to\nsubstantiate crack-free, long-life structures. The fatigue development test program has\nbeen completed in time to permit the designer to incorporate the test findings into the\ndesign. The DC-10 program was planned to utilize small inexpensive specimens as well\nas large aircraft components.\nSpecimen Development Testing\nDouble bow-tie wing specimens have been used to obtain reliable fatigue data in\nminimum time and at minimum expense. Results from specimens of this type have been\nfound to correlate closely with results from more complex and expensive specimens composed of skin and stringers. These tests permit rapid evaluation of various attachment\ntypes, hole sizes, hole-preparation methods, material-thickness effects, claddings, and\nso forth, on the fatigue life of the basic structure. Bow-tie wing specimens cannot be used\nfor all configurations; therefore, more typical simple wing slices were also used to evaluate fasteners. Over 300 specimens of these types were tested. The test results are\nshown in figure 10.\nThe simple longitudinal and transverse skin splices and the longeron-to -frame connection fuselage fatigue development tests were separately conducted to evaluate and\nscreen materials, fastener selection, surface treatment, and so forth. The results of the\nlongitudinal and transverse tests are shown in figure 10.\nComponent Development Testing\nStructural-wing-component fatigue development tests were conducted on actual parts\nthat are used in the final aircraft design. All the knowledge gained through the bow-tie\nand other specimen testing was incorporated in the structural components. Approximately\n140 tests were conducted. These aircraft components (fig. 3) were tested and improved\nuntil at least 150 000 to 350 000 flight hours were attained. The results are shown in\n182\n\nfigure 11 for constant-amplitude tests. After the final configurations were selected,\nflight-by-flight spectrum tests were conducted on major components to verify the minimum of 150 000 flight hours.\nSix curved stiffened 168- by 104-inch panels, representing various areas of the\nfuselage, were tested under combined biaxial loads, pressure, and inertia loads. The\ndesign features gained on the previously described specimen development tests were\nincorporated into the design of these panels. The panels consisted of eight frames,\n11 longerons, four-way splice (longitudinal and transverse) basic structure, and longeronto-frame connections. Fatigue tests were performed on the curved panels. Both pressure and axial loads were cycled at constant load levels to simulate stresses higher than\nthose which would produce fatigue damage equivalent to the full spectrum of loads experienced by the aircraft in flight (fig. 11). Additional fatigue tests were conducted on\nwindow-belt panels and pressure-bulkhead panels.\nThese specimens were tested in 1.5-million-pound fatigue test machines at the laboratory test facility. Four of these machines could each hold and test two specimens\nsimultaneously. In this way, the tests were finished quickly so that the findings could be\nincorporated into the drawings early in the design.\nDETAIL DESIGN\nThe basic design considerations for fatigue-resistant structure have been established for the DC-10 by paying strict attention to proven detail design concepts. Before\nfabrication, wooden models of all important structural fittings were made to review for\nnotch concentrations and unexpected machine mismatch areas. Photo stress tests were\nalso conducted on main fittings to determine the stress distributions and peak stress\nmagnitudes in areas where stresses are difficult to predict. On the basis of DC-8 and\nDC-9 experience, coupled with the extensive DC-10 development test program, many\nfatigue design features were established, as shown in figures 12, 13, and 14.\nThe fatigue life of the DC-10 inboard sweep break skin-stringer joint (fig. 12)\nbecame greater than that of the adjoining basic structure after the components were properly tapered and material was added locally at the discontinuities. Interference-fit\nattachments were also used to increase fatigue life.\nTo attain maximum fatigue-resistant structure of basic leading-edge skin to sparcap structure, a sacrificial doubler has been used to attach the interchangeable leadingedge section to the front-spar (F.S.) cap as shown in figure 13. This design allows the\nuse of interference attachments in the heavier spar-cap flanges.\nFigure 14 shows the fuselage detail design features. The use of properly stepped\ndoublers around the fuselage door corners reduces stress concentrations. Adding a local\n183\n\nchannel pad to the longeron reduces local bending between the longeron and frame connection. The scalloped longeron splice fitting and fingered doublers assure uniform load\ntransfer and reduce the first attachment load.\nQUALIFICATION TESTING\nThe DC-10 is undergoing a flight-by-flight production-airplane fatigue test to\n120 000 flight hours and 84 000 flights. The fourth production airplane is divided into\nthree major sections, as shown in figure 15. The shaded test structures shown at the\nends of each section represent steel drums that are a minimum of one fuselage diameter\nin length to assure that load is properly introduced into the aircraft structure. Special\ndesign aluminum transition sections modulate interaction effects between the steel drums\nand aircraft structure to preclude fatigue failures in that region. The division into three\nsections was based on the following factors:\n(1) There are fewer compromises in the load spectrum.\n(2) Noncritical loads can be eliminated and other critical loads added for each undivided section.\n(3) Sections can continue cycling while one section is down for inspection or repair.\nThe cycles are being applied to each individual section as shown in the following\ntable:\nNumber of cycles applied to \xe2\x80\x94\nType of load\n\nForward Wing-fuselage\nsection\nsection\n\nAft\nsection\n\nGround loads\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\nFlight loads\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\nLanding impact .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\t .\nGround-Air -Ground (G-A-G) * . . . . .\nFuselage pressurizations\t .\t . . .\t .\t .\t .\n\n252 000\n383 040\n37 800\n84 000\n84 000\n\n389 840\n913 332\n36 540\n84 000\n84 000\n\n168 000\n753 648\n37 800\n84 000\n84 000\n\nTotal:\n\n840 840\n\n1 507 712\n\n1 127 448\n\n*Inherently obtained because the load spectrum is applied on a flight-byflight basis.\nTesting experience has shown that proper loads can be applied more accurately to\nsmaller components subjected to large concentrated loads. The main and nose landing\ngears and adjacent support structure, therefore, are tested separately so that every\ndetailed area is subjected to the millions of cycles that occur in service (ref. 3).\n184\n\nDAMAGE-TOLERANT STRUCTURE\nThe DC-10 primary structure is designed to be fail-safe, with the exception of the\nlanding gear for which fail-safe design is not practical. The fail-safe criterion used in\nthe DC-10 is more stringent than specification requirements; that is, the structure must\nsupport the fail-safe load soon after several components have failed.\nIdentification of Sensitive Areas (Fuselage)\nThe radial loading due to cabin internal pressure can start a longitudinal skin crack\nin two locations:\n(1) At the skin line where the fingered doubler is attached to the skin of the longitudinal skin splice, shown in figure 16(a) (This type of fatigue crack results in a\none-bay longitudinal skin crack.)\n(2) At the first attachment of shear clip frame to skin, shown in figure 16(b) (The\nfatigue crack of this type can propagate into a two-bay longitudinal crack.)\nThe combined pressure and axial loads can start a transverse skin crack where the\nlongeron is attached to the frame. After failure of the longeron a skin crack can form\nwhich may propagate into two adjacent skin bays, shown in figure 16(c). Recognition of\nthese facts led to the following damage-tolerant conditions selected for the fuselage shell\nstructure shown in figure 16(d):\n(1) Two-bay longitudinal crack with center crack stoppers failed\n(2) Two-bay transverse crack with center longeron failed\nThe design selected contains titanium crack stoppers at each frame capable of arresting\na two-bay longitudinal crack. The hat section longerons act as natural transverse crack\nstoppers.\nStress Analysis (Fuselage Panels)\nThe equation for the fracture strength of stiffened thin panels containing a crack is\nKcRct\n\nQ\t\n\nR\n\nVW tan (&)\n\nwhere\nQR\t\n\ngross residual stress, psi\n\nKc\t\n\nplane stress fracture toughness, psi in.\n185\n\nRct\n\nCrack-tip stress of unstiffened panel\nCrack-tip stress of stiffened panel\n\nW\t\n\npanel width, inches\n\na\t\n\nhalf crack length, inches\n\nas\tstiffener stress, psi\na\t\n\ngross applied stress, psi\n\nToughness Kc is determined from tests on stiffened panels as shown in figure 17(a).\nThe ratio Rct is determined from analysis of unstiffened and stiffened panels having the\nsame grid size by taking a ratio between the crack-tip stresses (ref. 4). The idealized\nstructure and analysis are based on the FORTRAN Matrix Abstraction Technique\n(FORMAT) shown in figure 17(b).\nSkin Fracture Criterion (Fuselage Panels)\nResults of fuselage panel residual strength tests are shown that verify test and\ntheory correlation. The shape of the curve is determined by analysis and the height by\ncritical fracture toughness Kc . (Note the point of fast fracture.) The curve plotted in\nfigure 17(c) shows correlation with the analysis at critical crack length, crack arrest,\nand final failure.\nThe maximum allowable principal stress for a two-bay longitudinal crack is above\nthe maximum operating principal stress for the DC-10 and provides an adequate margin\nof safety.\nStiffener Criteria (Fuselage Panels)\nStiffener strength must be adequate. In order to maintain the skin fracture strength,\nthe stiffener must not fail. An example of frame (aluminum) stress and outer-crackstopper (titanium) stress correlation is shown in figure 17(d).\nFail-Safe Testing (Fuselage Panels)\nExtensive fail-safe testing has been completed. A comprehensive test program was\ninitiated early in the DC-10 design to verify analytical methods and to evaluate various\nstiffener configurations and materials. Figure 18 illustrates some of the fail-safe development test specimens. Finally, six 118.5-inch-radius curved panels were tested to\ndetermine the residual strength. These tests showed that the fuselage shell structure\n186\n\nprovides more than adequate fail-safe capability for the conservative two-bay selected\ndamage-tolerance criteria.\nStress Analysis and Testing (Wing Panels)\nAn important design consideration of the DC-10 wing structure is to sustain an initial failure of a member but allow for extension of the failure over a reasonable number\nof additional flight hours. This approach assures that an initial crack will not grow to\ncritical proportion before it is detected during routine inspection intervals.\nThe damage-tolerance criterion, a two-bay crack with center stringer failed, has\nbeen incorporated into the design of the DC-10 wing box structure shown in figure 19. In\naddition, four separate skin panels are used on the wing lower surface to arrest further\nany crack propagation.\nFigure 20 shows FORMAT analysis correlation with experimental results obtained\nfrom tests of large skin-stringer panels representing typical wing box construction.\nStresses at adjacent stringers have been calculated as functions of crack length. The\nresults have been verified by strain-gage test results.\nSTRUCTURAL INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM\nThe purpose of the structural inspection and maintenance program is to detect\nstructural problems on aircraft before airworthiness is affected or expensive repairs\nbecome necessary. The importance of the structural inspection and maintenance program\nwas recognized during initial DC-10 design stages. Goals were established to provide\nrequired structural airworthiness levels at minimum inspection and maintenance costs.\nThe main approach is to give full assurance that the aircraft structure will be relatively crack free for its intended service life of 60 000 flight hours and 42 000 flights.\nThis high degree of structural reliability was achieved by designing, analyzing, and testing\nto (1) a fatigue life in excess of 120 000 flight hours and 84 000 flights to crack initiation\nand (2) a fail-safe life based on a two-bay crack length requirement.\nFatigue Life\nItem (1) \xe2\x80\x94 that is, a fatigue life in excess of 120 000 flight hours and 84 000 flights\nto crack initiation \xe2\x80\x94 incorporates various design features.\nWorking stress levels. - Accurate stress levels were predicted for structural sizing\nusing FORMAT analysis. Stress levels are equivalent to those of the DC-8 and DC-9,\nwhich have excellent service experience.\n\n187\n\nDetail design. - Stress concentrations were minimized in joints, splices, and basic\nstructure by the use of proper tapering and scalloping, stress coining, and interferencefit attachments (ref. 5). Preload stresses were minimized by providing flexible structure\nin design, shop fabrication assembly, and installation tolerance control. Detail design\nquality of the structure is equivalent to, or better than, DC-8 and DC-9 quality, as verified\nthrough component fatigue test results.\nCorrosion and stress corrosion. - Corrosion was prevented through faying-surface\nsealing, priming, top coating epoxy paints, draining, using clad aluminum materials, and\nusing high-strength fasteners installed wet with sealant or primer. Stress corrosion\nresistance was maximized by utilizing 7075-T73 material, which has a high corrosion\nthreshold.\nFail-Safe Life\nItem (2) \xe2\x80\x94 a fail-safe life based on a two-bay crack length requirement \xe2\x80\x94 involves\ntwo main design considerations. The use of FORMAT analysis, verified by large panel\ncomponent tests, enabled the structure to be designed for slow crack growth and crack\narrestment.\nCrack growth. - Slow crack growth is attained through the selection of 2024 aluminum with its high fracture toughness properties (low notch sensitivity) and by the use of\nlow working stress levels (ref. 6).\nCrack arrestment. - Cracks are arrested by the use of titanium straps at fuselage\nframes, additional spanwise splices, separately attached but closely spaced wing stringers,\nand stiffeners attached to the fuselage shell and bulkheads.\nSignificant Structural Items\nBecause of the high probability of a long fatigue life, the inspection program will\nbe started rather late in the service life. Also, because the structure is fail-safe, the\ninspections can be spaced somewhat farther apart than those on older types of aircraft\n(ref. 7).\nThe selection of the significant structural items to be inspected is based on the\nknowledge and experience with past programs and the manufacturer\'s assessment of the\nmost fatigue- and corrosion-sensitive structure. It is necessary, therefore, to define\nthe following two steps:\n(1) External structural members are designed to crack before complex or hidden\njoints, doublers, frames, and so forth. This "controlled failure" approach was developed\nand confirmed by many component tests. For example, over 300 fuselage skin splice\nspecimens were tested to assure skin external crack failures (fig. 21).\n188\n\n(2) Internal members, if cracked, are designed to eventually propagate the crack\nthrough to the external members so that the crack becomes externally detectable. The\nslow crack growth provides sufficient time to inspect and detect cracks before failure,\nand crack arrestment and the two-bay-crack residual strength of the design provide adequate fail-safe strength.\nInitial Inspection and Intervals\nThe inspection plan has been designed to detect crack initiation, early signs of corrosion, and manufacturing variabilities (preload). The statistical approach was used to\nobtain a feel for the effect of fatigue variability (ref. 8) and fracture roughness characteristics. The variabilities required the use of knowledge gained from the DC-8 and DC-9\nsuccessful service experience.\nThe plan of inspection for structural fatigue critical items is listed below:\n(1) External items receive 100-percent inspection at periodic intervals.\n(2) Internal items, with external detectability, receive 100-percent inspection externally at periodic intervals.\n(3) Major load-carrying internal items, without external detectability, are inspected\nas frequently as the external items.\n(4) Other load-carrying internal items, without external detectability, receive only\nsampling inspection.\nThe inspection and maintenance program for the DC-10 is designed to assure maximum vehicle airworthiness at minimum cost.\nCONCLUSIONS\nTo date, both the DC-8 and DC-9 fleets have been flown with only a few isolated\nfatigue failures in the primary structure; this fact is significant because high-time DC-81s\nhave accumulated about 48 000 flight hours and 28 000 landings, and DC-9\'s have recorded\n32 000 landings.\nThe DC-10 is a third-generation jetliner and, therefore, is expected to be superior\nto its predecessors because of the following factors:\n(1) Crack-free life of 60 000 flight hours\n(2) Slow crack growth and arrestment\n(3) External detectability in main load-carrying structure\n(4) Completed development testing during initial design\n189\n\n(5) Detail design and fatigue procedures based on past experience\n(6) Working stress levels and deflections based on accurate design\n(7) Fatigue critical areas recognized in planning stage\n(8) Full-scale tests reveal weak links and check performance.\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Picard, J.; and Morris, R. C.: FORMAT II \xe2\x80\x94 Second Version of Fortran Matrix\nAbstraction Technique. AFFDL-TR-66-207, Vols. I and III.\n2. Warren, D. S.: Applications Experience With the FORMAT Computer Program.\nDouglas Paper 5095, presented to the Second Air Force Conference on Matrix\nMethods, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio, Oct. 15-17, 1968.\n3. Stone, M.: Fatigue and Fail-Safe Design of a New Jet Transport Airplane. Douglas\nPaper 3342, presented to the International Committee on Aeronautical Fatigue\n(ICAF) Symposium, Munich, Germany, June 16-18, 1965.\n4. Swift, T.; and Wang, D. Y.: Damage Tolerant Design-Analysis Methods and Test Verification of Fuselage Structure. Presented to the Air Force Conference on Fatigue\nand Fracture of Aircraft Structures and Materials, Miami, Florida, Dec. 15-18,\n1969.\n5. Speakman, E. R.: Fatigue Life Improvement Through Stress Coining Methods. Douglas\nPaper 5516, presented at AIAA Meeting in Los Angeles, California, July 14-16, 1969.\n6. Schijve, J.: National Aerospace Laboratory NLR, Amsterdam, Fatigue of Aircraft\nStructures, presented at the Twelfth Israel Annual Conference on Aviation and\nAeronautics, Mar. 1970.\n7. D. J. Maxwell\nRoyal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, Hampshire,\nUnited Kingdom\nSUMMARY\nThe paper describes the methods adopted in the United Kingdom to ensure the\nstructural integrity of military aeroplanes and helicopters from the fatigue point of\nview. It describes the procedure adopted from the writing of the specification to the\nmonitoring of fatigue life in service, and outlines the requirements to be met and the\nway in which they are satisfied. It also indicates some of the outstanding problems\nthat remain to be solved.\nINTRODUCTION\nThe formal airworthiness requirements for the design of military aircraft and\nhelicopter structures against fatigue are contained in the Ministry of Aviation Supply\'s\npublication AvP 970. This document lists a number of mandatory requirements\ntogether with advisory leaflets as to how these requirements may be satisfied. Although\nthe mandatory parts, which are written in fairly general terms, are still valid, the\nadvisory leaflets, written mainly in 1958-1959, are now a little out of date and do not\nalways agree with current practice. The object of this paper is to describe the existing\nprocess of ensuring an acceptable fatigue performance including both the satisfaction of\nthe mandatory requirements and the subsequent monitoring of that performance in\nservice.\nHowever, before starting the main part of the paper it is worth indicating how the\nStructures Department of the Royal Aircraft Establishment, which is part of the\nMinistry of Aviation Supply, is involved in the various phases of an aircraft\'s development and operational use. Its activities can be summarized as follows:\n(a) Making critical comments on the initial specification from the Ministry of\nDefence, who is the customer, and the early brochures from the manufacturers. These\ncomments are made through the Project team in the Ministry of Aviation Supply, which\nis the procurement authority.\n(b) Interpreting the aircraft usage in terms of load spectra by discussions with the\nMinistry of Defence and the manufacturers.\n213\n\n(c) Agreeing with the manufacturers, as required by AvP 970, on the extent of\nfatigue testing to be done.\n(d) Agreeing with the manufacturers after completion of fatigue testing on the service life to be promulgated to the Ministry of Defence through the Project team.\n(e) Acting as technical adviser to the Project team in discussions on fatigue arising\nin service.\nIt is clear therefore that Structures Department has a hand in every phase of the aircraft\'s life.\nTHE GENERAL PROBLEM\nThroughout the sequence of operations, the general fatigue problem will be considered under three basic headings:\n(a) The determination of the loads/stress spectra experienced by various parts of\nthe structure\n(b) The determination of the fatigue performance of various parts of the structure\n(c) The estimation and monitoring of the service life\nIn general, the procedure will be considered in two phases:\n(a) The design-development phase, that is, up to the aircraft\'s entrance into\nservice\n(b) The production and service phase\nFirstly, fixed-wing aircraft designed on safe-life principles will be considered; secondly,\nfixed-wing aircraft that are essentially fail-safe; thirdly, helicopters which are invariably designed safe-life; and lastly, fail-safe helicopters.\nWRITING THE AIRCRAFT SPECIFICATION\nWhen the fatigue life specification is written, two important aspects need to be\ncovered. Firstly, the role or combination of roles for which the specified life is required\nmust be described in sufficient detail to enable load spectrum estimates to be made.\nThis description is extremely important, as contractual compliance with the fatigue life\nrequirements will be determined by tests under these load spectra. Thus, the requirement should indicate\n(a) The types of role in which the aircraft will be operated (that is, route flying,\nground-attack, marine reconnaissance, etc.) and the proportion of time\nspent in each role\n214\n\n(b) Flight profiles anticipated (heights, speeds)\n(c) Operating weights and stores to be carried\n(d) Numbers of landings\n(e) Numbers of pressurizations\nSecondly, it must be made clear whether the required life is the minimum to be\nachieved in the stated mixture of roles or whether it is the average life to be achieved.\nThis definition of the life determines whether the life is to be achieved under the most\nsevere spectrum or under an average spectrum, estimated from the stated usage.\nDETERMINATION OF LOAD SPECTRA\nAt the beginning of the design-development phase, the load spectra for the aircraft\nare estimated for the specified utilisation. The estimates are obtained mainly from\ndata collected from previous aircraft. Toward the end of this phase, the estimates may\nbe modified by loads measured on prototype aircraft. The loads to be considered\ninclude those discussed in the following paragraphs.\nGust Loads\nThe gust loads are estimated from the flight profiles quoted in the aircraft specification by using mainly discrete gust data with rigid-body response giving centre-ofgravity accelerations. For larger aircraft some allowance is made for flexibility. The\nuse of power spectral methods to estimate gust loads in terms of centre-of-gravity\naccelerations is under consideration. The same discrete gust data are used to estimate\ntailplane and fin loads. Fin load frequencies are arbitrarily multiplied by 3 to allow for\nDutch roll type of response and to allow for some manoeuvre content.\nManoeuvre Loads\nManoeuvre loads again are obtained in the form of centre-of-gravity accelerations.\nThey are compiled mainly from the load spectra collected from fatigue (load) meters\n(counting accelerometers) on previous aircraft flying similar roles with some allowance\nwhere necessary for different design limit values of centre-of-gravity acceleration. If\nnew types of role are envisaged, manoeuvre loads must be estimated by consultation\nwith the operators. Manoeuvre loads are mainly of significance for the wing and fuselage but may also be important for the tailplane. Attempts have been made on some\naircraft to calculate the tailplane loads required to initiate the centre-of-gravity accelerations of the manoeuvre spectra. In general, such calculations suggest that peak loads\nof about twice the magnitude of the tail balancing loads for the manoeuvre under consideration are obtained.\n215\n\nGround-Air Cycle\nUntil recently this ground-air cycle, a once per flight cycle, which is mainly of\nimportance for the wings has been considered to range from a lower limit given by the\ndown load generated by a 1.2g acceleration while taxying under maximum take-off load\nto an upper limit occurring in the Ig level flight condition. It is now considered that a\nmore realistic allowance for the ground-air cycle is obtained for transport and heavy\nbomber aircraft if the upper limit of the cycle is taken as the Ig condition plus the positive load occurring once per flight. In addition, it recognised that the once per flight\ndown load for this class of aircraft is likely to be between 1.3g and 1.4g rather than 1.2g.\nThe ground-air cycle is normally considered to be unimportant for fighter-attack aircraft where negative manoeuvres in flight give greater down loads than those experienced\non the ground.\nGround Loads\nEstimates of ground loads are, of course, of primary importance for the fatiguelife assessment of the undercarriage, but the loads transmitted to the rest of the structure can also be important for the top surfaces of wings and fuselages of large aircraft.\nMany modern transports and heavy bombers have undercarriages on or near the fuselage.\nConsequently, the top surfaces of the large-span, fuel-filled wings are in tension on the\nground. The alternating stresses generated by ground loads can therefore cause fatigue\nproblems in the top wing surfaces. Similarly, bending loads in the long fuselages can\nproduce fatigue-prone regions. In general, little data analogous to the gust and\nmanoeuvre data exist. At present, methods of measurement and analysis of such loads\non development aircraft are difficult and no operational recorders are available.\nAlthough power spectral methods of analysis are giving some indication of the vertical\nloads likely to be experienced, little has been done to calculate side loads, which may be\nextremely important for the undercarriage.\nLocal and Acoustic Loads\nLocal loads include such loads as those due to flap and airbrake operations. Estimates of sound pressure levels for acoustic loads can be made once the engine type and\nconfiguration are known.\nCONVERSION OF LOAD SPECTRA TO STRESS SPECTRA\nThe structure is examined in detail and at all stations considered to contain possible\nfatigue problems, the local stresses corresponding to the various parts of the load spectrum are calculated. In general, rigid body conditions are used, but some allowance for\n216\n\ndynamic effects is made if it is thought that the stress levels will be significantly\naffected. In the later stages of the design-development phase, the stress calculations\nare supplemented by flight measurements on prototype aircraft. The importance of\nknowing the utilisation pattern in some detail again becomes apparent since the centreof-gravity accelerations of the load spectrum must be associated with the correct weight\nand flight conditions to obtain the corresponding stresses. Hence, an estimate must be\nmade of where in the flight the accelerations are most likely to occur.\nASSESSMENT OF FATIGUE PERFORMANCE\nThe initial assessment of fatigue performance is by a calculation using Miner\'s\nhypothesis to evaluate the lives of those components for which the stress spectra have\nbeen determined together with S-N curves appropriate to the type of component and\nmaterial considered. In general, manufacturers use their own S-N data based on tests\non previous aircraft with components similar to those proposed for the new model.\nWhere such curves are not available, either the basic material curves are used with\nsome allowance for stress concentrations and other effects or some typical curve such\nas those in the Royal Aeronautical Society/Engineering Sciences Data Unit Data Sheets.\nIn particular, the Heywood joint curve A, Data Sheet E.05.01 is regarded as a good\nstarting point for calculations on aluminium alloy structures. Parts shown by the initial\ncalculations to have marginally acceptable lives are tested under realistic load sequences\nof the required stress spectrum.\nASSIGNMENT OF PROVISIONAL SERVICE LIFE\nAt this stage, the end of the design-development phase, there will be a number of\nprototype aircraft flying and production will be about to start. In order to provide some\nsafeguard for early flying until the major fatigue test is completed, provisional fatigue\nlives are assessed on the basis of the calculations and test results available at this time.\nThe life of the aircraft as a whole will be determined by the life of the most critical\nirreplaceable component. Within that life, other components may need replacing. In all\ncases lives will be calculated by using the average spectrum for the sortie, or mixture\nof sorties, required and either the standard S-N curves or the later component tests.\nThese lives will then be the lives one would expect for average components, and must be\ndivided by the following factors:\n(1) By 2 to account for inaccuracies in calculation and component tests compared\nwith full-scale (major) tests. This factor is based on a paper presented by Raithby to\nthe I.C.A.F. in 1961 (ref. 1) which showed that lives based on component tests and calculations usually overestimated the lives subsequently achieved on the full-scale test.\n217\n\n(2) By a factor varying from 3 3 to 5 depending upon the number of specimens\ntested. This factor is essentially to allow for scatter. In this context, since the standard\nS-N curves are usually based on a large number of results a scatter factor of 33 is used.\nThe greater uncertainty compared with results based on the component tests is usually\nallowed for by using what are thought to be conservative S-N data.\n(3) By a factor of 1.5 to allow for variations in load spectrum from aircraft to aircraft flying the same role, when it is assumed that the calculated life is based on an\naverage spectrum. This factor is not required if the provisional life is to be monitored\nfor individual aircraft by the fatigue meter or some other method of recording individual\nvariations of load spectrum. If it is decided to use the fatigue meter to monitor the provisional life, a formula will be derived as described subsequently, but unless the major\nfatigue test is likely to be delayed or the particular aircraft are going to fly consistently\nin a severe role, it is normal to wait for the results of the major fatigue test before\ndeveloping the fatigue meter formula.\nTHE MAJOR OR FULL-SCALE TEST\nIt is now recognised that lives based on calculations or component tests are likely\nto be inaccurate. This condition exists partly because the loads on the particular components considered are difficult to assess accurately owing to the complex nature of the\nstructure and partly because of the difficulty of pred\'cting which are in fact the critical\ncomponents. It has therefore become a matter of policy to carry out tests either on the\ncomplete structure or on the major components (complete wing, fuselage, fin, etc.). In\nthe latter case, all parts of the structure must be covered.\nThe test specimen is normally an early production airframe to ensure that detail\ndesign and manufacturing standards are comparable with those of service aircraft. The\nload spectrum is again derived from the utilisation pattern in the specification. However,\nby this time some flight load measurements should have taken place on prototype aircraft\nso that more knowledge should be available, for example, on the dynamic response of the\naircraft, and should lead to more realistic relationships between local stresses and\ncentre-of-gravity accelerations.\nUsually the loads are applied in realistic sequences by using many load levels.\nFor transports and heavy hombers this procedure results in flight-by-flight loading so\nthat ground-air cycles are interspersed with flight loads and in most cases, a ground\nload spectrum also is applied. In addition, on some of these aircraft, the manoeuvres\nand gust loads have been applied in a random order between the ground-air cycles.\nThese realistic sequences are intended to ensure that the changing residual stress\n218\n\npatterns around the stress concentrations which are known to affect fatigue life, but\nwhich at this time are not taken into account in theoretical assessments, are reasonably\naccounted for on test. The random load sequence of gusts has another advantage over the\nmore common block programme in that it is easier to use a large number of load levels\nbecause there is no fixed pattern for each flight and hence no need to choose intervals\nof load that result in finite numbers of each level per flight. This procedure enables a\nbetter representation of a continuous stress spectrum to be made than can be achieved\nwith the usual block programme. The flight-by-flight representation is not always used\non fighter-attack aircraft if the negative flight manoeuvres impose bigger down loads\nthan those on the ground.\nThe test is normally carried on to the "factored" required life unless prior catastrophic failure occurs. If no such failure has taken place, a review is made and frequently the test is continued for another factored life or to failure to allow for any\nextension of life in service beyond that anticipated at the design stage.\nINTERPRETATION OF MAJOR FATIGUE TEST\nThe failure or failures that have occurred under the known loading on test have to\nbe related to the load spectra experienced in the various roles in service and safety\nfactors applied to allow for scatter. For each failure, the following procedure is adopted:\n(1) The S-N curve used to estimate the life of the failed item in the designdevelopment phase is adjusted by factoring the stress scale until the calculation using the\nstress spectrum applied on the test gives the test life to failure.\n(2) This adjusted S-N curve is then used to calculate the lives to be expected in the\nvarious service roles, using Miner\'s hypothesis and the anticipated spectra. The same\ncurve is used to derive the coefficients of the fatigue meter formulae which are obtained\nby the method described by Phillips. (See ref. 2.) The use of these formulae is\ndescribed subsequently.\n(3) The lives for each role and the coefficients of the fatigue meter formulae are\nthen divided by the factor to allow for scatter in performance. In general, only one\nspecimen will have been tested so that according to the recommended factors in\nAvP 970 a value of 5 should be used, but in practice, a factor of 3 3 has been used for all\nlives based on major tests. Although this procedure is difficult to justify theoretically,\nit was considered reasonable in view of the greater certainty obtained from this type of\ntest. As there has been no regular shortfall in achieved service life that could be\nattributed to this cause, the practice has been allowed to stand. It should nevertheless\nbe recognised that it is extremely difficult to obtain feedback of service data on which to\nbase a reliable correlation analysis.\n219\n\n(4) The lives for each role are divided by a further factor of 1.5 to allow for variations of load spectrum experienced by individual aircraft flying the same role. This\nfactor is not applied to the fatigue meter coefficients as the meter registers the individual variations.\nIt should be emphasized that the utilisation pattern originally laid down should\nrepresent as nearly as possible the anticipated usage in service because the fatigue test\nis based on this pattern and although estimates can be made for other patterns, as shown\nabove, the accuracy of prediction is likely to fall when the new patterns deviate markedly\nfrom that used on test.\nFAIL-SAFE STRUCTURES\nThe procedure described is aimed primarily at preserving the safety of safe-life\ntype structures which can fail without prior warning. A similar procedure is also necessary for fail-safe structures, which are defined as those in which fatigue cracks or\ncomponent failures can be found before the strength falls to an unacceptable level. As\nthe whole concept of fail-safe stands or falls by the ability to detect cracks early, the\nimportance of ensuring that all cracks can be found cannot be overstressed. Hence, it\nis essential to obtain as much information as possible from the full-scale test on the\nprobable location of cracks. Thus, the full-scale test is as important for fail-safe\nstructures as for the safe-life type although the emphasis is different.\nThe test should first demonstrate that the structure really is fail-safe, that is,\nthat at no time during the service life is there likely to be an undetectable major failure.\nThe main dangers are design errors leading to an early unexpected catastrophic failure\nor the accumulation of many small failures late in the life which are insignificant and\ndifficult to detect individually but which may suddenly join to give a catastrophic failure.\nThe long riveted joints of pressure cabins are particularly vulnerable to this latter type\nof failure as the skin experiences similar stress cycles at all rivet locations. Hence,\nsmall cracks, which will almost certainly escape detection, are likely to form at about\nthe same time along the rivet line, and these may suddenly join into one long, possibly\ncatastrophic crack.\nThe second purpose of the test is to show which are the likely areas of cracking,\nwhen the cracks are likely to occur and how fast they will propagate. This information\nwill enable inspections to be started early enough and to take place frequently enough to\nensure safety. In addition, the actual inspection techniques can be developed on the\ncomplete built-up structure.\nIn order to show that no catastrophic failures will occur during the required life,\na fail-safe structure is required to be tested to the same factors on life as a safe-life\n220\n\nstructure. In order to demonstrate that cracks are fail-safe, a crack must be allowed\nto propagate on test for three inspection periods after it has reached the shortest length\nthat can be found with certainty under the inspection method to be used. At the end of\nthat time it must sustain 80 percent of the ultimate load.\nThe demonstration of the residual strength characteristics poses a practical problem. The 80 percent ultimate load cannot be applied at the end of the crack propagation\nphase if the test has not reached the factored required life because if it does not survive\nthe application of the load, the specimen is lost or severely damaged and if it does survive, the rest of the test will be invalidated because of the unrepresentative residual\nstress pattern generated by this exceptionally high load. The usual technique is to run\nthe crack for three inspection periods or until the crack is considered long enough just\nto sustain the test load. (In this case a shorter inspection period will be imposed in\nservice.) The crack is then repaired with a patch and the test continued. At the conclusion of the test the patches are removed one at a time and the 80 percent ultimate load\napplied. This is clearly not entirely satisfactory but no completely satisfactory solution has been found. In some cases it may be possible to simulate the relevant cracks\non the static test specimen if this is still available and apply the test load to that, but\ncare must be exercised to ensure a crack tip that is typical of fatigue.\nThese requirements ensure safety but it is also necessary to ensure a reasonably\neconomic aircraft. It is therefore a requirement that the first crack shall not appear on\nthe weakest aircraft from a fatigue point of view before half the specified life has been\nachieved and that the amount of repair work shall not become uneconomic on the weakest\naircraft before the whole specified life is achieved.\nHence it can be seen that the test requirements are similar for both fail-safe and\nsafe-life aircraft. Therefore, although the designer is encouraged to design fail-safe\n(if he believes his design to be fail-safe he is at liberty to use lower factors in the design\nto allow for scatter than he would for safe-life design), the structure is judged on its\nperformance in the test, such failures that occur being judged on their merits. Failures\nwhich can be considered fail-safe will require inspection in service starting at the factored life, followed by repair or replacement only if they occur, whereas safe-life failures require either modification of the failed item or retirement of the whole structure\nat the factored life.\nMONITORING IN SERVICE\nThe object of monitoring in service is to relate the load spectra experienced by\nindividual aircraft to the failures that occur on the fatigue test. In order to assess the\nservice load spectra, each aircraft is equipped with a fatigue (load) meter, which is a\n221\n\ncounting accelerometer recording the number of times each of eight levels of centre-ofgravity acceleration is exceeded. The actual levels recorded depend upon the type of\naircraft, there being a number of standard instruments, but usually there are five levels\nabove Ig and three below. These instruments are read after every flight and the counts\nrecorded together with information on the type of sortie, take-off and landing weight,\nstores carried, number of pressurizations and any other details considered relevant to\nthe consumption of fatigue life.\nThere are then three main methods of using this information: the fatigue meter\nformula, role lives, and total number of occurrences of a particular event, each of which\ntells the operator to initiate some action. Each method relates a failure under the known\ntest loading to the loads experienced in service with the appropriate factors. If the failure on test is safe-life, reaching the factored life means either that the item must be\nreplaced or that the complete structure must be retired. If the failure is fail-safe,\nreaching the factored life means that inspection must start. These inspections continue\nat a frequency determined by the same methods; that is, the individual load spectra are\nrelated to the test loadings during the crack-propagation phase so that inspection periods\nmay fluctuate in time depending upon usage. In practice, inspections are called for either\nat fixed time intervals to coincide with normal scheduled maintenance or when the monitoring system indicates an inspection to be due; it is usually possible to ensure that most\ninspections occur at scheduled maintenance periods.\nOf the three methods of assessing the fatigue life, the fatigue meter formula is\nconsidered to be the most accurate and is used when the stress levels at the monitored\nstations can be related to centre-of-gravity accelerations. This usage usually covers\nwing stations and fuselage stations affected by longitudinal bending. The operator is\nsupplied with a formula consisting of coefficients by which to multiply the counts\nrecorded on each flight at each level of g, together with overall factors depending upon\ntype of sortie, take-off and landing weight, stores carried, etc. He thus calculates flight\nby flight a steadily increasing number which is a measure of fatigue damage. When the\nnumber reaches a certain value, he initiates the appropriate action, either retirement or\nstart of inspection. In the early days of fatigue meter formulae, one simple set of coefficients was used to monitor the one safe-life failure that determined the ultimate life\nof the structure. Today, with fail-safe structures it may be necessary to monitor a\nseries of possible failures, inspections for which will start at different times. In addition, with the large variety and weight of stores that can be carried, it has become necessary to allow for relatively large variations in the relationship between stress at the\nstation to be monitored and the centre-of-gravity acceleration recorded. Hence it is\nsometimes necessary to have a series of formulae and correction factors for one aircraft.\n\n222\n\nThe second method of monitoring, role lives, is used to cover periods of flying in\nwhich the fatigue meter is unserviceable or to monitor parts for which the fatigue meter\ncounts have no relevance but for which it is known that the load spectrum varies with the\ntype of sortie, or role flown. In this method, the load spectra are first estimated for\neach type of flight (in the case of flying with an unserviceable meter these are obtained\nby analysis of other aircraft records on similar sorties). The factored lives are then\ncalculated by using Miner\'s hypothesis and the adjusted S-N curve derived from the test.\nIt should be noted that if average load spectra are used, the factor of 1.5 for variation\nwithin the same sortie must be included. Each hour\'s flying is then divided by the\nfactored life in the role to give the fraction of damage done. When these fractions add\nup to 1, the appropriate action is taken. When used to cover periods of meter unserviceability, the operator is given a coefficient based on this fraction by which to multiply the\nnumber of hours flown in each role and this number can be added to the number obtained\nfrom the fatigue meter formulae.\nThe third method of monitoring is the simplest and can be used when the fatigue\ndamage in a part is due entirely to one operation, say pressurization, when the life to\n"action" is given in terms of the numbers of occurrences of that operation. Again the\ntime to action by the operator is based on the number of such cycles to failure in the\nfatigue test with the appropriate factor. In the case of pressurization, if the test is carried out by using maximum pressure differentials for every cycle and all pressurizations\nrecorded in service are assumed to be to maximum differential, the factor used is 31\nOne byproduct of the recording of fatigue meter readings after every flight together\nwith the type of sortie flown is that the load spectra are analysed on a sortie basis and\nused in estimating load spectra for future aircraft.\nIn general, it is felt that although the fatigue meter has provided and is still providing an extremely valuable method of monitoring fatigue life in service, more elaborate\nmethods are required to cope with the changes in the stress and centre-of-gravity acceleration relationship that now occur on most aircraft. Moreover, some monitoring system must be developed for areas such as the tailplane, fin and undercarriage for which\nmethods of monitoring are still in the exploratory stage and for which there is little or\nno operational data on load spectra.\nTHE GENERAL PROBLEM OF THE HELICOPTER\nIn general, the approach to the fatigue problem in the helicopter is based on the\nsame concepts as those used for fixed-wing aircraft; that is, the load spectrum and\nfatigue performance for each component must be determined and its life estimated and\nmonitored in service. In the helicopter, however, most of the critical items are\n223\n\ncontained in the rotating parts and their controls and these parts are subjected to fluctuating loads even under steady flight conditions. Therefore, large numbers of cycles\nare accumulated in a short time, and there is a consequent shift of emphasis to the\nfatigue behaviour at the low stress end of the S-N curve. This shift of emphasis results\nin one of the main differences between fixed-wing aircraft and helicopter requirements;\nall the factors are on stress instead of on life as factors on life become meaningless\nwhen the S-N curve is nearly horizontal. The fact that stress cycles are generated even\nduring steady flight has its impact on the estimation of load spectra. It is clear that in\norder to have any reasonable life at all, stress cycles in steady-flight conditions must\nbe below the fatigue limit. Therefore, the life is determined principally by occasional\nexcursions of the stress-cycle magnitude above the fatigue limit which are usually found\nto occur during a few transistory manoeuvres and short periods in a few flight conditions\nsuch as at high speed. Determination of load spectra becomes a process of defining\nthese manoeuvres and flight conditions, estimating the frequency with which they will\noccur, and estimating the magnitudes and numbers of cycles occurring in each of the\nmanoeuvres or flight conditions specified.\nTHE DESIGN-DEVELOPMENT PHASE FOR THE HELICOPTER\nEssentially, the same information needs to be written into the customer\'s specification for the helicopter as for the fixed-wing aircraft, that is, life required, types\nof sortie to be flown, operating weights, and stores to be carried. However, the estimation of load spectra from this requirement is in terms of frequencies of occurrence of\nthe various critical manoeuvres and flight conditions. Owing to the lack of measured\noperational data, these values have to be estimated from a consideration of how the\nhelicopter is going to be used. However, with the present state of knowledge it is virtually impossible to calculate the stresses arising in the many components associated\nwith the rotating parts and their controls during these critical manoeuvres and flight\nconditions. Consequently, at the design stage, the stresses calculated for steady cruise\ncondition are multiplied by 1.5 and maintained below the fatigue limit of the factored\nS-N curve. Past experience has shown that this method provides a reasonable design\nstarting point. The S-N curve used is either a relevant one from tests on similar components from a previous helicopter or a material curve with allowance for stress concentrations, etc. The factor at this stage is 2 on stress.\nDuring development, the loads and stress spectra are steadily acquired by progressive flight measurement on an extensively strain gaged prototype helicopter. Simple manoeuvres are flown, and stresses are measured, related to the appropriate S-N\ndata, and assessed for safety. The helicopter is then cleared for the next more complex\nmanoeuvre. At the same time S-N data are built up by constant-amplitude tests on the\nmore critical items.\n224\n\nHELICOPTER FATIGUE SUBSTANTIATION\nThe final life substantiation is based on flight measurements of stress, S-N curves\nobtained either by constant-amplitude tests or programme-load tests factored to allow\nfor scatter, and calculations using Miner\'s hypothesis.\nIn order to obtain the stress spectrum for each component, each of the manoeuvres\nor flight conditions considered likely to produce fatigue damaging cycles is flown at\nleast three times. In those conditions where the three flights give widely different\nresults, more measurements are made. In the first analysis only the maximum stress\ncycle is associated with each manoeuvre or flight condition and it is conservatively\nassumed that this cycle occurs at the typical frequency of the stress cycle in that component for as long as the manoeuvre exists. For those components and flight conditions\nwhere the subsequent fatigue analysis shows this analysis to give unacceptably low lives,\na more elaborate analysis takes place which provides a spectrum of stress amplitudes\nto be associated with that flight condition. The total stress spectrum can then be\nobtained for each component by using the frequencies of occurrence of each manoeuvre\nor times spent in each flight condition estimated from the specification together with the\nmeasured stress amplitudes for these manoeuvres and conditions. To allow for variations in stress from helicopter to helicopter when flying the same manoeuvres, the measured stresses are usually multiplied by a factor of 1.2.\nThe S-N curve for each component is obtained in most cases by testing at least\nsix specimens under constant-amplitude loading; normally three specimens are tested\nat each of two stress amplitudes. A curve of predetermined shape based on past experience is then drawn through the mean values of life obtained in each of the two groups\nand this curve is factored on stress values to allow for scatter. When six or more\nspecimens have been tested, a factor of 1.6 is used for light-alloy components, and\n1.4 steel and titanium. (The figure for titanium is provisional, being based on limited\ndata.) Where less specimens have been tested, higher factors are used. It is considered that gear boxes show less scatter than other components; therefore, a factor of 1.4\nis used if one gear box is tested and 1.3 if four or more specimens are tested. These\nfactors are appreciably bigger than those quoted in AvP 970, but are based on the latest\ninformation on scatter and current practice.\nThe fatigue life is then determined by using Miner\'s hypothesis except that a value\nfor\nof 0.75 is used. When the maximum stress amplitude in the whole stress\nspectrum is below the fatigue limit of the factored S-N curve for that component, the\nitem is considered to have a virtually infinite life. The fatigue limit for light-alloy\nspecimens is taken as that stress amplitude giving a life of 10 9 cycles and for low and\nmedium strength steels, that giving 5 x 10 6 cycles. Where testing of light-alloy\n\nIN\n\n225\n\ncomponents has only been taken to 5 x 10 6 cycles, a factor of 1.35 on stress is used to\nestimate the fatigue limit.\nFor components experiencing a complex load history, it is considered advisable to\ntest under a mixed load level to simulate more nearly the actual conditions, although the\nloads will be increased to allow for scatter and to obtain failures in a reasonable time.\n(This procedure is in contrast to fixed-wing practice where tests are conducted under\nreal loads for factored times.) The results are used to locate the mean S-N curve for the\ncomponent in the same way as for fixed-wing aircraft; that is, a predetermined shape of\nS-N curve is factored in the stress direction until the cumulative damage calculation\ngives the mean life achieved on test under the known loads.\nMONITORING HELICOPTER LIFE\nAt present there are no monitoring instruments for the helicopter analogous to the\nfatigue meter for the fixed-wing aircraft. Therefore, all components are assigned safe\nlives in flying hours. Although the helicopter is used in many roles, there has been no\nattempt as yet to define different lives for each role or record times spent in each role.\nConsequently, lives have been assessed in whichever role is considered to be most\nsevere for the component under consideration and those lives considered to be the\nretirement lives irrespective of the subsequent usage.\nFAIL-SAFE FOR THE HELICOPTER\nIt is clear from the previous two sections that in many ways there are greater difficulties in estimating safe lives for helicopters than for fixed-wing aircraft. The lives\nare very dependent upon a few transistory loads occurring during certain flight conditions\nand manoeuvres. The flight conditions themselves are not easy to define accurately and\nthe magnitudes of the loads within those conditions are likely to vary considerably\ndepending upon pilot technique and state of maintenance of the helicopter. Moreover,\nhelicopters of the same type are used for a wide variety of jobs; hence, variations in life\nof similar components are liable to be very large. In addition, minor damage such as a\nsmall score can result in a drastic reduction in life as the large number of cycles of\nstress otherwise below the fatigue limit are thus raised to a level where they add to the\ndamage. In the circumstances, designs to fail-safe principles are highly desirable from\na safety point of view.\nIt is often thought that this concept with its implication of redundancy can only be\nobtained at the cost of extra weight. It has been found in fixed-wing aircraft that this is\nnot necessarily the case and, in fact, once the principles of design detail have been\n226\n\nmastered, there may actually be a saving of weight in those areas of the structure\ndesigned by fatigue because lower factors to allow for scatter can be used in the design\nof fail-safe parts than could be used if those parts were safe-life. This condition occurs\nbecause it becomes no longer necessary to ensure that fatigue initiation probability\napproaches zero, the only criterion on frequency of fatigue failure being the economic\nones of maintenance and repair costs. The fact that so many of the helicopter rotating\nparts are fatigue designed and the variations of loading from aircraft to aircraft are so\ngreat and yet there are so few fatigue failures in service suggests that there may be\nappreciable overdesign and therefore significant weight saving to be gained by fail-safe\ndesign as well as the added safety.\nAt present, there are no requirements for fail-safe for helicopters in AvP 970,\nbut there should be no basic problem in writing such requirements in general terms.\nIndeed, the approach would be identical to that used for fixed-wing aircraft; namely, that\nany failure shall be found before the residual strength falls below an acceptable value.\nHowever, the real problem, once the principles of fail-safe as defined by the requirements are fully understood, is one of detail design and it is here that the main attack must\nbe made if the advantages of fail-safe design are to be realised. In addition, since the\nearly detection of failures or cracks is vital to fail-safe, it would be worth putting more\neffort into the development of inspection techniques. This effort may involve special\nsystems for particular parts, such as the blade inspection method developed by Sikorsky\nin which the blade is inflated and cracks detected by loss of pressure. However, it must\nbe remembered that helicopters frequently operate in relatively primitive conditions so\nthat simple techniques are required.\nFUTURE WORK\nThe procedure described in this paper for coping with the problems of fatigue in\naircraft structures which has evolved over the years has maintained an acceptable standard of safety. Nevertheless, every step in that process contains problems that could lead\nto inaccuracies. As the customer demands longer lives for his expensive aircraft, the\nneed for better life estimation is of paramount importance, both for the safety of safelife aircraft and the economy of fail-safe aircraft.\nThe areas in which effort is still needed can be considered in two main groups:\nthose associated with defining the load-stress spectra and those concerned with the\ndetermination of fatigue performance. If the load-spectrum problems are considered\nfirst, wing loads and fuselage bending loads are reasonably served by the fatigue meter;\nthis meter monitors loads on individual aircraft and provides operational data. However,\nwith the wide variation in the stress and centre-of-gravity acceleration relationship\n227\n\npossible in modern aircraft because of the high rates of fuel usage, and the large range\nof stores carried, some more direct method of obtaining stress spectra is required. If\nsuch methods should be developed for operational use, they would be invaluable in monitoring fatigue life consumption of fins, tailplanes, undercarriages, and possibly even\nhelicopter components, although in the latter case there is an additional practical problem\nof recording outputs through rotating machinery. In the event of monitoring by direct\nstress measurement being developed, it may be found that the process of feeding back to\nthe design stage will be more difficult than that for current monitoring methods using\ncounting accelerometers, bearing in mind that for both systems allowance must be made\nfor the response characteristics of the aircraft on which the measurements were made\nbefore these measurements can be applied to the new aircraft. This procedure is\nalready used to a large extent for response to turbulence, and the power spectral approach\nused in this connection is being applied to estimating undercarriage loads. However,\nmore work needs to be done in relating the theoretical work in this field to measurements in flight and during ground operations.\nThe problems associated with fatigue performance will now be considered. The\noutstanding need is for a new cumulative damage hypothesis that takes sequence effects\nand fretting into account. With the greater understanding of the effects of residual\nstresses around stress concentrations, it is hoped that methods of accounting reliably\nfor the former will not be too long delayed. In view of the increasing tendency to design\nfail-safe, there is a need for more work on methods of predicting crack propagation rates\nin complex structures under variable loading and the residual strengths of the cracked\nstructures.\nIt is unlikely that even improved methods of estimating initiation time, crack propagation rates, and residual strengths will enable us to dispense with the major fatigue\ntest. However, such improvements may help in the simplification and interpretation of\nthis test. There are a number of questions in this connection that still require further\nattention. Firstly, to what extent can the time-consuming low-level stresses be omitted?\nSecondly, what should be the magnitude of the biggest load applied in test? What precisely is the effect of a load equal to or greater than proof load on the subsequent\nbehaviour and can this effect be counteracted in any way ? This consideration is important in solving the problem of proving the residual strength of a cracked structure.\nTo summarize, it is considered that work will be required in the following areas:\n(1) Theoretical work on dynamic response giving load and stress distributions\n(2) Development of flight measurement and analysis techniques to check and modify\nthe theoretical assessments\n\n228\n\n(3) The development of operational monitoring devices measuring stress directly.\nThese devices may be expensive and consequently limited to use on a few aircraft.\n(4) The development of monitoring devices that can be used on every aircraft to\nmeasure parameters that can be related to the stresses measured on the more elaborate\ninstruments. It is considered essential on military aircraft that some monitoring device\nis used on every aircraft as the variations in load spectra on aircraft in the same role\ncan be very large.\n(5) Development of new cumulative damage theories to account for sequence effects\nand fretting\n(6) Development of methods of predicting crack-propagation rates in complex\nstructures under variable loading\n(7) Development of methods of predicting residual strengths of cracked structures\n(8) Assessment of what stress levels should be included in fatigue tests under\nrealistic loads\n(9) The development of aircraft capable of sustained supersonic flight means that\nmore work will be needed in the fields of estimating, measuring, and monitoring stresses\ndue to thermal effects, and interpreting their influence on the fatigue problem.\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Raithby, K. D.: A Comparison of Predicted and Achieved Lives of Aircraft Structures.\nTech. Note No. Struct. 301, Brit. R.A.E., 1961. (Paper presented at I.C.A.F.\nSymposium on Fatigue (Paris), May 1961.)\n2. Phillips, d.: Formulae for Use With the Fatigue Load Meter in the Assessment of\nWing Fatigue Life. Tech. Note No. Struct. 279, Brit. R.A.E., 1960.\n\n229\n\nPRECEDING PAGE BLANK NOT FILMEdM9^2_ ?9901\n\nA PROPOSED USAF FATIGUE EVALUATION PROGRAM BASED\nUPON RECENT SYSTEMS\' EXPERIENCE\nBy G. P. Haviland and G. F. Purkey\nAeronautical Systems Division, U.S. Air Force\nUnited States\nSUMMARY\nThe United States Air Force has published a document entitled, "Aircraft Structural Integrity Program" (ASIP). One phase of the program is concerned with the\nfatigue life certification of all types of military aircraft. The document describes the\ncriteria, analyses, and tests that are necessary in order to satisfy the USAF fatigue\nlife requirement. The authors have noted that some recent and valid criticism has\nbeen directed toward the document, particularly the fatigue-life requirements contained\nin it. This paper proposes some changes based on surveys conducted in the United\nStates and abroad as well as some recent systems\' experience. The surveys covered\nboth military and civilian organizations. The paper contains the fatigue certification\ncase histories of selected military and commercial aircraft. The design development\nelement tests, preproduction design verification tests, and full-scale fatigue tests of\neach are described. The paper concludes with a brief status report on the revisions to\nthe MIL-A-008860 series specifications.\nINTRODUCTION\nIn 1965, Miller and Lowndes presented a paper before this group entitled "The\nU.S. Air Force Weapon Systems Fatigue Certification Program." (See ref. 1.) Their\npaper described the evolution of the USAF fatigue life requirements up to that time.\nOne section of the paper listed the aircraft which were considered to be the first line\nsystems of the USAF in 1965. These aircraft are as follows:\nFighters\n\nBombers\n\nTrainers\n\nTransport\n\nF-89\n\nB-47\n\nT-37\n\nC-130\n\nF-100\n\nB-52\n\nT-38\n\nC-133\n\nF-101\nF-102\n\nB-66\n\nKC-135\n\nF-104\nF-105\nF-106\n231\n\nOf these only the following aircraft were committed to a fatigue evaluation program:\nFighters\n\nBombers\n\nTrainers\n\nTransport\n\nF-101\nF-104\nF-105\nF-106\n\nB-47\nB-52\n\nT-37\nT-38\n\nC-130\nC-133\nKC-135\n\nFive years later, the first line systems of the USAF are as follows:\nFighters\n\nBombers\n\nTrainers\n\nTransport\n\nF-100\nF-105\nF-106\nF-4\nF-5\nF-111\nA-37\n\nB-52\nFB-111\n\nT-37\nT-38\n\nC-130\nKC-135\nC-5\n\nOf these currently operational systems, every one except the F-4 has undergone the\nU.S. Air Force fatigue evaluation program. The F-4 was procured by the U.S. Navy and\nhas not been required to conform to Air Force Aircraft Structural Integrity Program\n(ASIP). It is also acknowledged that the F-100 although not originally designed or tested\nunder any formal program has required several life extensions. Each one has been\napproved after additional fatigue testing. It is interesting to note that all aircraft now in\nour inventory have undergone a fatigue evaluation program of some kind. This statement\nwas not true 5 years ago. With this as an introduction, we wish to expand on the USAF\'s\nfatigue evaluation program and how it has changed over the last 5 years.\nHISTORY OF STRUCTURAL EVALUATION PROGRAM\n1965 to 1968 Period\nFigure 1 shows a typical structural evaluation program of the 1965 to 1968 time\nperiod. (Also see refs. 2 and 3.) At that time, ASIP required element and component\ntests, but the number and specimen sizes were left to the contractor\'s discretion. The\nstatic test, flight loads survey, and the first fatigue test were run concurrently. After\ninitial operational capability (IOC) the program called for service-loads determination followed by a second fatigue specimen to be tested to the service-loads spectrum. At that\n232\n\ntime, it appeared to be a good plan and the requirements formalizing the program were\nwritten as an ASD Technical Report 66-57 "Air Force Structural Integrity Program\nRequirements," dated January 1968 (ref. 4) and into various specifications and contracts.\nFor those of you who are satisfied with your program now, please note that in 1968 we\nbelieved that this program was the best in the world. Events proved us to be wrong.\n1968 to Early 1970 Period\nIn September 1968 the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Research and\nDevelopment, Dr, Flax, requested that a study be performed addressing problems associated with structural test program planning and with scheduling practices. (This study\nis referred to as the Flax study.) Briefly restated, the action items were\n(a) Examine current Air Force structural test procedures and policies for aircraft\nin development.\n(b) Assess structural test program scheduling problems.\n(c) Assess past and present structural testing to determine problems or deficiencies\nin established policies and procedures.\n(d) Provide recommendations to revise present Air Force structural test verification practices and policies, considering proper balance between program risks and costs.\nThe approach used in the Flax study was to prepare case histories of the then current systems and a number of typical earlier systems on which information was available.\nIncluded in the study were such data as original test schedules, the details of static and\nfatigue tests, actual start and completion of the tests, and the production rates. The case\nhistories were carefully studied to establish trends and to identify problem areas. With\nthese thoughts in mind, let us consider the actual structural program schedules of some\nof the Air Force aircraft that were used in the study.\nThe first aircraft is a large transport, the C-141. Figure 2 shows the schedule.\nThe C-141 comes as close as any airplane to fulfilling the total ASIP requirements. It\nhas a static test, structural flight tests, full-scale fatigue tests of two articles, and a lifehistory recorder program, the data from which are being used for the second fatigue test.\nFigure 2 refers to fatigue test articles A, B, C, D, and E which are shown pictorially in\nfigure 3.\nThere were a large number of engineering changes generated by the C-141 fatigue\ntest program. Most of them were incorporated in production but very late in time. You\ncan see that there were essentially no component tests.
