Doty\nThe Boeing Company, Seattle , Washington, U.S.A.\nSUMMARY\nFor supersonic airline operations, significantly higher environmental temperature\nis the primary new factor affecting structural service life. Methods for incorporating\nthe influence of temperature in detailed fatigue analyses are shown along with current\ntest indications. Thermal effects investigated include real-time compared with shorttime testing, long-time temperature exposure, and stress -temperature cycle phasing.\nA method which allows deSigners and stress analyzers to check fatigue resistance\nof structural design details is the primary theme of this paper. A more communicative\nrating system is presented which defines the relative fatigue quality of the detail so that\nthe analyst can define cyclic-load capability of the design detail by entering constant-life\ncharts for varying detail quality. If necessary then, this system allows him to determine\nways to improve the fatigue quality for better life or to determine the operating stresses\nwhich will provide the required service life.\nA supersonic vehicle structure , which is subject to major airload center-of pressure shifts as well as to the addition of thermal-gradient stresses to mechanical\nstresses, experiences a relatively large percentage of damage from ground-air-ground\n(GAG) cycles. In studying the Ig thermal-gradient history of a design detail , the analyst\nwill produce a Ig stress history. Application of simple factors to this history allows\ndetermination of dynamically instantaneous maximum and minimum stresses statistically\nrealized once per flight which represent the GAG cycle. The relationship of GAG damage to total damage on various parts of the vehicle is used to facilitate a quick fatigueresistance check.\nA quick fatigue- check method for deSigners and stress analysts benefits the design\nby making designers and stress analysts more cognizant of fatigue problems throughout\nthe detail design phase of an aircraft development.\nTHE PROTOTYPE TASK\nAt the 1967 ICAF meeting in Melbourne, Australia, the philosophy and scope of an\nintegrated program of analysis, development testing, and verification testing for the\nAmerican supersonic transport (SST) were presented. Since that time the program has\ndeveloped to the point where the prototype configuration is being designed and fabricated.\nFigure 1 shows the SST in take-off and cruise configuration and figure 2 gives an idea of\n\n365\n\nthe structural configuration. Attention to fatigue and fail-safe requirements in the detail\ndesign of the prototype will assure a structure representative of the 50 000 flight hour\nand 20-year service life design goal for a production SST.\nIf a total SST program schedule is reviewed, the significant location of the prototype job becomes apparent. Figure 3 presents the essential schedule elements. A 30to 40-year time span is needed to include a 20-year operating period. The prototype\ndesign release, which is labeled NOW on figure, comes fairly early in the program after\na company study period, a research and competition period, and a prototype design development period. Careful planning and implementation of investigation programs with\nextensive testing will provide the required structural confidence for the production design.\nFor the prototype, fatigue resistance representative of production design must be engineered into the structure with a strictly fundamental analysis without a great depth of\ntitanium structural component tests. This paper presents the basic tools used along\nwith discussion of the significant factors affecting fatigue and how they are accounted\nfor in the prototype design.\nGood fatigue design is most effectively accomplished when both designers and design\nanalysts understand and implement fatigue requirements in the drawing release process.\nDesign analysts on the SST prototype are required to check their designs for production\nrequirements specifying 50 000 flight hours of normal usage. The projected composite\nairplane usage includes 49 250 hours of revenue service used in 22 000 flights and\n750 hours of training containing 1500 full-stop landings and 2600 touch-and-go landings.\nApplication of these service life requirements in addition to other loads criteria truly\nmakes the prototype design an exercise in production design.\nThe fatigue analysis procedure, made available to the design analyst in handbook\nform, allows him to determine the service life capability quickly. A rating system which\ngives the relative fatigue quality of a design detail so that the analyst can determine\ncyclic-load capability by entering constant-life charts for varying detail quality is presented. Consequently, he can determine whether to improve quality for known life\nimprovement or to establish operating stress levels which will provide satisfactory\nservice life. With a minimum of experience with different details, an engineering understanding of relative fatigue values is developed.\nTHE SUPERSONIC TRANSPORT FATIGUE PROBLEM\nIn the transition from subsonic to supersonic transport operations, the major new\nparameter influencing structural fatigue resistance is elevated-temperature exposure.\nThere are many other more subtle influences in this operational transition, but the\nthermal environment necessitates development of new tools for fatigue-performance\nevaluations.\n366\n\nFigure 4 shows schematically a comparison of equidistant subsonic and supersonic\ntransport operations. The supersonic mission is clearly a high-speed high-altitude type\nof operation with a lower percent of time spent in cruise operation. High-altitude operation puts the SST in a less damaging gust environment during cruise. Also, because the\nSST must be designed for efficient high-speed supersonic cruise, the effects of relatively\nlarge center-of-pressure shifts between the subsonic and supersonic operation are apparent on this type of vehicle. When the relative parts of the damage resulting from gust,\nmaneuver, taxi, take-off, landing, and ground-air-ground (GAG) operation are considered,\nit is apparent that a large part of fatigue damage will be due to the GAG cycle on critical\nparts of the primary wing and body structure. This conclusion is used to advantage in\ndeveloping a simple fatigue-check procedure.\nThe subsonic operation produces no significant thermal environment but supersonic\noperation at Mach 2.7 subjects the airplane to a stagnation temperature of 500 0 F. Figure 5 shows the stabilized temperatures existing during cruise. Realizing that the mission requires climb and acceleration into and finally descent and deceleration from such\na condition, the design analyst knows that fatigue analysis must account for many thermal\neffects. For convenience in the development of analytical procedures, the total thermal\neffect will be evaluated as thermal-gradient loading, long-time temperature exposure,\nand an interrelated cyclic exposure of stress and temperature.\nAfter analysis of projected operational SST route structures, a mean mission was\nselected to establish representative fatigue damage for the SST prototype structural\ndesign. Figure 6 shows the details of this mission. The consequences of this operation\non a structural detail are illustrated in figures 7 to 9. Figure 7 shows a typical 1g stress\nand external temperature history at a wing lower surface location. Figure 8 shows the\nthermal-gradient stress and temperature history as it will develop on two types of typical\nwing surface structures. Figure 9 shows a combined total stress and temperature history for the structural detail being analyzed. The design analyst studying the load and\ntemperature effects on any structural detail will prepare these histories to understand\nhis problem. These histories provide him with the initial tool leading into the fatiguecheck procedure.\nThe first step in the analysis procedure is to define the stress level of a primary\nGAG cycle from the data obtained in producing figure 9. It is not the intent of this report\nto discuss in detail the criteria loadings for gust, maneuver, taxi, take-off, and landing.\nHowever, with a clear definition of a GAG cycle, a statistical factor can be determined to\napply to the maximum and minimum stresses of figure 9 to establish dynamically instantaneous maximum and minimum stresses that are realized 1000 times in 1000 flights.\nThese factors, indicated in figure 9, are used by the design analyst to establish the stress\nlimits of a primary GAG cycle.\n367\n\nFrom the general aspect of fatigue analysis the analyst now has viewed the effects\nof the thermal cycle associated with supersonic flight and has established the GAG\nstresses for his design detail. It is now important to again realize that temperature is\nthe primary new factor affecting fatigue and that the balance of the factors affecting\nfatigue are handled in the same manner as those on subsonic transports. Consideration\nof the primary factors affecting service life will point out how they are evaluated and how\nthe effect of the thermal cylce is included in the analysis.\nFACTORS AFFECTING SERVICE LIFE\nBased on broad scope categories, the primary factors influencing service life of an\noperational vehicle are\n(1) Selection of structural material\n(2) Type of design and fabrication\n(3) Service reliability\n(4) Operational environment\nEach of these categories is handled in a particular manner to facilitate the application of\na fatigue-check procedure at the point of drawing release.\nAll factors associated with the SST mission, service life, and vehicle production are\nconsidered in selecting the structural material. Annealed Ti-6A1-4V was selected as the\nprimary structural material because good fracture and fatigue properties are combined\nwith a good strength-weight ratio, particularly in the SST operating environment. Highstrength steels, as applicable, augment the primary structural material. For analysis\npurposes, after the selection decision, the material is represented by S-N curves for\nvarying quality of structure. In addition, when considering service reliability, the level\nof backup test and service knowledge for the material and type of detail application influence the selection of reliability factors.\nType of design and fabrication with its many facets is controlled in this procedure\nby establishing a detail fatigue rating (DFR) number. Effectively, the DFR of a design\nwill direct the analyst to the correct quality of S-N data for determining the service\nlife. Surface finish, fabrication techniques, geometric design details, fastener installations, and design assembly patterns are typical influencing factors determined by the\ntype of design and fabrication. Based on test data and service experience, DFR values\nare determined with formulas or established in charts.\nService reliability must account for the variability of fleet statistics, loading environment, test representation, and structural material properties. In a well defined\nloading environment on a fail-safe design detail with good test and service background,\n368\n\nthe analyst can consider going as low as 2.0 for a fatigue reliability factor (FRF) to be\napplied to specified life for analytical life requirements. As background data becomes\nminimum in the design of a good fail-safe structure, FRF values of 4 to 6 are required.\nIn cases where fail-safe design is difficult or impossible, safe-life design must be developed with FRF values twice those that would be required for fail-safe design. For the\nanalysis procedure, FRY values are specified in general terms and the design analyst\nconsults with fatigue specialists if further refinement is necessary.\nThe operational environment is usually well defined at the current state of development of specifications and investigation studies. Gust, maneuver, taxi, take-off and landing criteria for the SST are very much like that required for subsonic vehicles with fairly\nwell defined adjustments to account for SST operation. The airline operation effects are\nincluded by developing a pattern of missions to represent the total scope of SST operation.\nThe means of including all these effects in determining service life are practically the\nsame for subsonic and supersonic operation and have been developed from a history of\nsubsonic transport operation. The new influence on service life not significantly present\nin subsonic operation, is the thermal cycle associated with a Mach 2.7 transport. The\neffects of this thermal cycle require special attention to assure a proper accounting in\nanalytical procedures.\nENGINEERING THE TEMPERATURE EFFECTS\nInvestigations of thermal cycle considerations required for Ti-6A1-4V structure in\nenvironments in the region of 5000 F indicated that developing the following areas of influence will properly account for the thermal cycle: real-time and short-time test correlation, long-time temperature exposure, and phase-cycle relationship of temperature and\nstress. As indicated in figure 9, the mechanical stress and thermal-gradient stress are\nadded directly when studying the history of stress with temperature on a design detail.\nConsideration of these factors shall provide the corrections necessary to account for\nthermal effects.\nTemperature and time have always been two variables strongly related in establishing material properties. Some indication of real-time and short-time test correlation is\nshown in figure 10. Initial testing reported under this Department of Transportation contract began in 1963 and is continuing at this date. The program data shown here was\ndesigned to compare a 65-minute flight cycle with three accelerated tests. An accelerated load spectrum was run at 900 F constant temperature, 5000 F constant temperature,\nand a 900 F to 500 0 F cyclic temperature. The accelerated tests on sheet and extrusion\nmaterial both showed a deterioration in life at higher constant temperature and also\nshowed deterioration at cyclic temperature, although not as great as at 500 0 F constant\ntemperature. Real-time tests have completed in excess of 36 000 flight cycles, only one\n369\n\nsheet specimen out of a total of 12 sheet and extrusion specimens failing. These test\nresults encourage further analyses with a hope that accelerated tests may correlate with\nreal-time tests somewhere near a factor of one. Testing is continuing and other tests\nare underway to augment this data.\nThe effect of long-time temperature exposure was conveniently included in the\nbasic S-N data by developing the data with specimens previously exposed to 500 0 F for\n500 hours. This procedure is justified by data shown in figures 11 to 13. Figure 11\nshows the ratio of exposed to unexposed cyclic maximum stresses and gives 10 5 cycles\nof life at a stress ratio R = 0.06 for Ti-6A1-4V baseline specimens heat soaked for the\nindicated hours and then tested at room temperature. Figure 12 shows the same ratio\nfor Ti-6A1-4V lap joints with varying fastener installations exposed to both load and temperature for 500 hours and 1000 hours. These data demonstrate a reduction in allowable\nstress for equivalent life with temperature exposure for 500 hours. Further exposure\nproduces little change. Figure 13 shows results of similar more extensive testing conducted in Ti-8A1-1Mo-1V center-notched specimens exposed to both steady-state and\ncyclic load and temperature. In this case subsequent fatigue testing is at 500 0 F after\nthe specified exposure. With varying exposure up to 20 000 hours cyclic and 30 000 hours\nsteady state, all data, independent of how much exposure, falls into a reasonable scatter\nband. For analysis of the SST prototype, this type of data justified a convenient, 500 0 F,\n500 hours (3 weeks) exposure before life testing. Thus, the effect of long-time temperature exposure is included in the S-N curves used for fatigue-check analysis.\nIn the accelerated test data of figure 10 with the same maximum temperature, there\nis an indication that fatigue life improved over that at constant temperature when temperature and stress were both cycled. From many sources the data of figure 14 establishes\na life ratio curve for life at constant elevated temperature. A comparison in figure 15 of\nthis curve with data from tests wherein temperatures were cycled in phase with stress,\nshows an improvement in fatigue life for the 0 0 phase difference stress-temperature\ncycle. Extending this basic idea through all phase-angle differences develops the life\nratio factor rl of figure 16 as a means to correct service life computations for variations of the phase angle between stress cycles and temperature cycles. The design analyst reviewing his temperature and stress history, in addition to determining GAG stress\nlimits, must determine the maximum temperature and the significant phase-angle difference between his stress and temperature flight cycle.\nIn order to engineer temperature effects into a simplified fatigue-check procedure\nfor prototype design, the following guidelines are offered:\n(1) Accelerated test procedures can be established to assure real-time and shorttime test correlation near a factor of one.\n\n370\n\n(2) Long-term temperature exposure is accounted for by exposing test specimens\nfor\n\nS-N data to 500 0 F for 500 hours and then testing at room temperature.\n\n(3) The stress-temperature cycle phasing correction factor\naccount for the balance of temperature effects.\n\nTJ\n\nof figure 16 will\n\nTOTAL DAMAGE RE LA TED TO GAG DAMAGE\nSince a method has been provided for the design analyst to define the primary GAG\nstress cycle, one key to establishing a quick fatigue-check procedure is to relate total\ndamage to GAG damage on the elements of primary structure. By extensive use of computer programs to define internal load distribution and conduct fatigue analysis on discrete parts of typical primary structure, the ratio 6 of GAG fatigue damage to total\nfatigue damage can be determined. Typical plots of the GAG damage ratio developed\nfor handbook use are shown for the wing lower surface in figure 17 and for the body sections in figure 18. It is now possible to set up a simple formula which determines a\nnumber of GAG cycles NGAG which will produce equivalent total fatigue damage.\n\nNGAG = nGAG\n\n(FRF)\n7]15\n\nwhere\nnumber of cycles to produce equivalent total fatigue damage\nthe number of flights in which the primary GAG cycle is determined for a\n50 000 flight hour service life, or where a primary GAG cycle is not apparent, a number of primary load cycles in a 50 000 flight hour service life for\nwhich the damage ratio 15 is known or can be estimated\nFRF\n\nfatigue reliability factor defined in handbook tables\nratio of fatigue life at stress-temperature cycle phasing to room-temperature\nfatigue life\nratio of GAG fatigue damage to total fatigue damage\n\nSince NGAG , GAG a\n\' and GAG a\nare known, it is now necessary to determine\nMAX\nMIN\nthe proper quality level of S-N data which can be used to determine service life.\n\n371\n\nRATING OF STRUCTURAL DETAILS\nIt has been common practice to rate structural details by determining apparent\nstress concentration factors Krr and using S-N curves with the same apparent stress\nconcentration factor to determine fatigue life of that detail. Many textbook and handbook\nsources are available to determine apparent stress concentration factors. For communication to the design analyst, who likes to do his thinking with loads, load paths , and\nstresses, Krr gives some feel for fatigue quality but does not necessarily provide good\ncommunication. High values of apparent stress concentration KT give low values of\nservice life. The quantity Krr defines some local magnification of stresses that reduce\nlife. Although for calculation purposes the detail fatigue ratings (DFR) defined in this\n\nreport depend on values of KT\' DFR values are a more useful communication term with\nan engineering feel closer to the design analyst\'s pattern of thinking.\n\nuMAX\n\nThe DFR number found useful in this report is defined as the maximum cyclic stress\nin a constant-amplitude loading cycle at which the design detail will withstand\n\n10 5 cycles at a stress ratio R of 0.06. This stress ratio is a convenient testing ratio\nand 10 5 cycles represents a re liability factor of 4 on 25 000 flights, which is near the\nfatigue life range of Significance on the SST prototype. Figures 19 and 20 show ranges\nof value of the DFR number for various detail coupon tests and for various lap joint tests,\nrespectively. If this DFR number is plotted against l/Krr for variations in a type of\nstructural detail, it will develop, within test scatter, as a straight line, as shown in figure 21. Consequently, for the convenience of the design analysts, tables can be produced\nwith governing constants specified for various design details. Somewhat more convenient,\nas more test data and experience develops, charts similar to figure 22 are prepared and\nadded to the analysis handbook.\nFor communication purposes the DFR number communicates a stress number; the\ngreater it is, the better the fatigue quality. A value of 65 ksi is high quality in Ti- 6Al-4V\nstructure and is achieved in basic skin- stringer structure with high-quality fastener\ninstallations. Low-quality values can go below 20 ksi in the low-quality joint installations.\nThe Significance of the DFR number in specifying S-N data is illustrated in\nfigures 23 and 24. Figure 23 is a set of S-N curves for a DFR of 30 ksi and figure 24 is for a DFR of 45 ksi. In each case this rating number establishes the relative quality of each set of curves by being the u\ngiving 10 5 cycles at R::: 0.06.\nMAX\nIf on each plot the design analyst considers a design detail for which he has determined\nGAG u\n= 50 ksi and GAG u\nMIN = 20 ksi, the service life variation is apparent.\nMAX\n\n(UM1N\n\nis the minimum cyclic stress.) At DFR\n\n= 30\n\nksi, the fatigue life is about\n\n5 x 10 4 cycles; at DFR = 45 kSi, the fatigue life is about 2 x 10 5 cycles.\nquality provides four times the fatigue life.\n372\n\nThe higher\n\nCONSTANT-LIFE CHECK CHARTS\nAfter development of a family of S-N curves for a range of design quality, it is a\nsimple procedure to prepare detail fatigue-check charts for a range of constant-life values. As shown for N = 10 5 cycles in figure 25, this procedure allows a plot of the two\nvariables, GAG AMAX and DFR, in a form most useful to the design analyst. These\ntwo variables plot as a family of lines for different values of stress ratio. With a family\nof these detail fatigue-check charts covering the range of cyclic interest, interpolation\ncan be conducted for a design detail at any NGAG to establish the required relationship\nof DFR and GAG AMAX at a known value of R.\nThe design analyst can enter the fatigue-check charts with either UMAX or DFR\nand determine important design trades. Entering the chart with a calculated cyclic\n\'MAX might represent a case where a desired level of working stress is apparent from\nother design considerations. Figure 26 illustrates this case and points out the design\nterms established for the case where N = 200 000 cycles. The ordinate value defines\na minimum detail quality required for this c\' MAX . If DFR is actually higher or lower,\nthe design analyst moves up or down the R value line to determine an appropriate allowable AMAX . Entering the chart with a trial DFR is illustrated in figure 27. In either\ncase the design analyst can quickly determine the value of improving his design quality\nor of changing his cyclic stress level.\nFATIGUE ANALYSIS PROCEDURE\nThe fatigue-check procedure is made available to each design analyst on the SST\nprototype by a structural fatigue handbook. By management directive, a design has not\nbeen structurally reviewed unless it has been checked for its repeated load environment\nas well as for its strength and stiffness requirements. Unless a specific exception can\nbe justified for prototype only, the prototype design details shall qualify for the specified\nproduction service life of 50 000 flight hours.\nTo illustrate the fatigue-check procedure, assume the design analyst is looking at\na wing lower surface skin-stringer detail forward of the rear spar at buttock line (BL) 550.\n(See fig. 17.) He would like to use standard rivet installations in order to minimize\nassembly costs. The procedure would be\n(1) Following through the segmented sections of the mean mission of figure 6, computations of internal load distribution and the gradient effects of the thermal cycle will\nproduce a normal operating stress and temperature history similar to that of figure 9.\nFrom such data the primary GAG stress cycle is determined as\n\'MAX=25ksi(R=-0.5)\n373\n\nAlso from a plot similar to figure 9 it appears that the stress-temperature phase relationship is near 90 0 with a maximum temperature of 430 0 F.\n(2) It is now necessary to determine the number of GAG cycles NGAG that will\nproduce equivalent total fatigue damage. By referring to figure 16, the stresstemperature cycle phasing correction is\n77\n\n= 0.85\n\nBy referring to figure 17, the GAG damage ratio is\n5 = 0.80\nFrom handbook tables and test data considerations, the fatigue reliability factor for this\ndetail in Ti-6A1-4V is\nFRF = 5.8\nConservatively, including full-stop landings in the number of required flights,\nn GAG - 23 500 cycles\nConsequently,\nR\n\nNGAG - nGAG F bF = 200 000 cycles\n(3)With N GAG and oMAX at R = -0.5 known, the design analyst enters figure 26 and determines the minimum DFR required to provide 50 000 flight hours of service life; that is, a required DFR of 40 ksi.\n(4) With the geometric, fabrication, and installation details, the design analyst must\ndetermine the actual DFR. From figure 22,\nActual DFR of 56 ksi > Required DFR of 40 ksi\nTherefore the installation provides more than satisfactory service life. If surrounding\ninstallations are compatible, weight may be removed from the installation by increasing\nstress levels to match the actual DFR. The weight reduction is only possible if static\nstrength and stiffness requirements will permit.\nIf testing or previous experience had not provided a chart of DFR values for this\ninstallation, the structural fatigue handbook would have provided the constants needed in\nfigure 21 to calculate an actual DFR. By the use of this procedure the design analyst can\ndevelop an understanding of the stress or detail quality modifications necessary to qualify\nfor service life.\n374\n\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\nA fatigue-check procedure requiring minimum additional effort is proposed for use\nby design analysts who must review structure and "firm up" design details before drawing\nrelease. The concept presented here satisfies part of the need of leaving the designer of\nstructural details cognizant of the good and bad points of design for service life.\nAs compared with subsonic transports the primary new environment variable\ninfluencing fatigue design on the American SST is the thermal cycle associated with a\nMach 2.7 cruise speed. The effects of this thermal cycle can be included in fatiguecheck procedures by accounting for real-time and short-time test correlation, long-time\ntemperature exposure, and phase cycle relationship of temperature and stress. Because\nof the SST type of operation, relatively large parts of fatigue damage develop on wing and\nbody primary structure from ground-air-ground (GAG) cycles. By determining the relationship of GAG damage to total fatigue damage on typical primary structures, fatiguecheck procedures can be greatly simplified.\nBy using a detail fatigue rating (DFR) designated by a maximum cyclic stress\ninstead of using the apparent stress concentration factor directly, a better communication term is available to evaluate relative fatigue quality of design details.\n\n375\n\n376\n\nc\n\n\'"\nE\n\n<1>\n\n.~\n\'-\n\n<1>\n\n\xc2\xab\n\n.s:::\n\nI-\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\n,\nN\n\n377\n\nV\'\n-.J\n\nco\n\nSST PROGRAM SCHEDULE\n\n1960\'S\nI NOW\n1970\'S\n1980\'S\n8 1 0 11 1 !31 15 16 17 18 191 0 i:l !2 I31 15 16 I 718 1910 11 I 2131 15 I 6 1718 191 0 11\n91\n2\n4\n4\n4\nPROTOTYPE (pT)\nDESIGN CONSTRUCTION\n100 HR. FlI GHT TEST\n\nCOMPANY\nSTUD IES\n\n:\n\nPRODUCTION AND\nAI RlI NE SERV ICE\n\ni\n\n- - -- - - - - - .\n\nRESEARCH AND\nCOMPETITION\n\nI\n\n!\n\nPROOUCTI ON (PO) AI RPLANE\nDEVElOPMENT AND CERTIFICATION\n\nI\n\n:\n\nPT STRUCTURAL DESIGN\n, PT 1ST FlI G\nHT\n\nI\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 PT STRUCTURAL LIMIT LOAD TESTS\n- - PD STRUCTURAL DES I GN\n, PD 1ST FLIGHT\n, FAA CERTIFICATION\n\nI II\n\nNO~\n\n, STATIC TEST COMPLETION\nI\nPROOU CT ION AI RPLANE\nFATI GUE TEST\n\nI:\n\nFigure 3.- SST program schedule.\n\nIIIIIIII I\n\n70\n\nI\n\n60~\n\n50\n\nALTITUDE,\n10-3 FEET\n\n3. 0 ~\n\nI\n\n401\n30\n\nSUPERSON IC\nTRANSPORT\n\nI\n\n2. 0 ~\n\n! ksi.\n\n399\n\n^o\n-50\n\n-40\n\n-30\n\n20\n\n-.2\n\ncn -10\n\nw\n\nm\n\ncn\n\nto\n\n0\n- ksi\nFigure 27 .- Detail fatigue check at N = 200 000 cyc les.\n\n60\n\nYttr.^%k^Ullvu\n\nrr^v^ ^\xe2\x80\x9e^^^ ^ iv v 1 r u,j1l^^ ^^ .\n\nd q\t\n\nEDING PAGE BLANK NOT FI\n\nPRACTICAL ASPECTS OF DESIGNING FOR AND\nEVALUATING STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY\nBy Marcel Peyrony and Daniel Chaumette\nAvions Marcel Dassault\nSaint-Cloud, France\nINTRODUCTION\nThe objective of this paper is not to show the results of very scientific studies,\nbut only to put forward some points which can be of practical use to the designer. The\nfollowing procedures apply generally in the tests discussed:\n(1) Skins are machined, either chemically or mechanically\n(2) Their surfaces are blasted with glass beads and wet sand\n(3) They are given a surface protection and painted\n(4) No bonding is used.\nFATIGUE PERFORMANCE IMPROVEMENT\nIt is well known that bolts with tight fit give a definite increase in fatigue life.\nHowever, this increase is guaranteed only if every bolt is mounted with the right fit\nand if no undetectable fault may change the assumed condition.\nConical Fasteners\nFor a long time we have been using bolts or fasteners with tight fits of 5 to\n30 microns, with very satisfactory results. But it is quite a problem to achieve a\nguaranteed fatigue life of 40 000 hours while saving much weight, especially in the\njoints or in the lower skin of the wing. The search for a higher admissible stress is\nthen a constant undertaking.\nConical bolts had at first sight appeared most interesting. There was indeed\nthe danger of stress corrosion when a tight fit of 90 microns was used with alloys such\nas 2024-T3 and 2014-T6, but riveting on short transverse components is infrequent,\nand less sensitive alloys may be used. A test program was started with two types of\ntest specimens, a "dog bone" type and a lap joint. (See fig. 1.)\nThe first test results (fig. 2) were most encouraging, until a test specimen broke\nafter a disappointingly low number of cycles. A more thorough inspection of the test\npiece (which had been inspected prior to testing) showed a reaming fault as in figure 3.\nThe bolt bears only on four regions.\n405\n\nIt was necessary to determine why this fault existed and why it had escaped inspection. The first problem was easy to resolve. It took many years to learn how to drill\na perfectly circular cylindrical hole. Conical holes, because of their high drilling\ntorques, will surely require still more development and tooling for reliable results.\nWith limited tooling, we succeeded in drilling correct holes up to 6 mm in diameter and\n8 mm deep. But for larger diameters, very rigid jigs and expensive tooling were needed.\nBoth the cost of tooling and the drilling time were found to be prohibitive for an extensive\nconical fastening.\nFurthermore, inspection was most difficult, with the necessity of blueing checks at\nevery hole, which increased the cost of the total operation. Finally, a subsequent test\nwith holes purposely drilled incorrectly showed a dramatic decrease in fatigue life. (See\nfig. 4.) These results, added to the danger of stress corrosion, led to the decision not to\nuse conical fasteners in the Mercure.\nHole Preparation\nIn an attempt to increase the fatigue life of structures, the following processes\nwere examined:\n(1) The way in which the hole is made:\n(a) Normal reaming\n(b) Heli-Armor reaming\n(c) Broaching\n(2) The finish given after reaming:\n(a) Deburring\n(b) Roll over\nSignificant differences were found between treated and untreated holes without rivets\n(fig. 5). On the other hand, once the bolt is set, these differences decrease and even\ndisappear (fig. 6).\nInterference Fit\nOn one hand, interference fit has a positive influence on fatigue life, but on the other\nhand, beyond a certain level of interference (30 microns), fretting under the fastener\nbecomes too important unless special care is taken. Figure 7 shows the type of failure\nin each case. With the free bolt, the crack started in the cylindrical part of the hole, but\nwith the interference-fit bolts, the cracks started by fretting in the countersink.\n\n406\n\nAntifretting Protection\nIn all previously described tests standard sealing and surface protection treatments\nwere used; that is, rivets were wet mounted with PR 1422 or Blendexite and the test\nspecimens were painted with PR 1460 or Cellolac 78-28. Figure 8 shows the effect on\nfatigue life when one of these two protections is omitted. The fatigue life was reduced by\nfretting underneath the fastener collar when the specimen was not painted, and in the\ncountersink when the rivet was dry mounted.\nSelecting Parameters for Mounting a Fastener\nThe results of these experiments led to the selection of the following procedures:\n(1) Use of a moderate amount of interference (bearing in mind the problem of stress\ncorrosion)\n(2) Painting and wet mounting\nThe influence of the way in which the hole is obtained is not so obvious. Broaching\nand Heli-Armor give comparable results, but broaching is an extremely reliable method\nof obtaining holes of a high standard, while Heli-Armor may be less reliable. The\n"miracle" alloy for the best life has appeared to be 2024-T3. (We have not tested\n7075-T73.)\nFAIL-SAFE DESIGNS\nGeneral Considerations\nThe greatest risk of crack initiation is surely incurred in joints. Multiplying stress\nconcentrations by using, for example, riveted reinforcements around door openings should\nbe avoided as much as possible. Integral structures mechanically or chemically milled\nmight seem a good solution, but then the difficult problem of fail-safe design enters the\npicture.\nWe have already made some remarks about this problem at Melbourne, having been\nunfavorably impressed by some examples of so-called fail-safe design, the most classic\nbeing a structure cut in two pieces and bolted back together. Since then the situation has\napparently worsened, judging by the design of some recent tail-unit hinges and controlsurface bearings.\nAre the regulations responsible? It is certain that FAR 25-573 encourages a\ndesigner who does not want to put questions to himself to demonstrate that a structure\ncan sustain the required static load when one of the elements has failed. This test\nallows him to claim that his structure is fail-safe. Moreover, the same paragraph allows\na failure to be considered only partial if it is obvious.\n407\n\nAs far as fatigue is concerned, the basic idea, in itself quite legitimate, of\nassuring security by means of residual strength has been put in a wrong way.\nFatigue and Fail-Safe\nOf course a fatigue test is not a fail-safe demonstration by itself, but it is not negligible in assessing structural fail-safe designs. Also, fatigue testing is a good method\nfor determining inspection schedules for the various parts of the airplane.\nWe do not believe that an element cut in two, but in which cracks appear and grow\nrapidly, is sufficiently fail-safe. What happens to the half of this element carrying the\nwhole load when the other half has broken?\nSome recent mishaps with elements working in parallel should prove of interest.\nOne instance was the F-14 prototype, in which two hydraulic tubes used on separate circuits, but subjected to the same fatigue duty, gave up in a 5-minute interval.\nAnother example of a more structural nature was found during a fatigue test on a\nmilitary aircraft. The main frame supporting the bending moment of the wing was made\nof two rings working in parallel. (See fig. 9.) Cracks appeared and grew almost identically in the two rings, and a rupture occurred in each, the load being then supported by\nthe remaining structure outside.\nAnother example concerns a wing attachment (fig. 10). Cracks grew at the same\ntime from five holes and, what is more, on both wings. To have separated the attachment\ninto halves would only have given a formal fail-safe structure without increasing enough\nthe safety of the design.\nThese problems occurred because the fatigue life was short enough for all the\npieces involved to be damaged. A quite different case appeared in the test of the Mercure\nmain frame. An artificial crack in the flange of the frame grew only on one half of the\nflange, not passing the "wall" of the web, and at a rate low enough to be found in\ninspections.\nHere the stress was lower, and this explains most of the difference. Thus a fatigue\ntest may give important indications for fail-safe designs.\nThere is a still worse method for obtaining fail-safe. Take a beam with an I-section,\nthe tensioned flange of this beam being perfectly smooth, without any hole. Then replace\nthe integral tension flange by riveted flanges, the tensioned area being the same. Failsafe is not definitely guaranteed and fatigue life is severely decreased.\nIf you feel unable to insure safety with such a monopiece structure, you can design\na double load path while avoiding putting rivets in the tensioned zone. You will keep good\nfatigue life and get a double load path at the same time, but perhaps you will have some\ntrouble with fretting or corrosion.\n408\n\nFail-Safe and Unexpected Cracks\nThe double load path finds its soundest justification in unexpected cracks. However,\nthis should not deter the designer from looking at the types of remaining risks and finding\na solution to them. These risks can be defined as flaws in the material, fretting, and\nstress corrosion. With correct designs, care, and inspection these difficulties can be\novercome, and we have to work for that in any possible way.\nImportant Conclusions Regarding Fail-Safe\nCertainly a low stress level is an important factor for fail-safe guarantee. For\nless important elements where weight loss is small, no regrets should be had in designing\nwith important margins for a theoretically infinite life. But this is not enough. During\nthe fatigue tests and after, it is necessary to monitor the crack propagation rates at every\npoint which may be critical. The results should be linked with the inspection schedule of\nthese particular points.\nDouble load path must not be neglected. But its reliability must be assured with\nregard to fatigue considerations as well as corrosion and fretting, and the structure must\nnot be weakened by a bad design.\nOUR FAIL-SAFE APPROACH\nIt must be admitted that we have often used the classic fail-safe methods described\nhere. However, even in these cases we applied the procedures described in the following\nparagraphs to investigate crack propagation.\nPhotoelastic Tests\nFor the Mercure design, we had previously developed tests on photoelastic models\nand on metal parts coated with photostress material (figs. 11 to 13). Thus, we were able\nto study stress concentrations on a particular component, and even on an entire element\nof the fuselage. Also, we were able to determine critical areas where we could provoke\ncracks.\nPartial Fatigue Test\nUsually the area where we want fail-safe capability of a one-piece structure is\ngreatly overdimensioned for fatigue. So we perform tests with normal fatigue loads,\nfollowed by cycles at higher loads. During these tests, cracks must not originate.\n\n409\n\nCrack Propagation\nNext we artificially provoke cracks in critical areas \xe2\x80\x94 that is, areas where calculations and photostress investigations show stress concentrations. (See fig. 14.) The\ncrack growth rate is plotted against time in order to define a schedule of inspections that\nwill provide detection in service before the risk of dangerous failure is encountered.\nThis implies that the tests are based on particular conditions.\nIt is best to have two types of cycles. The first, with only normal fatigue loads, is\napplied on specimens to monitor the crack growth rate. The second, including the same\nnormal fatigue loads, also includes "fail-safe" loads, and is applied on other specimens to\nevaluate the critical length of crack beyond which a static failure may occur.\nAnother possible application for fail-safe design is found in secondary effects (fuel\nleakage, for instance).\nCONCLUSIONS\nThe double load path, although a good fail-safe concept in many cases, is not entirely\nsatisfactory. It may be insufficient when fatigue life is too short, and superfluous when\nthe stress is low, detection is easy, or fail-safe capability is achieved by other means.\nThe best procedure is to rely on crack growth-rate studies and guaranteed crack\ndetection by inspection in service.\nThe use of double load path to cope with unexpected phenomena such as stress corrosion or flaws seems rather makeshift, and it is better to seek specific action (improved\nforgings, inspection, protection) in each case.\nThe easier the inspection, the better for fail-safe.\n\n410\n\nt\'-.\n\n(\'J\n\nI~\n\n+\n\n+1I\n\n+\n+ +1\n+ I\n+ +1\n~\n""\nt\'-.\n\nz\n\ncr::\nw\nW\nf-Ci)\n\n~\n\n......\n\n~\n\n\\Q\n\n0\n\n~\n\nI\n\n\\Q\n\n0\n\n4\n\nL/),\n\n-.0\n\n0\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nf--\n\nZ\n0\nJ\nCL\n\n~\n\n\xc2\xab\n\n~\n\nZ\n\nW\n\n0\n\nen\n(9\n\n0\n\n0\n~\n\nV>\n\nc:\nE\n\n<l>\n\n5}\n\n<l>\n\n\'u\n<l>\n\n\'t;\n\n~\n\n>,\n.....;\n0>\n\n:::J\n\n~\n\n411\n\n/\n\n......\n"""\nN\n\n10\n\n7\n\n1-\n\n--\n\n\'"\n\n<Ed>\n\n3.10 6\neyel es\n\n10\n\n3.10\n\n10\n\n6\nI\n\nn\n\nl::3\n\nI I\n\n5\n\n5\nLOOSE\n(BLIND\n\nFIT\nHUCK\n\nINTERFERENCE\nFIT\n\nTAPER\nLOK\n\nFASTE N ERS )\nFigure 2.- Early results with Taper Lok and classic fasteners in \'\'dog bone" sample of 2014 or 2024-T6 aluminum alloy.
