Burbach\nKrupp Forschungsinstitut, Germany\nThe elastic-plastic deformation behavior under cyclic stress of a number of different engineering materials was experimentally investigated with the aid of highprecision methods of measuring, some of which had been newly developed. (See refs. 1\nto 4.) The report covers, in particular, experiments made with a variety of steels, the\ntitanium alloy Ti-A16-V4, a cobalt (tungsten) alloy, the high-temperature material\nNimonic 90 and Dural (Al-Cu). The theory given \xe2\x80\x94 in an attempt to explain these\nexperiments \xe2\x80\x94 is aimed at finding general formulas for the cyclic stress-strain behavior of engineering materials.\nThe experimental and theoretical investigations made can be summarily described\nas follows:\n(1) Geometric relationships of stable mechanical hystereses at a given variation of\nstress or strain and normal strain-rate dependence at cyclic deformation\n(plain and notched specimens) (refs. 5 and 6)\n(2) Accurate and direct measurement of the second-order elastic constants of\npolycrystals and their influence on the test result\n(3) Accurate balance of elastic and plastic energy in cyclic deformation, particularly in microscopic inhomogeneous plastic deformation\n(4) Spreading of Luders bands in cyclic deformation; phenomena of strain hardening and removal of strain hardening\n(5) Inverse strain-rate dependence for aluminum-copper alloys\n(6) Investigations relating to cumulative damage at irregular cycling of stress.\nThe investigations, unfortunately, showed that cyclic stress-strain curves do not\nprovide sufficient information for developing cumulative damage formulas that are sufficiently accurate from the physical aspect or suitable for engineering application. For\nthis reason, it is not possible for the time being to give up practical simulation of actual\nmaterial stresses with modern fatigue-testing machines.\nThe accuracy of the measurements made is exemplified by the cyclic stressstrain behavior of a round bar specimen with a sharp notch. (See figs. 1 and 2.) The\nstress \xe2\x80\x94 related to specimen cross-sectional area in the notch root \xe2\x80\x94 is plotted against\nthe plastic deformation of the full-length specimen. It is clearly seen how the gradually\n425\n\npropagating crack causes a "nose" in the cyclic stress-strain curves; that is, the opening\nand closing of the crack becomes apparent.\nIn figure 1, the stress given is related to the notch-root cross section. The hysteresis curves shown were written with rising values of the plastic-strain amplitude. Strain\nmeasurement was made as usual at a distance between the edges of the inductive extensometer of 40 mm; thus, the mean value of the inhomogeneous extension was obtained.\nThe test represented by figure 1 was continued in such a way that with (approximately) constant amplitude of plastic strain, cyclic deformation proceeded. Continuation\nof the test eventually led to fracture of the specimen. See figure 2.\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Burbach, J.: A Tensile Machine With a Particularly High Spring Constant. Techn.\nMitt. Krupp, Forsch.-Ber., Bd. 24, 1966, pp. 79-88.\n2. Burbach, J.: The Static Tensile Test. Recent Methods of Metallurgical Investigation.\nVer. Dt. Eisenhuttenleute (Dusseldorf), 1970, pp. 19-36.\n3. Burbach, J.; and Vierling, P.: Experimental and Theoretical Studies of Strain Gauges,\nParticularly With Respect to Their Transverse Strain Sensitivity. Experimental\nStress Analysis (Dusseldorf), VDI-Rep. 102, 1966, pp. 131-136.\n4. Burbach, J.: Unavoidable Influences of the Loading Speed on the Indication of Load\nCells. Precision Measurements With Strain Gauges for Force Measurement and\nWeighing (Dusseldorf), VID-Rep. 137, 1970, pp. 83-87.\n5. Burbach, J.: Recent Investigations on the Plastic Behavior and Fracture Process of\nHard Metals. Techn. Mitt. Krupp, Forsch.-Ber., Bd. 26, 1968, pp. 71-80.\n6. Burbach, J.: Zum Zyklischen Verformungsverhalten Einiger Technisher Werkstoffe.\nTechn. Mitt. Krupp, Forsch.-Ber., Bd. 28, Heft 2, 1970.\n\n426\n\nriAl 6V6\ngekerbte Rundprobe\n\nFigure 1.- Cyclic stress-strain behavior of a notched round bar specimen. Notch angle, 600;\nnotch-root radius, 0.15 mm; notch-root cross-sectional diameter, 3 mm; Ti-A16-V4.\n\nrlAl6V6\ngekerbte Rundprobe\n\nFigure Z.- Continuation of test measurements shown in figure 1 into the cracking stage. Ti-A16-V4.\n\n427\n\n\t\n\nA)^a-ag9^a8\'\n\nPRECEDING PAGE BLANK NOT MMED\n\nA PARAMETRIC APPROACH TO IRREGULAR\nFATIGUE PREDICTION\nBy T. H. Erismann\nFederal Laboratories for Testing Materials and Research\nDubendorf, Switzerland\nSUMMARY\nThe method proposed consists of two parts: empirical determination of certain\ncharacteristics of a material by means of a relatively small number of well-defined\nstandard tests, and arithmetical application of the results obtained to arbitrary loading\nhistories. The following groups of parameters are thus taken into account: the variations of the mean stress, the interaction of these variations and the superposed oscillating stresses, the spectrum of the oscillating-stress amplitudes, and the sequence of\nthe oscillating-stress amplitudes. It is pointed out that only experimental verification\ncan throw sufficient light upon possibilities and limitations of this (or any other) prediction method.\nFUNDAMENTALS OF PARAMETRIC APPROACH\nThe fundamental procedural scheme of the method evolved in this paper consists\nof the following phases:\n(1) Determination of a number of characteristics of the material by means of\nstandard tests\n(2) Prediction of the fatigue life of the material on the basis of these characteristics and an analysis of the expected loading history.\nThe problem thus raised can, in principle, always be solved since for a specified\naccuracy there will always be a finite number of tests from which the necessary data for\na satisfactory processing of the second phase can be drawn. There is, consequently, a\nproblem of interpolation which can be solved with a finite number of base points. The\nquestion remains how to attain the goal economically. In view of the present state of\ndevelopment of servo-hydraulic testing equipment and digital computers, neither irregular stress sequences in the standard tests nor extensive algorithms in analysis and\nevaluation are prohibitive.\nThe progress of our knowledge of fatigue strength has in the last few decades\nbecome an alarming "parameter explosion." Thus, in order to avoid undue complications, no mention will be made of parameter groups connected with notch effect or\nenvironmental influences and nothing but the loading history will be considered.\n429\n\nConsequently, the following effects will be taken into account:\n(1) Mean stress effect (index M), influence of the chronological curve of the mean\nstress\n(2) Interaction effect (index J), influence of systematically occurring correlations\nbetween the effects of mean and oscillating stresses\n(3) Spectral effect (index P), effect of the statistical distribution of the oscillatingstress variations\n(4) Sequence effect (index Q), effect of the sequence in which the individual stress\nvariations follow one another.\nThe parameters linked to these effects will be called in this paper "M.I.S.S. parameters"\nfrom their initial letters.\nOwing to the inherent complexity of the problem, a certain number of simplifying\nassumptions must be made. In particular it is assumed that\n(1) Miner\'s rule is applicable with sufficient accuracy to sufficiently narrow sections of a stress spectrum\n(2) The influence of the mean-stress effect can be described with sufficient accuracy\nby the statistical amplitude distribution of the variations occurring in the mean stress\n(3) Every increment of a loading history produces an incremental interaction effect\napproximately proportional to its mean stress level and to its "linear-damage increment"\n(according to Miner\'s rule)\n(4) The effect of the sequence extends mainly to the "coarse sequence" (that is, to\nchanges of the spectrum over longer periods of the loading history), whereas the "fine\nsequence" (that is, the individual sequence of the single-stress cycles) is of minor importance in practice, provided the process under consideration can be described with sufficient accuracy by stochastic characteristics\n(5) The effects of the M.I.S.S. parameters allow with sufficient accuracy a linear\n(in one exceptional case, a quadratic) interpolation when the logarithm of the "Miner sum"\n\t\n\n(1)\n\nL^ u Ni\n1\n\n(which according to Miner\'s rule should always be equal to 1) is used as the interpolation\nvalue. In equation (1), n i is the number of cycles applied at stress level whereas Nj\nis the total number of cycles to cause failure at stress level.\nIt is not possible here to justify these assumptions. A justification of these assumptions is given in reference 1.\n430\n\nOUTLINE OF THE M.I.S.S. METHOD\nThe method outlined here starts from relation (1); it being clearly understood, however, that a sum not equal to 1 is permissible. In accordance with the assumptions\nmade, the four M.I.S.S. parameters P M , PJ , PP , and PQ are defined and\nf(PM ,PJ ,P P ,PQ ) .\t\n\n(2)\n\nis postulated. This postulation means that the spectrum, as in Miner\'s rule, is still the\nmost important group of parameters, but not the only decisive one.\nThus, the first phase of the method results in the performance of an unequivocally\ndefined series of standard tests with well-defined M.I.S.S. parameters and the determinawhich are to be considered as charaction of the resulting standard Miner sums \t\nL_js\n\nteristics of the material.\nThe second phase, that is, the application to an expected loading history with a\ngiven nominal fatigue life, is divided into the following partial phases:\n(1) Analysis of the loading history according to equation (1). The result is the\nWoehler-Miner sum\n(2) Analysis of the loading history according to well-defined formulae for determining their M.I.S.S. parameters.\n(3) Application of the M.I.S.S. parameters as a means of interpolation in the results\nfield of the standard Miner sums. The result is the Effective Miner sum\n\nvE\n\n(4) Formation of the quotient I /11W which indicates the chances of survival of\nE\nthe specimen. For &/^ W > 1, survival of the loading history is to be expected.\nThe first and fourth phases are carried out according to the known algorithms of\nMiner\'s rule. The interpolation in the third phase must mainly be carried out linearly\nfor log\nFigure 1 shows the interpolation for PM and PJ , with Pp and PQ\n\nI.\n\nheld constant. The heights of the column at its four edges represent the results of four\nstandard tests. The result of the interpolation is the height (heavy dotted line) for PM\nand PJ . Only the standard tests and the stress-history analysis need to be considered\nin more detail.\n\n431\n\nMATHEMATICAL TREATMENT OF PARAMETER GROUPS\nIt would be impossible to give a complete review of the mathematical deductions\n\napplied to obtain appropriate equations for the calculation of the M.I.S.S. parameters.\nIt must be referred, therefore, to more detailed works on the subject. (See refs. 1 and 2.)\nThe following remarks are made in order to give a general idea of the logical structure\nof the method.\nAll the equations used in this connection are based solely on the simplifying\nassumptions made. For instance, the second assumption means only that the mean\nstress effect for given values of the other parameters is determined by the "spectrum of\nthe mean stress" so that Miner\'s rule may be considered as applicable to the mean\nstress. Thus, an extremely simple definition of the mean-stress parameter is obtained;\nthat is,\nIll\n-\t\nP M\t(3)\nN O),\nL.1W\nwhere N o is the number of mean-stress variations of the value a, and N Q is the\ncycle number pertaining to Q according to the Q-N curve. The division by the\nWoehler-Miner sum ^ W is used for normalizing purposes.\nThe spectrum of a loading history is represented in principle by a parabolic\napproximation so that theoretically, three parameters are needed for the mean value, the\naverage slope, and the curvature of the parabola. The first of these parameters, however, is insignificant since in the chosen representation, the mean value of the parabola\nis given. It is a particular feature of the method that the ordinal numbers i of certain\nwell-defined stresses ai are used as values of the independent variable of the approximation so that the respective numbers ni are expressed by\nnl\n\n=c0+c1 \xe2\x80\xa2 i+c2 \xe2\x80\xa2i2. . .\t\n\n(4)\n\nNi 1W\nwhere co , c l , and c 2 are the spectral parameters PP.\nIII more or less analogous way, the parameters for interaction and sequence, P\nand PQ, are deduced from the assumptions made. Both are connected with variations\nof the spectral parameter c l ; thus, predominance of high- or low-stress amplitudes\nunder particular conditions is indicated. Although P establishes a correlation with\nthe mean stress am (taking into account such phenomena as the increased dynamic\nforces due to increased payload of a vehicle), P Q accounts for variations undergone in\n432\n\nthe course of the loading history as a whole (as encountered owing to more frequent overload when an aircraft is transformed from passenger to cargo transport); thus, it serves\nas a safeguard against unpleasant surprises, because many materials have a shorter\nfatigue life when first subjected to low- and then to high-stress amplitudes.\nThe influence of parameter variations upon loading histories is illustrated in figures 2, 3, and 4. In figure 2, the oscillating stresses are not present for negative mean\nstresses because of the choice of constants in the equations. In figure 3 the stress\namplitudes are higher in section II than section I; thus, a higher value of c l is indicated. In figure 4, the variation of c 2 results in predominance either of extreme (high\nand low) or of medium amplitudes. It will be observed that in figure 3, section II shows\nhigher stress amplitudes than section I; thus, a higher value of c 1 is indicated. Variation of c2 results in predominance either of extreme (high and low) or of medium\namplitudes (fig. 4).\nSTANDARD TESTS AND PRACTICAL APPLICATION\nSince linear interpolation of log\t\n\nhas been accepted for all parameters\n\n(excluding c l), variations through all possible combinations other than the meaningless\nones (PM = O i ; PJ + 0) would give 36 base points which can be found from 36 tests\n(plus repetitions). The cost is considerable but is certainly justified for important\nmaterials.\nExperience will show whether all 36 standard tests are really required. The number depends on how far the multidimensional functions of figure 1 can be approximated by\nplane surfaces. If, for example, it should be found that, apart from P P , the function\nsurface can be considered as sufficiently plane, then only the inclinations of this plane\nwould have to be known; that is, for every additional parameter only one single base point\nwould have to be determined and nine tests would suffice. Probably the truth lies between\nthese two extremes.\nAn actual "cooking recipe" for the details of the method is found in reference 1.\nThere the individual steps are not only commented on but are also compiled in tabular\nform so that the economic establishment of suitable computer programs is possible.\nPOSSIBILITIES AND LIMITATIONS\nBy the method described, it is possible to determine the probable fatigue life of a\nZ, material under a given loading history without having to carry out a large number\nof loading tests. As a matter of fact, the standard Miner sums as characteristics of a\nmaterial, together with the u-N curve, should contain enough data to predict the fatigue\n433\n\nlife of a material with sufficient accuracy even in irregular stress sequences. The main\npoint obviously is \'What is meant by "sufficient accuracy" T Of course, the M.I.S.S.\nmethod is more expensive than the determination of a number of u-N curves, although not\nimpossibly so. In return, it refines the results obtained from Miner\'s rule (which are\nderived only from Q-N curves). Only systematic tests with different materials can give\na definite answer. Such tests should prove worthwhile, for even Miner\'s rule in its\npresent form is better than it is usually believed to be. Thus, it should usually be possible to supplement it by introducing additional parameters (mean stress, interaction, and\nsequence) so that the result can satisfy the demands of practice.\nIt must be stressed in this connection that the testing equipment available should be\nimproved in the sense of cheaper and faster execution of large numbers of irregular\nfatigue tests. Only such a development will guarantee in reasonable time the acquisition\nof the information necessary for an efficient verification of the methods proposed here\nor elsewhere.\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Erismann, T. H.: Ein Verfahren zur Abschatzung der Lebensdauer von Materialien\nbei unregelmassigen Belastungsfolgen. Schweizer Arch. angew. Wiss. Tech. 36,\n1970, pp. 57, 103.\n2. Erismann, T. H.: Fatigue-Life Prediction Under Irregular Stress Conditions. J.\nStrain Analysis, vol. 5, 1970, p. 207.\n\nBIBLIOGRAPHY\n1. Miner, M. A.: Cumulative Damage in Fatigue. Trans. ASME, Ser. A, J. Appl. Mech.,\nvol. 67, 1945, p. 159.\n2. Palmgren, A.: Die Lebensdauer von Kugellagern. ZVDI, Bd. 68, 1924, p. 339.\n\n434\n\nlog Z\n.\n\n4,\n\n(3\n\nFigure 1.- Interpolation for PM and PJ.\n\nP =0; P=0\nM\n\nP # 0;\nM\n\nP =0\n\nP 7\'\t\nM\n\nP=1\n\nFigure 2.- Characteristic stress curves for various values of P M and P.\n\nPQ = 0\t\n\nP #\nQ\n\n-\n\n0\n\nQ\n\nFigure 3.- Characteristic loading histories for P = 0 and P\n\nQ # 0 and P M = P\n\n= 0.\n\nC 2< 0\n\nC2>0\n\n\xe2\x80\x94AAAA\t\n\n^^OA\n\nAAA\n\nA"\n\nFigure 4.- Characteristic stress curves for various values of the spectrum curvature parameter c2.\n\n436\n\nNW -ag70\nFRACTURE CONTROL PROCEDURES FOR\nAIRCRAFT STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY\nBy Howard A. Wood\nAir Force Flight Dynamics Laboratory, U.S. Air Force\nUnited States\nSUMMARY\nThis report reviews the application of applied fracture mechanics in the design,\nanalysis, and qualification of aircraft structural systems. Recent service experiences\nare cited.\nCurrent trends in high-strength materials application are reviewed with particular emphasis on the manner in which fracture toughness and structural efficiency may\naffect the material selection process.\nGeneral fracture control procedures are reviewed in depth with specific reference to the impact of inspectability, structural arrangement, and material on proposed\nanalysis requirements for safe crack growth. The relative impact on allowable design\nstress is indicated by example.\nDesign criteria, material, and analysis requirements for implementation of fracture control procedures are reviewed together with limitations in current available data\ntechniques. A summary of items which require further study and attention is\npresented.\n\n"Fracture Mechanics has, in fact, been a boon to the metal producing industry; it\nhas made the finite crack in a structure reputable and even fashionable." (Quoted from\nA. M. Freudenthal, Miami Beach, Florida, December 1969.)\nINTRODUCTION\nPrimary aircraft structural components generally contain flaws or defects of\nvariable shape, orientation, and criticality which are either inherent in the basic material or are introduced during the fabrication or assembly processes.\nFrom an industry survey (ref. 1) it was concluded that the majority of cracks\nfound in aircraft structures were initiated from tool marks, manufacturing defects, and\nthe like. When not detected, these flaws experience the combined driving forces of\nenvironment and service loading and may grow to serious proportions resulting in\n437\n\nreduction of service life or complete loss of the aircraft. The final fracture process is\nmost often sudden, unexpected, and almost totally devoid of gross plastic deformation or\nyielding. While this "brittlelike" behavior is most spectacular in the so-called highstrength alloys, it is seen to occur to some degree in most of the commonly used aircraft structural materials.\nRecent cases of catastrophic failure in primary structure of first-line aircraft\nhave emphasized the need for a "fresh" new look at the structural integrity process currently used to design and qualify structural systems. Under such an improved process,\nfracture control would insure the reduction in the probability of catastrophic failure due\nto the presence of undetected flaws and cracks. This assurance can best be achieved by\nthe intelligent material selection based on fracture as well as common strength considerations and by assuming the existence of flaws in "new" structures and accounting\nfor their probable growth during service.\nLinear elastic fracture mechanics analysis and testing techniques have reached\nthe state of development where they may be used with a moderate level of confidence to\nassess the degree of flaw criticality, to predict the extent of subcritical flaw growth\nprior to fracture, and to determine the resultant failure modes (ref. 2). Much of the\nbasic groundwork for the current application of linear elastic fracture mechanics to\n"real" structures can be attributed to the investigation associated with fracture control\nof metallic pressure vessels for space applications (refs. 3 and 4). While attempts to\ntranslate this technology to aircraft usage have been moderately successful, limitations\nmust be recognized which are due to the complex spectrum of loads, temperatures, and\nchemically aggressive agents that comprise the aircraft environment.\nFail-safe procedures in aircraft have resulted from civil requirements and from\nindependent regulation within the particular airframe company. These efforts have been\nbeneficial on many Air Force aircraft.\nApplication of fracture mechanics within the Air Force has been almost exclusively\n"after the fact" to determine remaining safe life with cracks, residual strength, and safe\ninspection intervals for older systems in which flaws have developed and progressed to\nnear-critical dimensions. Some examples of service application in which the Air Force\nFlight Dynamics Laboratory (AFFDL) actively participated are summarized in table I\n(see refs. 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10). In practically all cases, however, attempts to formulate\nreliable solutions were hampered by the lack of an adequate material-environmental data\nbase and deficiencies in analysis techniques, particularly those techniques which must\naccount for load interaction and environmental effects. One purpose of this paper is to\nreview those areas of application where deficiencies in the technology exist and to offer\nsuggestions for alleviating these deficiencies.\n\n438\n\nUnder the F-111 Recovery Program (ref. 9), basic fracture mechanics data are currently being amassed for D6ac steel by the contractor and several laboratories. (See\nrefs. 8, 11, and 12.)\nSpecific criteria, guidelines, or requirements for considering fracture mechanics\nprinciples in the design and procurement cycle for Air Force aircraft have not existed\nin the past. Only recently have requirements been levied for new systems. It is too\nearly to assess their impact. In the proposed revisions to the Air Force Airplane\nStructural Integrity Program (ASIP) which is given in reference 13, damage tolerance\nconsiderations are outlined. These changes are currently being reviewed prior to being\nformally incorporated.\nThere exists a natural unwillingness amongst many to accept the "preexistent flaw"\nconcept in aircraft design because of the weight penalties normally associated with\ndamage-resistant structures. There are those who cite system performance degradation and the time and cost of implementing fracture requirements as deterrents. The\nimposition of arbitrary fracture requirements should be done cautiously under current\nstate -of -the -art limitations in analysis methods and testing techniques are resolved and\nmaterial-environmental behavior is better understood.\nIn this paper, recent structural material utilization cases are summarized to indicate those problems associated with the use of high-strength material. General fracture\ncontrol procedures are reviewed with specific reference to the impact of safe crack\ngrowth and remaining strength requirements on system design. Examples are cited,\nincluding recent laboratory efforts in the analysis of crack growth under variableamplitude spectrum loading. Limitations in basic design criteria, material data, and\nanalysis are reviewed.\nSYMBOLS\na\t\n\ncrack size, length or depth, inches\n\nacr\t\n\ncritical crack size, inches\n\nap\tproof-test crack size, inches\nAa\t\n\nchange in crack size, inches\n\nB,t\t\n\nthickness, inches\n\nC\t\n\none-half surface crack length, inches\n439\n\nE\t\n\nmodulus of elasticity, ksi\n\nf\t\n\nfrequency of test load application, cycle/minute\n\nK\t\n\nstress intensity factor, ksi- in.\n\nKc\t\n\ncritical stress intensity factor, ksi- in.\n\nKI c\t\n\nplane strain fracture toughness, ksi- in.\n\nKISCC\t\n\ncritical stress intensity factor for stress corrosion cracking, ksi-in.\n\nKmax\t\n\nmaximum stress intensity factor, ksi-Fin.\n\nKmin\t\n\nminimum stress intensity factor, ksi-in.\n\nAK = Kmax - K min, ksi- in.\nM,N\t\n\nnumber of load cycles\n\nP\t\n\nmaterial density, lb/in3\n\nR= Kmin\nKmax\nry ,Ry\t\n\nradius of crack tip yield zone, inches\n\na\t\n\nstress, ksi\n\nOQ\n\nchange in stress, ksi\n\n9L\n\nlimit stress, ksi\n\nuys\n\nyield strength, ksi\n\nda/dN\n\nfatigue crack growth\n\nda/dt\n\nenvironmental crack growth\n\n440\n\nSubscripts:\n0,1,2,3,... reference values\nrequirements\n\nA,B,C,D,E,F,G\t\nc\t\n\ncritical\n\ni\t\n\ninitial\n\nf\t\n\nfinal\n\nmax\t\n\nmaximum\n\nmin\t\n\nminimum\nMATERIALS UTILIZATION IN STRUCTURAL DESIGN \xe2\x80\x94\nRESISTANCE TO FRACTURE\n\nWith the advent of higher performance air vehicles, weight minimization has necessitated optimum design and construction techniques and greater utilization of the highstrength, high-efficiency, and limited-ductility materials. The process also has evolved\nincreased operating stresses and, thus, lower tolerance to flaws and cracks.\nThese applications have resulted in critical flaw dimensions of the order of the\nmaterial thickness which make positive detection by current nondestructive inspection\n(NDI) practice questionable. Current trends in the structural design utilization of highstrength alloys for resistance to catastrophic fracture can be evaluated by examining\ntrends in two basic material parameters, the plane strain fracture toughness index KIc\nand the conventional yield strength Qys.\nFor a specific application, the designer must select a material of reasonably high\nstrength in order to meet static strength requirements and still achieve minimum weight.\nA parameter for evaluating structural efficiency (Qys/p) is mentioned later. In the\nselection process, however, fracture toughness must be a consideration. The achievement of maximum yield strength and maximum fracture toughness is often difficult as is\nillustrated in figure 1. It is generally recognized that within certain material groups,\ntoughness decreases with increasing yield strength. This trend is illustrated in figure 1\nfor aluminum, titanium, and several selected steels where material data from table H\nhave been plotted. Variations in KIc can be expected for any given alloy and strength\n441\n\nlevel, and these variations are generally due to metallurgical aspects, impurities, or\nmanufacturing processing. This variability makes the selection of a "design allowable"\nextremely difficult.\nIn specifying a particular material and strength level (minimum acceptable ays),\nthe designer usually would not be concerned about those quantities of material which\npossessed strength levels on the upper end of the normal range. However, because of\nthe dramatic decrease in K Ic , he must in many cases limit the upper bound of acceptable\nrange of yield strength. This is current practice in specifying titanium alloys. In figure 1, KIc ranges for two common titanium alloys are noted. These data are shown at\none yield strength value to illustrate the fallacy in specifying only Qy s minimum.\nRecent F-111 experience with D6ac steel has indicated a similar phenomenon; however,\nthe variation of KIc is dependent upon the heat treatment procedure (ref. 9). In this\ncase, two specimens of material from different lots might possess the same measured\noys and yet have a two-to-one range in KIc\xe2\x80\xa2\nThe material selection process is therefore a trade-off procedure wherein many\nconcurrent requirements must be satisfied. For the case in point, the designer must\nestablish criteria for accepting either a reduced toughness or a reduced strength level.\nThe choice might be dictated by overall flaw tolerance. This is illustrated in figure 2\nwhere the ordinate (KIc/uys)2, a parameter indicative of crack size, is used. Since\nstructures are designed to withstand (statically) a percentage of the yield strength, this\nparameter may be conveniently used to illustrate flaw tolerance sensitivity. Examination\nof figure 2 indicates a more dramatic reduction in the crack length parameter with\nincreased yield strength.\nThe same trend is repeated in figure 3; however, the yield strength has been normalized with respect to the material density p. The parameter Qys/p is one form of\nstructural efficiency used to select materials. Note that material ranking has changed,\nwith titanium being superior to steel. One exception illustrated is that 18Ni-Co-Mo\nmaraging steel and 9Ni-4Co-2C fall beyond the bounds illustrated. There are recognizable limits on the values of both (Klc/oys)2 and Qysp for materials in use today.\nThe bounds are illustrated in figure 3.\nThe data presented in figure 3 clearly illustrate the relationship of nondestructive\ninspection (NDI) capability and material selection to resist brittle fracture. For\nexample, a through-the-thickness crack will experience plane strain fracture when\nK = KIc = Q7Tacr\xe2\x80\xa2 If fracture is assumed to occur at the design limit stress, the value\nof critical crack length a cr can be computed. For many aircraft structures, design\n2\t\nK\n( K Ic \\2\nThus each\no\nlimit stress is of the order of oL = 0.6Qys and acr = 0.6 Q\nC\n\t\nys^ YJ\t\npoint in figure 3 might be considered the critical characteristic flaw dimension for plane\n442\n\nstrain fracture and thus would describe the sensitivity level required for fleet inspection.\nFor this type of selection criterion, many materials may be prohibited because of the\nextremely small flaws which must be detected. Limits of NDI practice are not well\ndefined.\nWith the technological trend in material utilization growing toward greater strengthdensity ratios, it seems logical also to define more realistic limits on the material selection based on uncontrollable "human element" defects. Thus, the crack size definition of\nfigure 3 might indicate limits produced by normal tool marks, scratches, or gouges produced during manufacture or maintenance. If these limits are recognized as sound, then\nmore effective means of inspection may be required, such as proof testing, if use is to be\nmade of these alloys (fig. 4).\nAll the data from table II has been plotted in figure 5 with both KIc and oys\nnormalized with respect to density p. This plot indicates an apparent technological\nlimit which material producers might find difficult to exceed (ref. 2).\nIn the previous discussion it was assumed that plane strain fracture is dominant.\nFortunately, this is not always the case because of the effect of thickness, plasticity, and\ngeometry (figs. 6 and 7). The question does remain, however, as to what role K Ic has\nin the material selection and analysis process.\nIt is perhaps safe to conclude that the selection of candidate materials for fracture\nconsiderations can be made on the basis of superior K Ic , as long as the materials are\nsimilar. The decision, however, rests upon the thickness required to fulfill the task. In\nfigure 7, the variation of critical stress intensity factor with thickness is illustrated for\nseveral alloys (ref. 2).\nMATERIAL SELECTION \xe2\x80\x94 RESISTANCE TO FLAW GROWTH\nUNDER REPEATED LOADS\nIn the preceding discussion, KIc and oys were shown to be effective parameterE\nin selecting a material class and alloy to resist brittle fracture under plane strain conditions. Wide variations in strength and toughness were indicated within a given material.\nToughness was also seen to vary within a given alloy group.\nMaterial selection based on cyclic growth considerations is not as clearly defined,\nsince observed trends in rate data for a nonaggressive environment indicate that materials within a group or class generally fall within a narrow scatterband, with little, if any,\ndependence on toughness. Average growth-rate curves have been included in figure 8 to\nillustrate the relative relationship between materials. Hahn (ref. 6) has observed that the\nrate da/dN can be approximated for many materials as\n443\n\nda = 8 (AK)2\nE\ndN\t\nin the central or log linear portion of the growth-rate curve. Several points are shown\nin figure 8 which were obtained by using the Hahn expression. Because of the relationship of growth rate to modulus E, the data can be normalized with respect to the material density p as indicated in figure 9 where rate curves are seen to converge. It is\napparent, then, that a material\'s advantage can only be assessed on an individual application basis. Growth under variable-amplitude spectrum loading, for example, may produce\ndifferent trends in growth retardation due to the interaction of loads. Generally speaking,\nhowever, the time to failure from an initial flaw is dependent primarily upon the toughness\nKIc . This is illustrated in figure 10, with cutoffs for several levels of toughness. The\nrelative effect, however, may be dependent upon the shape and severity of the spectrum.\nWhile the preceding discussion has been concerned with the cyclic flaw growth\nbehavior, the selection of materials for repeated load application in the presence of flaws\nmay be seriously influenced by the chemical and thermal environments in which the structure must operate. No attempt is made in this paper to cover these trends. The reader\nis referred to several excellent publications (refs. 6, 11, 14, and 15).\nFRACTURE CONTROL \xe2\x80\x94 BASIC CONSIDERATIONS\nThe traditional Air Force approach to structural integrity (ref. 13) requires that\n"safe life" be evaluated through the cyclic test program. The success of this approach\nin determining the overall fatigue resistance of full-scale structures has been well\ndocumented (refs. 6 and 16). The achievement of "fatigue quality" through careful workmanship, surface finishes, and detailed design (local stress levels) and the demonstration\nof resistance to crack initiation are basic and reasonable goals. Therefore, before presenting suggested procedures for fracture control, it is important that two basic tenets\nbe stated:\n(1) Damage tolerant design and fracture control philosophy should not be considered\nas substitutes for adequate fatigue considerations.\n(2) Consideration must be given to the probable existence of flaws within all basic\nprimary structures.\nCrack initiation resistance and fracture resistance should be considered as complementa\nobjectives.\nBy virtue of its complex nature and varied operational regimes, an airframe\nencounters a wide variety of natural and induced environments. While this makes the\napplication of fracture theory a rather difficult task, the general overall goals which must\nbe achieved are rather simply stated, as follows:\n444\n\n(1) Encourage the intelligent selection of fracture-resistant materials, manufacturing processes, and so forth\n(2) Provide an incentive to design for inspectability with damage-resistant\nstructural configurations (i.e., multiple load paths)\n(3) Aid in establishing effective and realistic inspection procedures\n(4) Assist in selecting and controlling safe operating stresses\nIn the Materials Utilization section, materials data were presented to illustrate how\nstrength-density ratio (efficiency) could result in the selection of material with an undesirable level of toughness. Likewise, the choice based on fatigue alone might lead to\nserious difficulty since many high-strength materials (steels, for example) may have\nacceptable fatigue resistance but possess low resistance to brittle fracture and subcritical\nflaw growth (stress corrosion cracking, for example).\nStructural configurations which possess multiple load paths, crack stoppers, and so\nforth, are necessary and desirable; however, their ability to function and meet specific\npreassigned goals must be demonstrated early in design.\nControlling design stress levels for common structural materials can have untold\nbenefits from both the strength and fatigue points of view and can prevent costly field\nmaintenance problems. For example, multiple load path, redundant, and fail-safe\narrangements may effectively prevent the loss of aircraft, so long as adequate and frequent inspections are planned. The sole dependence on the fail-safe approach to achieving fracture control without regard to limiting design stresses may result in frequent\nmember failures, costly unscheduled maintenance, and aircraft downtime. This situation\ncan be alleviated by requiring each member in the multiple or redundant set to be inherently resistant to flaw growth within prescribed bounds (i.e., it must have a safe life with\ncracks).\nThe ability to detect and quantify flaws and cracks, both in the raw product form\nand the final assembled structural article, remains as the most significant measure in\ndeterring catastrophic fracture. Instituting fracture control procedures is, in fact, a\nfrank admittance that serious flaws can and often do go undetected. This fact was\ndramatically pointed out by Packman, Pearson, Owens, and Young (ref. 17) in a study for\nthe Air Force Materials Laboratory. The data in figure 11 have been obtained from that\nreport and depict the sensitivity and reliability of common NDI methods in controlled\nlaboratory experiments. The results are quite surprising because relatively large flaws\nwere not detected. This does not mean that all hope is lost of improving present methods\nand procedures. On the contrary, continued development of improved NDI techniques is\nmandatory.\n\n445\n\nFracture control procedures are most beneficial if effectively implemented and\nmanaged. Implementation consists of satisfying specific requirements for analysis and\ntest based on established ground rules and definitions of required strength, assumed\ndamage, service life, and inspection intervals. A balanced design within the goals of\ndamage tolerance is thus insured. It is important that the basic definitions, goals, and\nfracture requirements be established early in the design phase in order to impact trade\nstudies. Implementation requires a firm material data base, knowledge of operational\nenvironments, design criteria, and an analytical capacity to perform complex flaw-growth\nand strength analyses.\nIf fracture control procedures are instituted early, they form a portion of the basic\ndesign criteria and no weight penalties can then be attributed to their existence. Weight\npenalties are only recognized if the requirements are levied after the design is frozen.\nFRACTURE CONTROL \xe2\x80\x94 REQUIREMENTS\nIt should be acknowledged that the preparation of detailed step-by-step requirements for fracture control is a difficult task because of the numerous classes of aircraft\n(i.e., fighter bombers, trainers, etc.) in use today by the Air Force and because of the\nvarious types of structural arrangements which comprise these airframes. With regard\nto the structural aspects, the term "Damage Tolerant" is perhaps most common and is\nused within the Air Force (ref. 13) to describe those configurations "which will minimize\nthe loss of aircraft due to the propagation of undetected flaws, cracks, or other damage."\nSupplemental requirements for the ASIP (ref. 13) and various military specifications (ref. 18) are currently being formulated to insure the achievement of damagetolerant design. Such requirements will be applicable to all primary structures, the\nfailure of which would reduce the strength level below specified limits and endanger the\nsafe operational flight characteristics of the aircraft.\nIn general, requirements to insure adequate fracture control take on the form of\nspecific directives in the areas of (1) design, (2) analysis, and (3) test.\nIn the following discussion, a representative set of specifications for fracture control is described to indicate the relative levels of importance placed on structural\narrangements, inspections, and so forth.\nIt is generally recognized that there are two major design steps which are required\nto produce a damage-tolerant structure:\n(1) Controlled safe flaw growth (safe life with cracks)\n(2) Positive damage containment (remaining or residual strength)\n446\n\nNeither of these should be considered separate and distinct, however, since it is the\njudicious combination of both that is required for effective fracture control.\nSince the assumption is made that flaws do exist in new structures and can go\nundetected, full compliance with this philosophy requires that consideration be given to\nthe probability that flaws will exist in any and/or all members, including each element of\na redundant or multiple load path group. This is important because it is easy to rationalize that each member of the multiple set could be flawed. For example, if stress corrosion is responsible for the existence of subsurface cracks in one member, there is no\nassurance that each adjoining member does not contain cracks of a similar character.\nThe first major requirement for fracture resistance must, therefore, dictate that any\nmember must have a safe life with assumed cracks present.\nFor any given application, the overriding factors which govern the details and complexity of the fracture requirements and demonstrations are (fig. 12)\n(1) The class or type of structure\n(2) The quality of production and assembly NDl\n(3) The accessibility of the structure\n(4) The assurance that the member will be inspected in service\n(5) The probability that a flaw of subcritical size would go undetected even though\nperiodic inspections are made\nMost structural members can be classified by load path (fig. 13):\n(1) Single load path\n(2) Single primary load path with auxiliary crack arrest features\n(3) Multiple and redundant load path\nClass 2 includes such items as pressure cabins and pressure vessels, where relatively large amounts of damage may be contained by providing tear straps, stiffeners,\nand the like. While some load shedding does take place, the primary load path is singular.\nDetection of damage for such cases is likely, because of fuel or pressure leakage.\nClass 3 structures are generally designed so that some percentage of original\nstrength is retained during and subsequent to the failure of one element (often called fail\nsafe). Assurance of this capability should be mandatory by analysis and tests. The containment of damage is often produced by natural barriers such as production splices and\nso forth.\nAccessibility and inspectability were indicated in the section on Basic Considerations for Fracture Control as major items in fracture control. This point cannot be\n447\n\noveremphasized. Not only should the structure be inspectable, but assurance must be\ngiven that it will be inspected periodically after assembly. Because of recent experiences with high-strength materials, speculation has arisen whether or not subsurface\ncracks of near-critical size can be found in service by use of routine inspection procedures and equipment. A positive criterion such as "leak before break" may have to be\nlevied in order to assure their detection. Otherwise, an inspectable structure would\nhave to be classified as noninspectable. (See fig. 14.)\nEngineering Criteria \xe2\x80\x94 Definitions\nBefore specific fracture requirements for design, analysis, and test can be levied,\ncertain aspects of loading and service must be defined for each type of aircraft. In most\ncases, these items will be unique for each particular system and will be specified in the\nbasic design criteria.\nStrength limits.- The percentage of unflawed static strength which is to be maintained with prescribed amounts of damage must be established. This load is generally\nthe limit load but may vary with aircraft types.\nDynamic factors.- The effect of dynamic load amplification due to the release of\nenergy as the damage is introduced must be included.\nInspection intervals.- Inspection intervals shall be consistent with required safe\ncrack growth intervals and the requirements for residual strength.\nDamage limits.- The size of initial flaws which may be expected to slip by inspection must be established from NDI capability studies. Final damage limits will be based\non fracture and inspection requirements. In addition, the number and locations of members which are to be considered failed for residual strength purposes must be identified.\nDamage limits should be established for each system based on individual requirements,\nmaterials applications, and so forth.\nDesign Trade Study Analyses\nA primary function of the fracture control requirements during early design stages\nis to assist in the selection of damage-resistant materials and structures, with some\nincentive offered to those that are easily inspectable and those that include multiple or\nredundant load paths. In figure 15, key factors which influence these trade studies are\nsummarized. Each member is first classified as to structural type, inspectability, and\nso forth, and a candidate material is selected. Limits of assumed initial damage size\nare assigned together with the engineering criteria for life, strength, and final damage\nsize. The analysis is then performed by utilizing the appropriate cyclic and sustained\nloads and environments. The process is then iterated until a satisfactory combination\n448\n\nof material and stress level is selected which fulfills the strength and life requirements.\nThe resultant information is then incorporated with other design considerations until a\nsatisfactory design is achieved.\nAnalysis \xe2\x80\x94 Detailed Requirements\nThe analysis consists of determining the growth rates of initial flaws under cyclic\nloading and environment and insuring that these flaws remain subcritical for the specified\ntime period. Initial flaw sizes generally reflect the NDI capability but may be influenced\nby such criteria as proof tests and manufacturing processes. The flaws are generally\nassumed to be normal to the maximum principal stress field. The character and shape\nof the flaws are usually influenced by such aspects as\n(1) Materials and processing\n(2) Manufacturing and assembly\n(3) Handling and service conditions\nExperience has indicated that the flaw types shown in figure 16 are most representative\nin aircraft.\nIn table III, a set of hypothetical analysis requirements have been tabulated for the\nthree classes of structures, based upon whether or not the assemblies will be inspected\nin service. l The information from table III has been translated into figures 17, 18,\nand 19 for clarity. As is indicated, each class is designed for a safe crack growth period\nfrom an initial flaw. The final fracture dimensions are governed by plane strain fracture\nat limit load unless conditions indicate that this mode of fracture is unlikely. Some\nmotivation to design with inspectability and with high-toughness materials (and thus\nhigher stresses) is offered for (a 3 > a5) and (a4 > a5). The final crack dimensions a3\nand a4 must truly be detectable however; otherwise, the structure should be reclassified as noninspectable. It was previously stated that subsurface flaws most likely should\nbe put in the noninspectable class (for service inspections). However, in most cases, it\nis possible to achieve through-the-thickness cracks and thus "positive detection" with\nproper selection of materials and stresses.\nA safe life period of two inspection intervals has been indicated for the class 1 and\nclass 3 inspectable cases. This will result in a slight reduction in allowable design\nstresses but will offer more chance to detect the subcritical crack.\nFor the class 1, single load path, structure the requirement to satisfy a safe life\nwith cracks is easily accepted because of the consequence of losing the member.\n1 These requirements are presented for purpose of illustration only and do not\nrepresent USAF policy.\n449\n\nHowever, as previously stated, the preexistent flaw concept requires that all members,\nincluding each member of a multiple load set, be assumed flawed. It is not sufficient\nsimply to design the multiple load path structure to a remaining strength criterion with\none principal member failed. This does not insure that initial flaws in a member will\nnot grow to critical size in a relatively short period of time and result in broken members and unscheduled, costly maintenance. Therefore, the safe life requirements C and\nE as listed in table III and indicated in figure 18 are applicable to every member of the\nstructure. However, since there should be some incentive to design class 3 structures,\nthe size of the initial assumed flaws in the class 3 structure is reduced from that in the\nclass 1 structure for the noninspectable case (a 1 < a2). By doing this, the designer is\nadmitting that the design is more comfortable and that he is willing to take a larger risk\nof operating with cracks.\nSupplemental safe life (with cracks) requirements (F and G) for the class 3 structure are listed in table III and are applicable to the remaining structure after the one\nprincipal member has failed. In these requirements, the assumption is made that the\nelement could fail at any time during the life (or inspection period) and go undetected.\nThe remaining structure (assumed to be flawed) would then be required to carry the maxi\nmum load for the duration of the remaining specified time period. The stresses which\nresult from requirements F and G most likely will dominate the design. In actual practice, studies would have to be conducted to determine the most appropriate time to\nassume the member failure. In requirement F, the remaining growth period would be\none inspection interval regardless of when the member was assumed to have failed. As\nis indicated in figure 19, the total growth in any one member is equal to the amount which\noccurs prior to the failure of the principal element plus the amount which occurs subsequent to the failure at an increased stress level.\nAlternate Scheme to Assess Remaining Life\nIn the previous section, requirements F and G (table III) were presented to satisfy\nthe requirement for some remaining life in the multiple load structure after the failure\nof any principal member. An alternate scheme, and one which may be less restrictive,\nhas recently been prepared for use in the Air Force. The principal difference is that\nthe remaining structure is considered to be intact (unflawed) subsequent to the failure of\nthe principal element. The requirement is stated as follows in reference 18:\n" Fail Safe. Primary structure that is designed fail safe shall be readily inspectable and meet the following requirements after failure of a principal\nstructural element: (1) the remaining structure shall sustain without failure,\nthe maximum expected load or limit load, whichever is greater, (2) the airplane shall be controllable within the design speed limits, and (3) catastrophic\n450\n\nfailure of the remaining structure will not occur under repeated load conditions during the time period to the next opportunity to detect the failure.\nVerification of the ability of the remaining structure to withstand the\nrepeated loads shall be accomplished by determining the crack growth\nperiod from an initial flaw to failure of the principal element, and then\ninsuring that the life (including a factor of four) of the remaining structure\nwill equal or exceed the time interval established for the next inspection.\nInspection intervals shall be as agreed to by the procuring agency . . ."\nFracture Control \xe2\x80\x94 Verification and Demonstration\nIn the preceding discussion, requirements for analysis were presented. In certain\ninstances, experimental verification or demonstration of compliance should be required.\nSafe crack growth tests (class 1 and class 3).- Although basic growth-rate data will\nbe generated to support analysis techniques, it is desirable to augment the constantamplitude tests with spectrum crack growth tests conducted on a meaningful flight-byflight basis. This is particularly true where reliance has been placed upon positive\ndetection by surface flaws penetrating the member thickness. In most cases, these\nexperiments can be conducted on representative coupons, or small specimens if stresses\nare well known. If the geometry is complex, it is more desirable to utilize prototype\ncomponent structure and run the growth tests in conjunction with the static or cyclic\npreproduction tests.\nDemonstration tests utilizing full-scale structures (i.e., complete aircraft) should\nnot be necessary since it is generally quite easy to duplicate localized conditions surrounding the crack tip.\nDamage arrest (class 2).- Demonstration of crack arrest capability and subsequent\ncyclic life should be required. These tests may be conducted on representative specimens or on the full-scale aircraft at the conclusion of the static or fatigue test. In most\ncases, critical damage is introduced mechanically to simulate service condition (battle\ndamage, etc.).\nEstablishment of Inspection Procedures\nAn additional function served by the safe crack growth analysis is the establishment of inspection procedures for an individual structure or for all members in the aircraft which are manufactured from the same material. The use of fracture analysis\nprocedures allows inspection or rejection with more confidence by classifying parts and\nregions within a part according to the required NDI sensitivity.\n\n451\n\nThe development of such an inspection procedure for a typical application is illustrated as follows. Spectrum crack growth information is plotted in figure 20(a) as a\nfunction of the initial crack size (only a0 is shown) for various degrees of spectrum\nseverity (maximum stress). In this example, the required safe growth period is N hours,\nand a0 is the largest crack size that can be tolerated for this material application. The\nmaximum expected spectrum stress is Q4 . NDI procedures must insure the reliable\ndetection of a 0 during fabrication and assembly.\nThis spectrum growth information is translated into more meaningful form in figure 20(b) where, for any level of design stress, the largest tolerable flaw which would\ngrow to failure in N hours is plotted. Rather than using fracture at N hours, a\ncriterion based on positive detection could be substituted and produce a similar diagram.\nApplication of Requirements\nWhile the full impact of the proposed fracture requirements can only be assessed\nthrough an extensive design application study on an existing system, the relative severity\ncan be assessed by studying typical examples. The following example illustrates the\nvalues of design stress for a single material which would result under each requirement\nlisted in table III:\nExample: Tension cover; aircraft type, fighter\n\nMaterial, 7075-T6\nKIc = 30 ksi- in.\nThickness = 0.375 in.\nInitial flaw assumptions (surface flaw) (a/2c = 0.5):\na l = 0.050 in. (for all inspectable cases)\na2 = 0.150 in. (for all noninspectable cases)\nFinal flaw size:\na4 = Minimum detectable size = 0.375 in.\na3 = Minimum acceptable equivalent = 0.500 in. for single load\npath structure\nStress information:\nThe fighter spectrum information is contained in table IV in\nterms of a unit of maximum stress value a = 37 ksi. These occurrences in table IV are the equivalent of 40 hours of flight. The maximum limit stress for design purposes is:\nUL = 1.5Q = 55.5 ksi\n452\n\nSpectrum growth-rate data:\nBy utilizing constant-amplitude growth-rate data (ref. 19), the\nCRACKS computer routine (ref. 20), and the AFFDL crack growth\nretardation model (ref. 10), the stress spectrum (table IV) was\ntranslated into plots of crack depth a as a function of number of\nflights starting with an initial crack length a l = 0.050 in. (fig. 21)\nand a 2 = 0.150 in. (fig. 22). All levels of stress from table IV were\nincreased or decreased proportionally to achieve the variation in\ngrowth due to spectrum severity.\nMaterial toughness:\nThe cutoff line for KIc = 30 ksi- in, is indicated in figures 21\nand 22. The effect of varying this parameter was not investigated in\nthis example.\nLife requirement:\nService life = 160 blocks = 160 x 40 = 6400 hours. Inspection\nintervals are planned each 1/4 lifetime of 40 blocks = 1600 hours.\nRequirement A:\nInitial crack depth:\nal = 0.050 in.\nFinal crack depth:\na3 = 0.500 in. (based on positive detection)\nLife requirement:\nNA = 80 blocks = Two inspection intervals\nDesign stress QA:\nThis goal cannot be achieved with this material since K Ic is\nlimited to 30 ksi-in, and the inspection requirement of 0.500 in. is\nnot possible. A material change would most likely be required.\nRequirement C:\nInitial crack depth:\na1 = 0.050 in.\nFinal crack depth:\na4 = 0.375 in. (based on positive detection)\n\n453\n\nLife requirement:\nNC = 80 blocks\nDesign stress, maximum:\n0C (allowable) = 1.270 = 47 ksi\nRequirement D:\nInitial crack depth:\na2 = 0.150 in.\nLife requirement:\nND = 160 blocks = One lifetime\nFinal crack depth:\na 5 = Plane strain fracture > 1.0 in.\nDesign stress, maximum:\n0D (allowable) = 0.810 = 31 ksi\nRequirement E:\nInitial crack depth:\nal = 0.050 in.\nFinal crack depth:\na 5 = Plane strain fracture = 0.58 in.\nLife requirement:\nNE = 160 blocks\nDesign stress, maximum:\n0E (allowable) = 1.080 = 40 ksi\nRequirement F:\n\nCoupled with requirement C is the additional requirement that the structure remaining after failure of the principal member will be capable of carrying limit load for one additional inspection period, or 1/4 lifetime. The lower\nportion of the growth data from figure 21 has been replotted in figure 23.\n(a) Assume that the member breaks accidentally after the first flight and\nremains undetected until the next inspection interval. The stress is assumed\nto increase by 20 percent, with the requirement being no failure at limit load in\n1/4 lifetime or 40 blocks. From figure 23, it can be seen that a stress level\n454\n\nof approximately 1.6Q = 60 ksi would grow to failure in 40 blocks.\nTherefore\naFa (allowable) = 160 0 = 50 ksi\n(b) Assume the member failure to be at 1/4 lifetime (just subsequent\nto inspection). The crack in the remaining structure has grown an amount\nDa during the first inspection period. Thus,\nNew initial a = al + Da = 0.050 + Aa\nThis condition can be satisfied by trial and error by using figure 23. The\nresult indicates that crFb z 1.2a = 44.4 is appropriate for this condition.\nFailure at any other time could be checked to see whether a lower stress\nwould result. Note that no criterion for positive detection was required\nsince at the next inspection the broken member would be found.\nRequirement G:\n\nIn a similar manner, requirement E should be checked for life after\nmember failure.\n(a) Assume failure on first flight (from fig. 21)\nQ\n\nE =1.08Q=40 ksi\nQ\n\n" gG\n\na 12-33.3 ksi\n\n(b) Assume failure at 1/2 lifetime. The incremental growth during the\nfirst 1/2 lifetime must be added to a l . The requirement for 1/2 remaining\nlife shall then be determined. From figure 21, by trial and error, a stress\nlevel of uGb = 1.Ou = 37.0 ksi is seen to satisfy the requirements.\nSummary:\nThe following table is a summary of the previous example:\nRequirement\t\n\nDesign stress, Q, ksi\t\n\nCondition\n\nA\nC\nD\nE\nFa\nFb\nGa\nGb\n\nNot satisfied\n47\n31\n40\n50\n44.4\n33.3\n37.0\n\nInspectable class 1\nInspectable class 3\nNoninspectable class 1\nNoninspectable class 3\nInspectable class 1\nNoninspectable class 3\n455\n\nThe results clearly indicate the advantages offered by designing for inspectability\nsince the allowable stresses for requirements C and F are greater than for requirement G. The incentive for multiple, in lieu of single, load path design is seen in the\nresultant allowable design stresses for requirements E and G being greater than for\nrequirement D.\nANALYSIS AND DATA REQUIREMENTS FOR IMPLEMENTATION\nThe successful implementation of the fracture control analysis requires the analytical capability for cyclic and environmental flaw growth, aircraft usage information,\nand basic strength and fracture data for proposed candidate materials.\nCriteria Requirements\nInitial considerations for fracture resistance and control of subcritical flaw growth\nmust be established during the criteria development stage and must reflect appropriate\nchemical, thermal, and operational loads environments. For example, recent materials\nusage has necessitated the generation of data on sustained-load flaw growth in aggressive\nenvironments such as fuel and water (fig. 24(a)). Because loading rate and dwell times\nare important in the assessment of environmental effects, it has become important also\nto generate load-time spectra of the type indicated in figure 24(b).\nMaterial Data Requirements\nThe major material strength and fracture properties required to perform the ana\nlyses and trade studies for fracture considerations are illustrated in figure 25. In all\ncases (except KIc) no approved standard test methods exist to determine these properties. Through experience, however, various test techniques and specimens have evolved.\n(See fig. 25.) As is often the case, a specimen developed for one function or application\nis used to generate a multitude of data. Testing techniques and data interpretation may\nmask important material responses or indicate false reaction to stress and environment.\nFor example, in a recent comparison of cyclic growth-rate behavior in D6ac steel\n(refs. 9, 11, and 12) comparative growth rates obtained from compact tension and surfaceflawed specimens indicated a predominant stress-level effect for the surface-flawed\nspecimen, whereas no clear dependency was observed for the compact tension case\n(fig. 26). These effects are currently being investigated.\nFracture Analysis Methods\nPrediction of fracture and growth behavior requires a means of translating external\napplied loads into stresses in the region of the crack tip. Finite-element techniques\n456\n\noffer a vast potential in the area, particularly in complex structural arrangements\n(refs. 21 and 22). A rather broad collection of stress intensity solutions exists (ref. 4);\nhowever, their use is limited in many cases and extrapolation is often required to provide the best estimate of K.\nConsiderable effort is being expended in the development of computer routines to\n"integrate" growth-rate (da/dN) data (ref. 20), for example, and to account for the retardation effect of overloads in variable-amplitude spectra. As an example of this type of\nactivity, the AFFDL has recently developed a mathematical model for predicting the\ngrowth delay effect (ref. 10). The basic model is concerned with the effect of the overload plastic zone on the subsequent rate of growth as indicated in figure 27. A hypothetical residual or reduction stress is then computed which suppresses the subsequent cyclic\nloads. Retardation is accomplished in three modes, depending on the relative size of the\noverload in relation to the subsequent cyclic level (fig. 28). Effective OK and R\nvalues are computed and reduced rates obtained from normal da/dN and OK relationships. Note that growth can be completely stopped (fig. 28). An extensive testing program is being completed at AFFDL to evaluate the merit of the model. In figure 29 are\nsome early correlations with single overloads in aluminum (ref. 6). Fairly good correlation is noted also with randomized block spectrum data for D6ac steel (fig. 30).\nGrowth analysis schemes need to be extended to include the effects of loading rate\nand delay time (sustained load growth). Free surface effects and flaw shape changes,\nincluding the transition of a surface flaw to a through crack, must be included.\nSUGGESTED AREAS OF STUDY\nThe suggested areas of study for the application of fracture mechanics in structural integrity have been summarized and are presented as table V. This table is\nobtained from reference 23.\nCONCLUDING REMARKS AND RECOMMENDED TOPICS FOR STUDY\nThe author has attempted to present the significant impact of fracture mechanics\nand fracture control in the overall program of airframe structural integrity. The true\nweight, cost, and performance trade-offs associated with the implementation of these or\nany requirement can best be judged by experience and application to existing systems.\nA fair assessment can only occur, however, if continued materials and structures development efforts are directed toward upgrading existing fracture mechanics and fracture\nanalysis technology.\n\n457\n\nThe author has summarized in tabular form a rather extensive "shopping list" of\nitems which require attention. In many cases, a relatively high degree of proficiency\nexists and application experience is all that is necessary while others require new\nthought and new direction.\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Donaldson, D. V.- SUGGESTED AREAS OF STUDY F OR THE APP LICATION OF FRACTURE MECHANI CS IN STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY\nPROGRAM :\nTOP I C AREAS:\n\nImplement rational fracture mechanics theory into the design criteria, material selection,\nanalysis, qualification, and utilization of aircraft structural systems.\nI\nII\nill\n\nIV\n\nV\n\nSUBJECT BREAKDOWN:\n\nCriteria\nData requirements and applications\nFracture analysis methodology\nQualification for fracture resistance\nUtilization - structural concepts\n\nI\n\nCriteria\na. Definition chemical and thermal environment for fracture requirements\nb. Review past experience, structural failure, and so forth\nc. Catalog critical structural materials arrangements and previous design considerations\nin order to establish which areas require extensive investigation\nd . Establish fracture criteria for material selection and trade-off studies\ne . Establish analogous "leak before break" criteria for aircraft application\nf. Assemble design data and criteria for fracture applications\ng . Definition of mission and analySiS, including estimates of time at load factor\nh. Incorporate criteria in basic specifications including ASIP modification\n\nII\n\nData requirements and applications\na. Establishment of measurable parameters Kc , KIc \' KISCC \' daj dt, da/dN,\nand others, including testing standards\nb. Application of Kc and KIc in design\nc. Fatigue crack growth data\nd. Subcritical crack growth rate, environment, and temperature\ne. Effect of loading sequence on cyclic growth or growth retardation\nf. Nonpropagating crack study, threshhold of ~K\ng. Parametric growth data, mission segments\nh. Extension of fracture mechanics testing standards to new classes of materials\ni. Study of statistically derived crack sizes and shapes based on nondestructive inspection (NDI)\nand nondestructive testing (NDT)\nj . Effect of stress state of fracture\nk. Mixed mode fracture study\n\n"\'"\n\nTABLE V.- SUGGESTED AREAS OF STUDY FOR THE APPLICATION OF FRACTURE MECHANICS IN STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY - Concluded\n\n0)\n0)\n\nSUBJECT BREAKDOWN:\n\nIII\n\nFracture analysis methodology\na. Assemblage of currently applicable K factor relationships including application\nb. Guidelines for estimating K or approximate K for complex cases (including superposition)\nc. Development of K for complex cases, elastic solutions\nd. Finite-element studies, crack growth, subcritical growth development of K, model crack\nelement for finite-element technique\ne. Plasticity and free surface effects\nf. Tabulation of equivalent cracks in complex flaw geometries\ng. Analytical crack model for growth under variable loading\nh. Routine for crack growth and life estimates including environment, rates, and load sequence effects\ni. Analytical study of variation of flaw shape and surface flaws\nj. Statistical analysis to establish confidence levels for toughness and life estimates, scatter factor\nfor application to analysis results\nk. Residual strength and static considerations\n1. Handbook preparation and design guidelines\nm. Development of semiempirical methods for estimating K\nn. Fracture arrest, damage-tolerant analysis methods\no. Study of the effect of crack bluntness on fracture behavior\n\nIV\n\nQualification for fracture resistance\na . Real-time flaw growth testing including temperature and environment (specimens)\nb. Real -time flaw growth (structures)\nc . Crack growth resistance and crack arrest testing\nd . Damage tolerance or fail-safe testing\ne. Test time reduction for (a) and (b) above\nf. Proof testing:\nRepeat work of Tiffany (Boeing) for typical aircraft structu res\nExtend knowledge and techniques to satisfy environment and requirements\nStatistical assessment of the risks and merits of proof testing\n\nV\n\nUtilization - structural concepts\na . Concepts for flaw and crack arrest\nb. New material utilization\nc . Performance and weight trade:..off studies\nd. Fabrication of structural concepts and full-scale testing\ne. Inspection, fracture mechanics interfa,ce, and flaw classification\nf. Proof testing, full scale\n\no^\n90\n\nU\n\nn\n\n\\i\t\n\n80\n\nD6ac\t\n\nI\n\np\n\n70\nTi-6A1-4V\n60\n\nTi-6AI-6V-2Sn\n\nz\n\nO o\t\n\n50\nCD\nZD\n0\n\n40\n\nz\n\nA\n\n30\n\nt\xc2\xb0\t\n\\ \xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\n\n\t\n\n\xc2\xb0 \xc2\xb0\n\nALUMINUM\t\n\nSTEEL\n\n\xc2\xb0\n\n20\nz\n\nn\n\nTITANIUM\t\n\n10\n\na\nJ\n\n0\n\nd\n\n100\t\n\n0\t\n\n200\t\n\n300\n\nYIELD STRENGTH, 6ys, ksi\nFigure 1.- Trends in toughness variation.\n\nN\nN\n\nT\nb\nU\n\n0.3\t\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\n\nCIE\n\nQ\n\nTITANIUM\n\n0.2\n\nI\t\n\nI\t\n\nSTEEL\n\n1\nI\n\nz\n\nc^\n\nLLj\n\nJ\n\nI\n\n0. 1\nALUMINUM\n\nY\nU\n\nd\n\nU\n\nn\n\n\xc2\xb0\n\n0\ni\n\nCif\n\n00\n100\t\n\n200\n\n300\n\nYIELD STRENGTH, 6ys, ksi\nFigure 2.- Variation of crack length parameter with yield strength.\n\n467\n\n0.3\n\nT_6A\n\nALUMINUM\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\t\nN\nN\n\nf DESIRED TREND\n\n0.2\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\t\n\nb\nU\n\n-_o\nHYPOTHETICAL\nNDT \'\'LIMIT\'\'\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2\t\ni\t\nTITA-\t\n\nz\nd\n\nd\nd\n\nNIUM o\t\n\nHYPOTHETICAL\nMANUFACTURING\n\noDEFECT LIMIT\n\n0.1\n\nz\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 ALUMINUM\t\nSTEEL\t\n\nc^\nz\nLL,\n\nJ\n\n\xc2\xb0\n\no I STEEL\n\no TITANIUM\t\n\nY\n\no\n\nI\n\nU\nd\nU\n0L\n0\n\nSTRUCTURAL EFFICIENCY PARAMETER , \t\n\nGyS/p\n\nFigure 3.- Variation of crack length parameter with structural efficiency parameter.\n\n/ PROOF STRESS\n\nap ^ IN ITIAL FLAW WHICH\nP ASSES PROOF TEST\n\nMAX.
