Fuel Weight\nFigure 15.- Landing fuel weights of jet-powered short-, medium-, and long-range airplanes.\n\n563\n\nPRECEDlliG PAGE BLANK NOT FILMED\nSTATISTICAL LOAD DATA PROCESSING\nBy G. M. van Dijk\nNational Aerospace Laboratory NLR, The Netherlands\nSUMMARY\nIn designing against fatigue the assessment of the loading environment still is a\n\nmajor problem. Especially with military trainer and fighter aircraft which may be\nused for a variety of duties, regular or continuous load recording programs have to be\nconsidered mandatory. Such load recording programs may serve either to assess the\nconsumed fatigue life of operating aircraft or to select design spectra for future aircraft designs and a fatigue-test setup. Within this scope the National Aerospace\nLaboratory has carried out a tentative load mOnitoring program.\nA recorder system has been installed on two operational fighter aircraft. Signal\nvalues from a c.g. -acceleration transducer and a strain-gage installation at the wing\nroot were sampled and recorded in digital format on the recorder system. To analyse\nsuch load-time histories for fatigue evaluation purposes, a number of counting methods are available in which level crOSSings, peaks, or ranges are counted. Ten different existing counting principles are defined. The load-time histories are analysed to\nevaluate these counting methods.\nFor some of the described counting methods, the counting results might be\naffected by arbitrarily chosen parameters such as the magnitude of load ranges that\nwill be neglected and other secondary counting restrictions. Such influences might\ninvalidate the final counting results entirely. The evaluation shows that for the type of\nload-time histories associated with most counting methods, a sensible value of the\nparameters involved can be found at which the counting results are rather unique.\nBesides assessing the influences of secondary parameter values, the different\ncounting methods are compared with each other. The analYSis shows that the counting\nresults obta.ined by level-crossing count methods and peak count methods compare\nrather well. For most of these counting methods the differences actually turned out to\nbe surprisingly small, especially for the c.g. -acceleration load-time history. The\nresults of the range count methods exhibit larger differences. Also, with the range\ncounting methods the differences appear to be larger for the strain-gage history. The\ncomparison of the different counting methods with each other is concluded by comparing the level-crossing and peak count methods with the range count methods.\nThree different ways are used to convert level-crossing and peak countings into range\ncountings. The results show that level-crossing and peak count methods do not compare well with range count methods.\n565\n\nFinally, the described counting methods are evaluated from the fatigue point of\nview while bearing in mind the purposes they will have to serve. It is concluded that in\nassessing the life consumed by individual aircraft, a sophisticated range count method\napplied to strain-gage histories should be preferred. For the selection of design spectra\nof future aircraft or a fatigue-test setup, level-crossing and peak count methods may be\nsuitable ; in fact, they may even be preferred.\nINTRODUCTION\nA major question in designing against fatigue concerns the assessment of the\nloading environment to which the aircraft will be subjected during their service life.\nCivil and military transport aircraft generally appear to be fatigue sensitive with respect\nto gust loads. This gust loading environment is substantially independent of the aircraft\nitself. In the past, extensive measurement programs have been carried out which\nenabled the assessment of the quantitative rules determining this loading environment .\nHigh-performance aircraft appear to be relatively insensitive to gust loads with\nrespect to fatigue. With this type of aircraft, fatigue damage will be primarily due to\nmaneuver loading. However, in contrast with gust loads the maneuver loading depends\ngreatly on both the tasks to be carried out and the maneuverability of the aircraft and is\nsubstantially independent of external conditions. On the one hand, the maneuvering capabilities of the aircraft as well as the intended usage differ enormOUSly from aircraft\nto aircraft. On the other hand, the way in which the intended composite tasks are\ncarried out will be highly dependent on training philosophy, pilot experience, and such .\nTherefore , the resulting loading severity will be somewhat unknown and, in addition,\nwill exhibit important differences from aircraft to aircraft. Consequently, to assure\nadequate structural integrity (especially with fighters and military trainer aircraft) ,\nload monitoring - either individual monitoring or sample monitoring - has to be considered mandatory. Such load monitoring will provide the means to assess the life consumed by the individual aircraft and will also provide information rega rding load spectra\nto be used in future aircraft designs and fatigue testing. Within this scope the National\nAerospace Laboratory has carried out a tentative load monitoring program under contract for the Royal Netherlands Air Force. Continuous load-time histories became\navailable from both the c.g. acceleration and a wing-root- bending- moment strain-gage\ninstallation.\nTo analyse such load- time histories for fatigue evaluation purpos es, a numbe r of\ncounting methods are available in which the number of certain load occurrences is\ncounted. In the past, these counting methods were compared to each other with respect\n\n566\n\nto gust loads. Bearing in mind the nature of a gust loading environment, the results of\nthat evaluation are not self-evidently applicable to maneuver-induced load-time\nhistories.\nThe main theme of the present paper is to evaluate the basic counting methods\nwith respect to maneuver-type loading. The results will be discussed from the fatigue\npoint of view while taking into account the purposes they might serve.\nPRINCIPLES OF DATA ANALYSIS\nActual load-time histories will consist of a number of load excursions with an\nirregular pattern and in irregular random sequence. The analysis of load-time histories has to be such that the amount of damage caused by these load excursions is\nsomehow quantitatively reflected in the final results. With all analysis procedures of\npresent interest, the actual time scale is irrelevant. Actually, the assumption is made\nthat for fatigue evaluation purposes load-time histories are fully characterized by all\npeak values in their actual sequence irrespective of the time elapsed between successive peaks.\nA number of different counting methods do exist in which specific occurrences\nwithin such simplified load histories are counted. The occurrences of interest are the\nfollowing:\n(1) Crossings of fixed levels with either a positive or a negative slope\n(2) Peak values (either maxima or minima)\n(3) Load variations (either load increments or decrements)\nWith counting procedures of type (1) and type (2), the counting results usually do\nnot provide any direct information about those load variations known to influence the\nfatigue process. Additional information about the load patterns that do occur will generally be needed. Thus, secondary counting prinCiples should be applied to account for\nsequence effects.\nThe different counting methods will be described in the next section. The discussion of each method will comprise these two distinct elements:\n(1) Uniqueness of the counting method\n(2) Usefulness of the counting results\nThe aspect of uniqueness will be discussed in connection with the secondary\ncounting principles. In applying these secondary counting prinCiples arbitrary parameter values may have to be adopted which may influence the final counting results.\n\n567\n\nSelf-evidently, such influence (if considerable) would reduce the validity of the\ncounting method, and the results would no longer be unique.\nThe usefulness of a counting method is influenced by its application; this relationship forms the basis for the discussion of the counting methods. The basic purposes\nare as follows:\n(1) Estimating the life consumed by individual aircraft\n(2) Estimating load spectra for future aircraft designs\n(3) Selecting the loads for fatigue testing\nThe discussion will take into account the state-of-the-art in realiSing these three\npurposes.\nDEFINITION OF COUNTING PROCEDURES\nTen different counting procedures are considered in the present evaluation,\nenumeration of which can be found in table I. It should be noted that although all methods\nare derived from the literature (refs. 1 to 7), slightly different names have been adopted\nfor some of the methods to emphasize the characteristic differences between them.\nSimple Level-Crossing Count Method\nThe simple level-crossing count method is the simplest way of analysing load\nhistories. A number of preset levels are chosen . . Each time the load crosses one of\nthese levels with positive (or negative) slope, a count is made. Obviously, it does not\nmatter whether level crossings are counted with positive or negative slope. Both procedures will provide almost exactly the same results (maximum difference will be\n1 count at each level for each load history analysed). With this method only momentary\nload values are of interest. Information regarding the actual load patterns is fully lost.\nIn order to interpret the counting results for fatigue evaluation purposes, additional\ninformation will be needed regarding the expected load patterns. The insufficiency of\nthis counting method is clearly demonstrated by figure 1. Although the load patterns\nshown on the left-hand and right-hand sides of this figure are highly different, the same\ncounting results will be obtained. Small intermediate load variations, which virtually\nare of minor tmportance in the fatigue process, will give rise to additional countings.\nGenerally, interpretation of the counting results will be such that the number of\ncrOSSings of a level is assumed to equal the number of maxima above (or minima below)\nthat level. Figure 1 also clearly demonstrates the incorrectness of this assumption.\nObviously, small intermediate load variations seriously hamper the validity of this\ncounting method. In practical applications a secondary restriction may be applied to\n\n568\n\ncompensate to some extent for this setback. It may be decided to neglect level\ncrossings which are associated with load variations smaller than a certain range value.\nThis decision would actually mean skipping all load variations which do not exceed that\nassumed range value. This range filtering may be carried out by means of a logical\nsystem or may be due to the type of load transducer used, as for example with scratch\ngages (ref. 8).\nRestricted Level-Crossing Count Method\nThe restricted level-crossing count method applies the same primary counting\nprinciples as the simple level-crossing count method. Different secondary counting\nprinciples are applied, however. A crossing of a level with positive (or negative) slope\nis not made until the load also has crossed a second lower (or higher) preset level in\nopposite direction. This counting method is associated with the so-called "Fatiguemeter"\ndeveloped at the British Royal Aircraft Establishment (RAE) and is normally referred to\nin the literature as the Fatiguemeter count method. Although the Fatiguemeter was\ndeveloped to count acceleration occurrences, the method may also be used to monitor\nother parameters such as strains. The adjustment of the secondary counting levels\ngenerally is of arbitrary nature. The drop or rise required to satisfy the secondary\ncounting condition may be the same for all counting levels or may be chosen in a progressive way. With the progressive adjustment, the higher (or lower) the primary\ncounting level concerned, the larger is the drop (or rise) required to satisfy the secondary counting condition. Still, however, interpretation is hampered by intermediate load\ncycles as is clearly demonstrated by figure 2. Rather different load patterns are\ndepicted on the left-hand and right-hand sides of this figure but, as in the simple levelcrossing count method, they will produce equal counting results.\nSimple Peak Count Method\nWith the simple peak count method all peak values are counted. The counting\nresults are presented separately for the maxima and the minima. From the definition\nit is understood that with this counting method, as well as with all other peak count\nmethods, the load patterns that actually occur are taken into account to some extent\nsince application of this method implies a peak detection. However, the counting results\nwill not provide any information regarding the sequence of the maxima and the minima\nthemselves. It is not possible to tell whether a counted peak was actually associated\nwith small or large load variations. Again interpretation is seriously hampered by the\nsmaller intermediate load variations. Much the same as with the simple level-crossing\ncount method, a secondary counting condition may be introduced to more or less compensate for this setback by disregarding peaks which are not associated with at least a\n\n569\n\ncertain load range. It sometimes is decided to count only maxima above a specified\nmean level and minima below that level. This Simplification does not improve the\nvalidity of the counting results at all. For example, minima associated with minor load\nranges are sometimes neglected whereas the adjacent maxima would still be counted.\nLevel - Restricted Peak Count Method\nThe principles of the level-restricted peak count method are very much the same\nas those of the restricted level- crossing count method (Fatiguemeter counting). In contrast, however, with the restricted level- crossing count method, only a count is made\npertaining to the highest primary counting level that has been crossed before the secondary counting condition was met, after which all othe.r previous crossings of primary\ncounting levels are disregarded. Actually, the crOSSings of primary and secondary\ncounting levels are considered merely to detect a peak associated with at least a certain\nload range. Figure 3 shows a comparison of this method (see fig. 3(b)) with the\nrestricted level-crossing count method (see fig. 3 (a)) . The final counting results do not\nprovide definite information regarding the actual sequence of the maxima and the minima.\nThe method has been widely used in association with VGH recording programs (ref . .3) .\nRange-Restricted Peak Count Method\nWith the range-restricted peak count method, the intention is to count merely the\nmore significant peaks. The method will merely count peaks that are associated with\nmajor load variations. The counting is restricted to peaks beyond mean threshold levels\n(e.g., minima below O-g and maxima above 2- g) . The peaks to be counted are those which\nare both preceded and followed by drops (or rises) of at least a certain magnitude (e.g .,\nI-g increment) or exceeding a fixed percentage of the incremental peak value (e.g.,\n50 percent), whichever is the greater. Here the incremental peak value is defined as\nthe difference between the peak value itself and the mean load level. The counting conditions for a maximum count are illustrated in figure 4. From the definition it is understood that intermediate load fluctuations are disregarded rather rigorously by this\nmethod. The method also neglects some load fluctuations which are not truly insignificant. However, counts pertaining to the higher maxima and the lower minima have\nbecome more relevant. The method has been used extensively with VGH recording\nprograms (ref. 6).\nPeak- Between-Mean- Crossings Count Method\nThe peak-between-mean- crossings count method is also intended to count only the\nmore Significant peaks. Only the highest maximum or the lowest minimum between two\nsuccessive crOSSings of a specified mean level is counted. With this method intermediate\n570\n\nload fluctuations are disregarded most rigorously. However, all counts are now known\nto be associated with major deviations from the steady-flight level. A further refinement of the counting procedure may be obtained by applying two mean threshold levels\nas references. The highest maximum will be counted between any two successive\ncrossings of the upper threshold level, as well as the lowest minimum between any two\nsuccessive crossings of the lower threshold level. The method is illustrated in figure 5.\nWith this refinement, peaks associated with minor deviations from the steady-flight\npattern will also be neglected. On the other hand, less high maxima and lower minima\nwill be disregarded in applying this counting procedure. The method has been used\nextensively in evaluating VGH records (ref. 9).\nSimple Range Count Method\nWith the simple range count method as well as with all other range count methods,\nthe load fluctuations are of direct interest. The fluctuations are known to be a primary\ninfluence in the fatigue process. A range is defined as the difference between two successive peak values. With the simple range count method all ranges are counted. It\nshould be noted here that counting ranges essentially implies a peak detection procedure.\nWith this simple range count method the loading sequence is taken into account to some\nextent; that is, with each count two succeeding characteristic values of the load history\nare considered. However, information regarding the peak values themselves is completely lost.\nIn practical applications it may be decided to neglect small load fluctuations which\n\nare not of much importance for the fatigue process. As is illustrated in figure 6, disregarding such small load fluctuations does affect the final counting results seriously.\nApparently, the final counting results will depend on the magnitude of the smallest load\nrange that will be counted.\nIt may also be decided to count only ranges pertaining to load increments or load\ndecrements. One should bear in mind, however, that the counting results for the positive\nranges might differ appreciably from the counting results for the negative ranges.\nConsequently, such a Simplification might yield less relevant reSults.\n\nRange-Mean Count Method\nThe prinCiples of the range-mean count method are very much the same as with\nthe simple range count method. However, this counting method does provide additional\ninformation. Not merely the load ranges are counted. With each count the corresponding\nmean value of the load range counted will also be taken into account. So each count is\nnow associated with two values which completely describe the load variation concerned.\n\n571\n\nAs is clear from the definition, the counting results will again be sensitive to the\nsmallest load range regarded.\nRange- Pair Exceedance Count Method\nThe range-pair exceedance count method is intended to analyse load histories in\nterms of load cycles rather than load ranges (half cycles). Since fatigue properties are\ngenerally presented in terms of load cycles, this is of course a favourable property.\nTo accomplish a count two conditions must be met. Each count of a range-pair\nexceedance of a certain specified magnitude, say R, will have to be associated with a\nload increment (positive range) of at least R succeeded by a load decrement (negative\nrange) of at least R. By proceeding as such and consecutively conSidering a number of\ndifferent range values, the counting result will finally give the number of range pairs\n(load cycles) exceeding a certain range value R. The counting procedure is illustrated\nin figure 7. The Vickers- Armstrongs strain range counter (ref. 10) is an example of a\ncounting device operating according to this counting method. In conSidering figure 7, it\nbecomes clear that the method will primarily count the major load fluctuations. Small\nintermediate load fluctuations will be regarded as superpositions on the major load\npatterns. Obviously, this counting method does take into account the loading sequence.\nFatigue test experience indicates that this characteristic feature is desirable. The\ncounting procedure also has the advantage of being insensitive to the magnitude of the\nsmallest load range regarded.\nAnother interesting feature of this counting method will become clear by considering the largest range-pair value that will be present in the final counting results.\nBy nature, the range-pair exceedance count method will combine the largest load incre ment and load decrement that both occur in the load history concerned and will count\nthem as one load cycle of that specifiC magnitude. Likewise, the counting procedure will\nalso combine the next largest load increment with the next largest load decrement, and\nso on. From fatigue experience it is known that extreme negative load excursions do\nactually influence the damage caused by a succeeding extreme positive load excursion.\nSo it may be stated that fatigue experience is indeed reflected in the counting prinCiples.\nNevertheless, this feature does imply a complication. It certainly is not relevant to\ncombine a very low minimum with a very high maximum which occur at instances very\nmuch apart. In practical applications the method should be carried out separately on\nsegments of the load history to avoid irrelevant countings. Treating each flight as such,\na separate load-history segment seems to be a both obvious and rather practical\napproach.\nAnother example of a counting device operating according to this counting proce dure is the Schenck range-pair counter (ref. 5). With this counting device, however, the\n\n572\n\nstarting procedure is not altogether in accordance with the basic counting principles.\nIn .starting the counting process the device will analyse the load history as if the\nstarting point of the load history were an extreme minimum. This actually means that\nfor the first count to be made, merely the second condition of the basic counting principles will have to be met. The effect is illustrated in figure 8 and demonstrates that\nthe Schenck procedure will produce higher counting results than the basic procedure. In\napplying the counting procedure on a flight-by-flight basis, the effect on the final counting\nresults might be significant.\nAlthough the range-pair exceedance count method does apply rather sophisticated\ncounting principles, the method is still hindered by two shortcomings:\n(1) No information will be provided regarding the mean values of the load cycles\ncounted.\n(2) Not all load excursions will be fully counted (see fig. 9).\n\nBoth shortcomings are offset by the next counting method.\nRange- Pair- Range Count Method\nThe range-pair-range count method is also intended to count load cycles. The\ncounting procedure operates in two phases. In the first phase all intermediate load\ncycles are detected and counted in connection with the associated mean values. Each\nintermediate load cycle will be eliminated from the load history after being counted.\nThe procedure is continued until the load history does not present any more intermediate\nload cycles. As may be easily verified, the residual load history will necessarily have a\ndivergent- convergent envelope such as depicted in figure 9. In the second phase of the\ncounting procedure, this residual load history is analysed according to the range-mean\ncount method, These counting prinCiples are illustrated in figure 10. The range-pairrange counting procedure is referred to in the literature as the NLR counting method\n(ref. 2) and the rain-flow counting method (ref. 4).\nThis range-pair-range counting method generally has the same advantages as the\nrange-pair exceedance count method without being hindered by its previously mentioned\nshortcomings. It should be noted that this counting method also is intended to analyse\nload histories on a flight-by-flight basis.\nNUMERICAL EVALUATION DATA\nUnder contract for the Royal Netherlands Air Force a tentative load monitoring\nprogram has been carried out. This load monitoring program was intended to serve the\nfollowing primary purposes:\n573\n\n(1) To demonstrate the feasibility of a digital load recording system\n(2) To demonstrate the feasibility of a strain gage as a load transducer in operational conditions for long-term load monitoring\n(3) To emphasize the desirability of recording strain histories instead of acceleration histories\n(4) To evaluate different counting methods\nTwo operational fighter aircraft have been equipped with both an accelerometer\ntransducer at the aircraft c.g. and a bending-moment strain-gage installation in the\nwing root section. Signal values from both transducers were sampled at a scanning rate\nof 24/sec. After being digitised, the data were stored on a magnetic recorder medium\nwith a 15-hour recording capacity. The beginning of each flight could be recognized by\na series of marking numbers which were automatically entered on the recorder medium\nat the activation of the aircraft electrical power. Every 15 flight hours the recorder\nmedium was removed for further proceSSing on ground-based facilities. By means of a\ndigital computer the data were checked for spurious readings after which a data compression was carried out.\nThe data compression reduced the enormous amount of data to a relatively small\nnumber of characteristic data resembling the peak values that did occur. The compressed load-time history still comprises all Significant information for fatigue evaluation purposes. During the data compression phase more than just peak values are\ndetected. Peaks which are not associated with at least a certain relatively small variation are disregarded to reduce the number of data and to remove data that are of less\nimportance for the purposes concerned. The minimum load range thus left in the compressed load-time history amounted to approximately 7 percent of the aircraft limit load\nlevel. When applying the counting procedures just described, such a range filtering is\neither obligatory or does not significantly . affect the counting results since other more\nstringent restrictions are applied. Consequently, the load histories resulting from the\nfinal data compression phase are still suited to evaluate the different statistical load\ncounting procedures. A plot of such a compressed load-time history for a typical fighter\nmission is shown in figure 11. Such load histories - covering some 75 flight hours were used to evaluate the different counting methods. The results of this numerical\nevaluation are presented in the next section.\n\n574\n\n---. --- -------- -----------------------------------\n\nNUMERICAL RESULTS\nGeneral Comments\nThe counting procedures which have been described herein were simulated by\nmeans of a digital computer to analyse the available load-time histories. The results\nobtained with the c.g.-acceleration history and the wing-root-bending-moment straingage history are presented separately. It should be noted that this paper is not intended\nto present a quantitative comparison of the counting results obtained for the acceleration\nhistory with those obtained for the strain-gage history.\nThe load data are presented in arbitrary units as a result of the digitisation\nprocess. In general, the counting results were calculated with an interval width of\n8 units. The results have been plotted without any fairing.\nApplication of some counting methods did imply the definition of a mean level.\nFor the c.g.-acceleration data the 1-g steady-flight level has been defined as such,\nalthough in terms of mathematical statistics this level is not actually the mean value\nbut rather the most probable value. An "equivalent" 1-g level has been assessed to be\nused as mean reference level in the strain-gage data analysiS. Actually, the equivalent\n1-g strain-gage value is not a constant value. Nevertheless, the definition remains\nrelevant since, on the one hand, merely a reference level has to be chosen while, on the\nother hand, with high-performance aircraft the \'variations in this 1-g strain-gage value\nare relatively small in comparison with the load fluctuations of general interest.\nBefore discussing the numerical results, it should be mentioned that the counting\nresults obtained with different counting procedures are not all fully independent of each\nother. The following relations do exist which will all be easily understood by considering\nthe definitions given for the various methods:\n(1) Simple level-crossing counting results may be derived from the counting\nresults obtained with the simple peak count method.\n(2) Simple peak counting results may be derived from both the counting results\nobtained with the range-mean count method and those obtained with the range-pair-range\ncount method.\n(3) Simple range counting results may be derived from the range-mean counting\nresults.\n(4) The results obtained with the simple peak count method and the peak-betweenmean-crossings count method will be the upper and lower limits of the counting results\nobtained with all other level-crossing and peak count methods described.\n\n575\n\n(5) Peak-between-mean-crossings counting results may be derived from the\n\nrange-pair-range counting results.\nResults From Level-Crossing and Peak Count Methods\nThe results obtained with the level-crossing and peak count methods are presented in figures 12 to 15 and table IT.\nAs previously stated, parameter values associated with secondary counting principles may influence the final counting results. The effect is illustrated in figure 12,\nfigure 13, figure 14, and table II for the counting results obtained with the simple levelcrossing count method, simple peak count method, peak-between-mean-crossings count\nmethod, and restricted level- crossing count method, respectively.\nIn figures 12 and 13 it is shown that the value of the smallest load range regarded\n\ndoes indeed affect the counting results obtained with the simple level-crossing and\nsimple peak count method. The effect of doubling the basic range-filter value (Ro)\nfrom 13 to 26 units does not seriously affect the counting results for the higher load\nvalues. Apparently the countings which were additionally disregarded were mainly\nassociated with load cycles near the steady-flight level. Further increasing the rangefilter value hardly changed the counting results for the higher load values. However,\napplying a smaller range-filter value yielded hIghly different counting results. The\nmain conclusion to be drawn is that if a sensible range-filter value is adopted, the\ncounting results for the higher load values are rather unique. It is nevertheless interesting to note that the counting results obtained by analysing the strain-gage history\nappear to be more sensitive to the adopted range-filter value than the results obtained by\nanalysing the acceleration history. In conSidering both load histories in more detail, the\nmajor load excursions from the strain-gage history presented small intermediate load\nfluctuations more frequently than did the major load excursions from the acceleration\nhistory. This effect is most probably due to dynamic effects (dynamic overshoot and\nbuffeting) .\nBy definition it is clear that the restricted level-crossing count method, the levelrestricted peak count method, and the range-restricted peak count method are intended\nto apply secondary counting principles which at least override the applied basic range\nfiltering. From the preceding results the effect of the applied secondary parameter\nvalues may be expected to be rather limited. This limited effect is indeed confirmed by\nthe data from table IT, in which the restricted level-crossing counting results are tabulated by applying two different adjustments of the secondary counting levels. The\ncounting results came out to be only slightly different. Similar results were obtained\nwith the level-restricted and range-restricted count methods. Also with the peakbetween-mean-crossings count method (fig. 14), the influence of the secondary parameter\n576\n\nvalues (e.g., mean threshold levels) was rather limited. From these findings it may be\nconcluded that the majority of the load fluctuations of interest were separate excursions\nfrom the steady-flight level.\nAll the level-crossing and peak count methods described are compared in figure 15.\nAs might be expected from the aforementioned findings, the differences are not large,\nalthough they are more pronounced with the strain-gage data than with the acceleration\ndata. Nevertheless, when accurate data are required, the results obtained with different\ncounting methods are not fully compatible (number of counts may differ by a factor of 2).\nResults From Range Count Methods\nThe results obtained with the range count methods are depicted in figures 16 to 18.\nIt should be noted that these results have been plotted without distinguishing between\npositive and negative ranges. This effect has been studied in connection with the simple\nrange count method. Comparative results showed that when applying the basic rangefilter value of 13 units, the number of positive and negative ranges counted did not differ\nvery much. However, when applying a smaller range-filter value, the differences\nappeared to be much more pronounced. The counting results pertaining to the negative\nranges appeared to be far more sensitive to the applied range-filter value than the\n:!ounting results pertaining to the positive ranges. Apparently, small intermediate load\nfluctuations more frequently occurred after the load had reached a maximum. The overall effect of the applied range-filter value on the results obtained with the simple range\ncount method is illustrated in figure 16. Doubling the basic range-filter value from 13 to\n26 units does appreciably affect the counting results, especially the results obtained by\nanalysing the strain-gage history. When applying a smaller range-filter value than the\nbasic one, the differences were even more pronounced. It should be noted that further\nincreasing the applied range-filter value (>26 units) still yielded appreciably different\ncounting results. Consequently, it is stated that the results obtained by the simple range\ncount method are not unique even when intermediate load fluctuations are disregarded.\nThe counting results from the various range count methods are compared in figure 17. The curves presented illustrate that the range-pair-range count method and\nboth variants of the range-pair exceedance count method do not produce very different\nresults. The simple range counting results, however, appear to be very different. It is\ninteresting to note that with the strain-gage data, both variants of the ra,nge-pair exceedance count method coincide completely because of the presence of the Ground-Air-Ground\n(G-A-G) cycle (with every flight the strain-gage history will exhibit a relatively low\nstarting value).\nIn comparing the mean countings as obtained by the range-mean count method and\nrange-pair-range count method, the results have been averaged - that is, all mean\n577\n\n- -- --\n\n------------\n\ncountings pertaining to a specified range interval have been averaged while a corresponding standard-deviation value has been calculated. The averaged means thus\nderived are represented in figure 18. With the c.g.-acceleration data as well as with\nthe strain-gage data, the range-pair- range count method yielded lower averaged mean\nvalues than did the range-mean count method. However, the differences are much more\npronounced with the strain-gage data. This fact may be easily understood by considering\nthe counting principles of the range-pair-range count method and bearing in mind that m\nevery flight the strain-gage history will both start and end with a low minimum due to\nthe G-A-G cycle. These results clearly demonstrate that with the range-pair-range\ncount method the G-A-G cycle is certainly accounted for .\nThe calculated standard-deviation values corresponding to the averaged means are\nnot plotted in figure 18. It is interesting to note, however, that these standard-deviation\nvalues were approximately equal for all range intervals considered and, besides,\nappeared to be relatively small (order of magnitude of 10 units). From this finding it\nmay be concluded that most load fluctuations of equal magnitude apparently occurred\nbetween approximately the same levels.\nComparison of Range Count Methods With Peak Count Methods\nBy nature the results obtained by the range count methods are not directly comparable with the countings resulting from the level-crossing and peak count methods\nsince different types of occurrences are counted. To enable a comparison the counting\nresults have to be converted. The present comparison will be accomplished by applying\ndifferent ways of converting simple peak countings into range countings. Reference will\nbe made especially to the range-pair-range counting results since this method is\nbelieved to represent best the amount of fatigue damage caused by the load history concerned. The following three conversion procedures are considered (see fig. 19):\n(A) Maxima and minima are supposed to occur in random sequence.\n(B) Maxima and minima are supposed to occur in random sequence; however,\n\nmaxima below a certain level (e.g., 115 units) and minima above a certain level (e.g.,\n95 units) are neglected. Although the additional assumption seems a curious one, the\ncase is relevant since actually the data disregarded generally are not available.\n(C) Maxima are to be combined with minima having the same probability of\nexceedance (equal cumulative frequency).\n\nThe results of these converted simple peak countings as well as the range - pairrange countings and simple range countings are plotted in figure 19. As is illustrated,\nthe applied conversion procedures do produce highly different results. Again the straingage data reveal the largest differences. However, none of the applied conversion\n\n578\n\nprocedures produce counting results which approximately coincide with the range-pairrange countings . From these findings, it is concluded that a quantitative comparison of\nrange countings with simple peak countings as well as with all other types of peak and\nlevel-crossing countings is hardly feasible for the type of load histories concerned.\nDISCUSSION\nBasically the counting methods as described herein are intended to interpret\nirregular load-time histories by counting the number of specific types of load occur rences. In the preceding sections the uniqueness of the information has already been\ndiscussed and illustrated. In discussing the usefulness of the counting results, one\nshould primarily take into account the purposes these results are meant to serve - that\nis, the type of information required.\nIn assessing the life consumed by individual aircraft, reference has to be made to\nexperimental fatigue data, either simple S-N data or full - scaie fatigue test data.\nAccomplishing such life calculations, however, will be useful only if the final counting\nresults are sufficiently accurate. Thus, in assessing the life consumed by individual\naircraft, a counting method should be used which fully takes into account the actual loadtime history and which does not need the application of additional assumptions to be\ninterpreted. Besides, the fatigue damage caused by the actual load-time history should\nbe reflected in the counting results (interaction effects). By conSidering its definition\nand bearing in mind the aforementioned requirements, it is felt that the range-pair-range\ncount method is best suited for asseSSing the individual aircraft fatigue damage. Also,\nthe range-pair exceedance count method may be rather useful; however, with this method\nthe counting results are not definite since no information is provided about the means of\nthe range pairs counted. Consequently, less accurate results are to be expected. It\nshould be noted that the same remarks hold when the counting methods are meant to\ncompare with any degree of accuracy the life consumed by individual aircraft of the same\ntype. Here, however, the requirements perhaps could be less stringent since it may be\nknown that the aircraft are operating according to the same type of load patterns. In\nthis case, restricted level- crossing or restricted peak count methods may be suited as\nwell.\nIn estimating load spectra for future aircraft designs or selecting the loads for\nfatigue testing of an aircraft type that possibly has not even been in service operation,\nthe requirements are somewhat different. Here, great accuracy would be more apparent\nthan real. The load patterns as well as the sequence in which they occur may be entirely\ndifferent with different types of aircraft. In particular, the number of intermediate load\nfluctuations at the higher load levels may be expected to be strongly related to the\n\n579\n\naerodynamic performance capabilities, which may be highly different for different aircraft types. Estimating loading spectra as well as selecting loads for fatigue testing\nusually implies a mission analysis procedure. The number of exercises (during a\nmission) that will be carried out has to be estimated. The assumption made is that each\nseparate exercise is associated with major load excursions from the steady-flight level\n("characteristic events"). Small intermediate load fluctuations are considered of less\nor even irrelevant importance. A counting method should be chosen which will provide\nthe number of such major load excursions and the peak levels they are associated with.\nAs will be understood, the peak-between-mean-crossings count method is very well in\naccordance with these requirements. However, a restricted level-crossing or peak\ncount method may be suited as well. To obtain a loading program for fatigue testing,\nthe number of "events" counted may be arranged in a realistic sequence. Interaction\neffects will then be accounted for to some extent.\nIt can be concluded that the range-pair-range count method apparently has the best\n\ngeneral validity. On the one hand, the method embodies some of the characteristics of\nthe other counting methods mentioned (simple level-crOSSing countings, Simple peak\ncountings, and peak-between-mean-crossings countings may all be derived from the\nresults of this range-pair-range count method). On the other hand, the load histories\nare taken into account by this method as much as possible from the fatigue point of view.\nConsequently, general application is recommended.\nCONCLUSIONS\n(1) Some counting methods require secondary counting restrictions involving the\nchoice of an arbitrary parameter value which may influence the final counting results.\nWith the exception of the simple range count method and the range-mean count method, a\nsensible parameter value can be found which will yield rather unique counting results for\nmaneuver-type load histories.\n(2) The restricted level-crossing and restricted peak count methods will yield\napproximately equal counting results, especially at the higher load levels. The simple\nlevel-crOSSing and Simple peak count methods, however, will yield conservative counting\nresults.\n(3) Level-crOSSing and peak countings virtually do not compare very well with\nrange countings.\n(4) The range-pair-range count method and the range-pair exceedance count\nmethod will produce approximately equal range counting results.\n\n580\n\n(5) Both the simple range count method and the range-mean count method will provide irrelevant information since the counting results are very sensitive to the magnitude of the smallest load ranges regarded.\n(6) Both the range-pair exceedance count method and the range-pair-range count\nmethod provide relevant information in assessing the life consumed by individual aircraft. However, the range-pair-range count method is to be preferred since this method\nprovides additional information about mean values of the ranges.\n(7) In comparing individual lives .of aircraft that are of the same type and that\noperate according to the same kind of duties, a restricted level-crossing or restricted\npeak count method may be sufficiently relevant.\n(8) In estimating spectra for future aircraft designs or in selecting load events for\nfatigue testing, the peak-between-mean-crossings peak count method will provide\nrelevant data.\n(9) The range-pair-range count method will have the best general validity. The\nresults obtained by this method are unique as well as definite and do suit. all purposes.\n\n581\n\nREFERENCES\n1.
