D. Henniker\nBritish European Airways\nUnited Kingdom\nand\nR. G. Mitchell\nBritish Overseas Airways Corporation\nUnited Kingdom\nSTRUCTURE INSPECTION\nThe requirement to operate a civil transport aircraft on scheduled operations for\na period of perhaps 15 to 20 years, with a constant level of safety , creates a need for a\nsystem of continuous monitoring of the structure. At the same time it is implicit that\nno unnecessary work should be done and that the time out of service should be minimal.\nIt is perhaps necessary first to outline the approach to the maintenance and\n\ninspection of the components and systems of the aircraft. It has become apparent that\nmost components, and therefore systems , suffer primarily from random effects . In a\nrelatively few cases a life can also be dictated by a wear-out rate , but random defects\npredominate and have to be dealt with by inspections and functional checks so that the\ndefect is detected at the earliest opportunity.\nBy duplication, or triplication , the integrity of the aircraft can be maintained , and\nthe study of reliability levels can set the periods for inspection or checks which limit\nthe period of dormant failure. Since a large number of components are functioned on\neach flight, the number of additional checks required to reveal a dormant fault is\nreduced.\nIt can be seen that for systems and components , the optimum periods for inspec-\n\ntion, maintenance , and overhaul can be safely developed in respect of a particular aircraft type and a particular operation by a process of recording and analysing data on\nfailures and strip reports and by general experience gained in service. The aircraft\nitself determines its own maintenance schedule.\nIn respect of structures , a different approach has to be adopted. With the advent\nof fail-safe structures , the duplication of load path which provides failure survivability\nhas been achieved. Unfortunately , no ready indication of failure is available. The\npurpose of inspection is therefore to detect failures before they become catastrophic ,\n599\n\nand to detect such deterioration with time and use which, in itself , will lead to failure.\nThe object of maintenance is to restore the structure to its original condition and to maintain the failure survivability originally built into it.\nIt is natural that there should be a desire to use the same downtime of the aircraft\n\nto deal both with structure and systems. Improved component life and improved reliability lead to longer intervals between major maintenance inputs. There is therefore an\ninevitable clash of requirements because the structure tends to deteriorate with age and\ndemands increased vigilance.\nThe structure inspection that emerges is therefore a compromise influenced by\nopportunity, and it changes with time. In deciding initially on the nature and extent of\ninspection, the design philosophy and the background of fatigue and fail-safe substantiation tests are of paramount importance. A structure inspection schedule for the lead\nfleet of a new type of aircraft is arrived at by extracting the structure content from the\ntotal schedule. A typical structure schedule is outlined as follows (in this schedule flighthours and flights are approximately the same):\nAt each departure and at each 72 hours elapsed time: A general walk-around\ncheck which would detect gross damage , due to either serious structural failure or\ndamage inflicted on the ground.\nAt each 300 hours or flights: A general visual inspection of the complete\nexterior, supplemented by opportunity inspection of such areas where access is\nrequired for maintenance and servicing. This check is also used to monitor any\nitem on special surveillance.\nAt 2000 hours (12 to 15 months): A more detailed visual inspection of the\nlower fuselage, externally and internally , including pressure bulkheads, and doorsurround structure. This is aimed primarily at detecting corrosion. Ultrasonic\nchecks are also made at this interval on bonded stringers in the lower fuselage ,\nand radiographic inspection is made in those areas of the lower fuselage not accessible for visual inspection.\nAt 5000 to 6000 hours or flights (2 to 2t years): The major maintenance\ncheck in which all access panels are removed and all structure inspected visually.\nThis represents the most detailed routine visual inspection of the structure possible\nby normal access, that is, without stripping out interior trim and lagging. At the\nsame intervals - but not necessarily at the same time - radiographic inspections\nare made of closed structures such as\nHorizontal stabilizer\nFin\nPrimary control surfaces\nSlats, flaps , air brakes , and so forth\n600\n\nAll these inspections are carried out on all aircraft in the fleet. The extensive\nareas of the internal structure of the upper fuselage (above floor level) are the subject\nof a sampling procedure. This approach is made because of the extensive downtime\ninvolved if all trim, soundproofing, thermal lagging, air ducts, and so forth are removed.\nExperience has shown that the area below floor level is that most prone to corrosion.\nThis can occur early in the aircraft life and can progress relatively rapidly. Experience\nalso suggests that the upper areas dry out more rapidly, and corrosion is only likely at\na later stage and will develop less rapidly.\nThe sampling programme is therefore started in about the 5th year of operation\n(10 000 to 12 000 hours). Because of the large work load and downtime involved, radiographic inspection is used extensively but is supported by visual inspection as follows:\n.In each of the 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th years of operation, one composite aircraft is examined,\n25 percent by visual means and 75 percent by radiographic means. The samples involve\nnot less than 60 percent of the fleet, and at the end of this period one complete composite\nfuselage will have been examined visually; and three, radiographically. It is planned that\nafter the 9th year the sampling will be extended so that by the 20th year all aircraft in the\nfleet will have been examined completely both visually and radiographically.\nThe choice of inspection method is basically economic. Where visual inspection is\nviable, it is preferred. Radiography is an adequate tool to detect the Significant craCking\nof internal structure such as frames, stringers, and cleats. It can also indicate corrosion and paint flaking - but requires considerable skill in interpretation. A 10-percent\nreduction in material thickness can be reliably detected , provided the corrosion deposits\nare not retained. The critical corrosion along the heel line of a stringer or lap joint is\ndetected mainly by evidence on the adj oining surface.\nIn a particular case where this inspection schedule has been applied up to an aver-\n\nage aircraft life of 12 000 flights or 6 years, 38 defects have been identified. Of these ,\n16 involved fatigu~ cracks, in secondary structure, and two involved corrosion in primary\nstructure. Most of these defects were detected on the major check. In the period concerned , the major check period has been progressively increased from 3000 to 5000 hours,\nor flights, on the basis that those items which have shown up and are not subject to modification action are retained as specific items on the annual or 300-hour inspection.\nFor detection of deterioration that could be the cause of fatigue, this increase in\nthe major check period is feasible. If, however, the major check is to form the basis\nfor detection of fatigue cracks concerned with the fail-safe design concept, then the period\nbetween inspections must have some finite limit. This should be the interval assumed in\nthe design concept from first detectable crack to the point at which crack propagation\nreduces the static strength to proof load. Ideally, this should be demonstrated by a fullscale test for all fatigue-critical regions of the structure. For the aircraft concerned\n601\n\nthe period is not less than 5000 flights, with proof load applied each 2500 flights. On\nthis basis each aircraft structure must be examined in detail at maximum intervals of\n5000 flights. It might well be argued, however, that when the aircraft life is relatively\nlow , so that this interval represents a Significant part of the probable scatter between\nidentical failures on aircraft of the same fleet, then staggered inspection over a longer\nperiod is perhaps justified on the basis that no cracked aircraft will fly more than 5000\nflights before the defect is detected in another of them. It is implicit that all aircraft\nwill be checked within a short period from the discovery of the first defect.\nAs the aircraft life increases, so that the safe period of crack propagation becomes\nsmall in relation to the probable scatter in failure , the inspection would have to be\nincreased to cover each aircraft in 5000 flights. As the aircraft life increases still further so that the probability of failure is high and simultaneous failures become probable,\nit would be prudent to reduce the inspection interval.\nFinally, it would seem logical that whilst the ratio of test life to aircraft life is 5\nor more, inspection can be done on a sampling basis only, to assess the general deterioration, such as corrosion. Thus, an ideal structure inspection schedule would result and\nwould be based on aircraft life and test life. (See fig. 1.) The practical problem would\nthen be to integrate this schedule with the remainder of the maintenance requirements\nand the seasonal demands on aircraft.\nIf there are several operators involved in making up a Significant fleet of "lead"\n\naircraft, there is a case for spreading the initial sampling across all the aircraft to thus\nreduce the requirement on the individual operator. This involves a reporting system so\nthat the manufacturer can coordinate results. There are possibly limitations to this\napproach, since each operator tends to operate on a different route structure and in a\ndifferent environment.\nMost aircraft types operated by British European Airways (B.E .A.) have carried\nsome form of in-flight recording equipment, either fleetwise or on selected aircraft. In\nsome cases this has been a condition in the terms of the warranty on the fatigue life of\nthe primary structure. The recording equipment has fallen into two categories:\n(1) Continuous recording of acceleration thresholds or strain-range thresholds\non entire fleets\n(2) Continuous recording of acceleration thresholds together with other flight data\non a limited number of aircraft\n\nIn the first category , counting accelerometers mounted at the center of gravity record\nthreshold counts at increments of 0.2g between 0 and 2g. Total counts in each level are\nread and recorded at each 300-hour check.\n\n602\n\nFatigue-meter data are fed back to the respective manufacturers at intervals,\ntogether with operational data from which a typical flight plan, representative of the\nroute network, can be deduced. This is done by taking significant samples of summer\nand winter operations and includes take-off weight, fuel state at take-off , cruise altitude,\nand flight duration . Fuel burn-off is computed and thus actual weight and fuel state at\neach phase of flight are deduced. The aircraft manufacturer then computes fatigue damage rate and compares this with the damage rate used in the fatigue test or calculated\nfatigue life.\nSimilar procedures are adopted in the case of strain-range counters, except that\nthese give \'a more direct indication of damage rate and require less operational data.\n\nIn both cases the manufacturers concerned have stated that an increase in service\nlife of up to 30 percent has been possible compared with the service life that would otherwise be imposed. So far, this has all been in respect of those parts of the structure\nwhich are on a "safe life" basis.\nBoth these types of recording instrument are such that they are quite practical for\nan airline to carryon all aircraft. They need little attention and are reasonably reliable.\nAs long as there are safe-life items in the primary structure, the improvement in life\nthat has been possible would appear to be adequate return .\nThe more comprehensive type of observer unit is more questionable. Attempts\nhave been made on two types of aircraft to get a simultaneous record of acceleration\ncounts, speed, height, time of flight, and so forth by use of film recorders, switched on\nat take-off and off on landing by an airspeed switch. " They have been installed in perhaps\ntwo aircraft of a new fleet with the object of obtaining more complete data for an initial\nperiod. The problems with film recorders have been\n(1) Short duration of film leading to either much lost recording time, or very\nfrequent film changes\n(2) Unserviceability revealed only after film development\n(3) Reference still required to flight documents to obtain aircraft weight and\nother data\n(4) Low order of reliability\nThe authors have found from experience that only about 10 percent of the total hours\nflown by the aircraft equipped with the film recorders were satisfactorily recorded. It\ndoes not seem practical to use this type of equipment in the environment of day-to-day\nairline operation.\nIt has been B.E .A. policy to record manually maximum cabin differential pressures\n\nfor each flight on all aircraft. The pilot records this in an appropriate box in the techni603\n\ncal log. This information is extracted and the total flights in each band of pressure, in\nincrements of 1/2 psi, are computed. Where there are maximum lives prescribed for\nmodification or replacement of structure, this information is forwarded to the manufacturers and to the airworthiness authorities at six monthly intervals. All unrecorded\nflights are assumed to be at maximum differential pressure, and a factor of 10 percent\nis added to the recorded pressures to allow for inaccuracies of recording. At the same\ntime, the equivalent flights at maximum differential pressure are computed and forwarded\nto the inspection department to allow mandatory life requirements to be monitored.\nThis policy has yielded Significant benefits where safe-life situations have existed.\nIt allows advantage to be taken of all flights where only low pressures are needed, yet\nretains the advantage of operational flexibility, such as cruise altitude on longer flight\nsections and occasional high rates of descent. This flexibility is otherwise lost if pressure is permanently reduced. On one type of aircraft it has allowed an extension from\n12 500 to 30 000 flights before a major modification, with its accompanying weight penalty,\nwas required and from 17 000 to 50 000 flights before wholesale replacement of fuselage\nskins.\nIt is true to say that the advantages so far gained by continuous recording in airline\n\noperation have all been associated with safe-life structure situations. It is questionable\nwhether real advantages can accrue in the case of a truly fail-safe structure. One of the\nadvantages, to the manufacturer, of a fail-safe philosophy is that the duration of the fullscale test can be reduced. If the structure is designed for a long fatigue life, it is probable that natural failures will not be produced on test. Provided adequate fail-safe tests\nare carried out, this may be satisfactory from an airworthiness point of view, but it would\nseem pointless, in this case, to try and correlate test and actual aircraft usage in order\nto try and predict the operator\'s long-term planning requirements.\nOnly if full-scale testing is extended until fatigue failures occur - and perhaps only\nif these then indicate the need to impose a finite life when action must be taken - can\nbetter data on actual aircraft usage yield some dividends.\nMAINTENANCE ASPECTS\nIt will be appreciated that although the modern public transport aircraft is a highly\n\ncomplex and sophisticated engineering product, it is also the means by which the airlines earn their revenue. The aircraft utilisation rate, which varies during the year and\nreaches its peak during the summer months, is laid upon a foundation of known work programmes which stipulate that various aircraft will be undergoing maintenance for block\nperiods of time during the year. It will be seen, therefore, that in order to support the\ncommercial plans, an extremely well-devised maintenance programme is required. For\n\n604\n\nan airline to operate at optimum efficiency , the maintenance programmes are planned to\nensure that the work requirement is matched by the necessary spares, materials , tools ,\nequipment , and labour at the commencement of the hangar check.\nThe unexpected and nonscheduled problem is, therefore, strictly an economic embarrassment. The discovery of a fatigue crack, corrosion, or any of the other mechanical\nfaults which beset airline operators from time to time and which must be repaired on an\nurgent basis are the ones which really cause the headaches.\nIdeally, the airline engineering base should be a facility carrying out planned maintenance and changing or repairing wornout components. This is, of course , an ideal situation which never exists in practice. For instance , a piece of ground-support equipment\ncould be run into the side of an aeroplane and thus cause a delay to the service. Similarly , the work necessary to repair the unexpected crack in a major piece of structure\ncan soon seriously upset the best planned engineering commitment and rapidly lead to\nnonavailability of aircraft.\nIt must also be remembered that there will be an internal conflict of interests within\n\nthe airline. The production and maintenance departments are charged with producing\naeroplanes for service to meet the commercial demands, and an engineering requirement which may extend the hangar check times or takes aircraft out of service is reSisted,\nunless vital to continued safe operation. Also, since modern aircraft construction is\nmaking ever-increasing use of integrally machined components , which in themselves are\nmuch more difficult to repair in terms of time and complexity than the riveted skinstringer combination, it also follows that the flow of spare parts from the manufacturer\nin the event of a rash of fatigue problems across the fleet could be inadequate to meet\nthe demand.\nAll aircraft exhibit cracks in various structural components. Many of these , having relieved a local stress condition , will then remain static in length for a considerable\nperiod of time, and the aircraft will continue in service with these known defects. Normally such defects are examined for signs of propagation at each scheduled inspection\nuntil the part can be replaced or repaired, ideally at a convenient hangar check. This\napplies mainly to multi-load-path and secondary structure, but of course all cracks and\ndefects are evaluated and a course of action decided upon which is dependent upon the\nsignificance of the defect. In the case of more serious defects the normal procedure is\nto raise a special check on the remainder of the fleet to determine the extent of the problem fleetwise. The speed at which the fleet examination takes place, of course, depends\nupon the severity of the initial defect. In this way the extent of the problem is assessed\nand the final action will take the form of a modification or repair, which can be raised\neither by the air line or manufacturer, or by replacement on a lifed basis. In many cases\nthe defect is subsequently monitored by the addition of a specific item to the approved\n605\n\nmaintenance schedule for inspection at appropriate intervals, or included in the reportable\nstructural inspection programme.\nIn the case of a repair, the structure is usually returned to the "as new" condition,\n\nbut when this is impractical or economically not justified, the fatigue life of the repair\nmust at least match the residual life of the aircraft. In many cases when extensive testing or investigation of a fatigue problem is required, it may be necessary to incorporate\na temporary repair which satisfies limit loads and thus keeps the aircraft flying. The\nlong-term action which may require a slightly more extensive repair can then be carried\nout at a later stage, usually at a major overhaul. It has been found from experience that\nthe manufacturer\'s solution to most light-alloy fatigue failures invariably results in a\nsteel replacement.\nOnce a defect is found, a repeat inspection of the area is established, which can be\nextremely frequent in serious cases. The general accessibility and nature of the defect\nwill determine the method of inspection, that is, visual or nondestructive testing techniques. In any event the general aim is to implement modification-campaign action to\neliminate the defect and its associated inspection.\nWhen a new defect is found , the airline informs the manufacturer, who then advises\nall operators of similar equipment to inspect for that particular defect. The manufacturer\'s notification usually ranges from a newsletter covering general advice, the service\nbulletin which forms the usual channel of communication, to the service cable for serious\nproblems which require rapid investigation.\nSince fatigue failures are generally related to total flying hours or landings , it follows that an airline operating "young" aircraft is less likely to be hit by the nonscheduled\nproblem than an operator with older aircraft of the same type, and has a better chance of\ncarrying out the rectification on a planned basis.\nA large number of fatigue problems encountered can be traced to detail design\nfaults, and occasionally the classic "don\'ts," such as sharp section changes and stress\nraisers, still seem to be perpetuated.\nIt has been found from experience that unnecessary disturbance of an area during\n\nmaintenance can in fact be detrimental in the long run . For example, abrasion of surfaces can break down sealants , particularly in integral fuel tanks, and minute scratches\nare then susceptible to corrosion or crack initiation.\nThe Corporation is an approved design organisation and designs and incorporates a\ngreat deal of repair work, particularly to components. For example, the Corporation has\na great deal of experience on the repair of honeycomb structures. Any repair work must\nmaintain the aircraft to airworthiness requirements. This, of course, includes correct\nheat-treatment techniques , particularly with the high-strength steels , and maintenance\n606\n\nof adequate strength reserves after such rework. A copy of the repairs is automatically\nsent to the manufacturer for his information , but naturally in the event of serious problems the manufacturer is consulted prior to making the repair.\nAlthough the primary airframe structure, critical joints, representative panels,\nand the like are subj ected to extensive fatigue testing at the design and construction stage\nto prove the integrity of the basic airframe, secondary structure does not receive the\nsame consideration. Experience shows that defects in secondary structure tend to be\nrepetitive and are both costly and time consuming to repair or replace. For example,\ncertain areas of most aircraft floors require frequent replacement because of corrosion\nunder and adjacent to galley and toilet areas and for damage due to cargo loading and\nrepeated walking traffic . It would seem that the original floor is largely designed by\nstatic load requirements on the grounds that a stronger and longer lasting floor, because\nof the weight penalty incurred, is not justifiable on economic grounds. This, of course,\nis all good theory , but replacement floor costs are extremely high. Because of the\nabsence of reliable fatigue data on floor materials, various sandwich floor-panel materials were investigated on a cost- effective basis which involved static testing and fatigue\ntesting a large number of samples. In fact, representative panels of various materials\nhave been installed for service evaluation. The airline is, of course, ideally suited to\nperform actual in-service tests, and new ideas are often subjected to field tests in a\ntrue operational environment. Although in the manufacturer\'s initial fatigue test every\nattempt is made to represent a true operational condition, it sometimes happens that\ndespite the best efforts of the designer, a part will fail prematurely because of the influence of a secondary unknown or neglected loading system. A case in point recently\noccurred when a fairly substantial shear angle hidden from immediate view was found\nto have cracks of considerable length along the bend radius. On investigation the fracture face showed that the angle, which had been designed to carry shear loads, was in\nfact also being subjected to secondary bending loads which tended to open and close the\nangle. Fortunately, in this case, the cracks were found before a failure occurred.\nAnother example in which the initial design failed to take complete account of the\nfull loading cycle is the fatigue cracks experienced in top wing skins of some aluminium\nalloys containing a high percentage of zinc. The alloy is chosen in the first instance\nbecause of its mechanical properties and because the normal flight loads give a compressive loading. It has been established, however, that the ground loads, which reverse\nthe wing bending system, cause tensile loads of sufficient magnitude to cause fatigue\ncracks around stress concentrations, fastener holes , for example , in this material.\nOne interesting case of structural failure occurred when the designer had assumed\na certain airspeed for flaps extended for his fatigue analysis within the flaps-out speed\nrange. The pilots , however , were in fact flying the aircraft right up to the flap limit\nspeed, and premature failures occurred. Another problem which occurred was that in\n607\n\n- - - - -- - - -\n\n~\n\n-\n\n-\n\nthe original design certain assumptions were made with respect to ground turns based\nupon airports known at that time. Subsequently the Commercial Department decided that\na great deal of revenue was forthcoming from lesser known airports, and ground manoeuvres in excess of the assumptions were made. Airports are very congested places on the\nground as well as in the air, and ground turns can be dictated by available ground space.\nAn aspect of airline usage which is outside the normal operating pattern is crew\ntraining. It is quite normal for one aeroplane to spend a considerable time on a training\ndetail, and this operation sometimes results in flying techniques which are not up to normal standards. The number of landings are very considerable over a short period of\ntime and since one of the objects of the exercise is to acquaint flying crews with aircrafthandling characteristics which are seldom met in practice, the airframe is subjected to\na great number of loads which are not normally met in passenger service. These facts\nmust be recognized at the design stage. Airframe damage has, in fact, resulted from\ntraining details.\nCivil aircraft are in service for a considerable period of time, some 15 years or\nmore typically. Airframe lives on the order of 60 000 flying hours are commonplace\nwith the current generation of aircraft, and of course the fatigue problem intensifies as\nthe aircraft get older. The economics of airline operation is such that operators are\ncarrying out life-extension programmes in order to achieve these lives by replacing\nand/or reworking critical areas at some stage during the service life of the aircraft. It\nis vital, therefore, that the initial assumptions, analysis, and testing faithfully represent\nas far as possible the complete loading programme and its environment, and that the\neffect of new materials is fully examined, particularly where no previous experience is\navailable.\nEach new generation of aircraft brings a new challenge both to the operator and\nmanufacturer, and the SST will be no exception. The operator must rely on the manufacturer to provide a trouble-free product, and to this end, practical airline experience\nof day-to-day operational problems and practices is freely available. Operational experience should be fed back into new deSigns to ensure long, trouble-free lives, particularly\nat the detail design stage.\nThe addition of speed and temperature will bring new complications to the SST. It\nis to be hoped that the racehorse will not exhibit the temperament of a thoroughbred but\nwill retain the cart-horse stamina for everyday reliability.\n\n608\n\nSUGGESTED BASIS OF MAJOR STRUCTURE INSPECTION\nTEST LIFE\nA/C LIFE\n\n1\xc2\xb75\n\n2\n\n3\n\n5\n\n+\n\n....\n\n+1\n\nL&J\nL&J\n\n+\n\n...J\n\nLa..\n\n....\n\nLa..\n\n!\nI\n\n+\n\nI\n\n-<\n\na:\n(.)\na:\n\n-<\n-\n\n+\n\n~\n\n--... I\nPROPAGATION\n\n-~.\n\n.\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI II I\n\n7 I\n\n[ I\n\nI\n\nI\nI\n\n~.-..\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI I II\n\n+\n\no\n\nAIRCRAFT LIFE\n\n10\n\nYEARS\n\n20\n\n20,000\n\nFLIGHTS\n\n40,000\n\nFigure 1.\nO\'l\n\no\n\n\'"\n\n/100 0/0 FLEET\nINSPECTION\n30 % FLEET\n+ INSPECTION\n\no COMPOSITE\n\nFUSE.INSP.\n\nPRECEDING PAGE BLANK NOT FILMED\nFATIGUE FAILURE OF METAL COMPONENTS AS A FACTOR\nIN CIVIL AIRCRAFT ACCIDENTS\nBy William L. Holshouser and Ruth D. Mayner\nNational Transportation Safety Board\nWashington, D.C., U.S.A.\nSUMMARY\nA review of records maintained by the National Transportation Safety Board\nshowed that 16 054 civil aviation accidents occurred in the United States during the\nI\n3-year period ending December 31, 1969. Material failure was an important factor in\nthe cause of 942 of these accidents. Fatigue was identified as the mode of the material\n~ailures associated with the cause of 155 accidents and in many other accidents the\nr~cords indicated that fatigue failures might have been involved.\nThere were 27 fatal\n,\naccidents and 157 fatalities in accidents in which fatigue failures of metal components\nwere definitely identified.\nFatigue failures associated with accidents occurred most frequently in landinggear components, followed in order by powerplant, propeller, and structural components in fixed-wing aircraft and tail-rotor and main-rotor components in rotorcraft.\nIn a study of 230 laboratory reports on failed components associated with the\n\ncause of accidents, fatigue was identified as the mode of failure in more than 60 percent of the failed components. The most frequently identified cause of fatigue, as well\nas most other types of material failures, was improper maintenance (including inadequate inspection). Fabrication defects, design defiCiencies, defective material , and\nabnormal service damage also caused many fatigue failures.\nI\n\nFour case histories of major accidents are included in the paper as illustrations\nof some of the factors involved in fatigue failures of aircraft components.\nINTRODUCTION\nCivil aviation accidents in the United States were investigated by the Civil Aeronautics Board from 1940 until 1967, when the National Transportation Safety Board was\nestablished as an independent agency within the Department of Transportation. On\nApril 1, 1967, the safety functions of the Civil Aeronautics Board, including the responsibility for investigating and determining the cause of civil aviation accidents , were\ntransferred to the new Safety Board. Hence , the information on accidents used in the\npreparation of this paper was taken from records and files accumulated partly by the\n\n611\n\nCivil Aeronautics Board (CAB) but now maintained by the National Transportation Safety\nBoard (NTSB).\nAn aircraft accident is defined in NTSB Regulations as "an occurrence associated\nwith the operation of an aircraft which takes place between the time any persons board\nthe aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all such persons have disembarked, in which any person suffers death or serious injury as a result of being in or\nupon the aircraft or by direct contact with the aircraft or anything attached thereto, or\nthe aircraft receives substantial damage." The Board regulations also contain definitions of terms , such as "serious injury" and "substantial damage ," that form a part of\nthe definition of an accident. During the last 10 years (1960-1970) the number of civil\naircraft accidents per year meeting this definition has ranged from 4709 in 1961 to 6185\nin 1967. More than 98 percent of these accidents were in general aviation, which, of\ncourse, means that, in general, they involved relatively small aircraft engaged in private\nflying, business trips, and small commercial operations.\nInformation on the extent to which fatigue failures in metal components are involved\nin the cause of accidents was obtained by reviewing accident records and la1;:>oratory\nreports that are available in Safety Board files. The accident records provided considerable data on material failures but did not provide statistically reliable information\nregarding either the mechanism or cause of failure. Hence, the data presented under the\nheading of "Accident Records" is included primarily as background information for the\nresults of the study of laboratory reports. Four case histories of maj or accidents are\npresented as illustrations of some of the factors that are involved in fatigue failures of\naircraft components.\nACCIDENT RECORDS\nThere were 16 054 civil aviation accidents in the United States during the 3-year\nperiod between January 1, 1967, and December 31, 1969. NTSB records show that material failure caused, or was a factor in the cause of, 942 of these accidents. Thus, material failure was involved in the cause of slightly less than 6 percent of the total number of\naccidents during this period. Only 20 of the 942 material failure accidents occurred in\nair carrier operations.\nFatigue was identified as the mode of material failure in 155 accidents. There\nwere many other accidents in which fatigue failures might have been involved but the\nfractures were not identified as fatigue in the record. For example, there were a number of in-flight failures of propeller blades and many cases of connecting rods, connecting\nrod caps, or connecting rod cap bolts failing in reciprocating engines in which the mode\nof failure was not identified. It seemed likely that in many cas es the investigator may\n\n612\n\nhave been unable to recognize evidence of fatigue or that such evidence might have been\ndestroyed by subsequent damage to the fracture surfaces.\nInformation obtained from the accident records is summarized in tables 1 and 2.\nThe serious nature of fatigue failure accidents is shown by the fact that the 16.4 percent\nof the material failure accidents in which fatigue failures were identified accounted for\n31 percent of the aircraft that were completely destroyed , 46 percent of the fatal accidents , and 63 percent of the fatalities.\nThere may be some inaccuracies in the classification of components in table 2\nbecause the specific part that failed was not always adequately identified in the record.\nFor example, a few parts listed as landing-gear components might actually be parts of\nthe hydraulic system or some parts listed under powerplants might be more properly\nidentified as electrical system components. However, the general trend of component\nfailures shown in the table indicates that landing gears and powerplants are major problem areas.\nThe records from which the data in tables 1 and 2 were obtained did not provide any\nSignificant amount of information regarding the basic cause of failure except in one category. Definite evidence of improper maintenance or inadequate inspection was found in\n130 accidents , whereas there were indications that many other accidents might have been\nprevented by better inspection and maintenance procedures.\nThe number of accidents listed in the tables, of course , represent only a small percentage of the total number of material failures in civil aircraft. Most of such failures\ndo not result in accidents and the failed components are replaced or repaired on a more\nor less routine basis.\nLABORATORY REPORTS\nAdditional information regarding the mechanisms and causes of aircraft material\nfailures was obtained from a study of 230 laboratory reports on the examination of failed\ncomponents . These were reports on work done in the Safety Board\' s laboratory , work\ndone for the CAB and the Safety Board at the National Bureau of Standards , and a few\nreports from industry laboratories. All the reports were on components from aircraft\nthat had been involved in accidents between 1962 and 1970. Reports on failed components\nthat were not pertinent to the cause of an accident were eliminated from the study insofar\nas possible.\nA summary of the results of the study is given in table 3. In classifying the causes\nof failure , fabrication defects were listed as such only when they appeared to have been\ncaused by a manufacturing operation. When this kind of deficiency occurred during maintenance, the cause of the resulting failure was classified as "improper maintenance."\n613\n\nThe "abnormal service damage" category includes only failures caused by service damage that probably would not have been detected by normal inspection procedures. The\ncause of failure was listed as improper maintenance if it appeared that the service\ndamage could have been found and repaired prior to failure by ordinary good maintenance\npractice. As anyone who has been involved in the investigation of service failures will\nrealize, the evidence regarding the cause of failure was not always conclusive. In many\nof the cases studied, some element of judgment entered into the classification. Stress\ncorrosion and hydrogen embrittlement failures were grouped together in the table because,\nin some cases, reports of studies of the fracture surfaces with an electron microscope\nidentified the fractures as "stress corrosion or hydrogen embrittlement" but did not\nattempt to distinguish between the two failure mechanisms.\nFatigue failures accounted for more than 60 percent of the failed components on\nwhich laboratory reports were available in NTSB accident files. The distribution of\nfatigue failures among the causes listed in table 3 illustrates one of the major difficul ties of preventing such failures in aircraft. So many different kinds of material defects,\ndesign errors, mechanical damage, and corrosive attack can contribute to the cause of\nfatigue failures that it is extremely difficult to guard against all of the possibilities. As\nin the review of accident records, the results of the study of laboratory reports indicated\nthat improper maintenance is the most frequent cause of fatigue and other types of material failures that contribute to the cause of aircraft accidents.\nSpecific causes of failure included in each category in table 3 are as follows. (No\nattempt was made to list these causes in order of frequency of occurrence. The exact\nnumber of failures due to each specific cause could not be determined because in many\ncases the failure could be placed in one of the broad categories but the cause could not\nbe more specifically defined, mainly because of discrepancies in maintenance records,\ninconclusive results of laboratory work, and more than one factor being involved in\nthe cause of failure.)\nImproper maintenance:\nInadequate inspection\nFailure to replace damaged parts\nFailure to comply with manufacturer\'s service bulletins or FAA Airworthiness\nDirectives\nInadequate lubrication\nFailure to service air drying system\nUnsatisfactory welding\nInadequate shot peening\nFailure to repair damaged protective coating\nInadequate or excessive torque applied to fasteners\nFailure to install fasteners\n\n614\n\nUse of unsatisfactory replacement parts\nInadequate cleanup after repairs\nForeign material left in gear housing\nImproper alteration of components\nSurface damage due to misuse of tools\nInadequate control of plating operations\nGrinding cracks\nApplication of excessive force to press fits not adequately prepared for assembly\nImproper adjustment of gear engagement\nInsufficient thread engagement\nDamage from misuse of inspection equipment\nDeSign deficiencies:\nInaccurate stress analysis (mainly due to insufficient consideration of sources of\nstress concentration)\nInadequate specification of dimensional tolerances\nFailure to allow for fabrication and assembly variables\nSelection of unsuitable material or incompatible combinations of material\nInsufficient consideration of the effect of possible bending loads on parts designed\nto resist tension or compression loads\nInsufficient consideration of the direction of grain flow in forgings and extrUSions\nInsufficient consideration of maintenance problems\nFailure to specify adequate decarburization limits\nFabrication defects:\nMachining errors\nUnsatisfactory welding or brazing\nUnsatisfactory plating\nImproper drilling of rivet holes\nSurface damage by defective tools\nDamage by careless use of tools\nFailure to remove cleaning solution from a closed cavity\nInadequate cleaning after an internal machining operation\nInadequate control of bonding operation\nDefective material:\nSurface decarburization\nHeat treating cracks\nOmitting heat treatment or surface hardening operation\nForging flaws\nDefective extrusion bonding\nOverheating during heat treatment\n\n615\n\nCasting porosity or cracks\nExcessive nonmetallic inclusions\nGas contamination\nFailure to use specified material\nAbnormal service damage:\nEngine overspeed\nExcessive vibration\nFailure of pilot to follow operating instructions\nInadequate securing of cargo\nUnauthorized towing procedures\nExcessive maneuvering loads\nDeformation from undetermined source\nBird strike\nExcessive loads resulting from damage to an associated component\nDISCUSSION\nThe results of the studies summarized in this paper emphasize the importance of\nfatigue and maintenance problems in the operation of aircraft equipment. By far the most\ncommon type of material failure encountered in aircraft accident investigation is in\nlanding-gear and powerplant components of small fixed-wing aircraft. Material failures\nmost frequently cause accidents when they occur while the aircraft is airborne or during\nlanding, although serious accidents may result from failures during any phase of operation.\nOpportunities to reduce the number of accidents caused by fatigue failures and other\ntypes of material problems exist in almost all phases of aircraft construction, maintenance , and operation. The greatest potential for reduction in the number of accidents is\nin improving the maintenance of general aviation aircraft. However, numerous accidents\nin both general aviation and air carrier operations could be prevented by improvements\nin design; better quality control during material proceSSing, fabrication, and assembly;\nimproved inspection and maintenance programs; and more careful handling of aircraft,\nparticularly on the ground during taxiing and towing operations.\nAlthough the air carriers have had relatively few accidents caused by material failure, in the 3-year period included in the review of accident records, 6 of the 20 air carrier accidents in which material failure contributed to the cause resulted in 138 fatal\ninjuries. Accidents involving fatigue failure accounted for 103 of these air-carrier fatalities. In several failures of landing-gear components and jet engine compressor and turbine diSks, major disasters were avoided only by fortunate circumstances. Thus , this study\nindicates that air carrier, as well as general aviation, aircraft have serious material\nfailure problems.\n616\n\nCASE HISTORIES\nFour case histories of accidents due to fatigue failures of components are presented.\nI. Los Angeles Airways, Sikorsky S-61L Helicopter; Compton, California;\n\nAugust 14, 1968\nThis helicopter crashed when a fatigue failure of one of the main rotor blade spindles caused the blade to separate from the rotor hub. The drawing of the failed spindle\nin figure 1 shows the location of the fracture. A fatigue crack had propagated from a\nsingle origin (fig. 2) in the journal-bearing fillet through approximately 70 percent of\nthe cross section of the spindle shank prior to complete failure. The spindle was made\nof quenched and tempered 4340 steel, with a specified hardness of 34 to 38 Rockwell C\nand a specified minimum ultimate tensile strength of 150 000 pounds per square inch.\nThis spindle had been reworked in 1966, 2 years before the accident, according to a procedure recommended by the manufacturer. The rework included regrinding, shot peening, and nickel plating the journal bearing surface and fillet where the fatigue crack originated. In June 1968, approximately 2 months before the accident, during a regular periodic inspection, the spindle was inspected for cracks by a fluorescent magnetic particle\nmethod . No cracks were detected.\nA laboratory study after the accident revealed the following factors that were probably involved in the cause of the spindle failure:\n1. The fatigue crack was a high cycle, low stress, slowly propagating crack that\nprobably had been present when the spindle was inspected for cracks 2 months before\nthe accident.\n\n2. The fatigue nucleus was in the steel, under the nickel plating, in an area where\nvery small, shallow pits were found in the surface of the fillet.\n3. In the area where the fatigue crack originated the steel had a banded microstructure. The overall hardness in this area was 28 Rockwell C, below the specified minimum\nof 34 Rockwell C, and the fatigue nucleus was in one of the softer bands where the local\nhardness was well below 28 Rockwell C.\n4. Residual tensile stress in the fillet surface as a result of nickel plating might\nhave contributed to the initiation of the fatigue crack although the plating process specified by the manufacturer was selected to minimize residual stresses.\n5. The fillet where the fatigue crack originated had not been properly shot peened.\nThis fact is considered to be an important contributing factor as adequate shot peening\nwould probably have eliminated the effect of the shallow pits and would have reduced the\neffect of the banded microstructure and low hardness.\n\n617\n\nII. Lake Central Airlines , Allison Prop-Jet Convair 340; Marseilles , Ohio;\nMarch 5, 1967\nA fatigue failure of a propeller torque cylinder (fig. 3) precipitated the crash of\nthis two- engine , turboprop aircraft. The fatigue failure , however, was caused by a prior\nfailure in another component of the propeller pitch control system. The initial failure\nwas excessive wear in the splines of the torque piston.\nPropeller blade pitch in this aircraft is controlled through torque units (one unit\nfor each of the four propeller blades) operated by hydraulic oil pressure. Through a\nsystem of splines , linear movement of the torque piston in the torque cylinder produces\nchanges in propeller pitch. An increase in hydraulic pressure moves the piston outward\nto increase blade angle and a decrease in pressure permits the normal aerodynamic loads\non the propeller to decrease blade angle. The piston has both internal and external\nsplines and after the accident both sets of splines in one piston were found to be severely\nworn. These splines had not been nitrided as required by the manufacturer\'s specification for the piston. The excessive wear in the splines allowed the piston to float free in\nthe cylinder without engaging the splines of the mating parts. This condition did not\nimmediately cause any detectable change in the operation of the propeller because of the\nredundancy built into the pitch control system . However, each time the oil pressure in\nthe system was increased the free piston was forced hard against the cylinder cap. This\nforce resulted in stresses exceeding the fatigue strength of the cylinder wall and eventually caused a complete fatigue failure of the cylinder.\nExamination of the fracture (fig. 4) showed that small fatigue cracks had propagated\nfrom the inner surface of the cylinder wall and combined to form a continuous crack\ncompletely around the inner circumference of the cylinder. This fatigue crack did not\npenetrate completely through the wall so that hydraulic pressure was maintained until\nthe cylinder failed completely. When the cylinder failed , loss of hydraulic pressure\noccun\'ed so suddenly that the propeller pitch lock failed and resulted in a severe propeller overspeed. All four propeller blades were thrown off the propeller hub; and one\nof them went through the fuselage and caused the airplane to break up in the air and crash.\nThe series of events that led to this accident started with the omission of the nitriding of the torque piston splines. As a result of investigations associated with the accident , changes were made in the quality control system of the propeller manufacturer and\nseveral design modifications were made in the propeller pitch control system. These\nchanges appear to be adequate to prevent a similar set of circumstances causing another\naccident.\n\n618\n\nlIT. Wein Consolidated Airlines, Fairchild F-27B; Pedro Bay, Alaska;\n\nDecember 2, 1968\nThis aircraft encountered severe to extreme .clear-air turbulence and crashed during a flight from Anchorage to Iliamna in Alaska. Investigation of the accident showed\nthat an in-flight structural failure of the right wing had occurred through an area where\nfatigue cracks had weakened the structure on both sides of an access door in the bottom\nsurface of the wing.\nThe piece of wreckage in which the fatigue fractures were found is shown in figure 5. Fatigue cracks had originated at four fastener holes, two on each side of the\naccess door, that were alined in a chordwise direction. These initial cracks had propagated and joined to form a crack about 31 inches long on the aft side of the access opening and about 2~ inches long on the forwaid side. No evidence of fatigue cracking was\nfound in the access door cover. Adjacent to the fastener holes, the fracture surfaces\nwere flat and smooth, as shown in figure 6, but as the cracks progressed away from the\nholes, they showed an increasing tendency to propagate as slant fractures. Numerous\ncrack jump marks (small regions of ductile rupture) were found in both the flat and slant\nfracture areas. An example of the appearance of these jump marks is shown in figure 7.\nFatigue and fail-safe tests of an F-27 wing made several years before the accident\ngave some indication that a load equal to about 77 percent of limit load might have been\nrequired to break the wing with cracks about 3 inches long on both sides of the No.1\naccess door. However, the numerous indications of high stress intensity found on the\nfatigue fracture surfaces suggested the possibility that high gust loads might have caused\na rapid tearing extension of the cracks shortly before the wing failed completely. Such\na rapid crack extension would not have left any visible evidence on the fracture surface.\nIf it included rupture of the access door cover, it would have connected the two fatigue\ncracks; thus the crack length was increased to more than 17 inches and the load required\nfor final failure was reduced.\nA Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Airworthiness Directive requires u.S.\noperators to make periodic inspections for cracks at many locations in the F-27 wings.\nFor several years before the accident, X-ray inspections at 1200-hour service time intervals had been made in the area of the No.1 access door in both wings of the plane that\ncrashed. There was nothing in the aircraft maintenance records to indicate that cracks\nhad been detected. Reexamination of the inspection radiographs after the accident, however, revealed evidence that cracks had been present in the vicinity of the access doors\nin both wings for more than a year before the accident. Crack indications were found in\nthree sets of radiographs made during this period. If the cracks had been detected and\n\n619\n\nreported, the operator would have been required by the Airworthiness Directive to make\nan approved modification of the wing structure which would have increased the strength\nof the access door area where the wing failed.\nAs soon as the crack indications were found in the radiographs, the FAA was notified and a special inspection was recommended by the Safety Board. The FAA issued a\ntelegraphic Airworthiness Directive requiring an immediate inspection for cracks in the\nwings of all F-27 aircraft with 5000 hours or more time in service. Sixty-seven aircraft\nwere inspected in compliance with the Airworthiness Directive and 13 cracks were found\nin eight aircraft.\nIV. TAG Airlines DeHavilland Dove; Lake Erie near Cleveland, Ohio;\nJanuary 28, 1970\nA TAG Airlines DeHavilland Dove crashed through the ice into Lake Erie in January\n1970, after a fatigue failure of a wing attachment fitting. The appearance of the failed\nfitting is shown in figure 8 and the surfaces of the fatigue fracture in figure 9. Fatigue\ncracks had originated at the edge of the hole for the main wing-to-fuselage attachment\nbolt and had propagated through approximately 75 percent of the cross-sectional area at\nthat point before the fitting failed completely.\nThe fitting was made of steel that had been heat treated to an ultimate tensile\nstrength of approximately 175 000 pounds per square inch, and the bore of the hole where\nthe failure occurred had been chromium plated. No chromium plating had been used in\nthe original design, but some fittings with chromium plating in the attachment bolt hole\nwere installed prior to 1961. The National Transportation Safety Board report on this\naccident stated:\n"The manufacturer had long been aware of the problem caused by the chromium plating process and had reduced the \'safe life\' of this fitting to 10 000 flying hours in July 1961 (Technical News Sheet 178). At this time, it was recommended that an inspection for the chromium plating of the root-joint attach fitting\nbe carried out at the next convenient opportunity and, in any case, prior to the\naccumulation of 10 000 flying hours. It was recommended that any fitting found\nto have the chromium plating be changed at the next removal of the wing or before\n10 000 hours, whichever came first. This recommendation had the approval and\nconcurrence of the United Kingdom\'s Air Registration Board. These requirements\nbecame mandatory for aircraft registered in the United Kingdom but not for those\nregistered in the United States.\n"Based upon this recommendation by the manufacturer, the Federal Aviation\nAdministration issued Airworthiness Directive 61-18-3, effective September 1, 1961.\nThis directive repeated the opening preamble of the Technical News Sheet 178 but\nadopted only the requirement to inspect the fitting for chromium plating and to\n620\n\n~~---\n\n---\n\nreplace it, if so plated, prior to the accumulation of 10 000 flying hours. The\nrecommendation to replace any chromium plated fittings at the next wing removal\nwas not made a part of the requirement by the FAA on the U.S. registered aircraft."\nIn November 1965 the wings of the aircraft had been removed for certain required\n\nmodifications. At that time, the fitting that eventually failed had been in service for\n4998 hours. It was inspected for cracks, but was not replaced, and failed after 9383 hours\nof service time. A factor in the failure of the fitting before it reached the 10 OOO-hour\nmandatory removal time was the severe operating conditions at TAG Airlines. TAG\nflights were considerably shorter and were flown at higher speeds and lower altitudes\nthan the standard flight profile for Dove aircraft.\n\n621\n\nTABLE 1.- U.S. CIVIL AVIATION ACCIDENTS INVOLVING MATERIAL FAILURE\nAS A CAUSE OR CONTRIBUTING FACTOR\n\n@anuary 1, 1967 to December 31, 196~\nAir\ncarrier\nAll material failure accidents:\nNumber of accidents . . .\nNumber of fatal accidents\nNumber of fatalities . . .\nMaterial failure accidents involving\nfatigue failure:\nNumber of accidents . . .\nNumber of fatal accidents\nNumber of fatalities . . . .\n\n622\n\nGeneral\naviation\n\nTotal\n\n20\n\n922\n53\n110\n\n942\n\n6\n\n138\n\n12\n4\n103\n\n59\n\n248\n\n143\n23\n\n155\n\n54\n\n157\n\n27\n\nTABLE 2.- U.S. CIVIL AVIATION ACCIDENTS INVOLVING MATERIAL FAILURE\nAS A CAUSE OR CONTRIBUTING FACTOR\n@anuary 1, 1967 to December 31 , 196~ .\nNumber of\naccidents\nType of aircraft:\nSmall fixed wing\nLarge fixed wing\nTurboprop . .\nReciprocating engine\nTurbojet and turbofan\nHelicopters . . .\nPhase of operation:\nIn-flight.\nLanding . . . . . .\nTake-off . . . . .\nTaxiing or towing\nParked . . . . . .\nExtent of damage to X V3.\n\n629\n\nFigure 9. - Appearance of the fracture in the failed fitting shown in figure 8. X 2.\n\n630\n\nFATIGUE TESTS ON BIG STRUCTURE ASSEMBLIES\nOF CONCORDE AIRCRAFT\nBy V. P. N\'Guyen\nSociete Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale\nToulouse, France\nand\nJ. P. Perrais\nCentre d\'Essais Aeronautiques\nToulouse, France\n\nINTRODUCTION\nThe Concorde, a delta-shaped-wing aircraft, has been submitted to numerous material, attachment and protection tests since, with its structural design, it is capable of\nreaching supersonic speeds (Mach number, 2.05). In addition, this aircraft has been\ntested in the scope of structural engineering tests performed on substructures. In this\npaper, only development tests on large structure assemblies and airworthiness substantiation full-scale tests are considered.\nThis paper is limited to the tests performed at the Centre d\' Essais Aeronautiques\nof Toulouse (C.E.A.T.), France. The tests carried out in the United Kingdom are to be\npresented by the Royal Aircraft Establishment (R.A.E .). As a rule, the development\ntests achieved both in France and in the United Kingdom are usually performed on structures for which Aerospatiale and British Aircraft Corporation are responsible. All certification static tests are to be carried out in France and all certification fatigue tests are\nto be performed in the United Kingdom.\n\n/\n\nEXPERIENCE FROM STATIC TESTS\n\nTwo main sections have been submitted to pressure, mechanical load, and thermal\nstatic tests and are shown in figure l.\nI\nI\n\nI\n\nFuselage Section 1 bis.\n\nThe structure, named fuselage section 1 bis. or 1(a), consisted of a 4.68-meter-Iong\ntwin-looped cylindrical fuselage section including six standard frames and two main\nfrrmes. On both sides of the lower part of the fuselage, rectangular structural boxes\nrepresented the wing assembly and its fuselage junction section. The purpose of this\noperation was to create the same thermal stresses over this area as those encountered\n,\n631\n\nin flight. The skin panels (A - U2GN sheet) were attached in a classical way to the\nstringers and frames.\nThe aim of the tests was to observe the structural behaviour under the most severe\nflight conditions such as combined pressurization, fuselage torsion and loads on floor,\nand thermal stresses. Test measurements of temperatures and mechanical strains were\nalso compared with calculated values of thermal stresses in order to (1) justify design\nmethods, (2) make an analysis of the role played by thermal stresses among total stresses\n(to manage a test program of structures which will be tested in the future), and (3) perfect\nnew test methods, especially in the scope of infrared heating and air-cooling units\ninjecting liquid nitrogen. The tests started at the end of 1964 and ended in the spring\nof 1966.\nThis testing enabled the manufacturer to check for the thermal stress level in the\nfuselage areas hidden by the wing assembly and in the longitudinal stringers located at\nthe bottom of the fuselage. (Fig. 2 shows the results of comparative tests on the heated\nlower part and the unheated lower part to simulate the presence of a fuel tank.) It was\nnecessary to carry out tests, especially fatigue tests, by representing in a most accurate\nway thermal stresses where they are significant.\nSection 2.8.b\nThe test structure, section 2.8.b, was composed of a fuselage section (first definition of the aircraft, 10 m ;: : 35 ft long) and of main adjacent wing elements having an overall span of 44 ft. (Refer to fig. 1.) This structure is a genuine aircraft element. The\npurpose of the test was\n(1) To check in a more exact way the aircraft design methods. Therefore, the test\nstructure itself with its proposed end effects has been calculated by means of the same\nnetwork as an aircraft (analog electrical network for internal load computation).\n(2) To compare thermal stress distributions obtained from different aircraft missions. These distributions are not easily obtained by computation.\n(3) To evaluate fuel influence in the tanks on these thermal stresses.\n(4) To study the superimposition of cabin and tank pressure, of air and inertia\nloads, and thermal effects.\n(5) To prove the "fail-safe" characteristics of this structure by making some cuts\nto simulate cracks in the main spars, ribs, and frames, and then performing residualstrength tests.\n\n632\n\n(6) To familiarize test laboratories with exceedingly complex installations in order\nto proceed with the certification static tests on a full-scale aircraft structure (fig. 3)\nunder satisfactory conditions.\nThese tests commenced in the autumn of 1966 and ended in the summer of 1969.\nResults are too extensive to be presented in this paper. Therefore, only tests which\nmade it possible to perfect the fatigue test programs are presented.\nIt was shown by the design calculations that the maximum thermal stress values\n\nhighly depended upon the aircraft acceleration laws. This dependence was verified when\na few wing panels buckled locally during tests simulating missions with high acceleration\nand low take-off weight. (See fig. 4.) (It was a case of a flight corresponding to a previous definition of the aircraft.) The purely thermal stresses remain moderate in absolute value but are reversed, and their peak-to-peak values are significant. The presence\nof fuel causes the stresses in heavy parts of spars and ribs to be reduced. On the other\nhand, the internal skin surface is subjected to tensile thermal stresses when the fuel\ntank is empty. These tensile stresses add to the internal tensile stresses due to flight\nloads. The following conclusion may be drawn from this program. For tests on partial\nstructures, great care should be exercised in Simulating the temperature distributions\nover the fuselage internal areas (especially those areas hidden by wing assemblies). (The\nparasite end effects are very strong.)\nBecause of the high strength of the fuselage in the presence of large cuts (as\nrequired in the FAA fail-safe tests), fatigue tests can be safely conducted by using air to\ncyclically pressurize the fuselage.\nA few "dynamic-cut" tests which were performed on the fuselage throughout frames\nended the fail-safe tests; the data from these tests will be used for certification\nsubstantiation.\nSTATIC TESTS FOR AmWORTffiNESS SUBSTANTIATION\nThe test structure is a full-scale aircraft. The test program consists of a\nsequence of tests to be performed under room-temperature conditions and including five\ndifferent tests with loads on a part of the aircraft. All tests were conducted at least up\nto ultimate design load of the structure and some of them even beyond. The latter\nsequence of tests will be made under thermal conditions about July 1971 and will start\nwith thermal tests only, during which several aircraft missions will be achieved under\nrealistic conditions. In a first stage, to investigate ovens and cooling problems, C.E .A.T.\nwill use calculated temperatures which are being verified by means of flight measurements on the prototype. The test temperatures will be submitted to the Airworthiness\nAuthorities for approval. Figures 5 and 6 illustrate different static-test sequences.\n633\n\n- --\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\n-\n\n----\n\nFATIGUE TESTS\nThese tests have been performed on many structural components, but the test programs achieved by use of big substructures 2.3.2 and 2.6/2.7 (fig. 1) are by far the most\nsignificant.\nPreliminary static tests showed that it was necessary to reproduce the temperature\ndistributions during acceleration and deceleration sequences. When the fatigue test programs were initiated, it was found that this operation would require a test of long duration; the time cycle in the laboratory was almost equal to the time required for an actual\nflight. It was absolutely necessary to compromise some part of the test program in\norder to obtain some desired results for the structural behaviour within a reasonable\nperiod of time.\nTwo changes were made in the test program to compensate for accelerating the\nthermal tests: (1) To compensate for creep, normal structural temperature has been\nincreased by 20 0 C (from 1000 C to 1200 C), (2) To compensate for deteriorations due to\nthermal stresses, the heating rate d 8/dt has been increased during acceleration and\ndeceleration sequences in order to increase the stresses by 15 to 20 percent, depending\nupon particular components.\nIn order to a ccelerate testing, the time during which the external wall temperatures\nwere constant was decreased. Figure 7 shows that this decrease was feasible since\n(a) the same maximum temperatures were achieved as in actual flight for both external\nwall and internal structure, (b) the wall and structure returned to room temperature at\nthe end of the programed time cycle, and (c) the heating sequence during the time of constant temperature produced satisfactory thermal gradients during the deceleration\nsequence.\nOn the test section 2.3.2, this requirement was met by blowing hot or cold air onto\nfuselage areas hidden by the wing assembly. On test section 2.6/2.7, the same result\nwas obtained by injecting hot and cold liquid into the fuel tanks, as required. These procedures are called "complementary means."\nDetermination of Cycle\nRandom maneuver and gust loads were applied by lever jigs. For these development tests to be performed, it was preferable to reduce the typical loading spectrum to\nits simplest terms to investigate more easily the possible crack propagation rates. Pressure loads, since they are actually known, have been used at their flight true values; that\nis, p = 736 mb inside the cabin compartment, and p = 250 mb inside the fuel tanks.\nThermal stresses were increased 10 to 20 percent, depending upon the area, to accelerate\n\n634\n\nthe observance of the deteriorations due to thermal stresses. By using this increase, an\nattempt was made to double the damage value due to thermal stresses.\nThree mechanical and three pressure cycles were superposed on each thermal\nstress cycle. In one instance (A), the mechanical and the pressure cycles were applied\nsimultaneously while the thermal stresses were high. In two other instances (2B), the\nmechanical and pressure cycles were applied simultaneously while the thermal stresses\nwere small or nil (corresponding to a slow return to room temperature). This sequence\nof loading produced a threefold increase in damage due to the usual loads. Cycles\nC = A + 2B are performed one after the other.\nFinal Test Conditions\nFinal test conditions were based on and perfected from typical tests. During these\ntypical tests, the actual flight real time requirements were met in order to accurately\ndetermine the required heating rates and thermal stresses during a flight. Based on the\nresults of these typical tests, several short time cycles were tested and complementary\nmeans were used to obtain the desired temperature and stress evolution (especially\npeak-to-peak) at all significant measurement points. The complete time cycle of test\n2.3.2 is shown in figure 8; whereas the complete time cycle of test 2.6/2.7 is shown in\nfigure 9. It is easily noticed that with 1 hour\'S cycle (of which 40 minutes is thermal)\nfor 2.6/2.7 tests and that with a 34 minutes\' cycle (of which 26 minutes is thermal) twice\nthe thermal damage and three times the mechanical damage of a 3 hr 15 min flight is\nproduced.\nResults Obtained on Test Structure 2.6/2.7\nBy March 10, 1971, 9900 cycles (A + 2B) and 10 900 additional B cycles (representing purely subsonic flights) were applied. This stress history corresponds to the\ndamage caused by 40 600 flights under mechanical fatigue conditions and about\n19 800 flights under thermal fatigue conditions. The deteriorations that were noticed\noccurred on the (current) fuselage frames at the level of the cabin floor. They were due\nto a combination of pressurization and thermal cycles. As a result of these deteriorations, design improvements were made on partial assemblies representing the damaged\narea (fig. 10). In tests on these partial assemblies, a special fixture was used to simulate\nthe frame warping due to thermal stresses. The results of these tests were very satisfactory, and enabled an excellent behaviour of the frames to be foreseen on series\naircraft.\n\n635\n\nResults Obtained on Test Structure 2.3.2\nBy March 1, 1971, 14 000 complete cycles (A + 2B) and 4000 purely subsonic flights\nwere applied. This stress history corresponds to the damage caused by 46 000 flights\nunder mechanical fatigue conditions and about 28 000 flights under thermal fatigue conditions. The deteriorations that were noticed confirm those which were obtained with the\nsubstructure 2.6/2.7 , and indicated that the same design improvements were required.\nSome minor deteriorations were found in the door and emergency exit lOCking devices.\nThese deteriorations very likely come from local bending effects due to thermal stresses,\nand to defects in the door. A few cracks on metal sheets were detected and the investigation of the crack propagation rate is being made. Inside the wing fuel tanks, the original rods fitted with clevis welded by an electron bombardment process did not have a\nsuitable fatigue life and have been replaced by conventional design rods.\nResidual Strength Mter Deteriorations\nDeteriorations, especially those concerning fuselage frames, were always found\nduring the systematic inspection of the structures, that is, following completion of a program block including 1000 cycles (A + 2B) . The damaged structure exhibited satisfactory\nresidual strength during the last cycles of the program block.\nA flight limit load test upon occurrence of deteriorations has just been made on\nstructure 2.6/2.7; this test will be used for certification purposes. Figures 11 and 12\nillustrate the test rigs 2.3.2 and 2.6/2.7.\nCONCLUSIONS FROM DEVELOPMENT TESTS\nThe main conclusions are as follows:\n1. On a supersonic aircraft whose structure weight is a Significant part of the weight\n\nanalysis, many fatigue and static strength development tests should be made.\n2. Fatigue thermal tests are absolutely necessary. Temperature and thermal\nstress calculations, although they are very developed, cannot foresee any fatigue failures\ncaused by distortion incompatibilities which are not easily evaluated.\n\n636\n\n2.8. b\n\n2.3.2\n\nSTATIC TEST\n\nFATIGUE TEST\nFRENCH\n\nTEST\n\nCONCORDE\n\n2.6/2.7\nFATIGUE TEST\n\nSUBSTRUCTURES FOR\n\nDEVELOPMENT\n\nTESTS\n\nFigu re 1.\n\n637\n\nSTRINGER\nSTRESS)\ndaN/mm 2\n\nz\n\nksi\n\n\xc2\xb0C\n115\n100\n\n80\n\nSTRINGER\nTEMPERATURE\nWITH FUEL\n\n6\n\no\n~\nz\nw\n\nTEMPERATURE)\n\nSTRINGER TEMPERATURE\nWITHOUT FUEL\n\n4\n\n,-,\n__\n\n~2\n\n60\n\n"\\.\n\n"\\.\n-~-\n\n"-\n\n40\n20\n\no ~~--~~--~--~--~----~~~--~~~ o\n"\n3,000\n\n-2\n\\\n-4\n\\\\\no\n~ -6 :10\\\n\nSTRINGER THERMAL\n\nz\n\nw\n\ng:\n\n-8\n\nSTRESS WITH FUEL\n\n1\n\n2\n\nI\n\nI\n\n0-10\nU\n-12\n\n./\n\n\\\n\n-20\n\n4,000\n\n\\\n\n"\'\n-"\n\n,,"\n\n/\n\n----- ---\n\ns,doo\n6,000\n7,000\nI TIME) seconds -20\n\'\nI\n\nI\n-)\n\n- - - - - -- - ,\nSTRINGER THERMAL\nSTRESS WITHOUT FUEL\n\nSTRUCTURE 1 bis -EFFECT OF THE FUEL ON LONGITUDINAL THERMAL\nSTRESSES ON A BOTTOM STRINGER OF A FUSELAGE FUEL TANK\nFigu re 2.\n\n638\n\n2.
