FURTHER\nREPORT ON UNITED KINGDOM TESTS\nBy Norman Harpur\nBritish Aircraft Corporation Limited\nFilton, United Kingdom\nSUMMARY\nThis section of the United Kingdom review of structural testing for the period\n1969 to 1971 gives a summary of the tests being carried out on Concorde nacelle\nstructure as part of the structural development and certification programme. It\nattempts to complete the overall picture provided by other papers which primarily\ndeal with testing of the remainder of the Concorde airframe.\nINTRODUCTION\nDuring this symposium, much information has been presented on the structural\ntesting of Concorde. In particular, paper no. 1 by E . L. Ripley, given as the Third\nFrederick J. Plantema Memorial Lecture, deals extensively with the Concorde airframe major fatigue test and similar development tests on fuselage components.\nPaper no. 20 by V. P. N\'Guyen and J. P. Perrais gives a summary of the Concorde\nmajor airframe static test and other large fuselage" wing component tests at the Centre d\'Essais Aeronautiques de Toulouse (C.E.A.T.) in France.\nTo complete the picture, the present paper gives an account in general terms of\na series of tests being carried out in the United Kingdom (U.K.) on Concorde nacelle\ncomponents. These components are relatively large structural elements (e.g., the\nintake is 3.5 by 7 by 17 feet) subject to unique types of loading and involving novel\nforms of design and construction. They are designed to meet the full static strength,\nfail-safe, and fatigue requirements of the basic airframe and, thus, have to be the\nsubject of a complete certification test programme. In this sense, they must be considered as a complementary part of the major static and major fatigue test\nprogrammes.\nSYMBOLS\nM\n\nMach number\n\nn\n\nmanoeuvering load factor\n649\n\n----\n\n-----~~\n\ndesign cruiSing speed\ndesign diving speed\nDESCRIPTION OF NACELLE STRUCTURAL SPECIMENS\nA supersonic aircraft, such as Concorde, requires a sophisticated power-plant\ninstallation, including a variable-geometry intake with its own automatic-control system,\nan engine bay providing full accessibility, and a variable - geometry nozzle incorporating\nthrust reversers. A general view of the complete Concorde nacelle is shown in figure 1,\nand a more detailed description of the specimens is given in the appendix.\nPart of the basic philosophy for the production nacelle structure has been to design\nthe three main components - intake, engine bay, and nozzle - as separate units linked\ntogether in a statically determinate manner to minimise redundant interaction forces\narising because of wing distortions. For the same reason, the engine bay itself has been\ndesigned in two halves - a forward bay and a rear bay - simply spigoted together at the\njoint.\nAdvantage has been taken of this design philosophy to reduce the complexity of\ntesting; thus, the air intake was tested separately from the engine bay and nozzle, and the\nforward engine... bay was tested independently of the rear engine bay.\nA summary of the nacelle structural test specimens either tested or to be tested\nas part of the Concorde development and certification programme is given in table 1 for\nthe intake and in table 2 for the engine bay and nozzle.\nAn additional production nozzle specimen is also being provided, and will be tested\n\nunder operating environmental conditions behind a pair of Olympus engines installed in a\ntest bed at Societe Nationale d \'Etude et de Construction de Moteur d\'Aviation (SNECMA)\nin France.\nPROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH INTAKE TESTING\nSummary of Loading Actions\nThe primary loading action on the intake results from internal pressures due to the\nairflow through the ducts. The internal pressures due to two typical operating conditions\nare shown in figure 2. Since part of the top of the intake is closed by the lower surface\nof the wing, these pressures produce significant loads in the wing-nacelle attachment\nlinks, as well as designing the intake shell. Additional loading in intake and links is due\nto the interaction forces at the links due to wing distortions.\n650\n\nDuring supersonic cruise conditions, the intake is also subjected to elevated temperatures with the internal temperature reaching a maximum of 125 0 to 1300 C and the\nexternal temperature a value of 1000 C. Because both inside and outside surfaces are\nsubjected to similar forcing conditions, thermal stresses during acceleration and deceleration are, in general, less than those produced by the cruise temperature gradients\nquoted previously.\nTest Realisation\nFor all three intake test specimens, the approach to the problem of simulating wing\ninteraction loads and pressure loads is the same. To represent Wing-nacelle interaction\nloads, the specimens are mounted from a rigid test frame by links at the points A, C, E,\nand G shown in figure 1. Each link is then calibrated to enable the link-reaction load to\nbe measured. Three remaining links (points B, D, and F) are attached to hydraulic jacks\nwhich are controlled to apply specified displacements.\nThe representation of the varying pressure distributions within the ducts has been a\nmajor difficulty. The interior of the specimen was divided into four main zones, with a\nfifth zone representing the boundary-layer bleed between the wing and the forward part of\nthe intake. (See fig. 2.). Between adjacent zones a pressure seal has had to be developed\nin such a way that while maintaining the interzone pressure differentials, local loading and\nrestraint to specimen movement have been avoided. The final solution, following extensive development, has led to the design of flexible suction seals mounted off a central\ncore rigidly supported by the test frame. The assembly of one such core for the roomtemperature tests on specimen 2.9B is shown in figure 3.\nFor the thermal testing on specimen 2.9.4, the specimen has to be heated cyclically\ninside and outside. Each internal zone is thus supplied with pressurized air through a\nseparate closed-circuit system of ducts with outlets into the specimen through the central\ncore. The heating of this air is controlled through a heat exchanger. For cooling, the\ncircuit is depressurized and switched to open circuit; ambient air is then blown through\nthe specimen. The exterior of the specimen is surrounded by a duct through which\nunpressurized air is blown at the requisite temperatures. This system, which is duplicated for each intake duct, results in an extremely complex facility. A scale model of\nthis facility is shown in figure 4.\nWith this facility it is possible to simulate adequately the major loading actions. In\nthe fatigue test, advantage is taken of the absence of Significant climb and descent thermal\nstresses by shortening the thermal cycle to simulate only cruise gradients and imposing a\ntest cruise time of 12 minutes compared with an average aircraft cruise time of 75 minutes. To compensate for this shorter test time at temperature, creep rate is increased\nby a factor of approximately 5 by increasing maximum test temperatures 15 0 C. The\n651\n\nproposed test cycle is shown in figure 5. The aim is to achieve a rate of testing comparable with the major airframe fatigue test (where each 1-hour test cycle simulates the\ndamage done in two typical aircraft supersonic flights).\nPROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH ENGINE-BAY AND NOZZLE TESTING\nSummary of Loading Actions\nThe loading actions on the engine bay and nozzle are similar to those on the intake,\nbut there are some significant differences which are summarized below:\n(1) The distribution of pressure in the engine bay and nozzle is essentially constant;\nthus, only one internal-pressure zone is required in each duct.\n(2) The concentrated system of hydraulic jacks required to represent reverse-\n\nthrust bucket loads, bucket operating jack loads, and engine jet pipes leads to local complications in the heating, cooling, and pressurisation system.\n(3) The maximum operating temperatures in the rear engine bay and nozzle are\nhigh, reaching about 240 0 C in the engine bay and between 320 0 and 410 0 C in the nozzle ;\nas in the intake, a steady gradient is present during cruise causing Significant thermal\nstresses. In addition, large transient thermal gradients arise in the nozzle centre-wall\nstructure during descent and due to reheat in the climb and result in another thermalstress cycle. These temperatures are shown diagrammatically in figure 6.\nTest Realisation\nTwo of the engine-bay specimens (specimen 1.11.2.2 and specimen 2.9.4.2) are\nrelatively simple; tests on these specimens involve static pressure and mechanical\nloading at room temperature. Specimen 2.9.4.3 is subjected to a pressure fatigue test\nat elevated temperature. This test poses no serious problems apart from the control and\nmonitoring of temperature and the timing of the pressure cycle to ensure a consistent\naccumulation of creep and fatigue damage.\nThe fourth specimen, specimen 2.9.6, is subjected to both static and fatigue testing\nwith representation of thermal conditions. This testing requires a complex test facility\nsimilar to that for the intake shown in figure 4. The simulation of wing distortions and\nbay pressures is done in a similar manner to that for the intake; the number of pressure\nzones is less, but seal design is complicated by the higher temperatures required.\nIn order to limit the test temperatures, advantage is taken of the fact that thermal\nstress due to temperature gradient is the most Significant requirement since creep and\nmaterial degradation at the aircraft temperature levels are unimportant for the stainless\nsteel materials of the nozzle bay and the titanium and inconel alloys of the engine bay.\n652\n\nThe required temper .\nrrradients of about 250 0 C maximum through the nozzle side. by blowing air at room temperature over the outside of the\nwalls are therefore o.\nspecimen and blowing hot ~\nfrom the rear to the front through the inside. A special\nproblem arises in simulatir.; t1 temperature gradients through the centre wall of the\nnozzle during descent and duf\' \' , reheat in the climb.\nTo achieve these in as -,nort a time as possible, a special system is provided to\nblow alternately hot and cold air into the centre wall void. This system is switched on at\nappropriate times in the cycle, thus enabling the required cruise and recovery equilibrium conditions to be rapidly achieved. (See fig. 7.) A diagram of the fatigue cycle\nachieved with this forcing system is shown in figure 8; the target, as in the case of the\nintake, is to achieve a rate of testing comparable with the major airframe fatigue test.\nTEST CONTROL\nBoth the intake (specimen 2.9.4) fatigue test and the engine-bay and nozzle (specimen 2.9.6) fatigue test are to be controlled and monitored by a single IBM 1800 computer,\nwhich will also provide data logging and both on-line and off-line data analysis and\ndisplay.\nThe monitoring facility checks the applied values of all control variables with the\nrequired values against a set of inner and outer limits; the inner limit exceedances are\nprinted-out and the outer limit exceedances cause shutdown of the test.\nA general view of this installation is shown in figure 9, and a flow diagram illustrating the control logic of the test facility is shown in figure 10.\n\n653\n\nAPPENDIX\nDESCRIPTION OF PRODUCTION NACELLE STRUCTURE\nAir - Intake Structure\nA structural breakdown of the intake is shown in figure 11. The operating temperature during Mach 2.0 cruise is approximately 120 0 C, and aluminium alloy is used for\nall the structure with the exception of the rear frame (frame 204), which is made from\ntitanium alloy to provide a fireproof bulkhead. The forward lip, the forward- and centreduct skins, and the intake frames are mostly machined from thick plate. The moveable\nramps are made from aluminium alloy honeycomb.\nThe intake is suspended from the wing at six points, with a forward and rear attachment on each of the three walls. Five of the attachments are simple links taking vertical\nloads only; the sixth, at the centre of the rear frame, is a fixed-point attachment taking\nloads in all planes. A secondary horizontal link is also provided on the forward centre\nwall to provide yawing restraints.\nEngine - Bay Structure\nThe general arrangement of the engine bay can be seen from figure 1. Since the\nengines are mounted directly from the wing, engine-bay loads derive predominantly from\ninternal pressures. The bay consists of a forward and rear section, simply spigotted\ntogether; each section consists of a fixed centre wall with an L-shaped door forming the\nside and bottom walls of each bay. The front and rear bulkheads of the bay are formed\nby the rear frame of the intake and the front frame of the nozzle-fixed structure,\nrespectively.\nThe centre wall (see fig. 12) has a maximum operating temperature of 250 0 C and\nmust resist flame temperatures of up to 11000 C for 5 minutes. Thus, both front and\nrear sections are made from a nickel alloy (Inconel 718) honeycomb-sandwich panel.\nThe forward doors (see fig. 13) have a maximum operating temperature of 1500 C\nand are made from aluminium alloy. Inner and outer skins are riveted and spot-welded,\nrespectively, to close-pitched frames of the extruded I-section. The rear doors (shown\nin fig. 14), where maximum operating temperatures are about 200 0 C, are of similar construction but made of titanium alloy with the frames either machined from bar or fabricated from welded plate. Both sets of doors are provided with fore and aft sliding freedom of about 30 mm along a line near the door corner. This freedom has been provided\nto eliminate large interaction forces between the wing and door which would otherwise\narise because of wing distortions in flight. The slide also incorporates a hinge, so that\n\n654\n\nAPPENDIX\nit is possible to open the bottom part of the door independently for simple servicing.\nAlso to avoid interaction forces due to distortion, the doors are supported from two\nhinges, at the front and rear of the top edge only. Intermediate hinges are provided but\nare designed to only restrain the door against lateral pressure forces.\nNozzle structure\nThe general arrangement of the nozzle fixed structure is shown in figure 15. The\nmaximum operating temperature of the structure is in the region of 4500 C, and for this\nregion stainless steel is the basic structural material.\nThe basic structure is made up of a pair of barrels forming the main ducts, supported by spectacle frames and enclosed by an outer fairing. These components are\nmainly fabricated from stainless steel stresskin honeycomb. Upper and lower fore and\naft longerons run between the inner barrels and outer fairings in the sidewalls and centre\nwalls. These form the primary load path for the reverser bucket loads; these buckets\nare attached to hinge fittings which connect with the aft end of these longerons.\nThis fixed structure is attached to the engine-bay-wing interface at three nonredundant fittings, one on each sidewall and one on the centre wall. A fourth attachment\nat the centre wall is provided as a fail-safe standby. The main centre-wall attachment\nconnects with the engine-bay centre wall, the two sidewall attachments connecting with a\npair of triangulated frames attached to the wing undersurface.\nProvision in the fixed structure is made for attaching the engine primary nozzle by\nmeans of three spigot fittings projecting into the main ducts. Additional attachments are\nprovided for the reverser-bucket operating jacks, four in each duct.\n\n655\n\n0)\n\n01\n\n0)\n\nTABLE 1.- INTAKE MAJOR STRUCTURAL TEST SPECIMENS\nDescription\n\nSummary of test requirements\n\nRemarks\nStatic\n\nSpecimen 2.9B\n(prototype air\nintake)\n\nA twin left-hand intake\nto prototype standard.\nRig applies internal\npressure in four zones per\nduct with wing distortions.\n\nFail-safe\n\nFatigue\n\nStatic design cases at room\ntemperature up to 85 % ultimate\nload to clear prototype flying .\nTest cases include\n(1) Symmetric and asymmetric\n\nsurge cases\n(2) Ground running manoeuvre\ncases at YD.\nSpecimen 2.9.4\n(production\nair-intake\nfatigue\nspecimen)\n\nA twin right-hand\nintake to preproduction\nstandard.\nRig applies internal and\nexternal heating in association\nwith internal pressure in four\ninternal zones . H. Hooke\nAeronautical Research Laboratories\nDepartment of Supply\nCommonwealth of Australia\nSUMMARY\nBoth the conventional and reliability analyses for determining safe fatigue life\nare predicated on a population having a specified (usually log normal) distribution of\nlife to collapse under a fatigue test load.\nUnder a random service load spectrum, random occurrences of load larger than\nthe fatigue test load may confront and cause collapse of structures which are weakened,\nthough not yet to the fatigue test load. These collapses are included in reliability but\nexcluded in conventional analysis.\nThe theory of risk determination by each method is given, and several reasonably\ntypical examples have been worked out, in which it transpires that if one excludes\ncollapse through exceedance of the uncracked strength, the reliability and conventional\nanalyses gave virtually identical probabilities of failure or survival.\nINTRODUCTION\nThe conventional approach to safe-life estimation envisages a fatigue test which\nimposes on at least one full-scale structure the equivalent fatigue damaging effect of\nservice loading, according to some regular pattern which restricts, however, the\nlargest load, regularly applied, to some fraction of the virgin strength. Life to\ncollapse is regarded as a statistical variable, of whose population mean the test failure\nis treated as an estimator. Variability is estimated from other representative experiments in which each member\'s strength falls to a single lower value (in different lifetimes), which is accounted failure, and the probability density function of life to failure\nis usually assumed log normal.\n\n.\n\nDetermination of the safe life as a function of desired or acceptable probability\nof failure requires merely the estimation of the desired percentile of the population,\nthat is, the desired percentile of the distribution of fatigue lives, measured to the point\nat which each member \' s strength has fallen to the largest applied load in the test\nsequence.\n667\n\nReliability theory, applied to this problem attributes the same strength properties\nto the population as before, including the decay of strength as fatigue crack growth occurs,\nbut does not assume that collapse occurs when each member\'s strength has fallen to a\ncommon value. Collapse occurs rather when a member of the population meets a load\nlarger than its current strength, and this event would correspond to a conventionally\nassessed life for that member if the service spectrum were modified or truncated so that\nall load peaks larger than the fatigue test load were reduced to that value.\nThe purpose of this study was to present the theory of risk determination for each\nmethod and to ascertain by the working of several reasonably typical examples whether\nthe conventional method significantly underestimated the failure risk through ignoring\nservice loads higher than the fatigue test load.\nSYMBOLS\nb\n\nratio of maximum fatigue test load to virgin strength or strength at critical\ncrack length\n\ng\n\nratio of crack propagation time (from detectable to critical size) to total\nlife H\n\nH\n\npopulation life in hours; a log normal random variable\n\nH\n\npopulation geometric mean life in hours\n\nl\n\ncrack length\n"critical" crack length at which strength U has fallen to bUo\ncrack length detectable with certainty\n\nm{V)\n\nfrequency of occurrence, per hour, of applied load >V\n\nn\n\nnumber of load cycles applied\n\np{U)\n\nprobability density function of strength for population\n\np{V)\n\nprobability density function for applied load V for some arbitrary time\ninterval\n\n668\n\nP(t)\n\nprobability of collapse before time t\n\nP(n)\n\nprobability of collapse before nth applied load\n\nPc\n\nprobability of collapse in arbitrary time interval\n\noP c\n\nprobability of collapse in arbitrary time interval of small element of population characterised by its value of H\n\nr(t)\n\nrisk or risk rate or risk of failure at time t of survivors at time t\n\nr(n)\n\nrisk or rate of failure at the nth applied load of survivors of (n-l)th load\n\nR(t)\n\nreliability at time t or probability of survival to time t\n\nR(n)\n\nreliability at nth applied load or probability of survival from first to (n-l)th\nload\n\nt\n\ntime, hours\n\nTb\n\nsafe inspection period for probability of failure p\n\nU\n\nstrength\n\nUo\n\nvirgin strength\n\nV\n\napplied load\n\na\n\nstandard deviation of log H\n\n1>\n\nstrength decay function of crack size\n\ntJ;\n\ncrack propagation (time function)\n\n=p\n\npercent of gH\n\nSTATISTICAL MODEL AND SAFE-LIFE ANALYSES\n\nThe statistical model used herein is the one used in references 1 and 2, as shown\nin figure 1 in both normal and logarithmic coordinates, and has the following features:\n\n669\n\n(1) The population life H is log normally distributed with geometric mean H\nand variance a2 , H being the hours in which the strength U is reduced from Uo to\nbUo which corresponds to the largest load in the test spectrum.\n(2) Crack propagation in each member is scaled to the member\'S potential life to\n\nfailure H under the specified test history and follows the expression\n_l\nlcr\n\n= lj;(!:..)\n\\II\n\n(3) Strength is related to crack size; thus,\n\nand the condition (1) gives\n\n<1>(1)\n\n= b.\n\n(4) Whereas crack propagation is governed by condition (2), failure is governed by\n\nthe frequency of occurrence m(V) per hour, of service loads exceeding V, or in nondimensional terms, the frequency m(V /U o ) of service loads greater than V / Uo \'\nIn conventional analYSiS, a safe life for a probability of failure p is merely the\np percentile of the variable H. Insofar as H is the time at which U falls to Uo,\nit is independent of the shape of the crack propagation curve and is only dependent on the\ntime H at which l = lcr.\nThe calculation of failure by the reliability approach requires the following definitions (refs. 4 and 5):\nP{t)\n\nprobability of fracture before time t\n\nR{t)\n\nreliability at time t or probability of survival to time t\n\nr{t)\n\nrisk or rate of failure at time t of survivors to time t, _1_ dP{t)\nR{t) dt\n\nand the expression\n-It r{t)dt\nR{t) = e 0\n\n(1)\n\nOr, alternatively, the probability of failure before a given time, the reliability and the\nrisk (hazard rate or force of mortality) may be expressed as a function of number of\ncycles n, as P{n), R{n), and r{n). In this case r{n) dn is the probability of failure\n670\n\nin dn cycles of members surviving at n cycles, so that (With dn = 1), r(n)\nprobability of failure per cycle of members which survive to the nth cycle.\n\nis the\n\nIf the probability density functions of strength and of load occurring in some arbi-\n\ntrary time are p(U)\n\nand p(V), respectively, as shown in the following diagram,\n\nProbability\ndensity\n\np(U)\n\nStrength U\n\n~\n\nAppl ied load V\nthen the probability of collapse in this arbitrary time is the probability that a load V\nfalls on a structure of strength U less than V. For a load lying between V and\nV + dV, occurring with probability p(V) dV, its contribution to the probability of collapse\nis\nU=V\np(V) dV Su=o p(U) dU\n\n(2)\n\nand the total probability of collapse is\n\nS\n\nV=oo\n\nPc =\n\nV=O\n\n1\n\nU=V\n\np(V)\n\np(U) dU dV\n\n(3)\n\nU=O\n\nOr , alternately, if there is considered an element of the population of structures lying\nbetween U and U + dU, the probability of a structure having a strength in this interval\nbeing p(U) dU, its contribution to the probability of collapse is\nV=oo\np(U) dU Sv=u p(V) dV\n\n(4)\n\nso that the total probability of collapse is also\nV oo\nPc = rU= oo p(U) r : p(V) dV dU\nJU=O\nJV=U\n\n(5)\n\n671\n\nIn the example of concern, in which strength\n\nU is distributed as a function of Hand\nalso decreases with time, the calculation is most readily made by taking small elements\np(H) dH of the population characterised by their values of H and using equation (4) to\nfind the contribution to the probability of failure by each element; that is,\n\nrV=oo p(V) dV\nJV=U\n\noP c = p(H) dH\n\n= p(H)\nIt will be noted that\n\ndH\n\n~r(V >\n\nUD\n\n(6)\n\nU is a function of time U(t) = Uoep {lft(t/H))\n\nso that\n\noP c = p(H) dH [!>r(V > U(t)B\n\n= p(H)\nfrom equation (1),\n\nr(t)\n\n-S, r(t)dt\n\nf\n\nt\n\ndH 1 - e\n\n}\n\n0\n\nbeing the risk function for this element,\n\noP c = p(H) dH\n\n[ -s,\\n(v> U(t))dt;\n\nl\n\n-\n\ne\n\n0\n\n(7)\n\nwhere m(V> U(t)) is the frequency per hour with which the applied load exceeds the\nelement\'s strength U(t).\nThe total probability of collapse is\n\nH=oo\n\nPc =\n\nS,\n\nf-\n\np(H) 1 - e\n\nS,t m(V > U(t))dj\n0\n\ndH\n\nH=O\n\nwhich is identical, allowing for a difference in notation, with the expression\n\nS,\n\nF(U)=l\n\nP(t)\n\n=\n\nS\n\nF(U)=O {\n\nof reference 2 (p. 29).\n\n672\n\n1- e\n\n- t n(U)dt}\n0\ndF(U)\n\n(8)\n\nINSPECTION INTERVAL ANALYSIS\nSafety may be achieved in an inspectable structure if the critical crack length lcr,\nat which strength falls to a selected unsafe value, is larger than the crack length detectable with certainty ld\' The time remaining in which a crack propagates from ld to\nlcr (and strength to U = bU o) is some fraction of the life H, say gH, and with this\nmodel g is a constant for all members of the population. Thus gH is log normally\ndistributed with median gH and variance 0-2 .\nIn conventional analysis, the critical length lcr is the same for all members of\nthe population, and the unsafe value of strength is equated to b Uo , the highest load in the\nfatigue test programme. A safe operating period after inspection Tb for a probability\nof failure p in the interval is the p percentile of the variable crack propagation\ntime gH, since it can readily be seen that only p percent of cracks can propagate from\nld to lcr in a time less than Tb\' This result assumes that all structures are cracked\nto just below ld at the inspection date, and it is seen to be independent of the shape of\nthe crack propagation curve for cracks smaller than ld\'\nIn reliability analysis, structures may be conSidered to be cracked to just below ld\nat the beginning of the propagation time but to reach a failure state governed by load\nexceeding strength. Where the safe lives, as calculated by reliability and conventional\nmethods, coincide it is concluded that this will imply a coincidence of the values of safe\ninspection intervals.\nAPPLICATION OF THE THEORY TO TYPICAL EXAMPLES\nExample A(l) represents a military aircraft situation where the structures are subjected to the manoeuvre load spectrum (curve A of fig. 2) in which limit load is exceeded\nonce per 100 hours, crack size l / lcr is a power function of t / H, the decay of strength\nwith crack size conforms to the laws of fracture mechaniCS , and the standard deviation 0is 0.167.\nExample A(2) represents the same situation as example A(l) except that the standard deviation a is 0.16712.\nExample B(l) represents a civil aircraft situation where the structures are subjected to the gust spectrum (curve B of fig. 2) in which three-fourths of limit load is\nexceeded once in 5000 hours, crack propagation follows figure 28 of reference 3, the\ndecay of strength is a linear function of crack length, and the standard deviation is 0.17.\nExample B(2) represents the same situation as example B(l) except that (perhaps\nunrealistically) crack growth is assumed linear from zero time up to failure.\n\n673\n\nConstants used in the various calculations are listed in table I, and the results of\nthe calculations are shown in figure 3 where probability of failure or survival is plotted\nagainst life in hours. Calculations for the conventional analysis have been made with the\nsame computer programme by truncating the load spectra at b Uo \'\nDISCUSSION OF RESULTS OF THE ANALYSIS\nExamination of figure 3 shows that for the Civil example B(l) both methods of\nanalysis gave virtually identical results within the computed range from p = 0.001 to\np = 0.999. In the computations the distribution of H was divided into its 0.1 percentile.\nIf results are desired for p < 0.001 these can readily be obtained by computing with\nsmaller elements of the distribution of H. For example A(l), both methods gave virtually identical probabilities of failure for lifetimes longer than 3000 hours, but for shorter\nlifetimes the reliability method gave higher probabilities than the conventional method.\nIt is appreciated that the reliability method of analysis included, whereas the conventional\nmethod excluded, the risk of failure from loads exceeding the virgin strength (whether of\nuncracked structure or of cracked but yet unweakened structure).\nThe probability of such overload failures can readily be derived from the frequency\nof exceedance of Uo for example A, namely once per million hours. This probability of\noverload failures is plotted as a dashed line in figure 3; the reliability calculation closely\napproximates this curve at low probabilities of failure.\nThe result for example A(2) is similar to that for example A(l), except that, because\nof the larger scatter, the reliability calculation assessed a given probability to have been\nreached in a slightly shorter lifetime; for example, a probability of failure of 0.002 was\nreached in 1500 hours by reliability analysis and in 1750 hours by conventional analysis\nwith the corresponding scatter factors being . ~ and\nrespectively. Again, at a probability of failure of 0.001, the major contribution was overload failure through loads\ngreater than the virgin strength.\n\n4,\n\nReliability analysis provides a rigorous method for validating the conventional\nmethods of safe life and inspection interval analyses which are based upon a seemingly\narbitrary choice of the value of unsafe strength, this choice having been made by choosing\nwhat is to be the highest load in the fatigue test programme on the representative structure to estimate mean life. The conventional analysis is vastly less time consuming than\nthe reliability analysis, since it involves a simple slide-rule calculation rather than a\ncomplex digital computer programme run.\nExamples A(l), A(2), and B(l) were constructed to represent closely conditions\nexisting in military and civil aircraft situations. For the most part the reliability analysis validates the Simpler conventional analysiS. For the military type of spectrum and at\n674\n\nshort lives, the probability of failure is dominated by loads exceeding the uncracked\nstrength; when these are added to the conventional analysis, the result agrees closely\nwith the reliability methods.\nExample B(2) represents an artificial extreme example of a structure assumed to\nhave linearly decaying strength from zero time up to failure. Nevertheless, here again,\nat probabilities of failure less than 20 percent, the corresponding lifetimes were virtually\nidentical with those for a more usual strength-decay curve , or, indeed, for the stepfunction strength decay curve which is implicit in the conventional analysis.\nThe examples that have been discussed have not considered the case of a long\nperiod of detectable crack propagation during which the strength does not decay below\nvirgin strength. Here inspection will not prevent failures from exceedance of the virgin\nstrength, but will weed out cracked structures before they become weakened.\nCONC L USIONS\nFor a range of conditions which are typical of military and civil aircraft structures\nand load histories, reliability analysis validates the much simpler conventional methods\nof safe life and inspection interval analysis.\nThe reliability method, ipso facto, includes the probability of failure through loads\nexceeding the virgin strength - a factor which is inevitable by any fatigue analYSiS,\ninspection schedule, or safe-life determination.\nWhere there is a long detectable crack propagation time without diminution of the\nstructural strength, inspection will weed out cracked structures before they become\nweakened but will not prevent failures from loads exceeding the virgin strength.\nACKNOWLEDGEMENT\nThe author desires to gratefully acknowledge the assistance of Mr. M. R. Thomson\nin performing the computations.\n\n675\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Hooke, F. H.: Consideration of the Rationale of the Use of Half Critical Crack Length\nas a Failure Criterion. A.R.L.
